name: FSM: Drought - 2023-12 - El Nino Watch
summary:
The situation is still evolving with over 95% of the possibility of occurrence of El Niño. This has placed North Pacific on El Niño alert triggering our need for early actions and preparedness for drought. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), a transition from ENSO-neutral to El Niño has taken place during May-July 2023. According to the International Research Institute (IRI) of Columbia Climate School, as of mid-Aug 2023, the previously moderate El Niño conditions in the central-eastern equatorial Pacific have strengthened further. Key oceanic and atmospheric variables are consistent with the El Niño, though the atmosphere is not yet fully coupled to the warm sea surface temperature anomalies in the central-eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean. A CPC El Niño advisory remains in place for August 2023. Almost all of the models in the IRI ENSO prediction plume forecast an El Niño event during boreal autumn continuing into winter and early spring of 2024, while weakening during the end of the forecast and ENSO-neutral become the most likely category (Apr-Jun 2024 with 59% chance)

El Nino is an evolving situation where the ocean temperature is expected to rise. Warmer waters in the Equatorial Pacific Ocean can suppress the formation of clouds and rain. The hot weather in the North Pacific will trigger more evaporation and available water sources will deplete, while demands for water may increase. Many North Pacific Islands are dependent on the rains to meet daily water demands. The increase in heat and decrease in rainfall means the scarcity of water for inhabitants of the islands. Most of the Islands in the North Pacific countries are remote and transportation is very expensive that which may worsen the situation if early readiness actions are not taken place. Recent El Niño events occurred in 2015-16 and 2018-19. The El Nino in 2015-16 was very strong which resulted in the worst drought in the history of the North Pacific affecting Palau, Federated States of Micronesia (FSM), and the Marshall Islands. The El Nino was much weaker in 2018-2019 however most of Micronesia i.e., Yap state, Palau, and Mariana Islands experienced extensive drought in the early months of 2020. In the past El Niño years, FSM suffered from drought conditions during the winter and spring months. Because they are further west, Yap and western Chuuk tend to be affected earlier and more harshly. In an El Niño year, the winds are weaker than normal (or absent). Warm ocean water from Micronesia surges into the central and eastern Pacific Ocean. This leads to a falling sea level and a greater chance of drought in Micronesia.

name: TZA: Flood - 2023-10 - EL NINO TANZANIA
summary: Tanzania Meteorological Agency (TMA) is informing the public about the current ongoing El Nino status in the Pacific Ocean and its likelihood to affect our country (Tanzania). The Agency is making close follow up on the weather updates and it forecasts its likelihood to occur is from October to December 2023. The consequences from the El-Nino will greatly depend on the extent and the duration that it will last. Additionally, the consequences also depends on the conditions and direction of other weather weather systems including wind direction and sea temperature in the Indian ocean. This is likely to affect significant amount of human settlements, properties, buildings, and infrastructure systems that are crucial for the daily livelihood and the country development.

name: GHA: Flood - 2023-09 - Buipe Floods
summary: According to the local National Disaster Management Organisation(NADMO) the overflow of black volta as a result of spillage from Bui dam has caused extensive flood water damage to several homes at Buipe community in the Central Gonja district of Savannah Region. The majority of affected households have been evacuated to the jointly set-up evacuation center by Local Red Cross and National Disaster Management Organisation. The local branch of Ghana Red Cross Society is currently assessing how best to support the most vulnerable families affected by the disaster.

name: GTM: Civil Unrest - 2023-09 - Protests in Guatemala Electoral Process 2023
summary: Civil organizations have called for a national strike and blockades of different important road sections in Guatemala, for this September 19, demanding the resignation of the Attorney General and Head of the Public Ministry, the Chief of the Prosecutor's Office against corruption, the Judge in charge and other officials who are involved in the oversight of the electoral process carried out in June and August this year, with which they intend to invalidate the vote, according to the complaint made on social networks by the organization called CODECA. https://www.prensalibre.com/guatemala/elecciones-generales-guatemala-2023/manifestaciones-en-guatemala-codeca-anuncia-bloqueos-para-exigir-la-renuncia-de-consuelo-porras-y-otros-funcionarios-breaking/

name: AZE: Flood - 2023-09 - Flooding in Zagatala
summary:
Due to torrential rains, floodwaters filled the courtyards, basements and first floors of more than 100 houses in Zagatala, and four bridges were damaged.

The torrential rains, which started in the evening on the 17th, continued until the night of September 18. The area of Car and Yukhari Tala villages of the district was flooded. Several trees fell due to strong wind. Due to the torrential rains that fell on the mountainous and foothills of the region, the water in the Tala, Zilban, Bekmez and other rivers of the region has increased excessively. Tala, Zilban and Bekmez rivers were flooded for a short time. Three bridges in the area of Jar village and Gazangul settlement have become unusable due to the flood in the Bekmez river.

Due to the overflow of the Zilban river, the bridge in the part of the river passing through the territory of Zilban village has become unusable. Due to overflowing of the Tala river, the village of Yolayrj of the district was flooded.

name: WWG: Civil unrest - 2023-09 - Preparing for internal unrest in the framework of the 2023 electoral process
summary:
Guatemala experiences high levels of political and social tension since March 2023, due to the general election process that was held on June 25 in its first round (electing municipal corporations, deputies and presidential candidates who went to the second round) and on August 20 the President was elected for the next four (4) years; since the beginning of this process at least three (3) political parties were excluded from the electoral contest for various reasons and at the conclusion of the first electoral round, the Public Ministry has initiated criminal proceedings against the political party that finally won the presidency. 

Since the beginning of the electoral process, there have been 16 violent deaths of candidates, supporters and members of political parties, 10 assassination attempts, 38 attacks including beatings and threats, 3 hostage-taking and 1 kidnapping or disappearance, 33 protests for disagreement with the electoral process or results, 12 roadblocks; in the municipalities of Guatemala and Mixco, explosive devices were thrown at two polling stations.  These acts of violence and electoral conflict have been compiled by the Public Prosecutor's Office, the Office of the Human Rights Ombudsman and the Electoral Observation Mission in Guatemala (MOE-GT).

Since the beginning of the electoral process, there have been 16 violent deaths of candidates, supporters and members of political parties, 10 assassination attempts, 38 attacks including beatings and threats, 3 hostage-taking and 1 kidnapping or disappearance, 33 protests for disagreement with the electoral process or results, 12 roadblocks; in the municipalities of Guatemala and Mixco, explosive devices were thrown at two polling stations.  These acts of violence and electoral conflict have been compiled by the Public Prosecutor's Office, the Office of the Human Rights Ombudsman and the Electoral Observation Mission in Guatemala (MOE-GT).

Map of Electoral Violence and Conflict prepared by the Electoral Observation Mission of Guatemala. 

On August 24, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights (IACHR) granted precautionary measures to the presidential binomial that won the August 20 runoff in Guatemala considering that at first glance "they are in a situation of gravity and urgency of risk of irreparable harm to their rights", the above was derived from an amparo that was presented before said Court for two alleged plans to attempt against the lives of the elected candidates. However, the state of Guatemala dismissed the accusations and assured that the General Directorate of Civil Intelligence has no information regarding any real threat.
On 20 July, the Ministry of the Interior confirmed the armed attack against the elected candidate of the municipality of Ayutla, in which a municipal police officer was injured; on August 30, at least 7 people died in an armed attack allegedly carried out by non-state armed groups, directed at the chief and another member of the Municipal Police of Ayutla; As a result, the Ministry of the Interior and the Guatemalan Army have deployed resources to reinforce security in the area.  In order to protect the integrity and life of the volunteers of the Guatemalan Red Cross Delegation Tejutla, the programmatic actions of migration in this jurisdiction have been suspended until there are security guarantees that allow humanitarian access.    

On September 1, the Organization of American States (OAS) convened an extraordinary session to address the situation in Guatemala. Meanwhile the social and political crisis continues.

name: DZA: Fire - 2023-09 - Bejaia and Jijel Fires
summary:
On the evening of the 15th of september 2023, fires ignited in the Wilaya of Bejaia, in the cities of Tichy, Saket, Aach El Baz, Souk El thnin and Tamricht, and spread on the 16th of september to the wilaya of Jijel, in the cities of Awana, Ziama, Teksana and others, causing damages in lands, crops, forests and cattle, as well as material damages (Houses and cars), leading to the evacuation of a number of people, and finding shelter to the displaced.

Bejaia's fires were put down in the span of 24H, whereas the fires in Jijel are roaring still. The fires have affected approximately 10 families, which translates to 50 persons. 80 persons were displaced, as well as 20 people were Injured, without registering any deaths so far. In the municipality of Chefka, 600 m² of lands caught fire then were put off in the same day.

On the 16th, 1.5 hectars of forests and olive trees were damaged in El Millia, and 5000 m² of bushes and forest area caught fire, while rescuing the nearby fruitful trees and the rest of the forest.

name: BOL: Drought - 2023-09 - El Niño phenomenon
summary:
So far there are 27,000 families, 5,900 hectares affected and 4788 animals with water stress due to lack of water due to drought in Bolivia, reported the Vice-Ministry of Civil Defense (VIDECI).

83 percent (290) of the country's municipalities in eight of the nine departments have declared a state of emergency or disaster. The phenomenon has affected the mountainous areas of the west and southwest of the country most strongly. In the department of Potosi, the drought has forced the supply of water to be subordinated to mining activity.

The decrease in water levels in the great lakes Titicaca, Poopo (the latter almost dry) and the Pilcomayo River, are having negative effects in rural areas, especially in agricultural and fishing sectors.

name: LBY: إعصار - 2023-09 - Weather Situation ( Floods- Heavy Rains ) in Libya as a result of Hurricane Danielle
summary:
In the early hours of Sunday  , eastern Libya was subjected to severe weather fluctuations as a result of the impact of Hurricane Daniel. According to data provided by windy and other weather sources, strong winds and heavy rainfall were recorded in these areas.

 

These weather fluctuations have led to negative impacts on infrastructure and property, causing some significant damage. The affected areas experienced sudden weather changes, with strong winds, heavy rain and the formation of strong thunderstorms.

Floods hit some different areas and a large number of families were evacuated in these areas 

 

In view of the expectation that the effects of Hurricane Daniel will continue, the Libyan Red Crescent, in coordination with the authorities, sent several awareness messages to take the necessary precautions and follow the instructions issued by the concerned authorities. Residents are advised to stay away from vulnerable areas and stay in safe places until the weather stabilizes.

 

Weather data:

Based on data provided by windy and other weather sources, Hurricane Daniel was found to have caused violent weather storms in eastern Libya. The affected areas witnessed strong winds exceeding the safe limit and sudden heavy rainfall. Weather reports indicate the formation of strong thunderstorms and hail in some areas, including

 (Derna and its suburbs - Al-Haniya - Al-Bayda - Sahel - Jardas Al-Obeid - Al-Kharouba - Taknes - Al-Marj - Al-Malitaniya - Al-Abyar - Tokra Al-Mabani - Benghazi - Zueitina - Ajdabiya - Saluk).

 

Effects and damages:

Infrastructure and property in these affected areas have been affected

 significantly as a result of these weather fluctuations. Public and private buildings and facilities were severely damaged, and infrastructure was damaged

. These damages have greatly affected the lives of the population.

 

Libyan Red Crescent response:

The Libyan Red Crescent works alongside local and other government agencies to provide support and assistance to those affected. A main emergency room has been formed and emergency and rescue teams have been directed to provide urgent assistance, distribute basic aid and shelter to those affected, and provide necessary medical care to the injured.

name: LBY: Flood - 2023-09 - Weather Situation ( Floods- Heavy Rains ) in Libya as a result of Hurricane Danielle
summary:
Due to the explosion of the dam that caused this disaster, Derna has become geographically divided into two banks separated from each other "eastern and western side", where most neighborhoods face power and water outages

.

The host community and IDPs face problems in providing their humanitarian needs of food, medicine, drinking water, hygiene water and others.

- For the western side of the city, the situation is stable, where aid arrives with ease, as well as work in the field and the traffic route is not difficult in terms of access and movement

- As for the eastern side of the city, it is facing a difficult situation in terms of safe access and aid  access, as well as the concerned authorities, all our focus is on supporting this area currently in conjunction with the provision of humanitarian services to the other region on the western side. "At these moments, a road linking Both sides of each other to facilitate safe access"

The response operations immediately after we entered the city consisted of several tasks, including search and rescue teams, body recovery teams, assessment teams, relief teams and work teams at shelters.

All teams are now working within the field, each in his field of competence according to the instructions of the operations room.

name: LBY: Flood - 2023-09 - Floods in the mountain alakhder area
summary:
In the early morning hours of Sunday, September 10, 2023, eastern Libya was subjected to severe weather fluctuations as a result of the impact of Hurricane Daniel. According to data provided by wind sources and other weather sources, winds were recorded Strong and heavy rains in these areas.

These weather fluctuations have had negative impacts on infrastructure and property, causing significant damage. The affected areas experienced sudden weather changes, with strong winds, heavy rain and strong thunderstorms.  

In view of the expected continued effects of Storm Daniel, the Libyan Red Crescent, in coordination with the authorities, sent several awareness messages to take the necessary precautionary measures and follow the instructions issued by the concerned authorities. He advised residents to stay away from vulnerable areas and stay in safe places until the weather stabilizes.

 

Field interventions were carried out in the affected areas that were accessible (Al-Bayda, Tukins, Bata, Al-Marj, >weevil, apse, rosary, and back, jarjar amah, touch it),

name: MAR: Earthquake - 2023-09 - Marrakesh Earthquake 2023
summary:
An earthquake of 6.8 magnitude shook Morocco on September 8, 2023, at 11 p.m. local time, followed by a magnitude 4.9 aftershock 19 minutes later. According to USGS, the quake originated deep below the surface, at a depth of 18.5 km with its epicenter identified in the High Atlas Mountains, 71km south-west of the city of Marrakesh. The earthquake was felt as far away as Portugal and Algeria. 

At least 2,901 people were killed, mostly in Marrakech and five provinces near the epicenter, and another 5,530 were injured, according to Morocco’s Interior Ministry. According to the GDACS report, approximately 320,000 people were exposed to the earthquake with the remote villages nestled in the High Atlas Mountains, right at the earthquake’s epicenter, suffering substantial losses. According to Reuters the destruction in some areas is described as “absolute,” with not a single house left standing.

The continued risk of landslides and the large distances involved complicated the rescue and relief efforts. with emergency services facing difficulties in reaching people in need. While earthquakes of this size in the region are uncommon (since 1900 there have been only nine magnitude 5 events), this earthquake was the deadliest in Morocco since 2004.

 

Please click here to view all IFRC interviews about the Moroccan earthquake.

name: GEO: Landslide - 2023-09 - Flood and landslide in Guria
summary:
A devastating landslide and flooding have struck the Guria and Adjara regions in Georgia's western part. According to the Georgian Internal Affairs Ministry's report on Friday, three individuals, including two minors, are currently missing in the aftermath of this disaster.

 

The Public Safety Command Centre has received over 100 notifications from the affected zone. The landslide has resulted in the flooding of residential houses, uprooted trees, and extensive damage to critical infrastructure. Additionally, heavy rainfall and subsequent landslides have cut off several villages in the Guria region, exacerbating the crisis.

 

Search and rescue operations are underway. The Ministry of Internal Affaris reported the discovery of the body of one minor during rescue operations in the village of Jumati. The search for the remaining two missing individuals is ongoing.

 

This natural disaster has caused significant damage to the region's infrastructure, including houses, bridges, and roads connecting villages. Various departments of the Ministry of Interior are actively present on the ground, with mobilized equipment and an active response mode.

 

The Ministry of Internal Affaris urgently advises residents in the affected area not to relocate and to strictly adhere to the instructions provided by its representatives on-site.

 

According to Aleksandre Sarishvili, the mayor of Lanchkhuti, landslides have impacted several villages in the Chochkhati community, resulting in the destruction of at least 10 houses.

 

The Emergency Management Service (112) of Guria and Adjara regions has received more than 100 reports, indicating the widespread impact and urgent need for assistance.

name: CRI: Insect invasion - 2023-09 - Dengue outbreak
summary:
La cuarta semana de agosto reportó 8261 nuevos casos de dengue, lo que significa un aumento de casi el doble de los enfermos que se reportaron en la misma fecha del 2022.

El Ministerio de Salud emitió, este miércoles, una nueva alerta sanitaria debido al aumento de casos de dengue que ha registrado el país en las últimas semanas.

Según datos de la institución la semana epidemiológica 34 que abarcó del 20 al 26 de agosto reportó 8.261 nuevos casos de la enfermedad, lo que significa un aumento de casi el doble de los enfermos que se reportaron por dengue en las mismas fechas del 2022, pues se pasó de 4780 el año pasado a 8261 este año (un 42% más).

Los cantones con mayor número de casos son Sarapiquí (con 964 casos), Siquirres (con 732 casos), Pococí (con 682 casos), Puntarenas (con 625 casos), Talamanca (con 566 casos) y Limón (con 556 casos).

Sin embargo y según Salud "en el resto de los cantones del país también se reportan casos por lo que es importante que la población no baje la guardia".

Según indicó la ministra de la cartera, Mary Munive Angermüller:

 

Toda la ayuda por parte de la población es de gran importancia para poder disminuir la cantidad de casos, el trabajo en conjunto entre nosotros desde el Ministerio y la comunidad es primordial para que juntos combatamos esta enfermedad. Necesitamos que usted, que está en su casa, elimine todos los criaderos y enseñe a sus niños para que crezcan con esta cultura y así disminuyamos los casos".

Tras la declaración sanitaria Salud reforzará las campañas de fumigación y de recolección de llantas, así como las alianzas con distintas instituciones y empresas para intervenir zonas prioritarias.

Asimismo semanas atrás se lanzó la campaña “Basta de aplausos” con el objetivo de llegar a la población por medio de mensajes sobre la eliminación de criaderos para combatir las enfermedades vectoriales.

El ministerio agregó que:

A la población en general se le insta a revisar periódicamente sus casas, patios y comunidades para eliminar potenciales criaderos del mosquito transmisor del dengue, así como estar pendientes de las comunicaciones de este ministerio con las recomendaciones".

Fuente:https://delfino.cr/2023/09/salud-emite-alerta-sanitaria-por-aumento-de-casos-de-dengue-en-el-pais?utm_source=Notificacion&utm_medium=WA

name: GRC: Flood - 2023-09 - VOLOS- KARDITSA- LARISSA FLOODS
summary:
The recent flood disaster of Volos-Karditsa and Larissa is a result of heavy and prolonged rainfall in a region prone to flooding. The rainfall has exceeded normal levels, leading to the overflow of rivers and the inundation of low-lying areas. This flood disaster can be classified as a riverine flood. It's Immediate Impacts are as listed:

a. Property Damage: The floodwaters damaged homes, buildings, and infrastructure, leading to significant financial losses.

b. Evacuations: Local authorities issued evacuation orders to ensure the safety of residents in affected areas (emergency number 112)

c. Loss of Life: Unfortunately, the flood resulted in casualties with many missing citizens (search and rescue ongoing)

d. Disruption of Services: disrupted essential services such as transportation, electricity, and clean water supply.

name: CRI: Insect invasion - 2023-09 - Dengue outbreak with 4 Zero types
summary:
The Ministry of Health issued a health alert due to the large increase in dengue cases. In epidemiological week 34, which covers August 20-26, 8,261 cases of dengue are reported, which means an increase of almost double the number of cases that had been reported last year to the same date. That is, it went from 4,780 to 8,261 cases, 42% more than in 2022.

The cantons with the highest number of cases are Sarapiquí with a report of 964 cases, Siquirres with 732 cases, Pococí with 682 cases, Puntarenas with 625 cases, Talamanca with 566 cases and, finally, Limón with 556 cases. However, in the rest of the cantons of the country cases are also reported.

name: BGR: Flood - 2023-09 - Burgas
summary:
Floods at Bulgarian coastline

More than 130 people have been evacuated. Different media sources announce 2 people dead and two to three people are said to be missing as heavy rains continue. Earlier today, 5 September 2023, a sand-sprout (tornado) and intensive rainfall unleashed flooding on Bulgaria’s southern Black Sea coast. Infrastructure was heavily damaged, with floods sweeping cars and caravans into the sea and inundating housing, hotels and campsites in parts of the region. 

Bourgas district governor Plamen Yanev said that there had been a call to universal emergency number 112 saying that a car with two passengers, as well as a pedestrian, had been swept away by rising water on a bridge.

The Arapya and Oasis campsites, and the village of Kosti in the Strandzha area, were underwater.

In Lozenets, 60 people had been evacuated and accommodated in a municipal hall, reports said.

It was said that smaller town Ahtopol, and the villages of Varvara, Sinemorets and Resovo were cut off because bridges had been destroyed by powerful floodwaters.

name: BRA: Flood - 2023-09 - SOS Vale do Taquari
summary: Em 04/09/2023 o Rio Grande do Sul foi afetado por fortes chuvas provocadas durante a passagem de um ciclone extratropical, o rio Taquari subiu e registrou a sua segunda maior cheia já registrada com 29,62m. A região mais afetada foi o Vale do Taquari. Existem 9 rodovias com bloqueio parcial ou total. A filical de Caxias do Sul - RS está atuando com sua equipe de GRD

name: ISR: Civil Unrest - 2023-09 - Eritrean irregular migrants civil unrest in Tel Aviv
summary:
On the 2nd of September, according to media reports and police statements, during a protest against an event organized by the Eritrean Embassy, violent unrest erupted between hundreds of Eritrean irregular migrants and police in Tel Aviv.

Police forces attempted to disperse the rioters using riot control measures and live ammunition. Some 30 police officers were injured in the clashes, and protesters were shot by police firing live rounds after they felt a "real threat to their lives." In total, 135 people were injured during the hours of unrest.

The authorities requested that residents of the neighborhoods where the unrest took place remain indoors and follow the instructions of law enforcement personnel.

After hours of turmoil, law enforcement announced that peace had been restored to the area, and 39 rioters were arrested.

name: LBR: Flood - 2023-09 - Liberia: Robertsport Floods
summary: On today, September 1, 2023, coastal floods and erosion swept through the Kru Town beach fishing community of Robersport City (capital of Grand Cape Mount County) in Western Liberia bordering Sierra Leone. The community of Kru Town has suffered sporadic incidents of erosion and flooding over the years. 1,955 persons are affected so far with 520 displaced in public buildings. The Liberian Red Cross has been coordinating with the National Disaster Management Agency (NDMA) on the response in the last 24 hours. The NS has deployed a surge support team from its HQ in Monrovia to the affected area to provide support to the volunteers and staff who are already conducting rapid assessments. NS is mobilizing local supplies from its warehouses to provide an initial response while engaging partners' support. The NDMA will support the response with coordination. Women and children are the most affected as photos show them displaced and sleeping in open buildings with no proper safety measures in place.

name: GRC: Population Movement - 2023-08 - Population Movement, Kalamata
summary: Thursday, August 31 2023. After one in the morning, at the port of Kalamata arrived seventysix migrants who were rescued 64 n.m. Southwest of Zakynthos island. The people were on board on a sailing vessel which was in danger and were picked up by an Egyptian-flagged cargo ship. They were transported to Kalamata, Peloponese where they will be registered and temporarily accommodated until they will be able to moved to an organized accommodation structure in the country.

name: GTM: Epidemic - 2023-08 - Epidemiological Alert for Dengue in Guatemala
summary:
The positivity rate is 32.8% in 2023. Lethality 0.23%. 53% (6,527 / 12,263) correspond to women.
The most affected departments are: Zacapa, Chiquimula, Izabal, Petén, Escuintla, Quetzaltenango and Baja Verapaz.

name: TJK: Flood - 2023-08 - Floods/Mudflows/Landslides/Rockfalls, Tajikistan:
summary:
Heavy rainfall that occurred in Tajikistan on August 27-28, 2023, caused widespread flooding, mudflows, landslides, and rockfalls.

The affected areas include Dushanbe, Vahdat, and Hisor cities, and Rudaki, Varzob, Devashtich, Rasht, Sangvor, and Tojikobod districts.

As of August 30, 20 casualties have been reported, and the death toll is expected to rise as mud cleaning and debris removal operations continue.

The disaster has also damaged or destroyed homes, roads, bridges, schools, agricultural land, livestock, and other infrastructure.

The State Emergency Situations Commission (ESC) has been set up and is working to assess the full extent of the damage.

According to the preliminary assessment of the ESC as of 30 August, the disaster caused damage to 1,021 residential and auxiliary buildings and household/kitchen plots.

Local emergency services, supported by the local population, are engaged in response operations, including mud cleaning and debris removal.

name: AZE: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2023-08 - Flooding in Goychay
summary:
As a result of heavy rains on August 26, 2023, a flash flood occurred in the villages of Garayazi, Garamaryam, Yekakhana, Ashaghi Garamaryam and Garabaggal of Goychay district. As a result of the flash flood, roads, electricity, natural gas, communication, drinking water lines, private households, cars, and other objects in the area were damaged.

A part of the road in the 194-205 kilometers of the M4 Baku-Shamakhi-Yevlakh highway, which passes through the territory of Garamaryam village of the region, has fallen into disrepair and traffic has been temporarily restricted. On August 27, 2023, the road was partially restored.

Also, in the area of the village of Ashagi Garamaryam, 3 automobile and 2 pedestrian bridges were blown up. As a result of flooding of the dump of household waste, located in the village of Garabakgal of the district, the waste scattered throughout the territory.

name: GRC: Population Movement - 2023-08 - Population Movement Pylos, Peloponnese
summary: In the port of Kalamata, a total of 21 migrants, who were spotted on Wednesday, August 23, afternoon by the Coast Guard, in a 70 nm boat  west of Pylos, Kalamata, Peloponnese disembarked and are being accommodated since this morning, Thursday, August 24, 2023.

name: USA: Fire - 2023-08 - Hawaii Wildfires
summary:
Since the fires began, the American Red Cross and county government have provided more than 5,300 overnight shelter stays in 16 emergency shelters on Maui and Oahu. The Red Cross is working with the Hawaiian Emergency Management Agency (HIEMA) to move displaced residents to hotels rather than congregate shelters. This temporary solution will help residents feel more comfortable as more permanent plans are developed. Many people continue to search for missing loved ones while also facing the loss of their homes and all of their belongings. Early reports indicate the climate-driven fires destroyed as many as 2,200 structures, most of which were homes.

 

More than 300 trained Red Cross disaster workers from Maui, other Hawaiian Islands and all corners of the country are working 24/7 with partners to get help to people as quickly as possible. With the help of partners, Red Cross has provided more than 32,600 meals and snacks to people in need. Emergency shelters are serving as multi-purpose service centers where people can access hot meals, relief supplies, health, mental health and spiritual care services, support with finding loved ones and casework assistance.

 

Approximately 6,000 local residents have begun their Red Cross volunteer training since the fires began. Preliminary damage assessment process is days ahead of our normal timeline, a result of our partnership with Microsoft's AI for Good Research Lab that is using sophisticated AI models and satellite imagery to analyze the extent of the damage. Damage assessment information is vital as it’s used to make operational decisions such as where to focus our services. It’s also the first step in validating addresses for residents that may qualify for Red Cross financial assistance.

name: UGA: Other - 2023-08 - Hailstorm-Nakapiripirit District
summary:
On 23/8/2023, there was a stong Hailstorm in Nangoromit Town council which blown off Roofs of houses and destroyed gardens and property, 49households were affected estimated to be around 200 people

Villages affected: Nangoromit, Lobulio

There were also schools affected and these include;

Okwapon primary school, Amalar primary school, Kakomangole primary school,Namale sss. Nading school Namatata primary school where latrines collapsed and buildings were destroyed

name: PAN: Flood - 2023-08 - Panama Floods
summary:
SINAPROC declares a green alert (preventive) in the provinces of Panama, Coclé, Colón, Los Santos, Chiriquí, Panamá Oeste, Veraguas, Darien and in the regions of Ngäbe Bugle and Guna Yala, due to the instability of the climate, associated with the monitoring of Tropical Storm Franklin.

According to the Institute of Meteorology and Hydrology of Panama (IMHPA), significant amounts of rainfall are expected during the next 24 hours for Colón, Panamá Oeste, Chiriquí, Veraguas, Los Santos, Comarca Ngäbe Buble, Guna Yala and Coclé. The Green Alert will be maintained until Thursday, August 24, 2023 and it is given as a preventive warning for monitoring and surveillance of possible threat that may affect the community, region or country. The National Civil Protection System recommends to the Mayors, Governors, Local Authorities, Representatives of the Institutions of the Emergency Operations Center to remain in a ready state, with a monitoring team to prevent emergency situations.

name: UGA: Other - 2023-08 - insecurity-cattle raiding and wild animals
summary:
Cattle rustlers killed 2 soldiers and injured 1 while tracking cows at Kasita

Over 500 cows raided in a period of 1 week

Elephant invasion-killed a man at Akuyan parish

name: DOM: Cyclone - 2023-08 - Tormenta Tropical Franklin 2023
summary:
Por el momento la vaguada a nivel alto sigue bloqueando el movimiento de Franklin, sin embargo, esta vaguada ha iniciado lentamente a 

moverse hacia el oeste/noroeste, ubicándose sobre el canal de Los Vientos, y a medida que siga alejándose del área, es probable que entre 

la tarde y la noche de hoy, Franklin acelere un poco más hacia el noroeste. A las 7:00 A.M. el centro de Franklin fue ubicado próximo a la 

latitud 14.9 norte y 70.3 oeste, esto a unos 415 km al sur de Santo Domingo. Sus vientos máximos sostenidos se mantienen en 85 kph, con 

ráfagas superiores. Los vientos de tormenta se extienden a unos 110 km fuera de su centro y se mueve hacia el noroeste a unos 6 kph. 

Los modelos siguen siendo consistentes con respecto a la trayectoria futura, y se espera que Franklin gire hacia el norte durante el día de 

hoy, y de continuar así y acelere, el centro de la tormenta estaría colocándose su centro próximo a la costa sur de República Dominicana 

en la madrugada de este miércoles. SIGUE EN VIGENCIA EL AVISO POR CONDICIONES DE TORMENTA TROPICAL DESDE PEDERNALES, FRONTERA 

CON HAITI HASTA LA ISLA SAONA, Y UN ALERTA DESDE ISLA SAONA HASTA MONTECRISTI EN LA COSTA NORTE 

FUERTES PODRÍAN AFECTAR LAS ZONAS BAJO AVISO. 

UN ALERTA SIGNIFICA QUE EN UN PLAZO DE 48 HORAS O MENOS, UNO DE LOS EFECTOS ASOCIADOS DEL 

CICLÓN TROPICAL PODRÍAN AFECTAR LA ZONA BAJO ALERTA. 

Actualmente Franklin permanece en un entorno desfavorable originado por la vaguada a nivel alto cerca de la frontera dominico-haitiana, 

y aire seco al noroeste de Franklin, interrumpiendo gradualmente la organización de la tormenta, lo que no permitirá probablemente que 

pueda alcanzar la intensidad de huracán antes de tocar tierra dominicana, sin embargo, los modelos de pronósticos indican que en las 

próximas 12 a 24 horas, estas condiciones serán menos desfavorables y ayudara a adquirir alguna intensificación antes de afectar a 

República Dominicana. 

Las recientes imágenes satelitales, así como de radar doppler continúan mostrando ingresos de campos nubosos generando lluvias hacia el 

noreste, sectores del litoral costero caribeño y el centro del país, incidiendo en las provincias de Samaná, Monseñor Nouel, Peravia, San 

Pedro de Macorís, San Cristóbal, El Gran Santo Domingo, entre otras. Provocando aguaceros moderados a fuertes ocasionalmente y ráfagas 

de viento frecuentes. Dichos efectos indirectos asociados a la tormenta tropical Franklin se irá extendiendo gradualmente al resto del país. 

Los acumulados de lluvias esperados con relación a este sistema oscilarán entre 75 y 200 milímetros, pudiendo ser superiores en puntos 

aislados. Estos valores se ajustarán, dependiendo los cambios futuros; tanto de la trayectoria como de la estructura nubosa de la tormenta 

Franklin. Los modelos siguen indicando que el sistema mantiene la capacidad de generar valores acumulados de lluvias cerca o mayores a 

los 300 milímetros 

De acuerdo a los valores acumulados esperados de lluvias, la ONAMET MANTIENE AVISOS Y ALERTAS METEOROLÓGICAS ante 

posibles crecidas repentinas de ríos, arroyos y cañadas, generadores de inundaciones urbanas y/o rurales, así como, deslizamientos de tierra, 

para las zonas de mayor riesgo de las provincias de La Altagracia, San Cristóbal, El Gran Santo Domingo incluyendo el Distrito Nacional, 

La Romana, San Pedro de Macorís, Monte Plata, Peravia, Azua, Barahona, Pedernales, Hato Mayor, Monseñor Nouel, San José de Ocoa, 

La Vega, San Juan, Elías Piña, Independencia, Bahoruco y El Seibo.

name: ETH:Drought(EAP)
summary:
Recurring droughts and floods have the most severe impact on Ethiopia’s population and the country has a long history of recurring droughts, which have increased in magnitude, frequency, and impact since the 1970s. The pastoral and agro-pastoral communities in drought prone areas, increasing aridity and recurring drought conditions present the most significant climate hazard. Ethiopia is highly vulnerable to climate shocks and is one of the most drought-prone countries in the world. The severe drought that began in late 2020 has continued into 2023 with the passing of five poor to failed rainy seasons. Under the 2023 Humanitarian Requirement Document (HRD),13 million people require humanitarian response in drought affected areas.

The following areas were identified as drought prone and where timely early actions could make a difference in mitigating the negative impacts, includes Belg receiving (East and West Harerge), Northern pastorals (Afar Zone 1 and Zone 3, Norther Shewa, North and south Wollo, South Gonder, and Southern Tigray region) and Southern pastoral livelihood zones (seven zones in Somali (Afder, Dhawa, Dollo, Fafan,, korah, liben and Shebelle zones), Borena and Guji, Erer, and East Bale zones) are identified as high risk areas.

name: PAK: Flood - 2023-08 - Monsoon Rains in Pakistan
summary:
During this monsoon season, numerous regions have been impacted by a combination of floods, landslides, and substantial rainfall.

On Saturday, the Sutlej River reached "exceptionally high levels" at the Ganda Singh Wala Barrage, evacuating hundreds of families from 72 villages in Kasur and Chunian. Tragically, during this flood event in Kasur, three individuals lost their lives while attempting to seek higher ground. 

The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) has issued a report indicating severe flooding in the Sutlej River. The outcome hinges on the water flow at Harike Headworks and Ferozepur Headworks. Currently, the water level at the Ganda Singh Wala Barrage has risen to 23 feet, with a flow rate of 269,000 cusecs. In Sulemanki, there is a moderate level of flooding with a flow rate of 83,072 cusecs. There is a looming threat of extremely high-level flooding at Head Sulemanki in the next 24 hours.

At Head Islam, the water flow has surged to 30,142 cusecs. The potential for extreme flooding at Head Islam is anticipated to commence on August 22. However, the water flow in Sindh, Jhelum, Chenab, and Ravi rivers remains normal.

The administrative authorities of the districts adjacent to the Sutlej River were put on high alert and measures had been implemented to restrict the movement of people in areas near Sutlej. Relevant deputy commissioners have been directed to reinforce the dykes along the Sutlej River.

Additionally, in a distinct incident, more than 100 buffaloes owned by a farmer in Usmanwala village, close to Ganda Singh, were carried away by the floodwaters while they were being relocated. Numerous individuals and animals found themselves trapped in the floodwaters because, despite early warnings of severe flooding during the past week, the authorities did not manage to evacuate them from their homes.

Please go through the below details;

countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Republic of Kazakhstan
name: KAZ: Drought - 2023-08 - Heat Wave
summary:
Emergency mode was introduced in six districts of Zhambyl region

Due to the abnormal heat and lack of irrigation water in the Bayzak, Zhambyl, Kordai, Merken, T.Ryskulov and Talas districts, an emergency was introduced, the akimat of Zhambyl region reported

The issue of allocating funds from the government's emergency reserve to cover farmers' losses is being resolved. The akimat reported that this year the crop losses will be 25-30 percent more compared to last year. The amount of damage to farms will be determined before the end of the growing season, and in the coming days they will specify the area of unsuitable fields and the amount of losses

Minister of Agriculture Yerbol Karashukeyev said that due to the small flow of water from Kyrgyzstan, about 7.8 thousand hectares were affected in the Zhambyl region, including 1.2 thousand hectares of sugar beet

name: CHL: Pluvial flood / flood - 2023-08 - Floods - Chile 2023
GRC: Fire - 2013-08 - Wildfires Greece August 2023
summary: Friday evening 18/08/2023, a wildfire broke out at the island of Zakynthos close to Akrotiri area. Due to the strong winds the fire continue southeast. Νo houses had any damages, in contrast with many hectares which burned down. Τhe intervention of the Fire Department and the local authorities was immediate, thus the fire went under control after some hours.

name: NER: Imminent floods 2023
summary:
Niger is currently in the midst of the rainy season, with the heaviest rainfall expected in late August or early September. The Ministry of Humanitarian Action has predicted that around 300,000 people will be affected by flooding this year between July and September. Based on historical data from the Ministry of Humanitarian Action (flooding in 2020, 2021, and 2022), an average of 250,000 people are affected by the impacts of floods each year in the high-risk flood-prone regions. This year, based on seasonal forecasts (a mapping of risk-prone regions has been conducted, identifying regions such as Maradi, Zinder, Dosso, and Tahoua with low risk), it is projected that the floods for this year will have a greater impact than in previous years. It is therefore anticipated that the number of victims could exceed 300,000 people, given the vulnerability of the populations to the predicted amount of rainfall in these areas this year. Examining historical data, it is anticipated that people will suffer damage to homes and property, as well as losses in agricultural fields. In June, the FAO emphasized that the increased risk of flooding in the coming months could worsen, which is an already alarming food security situation.

Floods that damage crops and cause harvest losses, along with the destruction of property and loss of livestock in exposed areas, are identified risks that could contribute to an increase in food insecurity among affected the populations. In 2022, approximately 100,000 hectares of crops were destroyed, leading to the loss of livelihoods for around 256,000 people. As Niger is in the midst of the rainy season, the early consequences of the rains are already visible. Above-average rainfall has been recorded since May 2023. According to the results of field assessments by OCHA, heavy rains have displaced over 85,000 people in Zinder and affected over 80,000 people in Maradi. According to the Minister of Humanitarian Action, 146 people were affected by floods in the Dosso region in July. Through other programs, the Red Cross of Niger has sought to assist these affected individuals. However, it should be noted that the impacts on these families remain relatively limited. With the peak of the rainy season being three weeks away, there is still time to trigger and implement activities in the coming seven days. Given the forecasts outlined by meteorological institutions, the contamination of water points is a concern, which could facilitate the emergence and spread of waterborne epidemics and other diseases (cholera, acute diarrhea, malaria, etc.). These risks are even higher for the most marginalized and vulnerable groups such as women, disabled individuals, displaced persons, and children.

name: ESP: Fire - 2023-08 - Incendio Forestal Arafo Candelaria
summary:
El fuego, que sigue sin control, afecta ya a 8.400 hectáreas y ocupa un perímetro de 70 kilómetros. La orografía y la existencia de combustible seco por las altas temperaturas de los últimos días complicaron las tareas de extinción desde el primer momento. El incendio se ha propagado por los términos municipales de 11 de los 31 municipios de la isla (Arafo, Candelaria, El Rosario, La Orotava, Santa Úrsula, La Victoria, El Sauzal, La Matanza, Güímar, Tacoronte y Los Realejos). La zona más afectada hasta el sábado era el monte de La Esperanza, cerca del núcleo de población de El Rosario, y el parque natural de La Corona Forestal, en el noreste de la isla. El pronóstico de la Agencia Estatal de Meteorología (Aemet) para este sábado era de calor y calima en las islas Canarias, con temperaturas que podrían llegar hasta los 34 grados. El viento cambiante podría complicar las labores de extinción. La proximidad de las llamas ha obligado a la evacuación de 12.279 personas.

The fire, which remains uncontrolled, already affects 8,400 hectares and occupies a perimeter of 70 kilometers. The orography and the existence of dry fuel due to the high temperatures of the last days complicated the extinguishing tasks from the first moment. The fire has spread through the municipalities of 11 of the 31 municipalities of the island (Arafo, Candelaria, El Rosario, La Orotava, Santa Úrsula, La Victoria, El Sauzal, La Matanza, Güímar, Tacoronte and Los Realejos). The most affected area until Saturday was the mountain of La Esperanza, near the town of El Rosario, and the natural park of La Corona Forestal, in the northeast of the island. The forecast of the State Meteorological Agency (Aemet) for this Saturday was for heat and haze in the Canary Islands, with temperatures that could reach up to 34 degrees. The changing wind could complicate the extinguishing work. The proximity of the flames has forced the evacuation of 12,279 people.

name: KGZ: Epidemic - 2023-08 - Measles outbreak in Kyrgyzstan
summary:
Measles is dangerous with complications, inflammation of the lungs, brain, eyes, leading to blindness. 
The Ministry of Health of KR reports, 2 deaths from measles have been registered in Kyrgyzstan August 14, 2023. Lethal outcomes were recorded in Bishkek city (3-year-old child) and in Chui region (one-year-old child). In both cases, the children did not receive vaccinations according to the National vaccination calendar, the parents refused due to religious beliefs.
The Ministry of Health notes that refusals are registered among newborns whose parents refuse preventive vaccinations against viral hepatitis and tuberculosis.
“The current situation leads to the accumulation of a susceptible contingent, a decrease in population (collective) immunity and the creation of conditions for the circulation of dangerous vaccine-preventable infections,” the ministry said.

name: DOM: Complex Emergency - 2023-08 - Daños por Explosión e Incendio en cadena
summary:
El día 14 de agosto a las 3:16 PM, en la Calle Padre Ayala en la Provincia San Cristóbal se vio afectada por una explosión de proporciones devastadoras. La onda expansiva generó daños considerables en edificios dentro de un radio de cuatro esquinas alrededor. La rápida respuesta de los equipos de emergencia fue crucial para mitigar el caos resultante y brindar asistencia en esta situación crítica.

En los primeros instante la filial de San Cristóbal se encargo de brindar asistencia a las víctimas del mismo. En coordinación con los equipos en terreno la sede central desplego un centro de coordinación, dos equipos de respuesta y una unidad de atención prehospitalaria. Hasta el momento se ha dado indicaciones de seguridad a todo el personal en terreno.

name: GRC: Earthquake - 2023-08 - Earthquake Samaria Gorge, Crete
summary: Sunday, August 13, 2023, Samaria Gorge, Chania, Crete. The region was rattled by a magnitude 4.9 quake, the temblor triggered the evacuation of more than 600 people along the 16-kilometer (10-mile) Samaria hiking trail. A 45-year-old Spanish hiker was transported by helicopter to a state hospital in the port city of Chania, where he remained in critical condition after part of his right leg was amputated.

countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Republic of Kazakhstan
name: KAZ: Flood - 2023-08 - Zhetisu Region
summary:
As a result of heavy precipitation, there was a slope runoff, which is the cause of flooding of houses in several settlements.

 

The Almaty regional branch of the Red Crescent has completed an assessment of the situation in the Jetysui region.

 

Eskeldinsky district, Abay village - 3 houses, 16 people;

Eshkiolmes village - 27 houses, 120 people.

People's property was damaged, including household appliances, furniture, shoes, clothes.

In the Koksu district, village of Mambet, where 5 houses were damaged, the assessment has not yet been carried out.

name: UGA: Other - 2023-08 - Hailstorm in Lakang Sub-County, Amuru District Nothern Uganda
summary:
According to the local government (DDMC), The findings of the Rapid Needs Assessment carried out revealed that the district received very heavy storm which resulted into a number of damages among others; 

A school roofing for 3 classroom blocks, school blocks collapsed,

Over 480 acres of farm crops were destroyed to the ground in both Lakang and Pabbo Sub-counties

Over 80 three seater desks were destroyed in Lakang Community School.

Learning of about 220 school pupils has been totally disrupted

WASH facilities have also been greatly damaged

200 Households were affected with close to about 900 people affected

name: WRC: Population Displacement - 2023-08 - Population Movement MAYO DANAY
summary: On August 11, 2023, following heavy torrential rains, the protective  along the Logone River broke on the Chadian side causing heavy flooding in this area bordering Cameroon is currently uninhabitable. Fields, houses, livestock were destroyed. The most affected villages are Makaroua, Mirbidim, Mala and Pit-Arrey. Since August 12, these Chadian populations have gradually moved to Cameroon   especially in the village of Moula, Maga district, Mayo Danay Department.  The figures of the census carried out by the administrative authorities show 272 households or 1,962 persons. These populations were welcomed and temporarily housed by the sub-prefect in the classrooms of the public school of Moula. These populations have not taken anything with them and therefore live in very precarious conditions that aggravate their vulnerability. The first assessments made it possible to identify the needs for bedding materials, hygiene equipment, food needs, essential household equipment. L people keep arriving. This figure could change.

countries society-name: The Republic of Korea National Red Cross
name: KOR: Cyclone - 2023-08 - Typhoon Khanun
summary: Typhoon Khanun originated in the east of the Philippines on 28 July, and moved toward the Korean Peninsula, making its closest approach to Okinawa, Japan on 2 August. It is expected to be the fisrt typhoon ever to cross the Korean Peninsula, and according to the Korea Meteorological Administration, the entire country is expected to experience heavy rainfall of up to 600mm and strong winds of up to 40m/sec between 9 and 11 of August. There is no loss of life but 7,606 households(10,373 people) are temporarily evacuated from 11 cities and provinces.

name: MNG: Epidemic - 2023-08 - Bubonic plague
summary: On August 8, 2023, today, one case of bubonic plague was reported in Ulaanbaatar. The patient was isolated in the National Center for Zoonotic Dissease (NCZD) and treatment was started. Responding measures are being organized by Zoonotic Disease Response Unit in Khentii province where the case is expected to be originated from. Five first contacts have been isolated and preventive treatment has been started. The Rapid Response Team of NCZD is working at the scene

name: USA: Fire - 2023-08 - Hawaii Wildfires
summary: In early August 2023, a series of wildfires broke out in the U.S. state of Hawaii, predominantly on the island of Maui. They have been recorded as the the deadliest U.S. wildfires in recent history and have damaged or destroyed more than 2,200 structures in the historic town of Lahaina. Most of these were homes, and now thousands of residents are displaced. More than 220 trained American Red Cross disaster workers from Maui, other Hawaiian islands, and all corners of the country are helping now with more on their way. Disaster workers are also virtually helping people affected by the fires. When the fires began, the Red Cross responded immediately, opening shelters for those affected by this climate-driven crisis. The Red Cross keeps disaster supplies pre-positioned on the islands, which allowed volunteers on Maui to offer immediate help to evacuees. Today our teams are working alongside partners to provide people with a safe place to stay, food to eat and emotional support during this challenging time. In partnership with the county government, trained Red Cross disaster workers are supporting emergency shelters on the islands of Maui and Oahu. The shelter on Oahu is helping Maui residents and tourists that fled in search of safety from the fires. Since the fires began, the Red Cross and partners have provided more than 3,300 overnight shelter stays. First responders are still conducting search and rescue efforts, and officials report communities will not reopen until these efforts are completed. Some power has been restored, but more than 5,000 customers remain without electricity. Communications are difficult with most cell service down, and critical infrastructure has been destroyed. Officials indicate it could be weeks before these systems are restored.

name: MNG: Flood - 2023-08 - Mongolia floods
summary: Heavy rainfall occurred on August 5 between 19:30 - 20:30 across central area of Mongolia including Ulaanbaatar city. Flash floods were triggered due to rainfall in 2 locations of Ulaanbaatar. Flooding caused 4 (2 adults, 2 children) casualties. Currently, confirmed damage data states 18 households had their gers completely destroyed, 246 households' gers, houses, fences, 105 vehicles were severely damaged. Due to increased risk of electricity failure, 6926 households were cut off from electricity on August 5 and 178 households are currently under power outage on the reporting date. As of August 7, 59 (49 adults and 10 children) people are at temporary shelter.

name: NOR: Flood - 2023-08 - Extreme weather, flooding and land slides in Southern Norway
summary: The rainstorm "Hans" passed Northern Europe this week, and hit parts of Southern Norway with heavy rainshowers up to 120 mm per day, startin on the evening of Monday the 7th of August. Raining continued through the night and through the following two days, showering large areas with the same amount in 24 hours, that is a normal amount in the month of August alltogether. Many municipalities were severely affected, leading to flooding, land and mud slides, and disruption of critical infrastructure in large parts of inland Southern Norway. All main roads from Oslo going North and Northwest were closed due to slides and flooding, as well as rail connections and smaller roads, isolating towns and villages. Several days after the rains subsiding, the large amounts of water is still affecting huge areas, now mainly with flooding, as the risk of land slides is now more moderate. The situation has been, and still is, serious, leading to large evacuations of several thousand people, as well as destroyed infrastructure, reduced accessibility to critical services for the population. There is still a risk to life and health, and this will carry on for the next few days as the flooding continues in to early next week.

name: BGD: Flood - 2023-08 - Flash Flood and Landslide' in Chattogram Region
summary:
Heavy rain triggered flash flood in the hilly district of Bandarban on 6 August 2023 afternoon as the Matamuhuri river flowed up to 13.79 meters which was 199 cm above its danger mark at Lama sub-district. on 7 August 2023 the water level of river Sangu rose to 17.63 meters which is 283 cm above the danger mark according to Flood Forecasting and Warning Centre (FFWC) of the Government of Bangladesh (GoB).

 

The FFWC in its daily bulletin issued on 7 August 2023 morning indicated that there is a chance of heavy to very heavy rainfall in the South-eastern hill basin & adjacent upstream parts of Bangladesh in next 24-48 hours. For this reason, all the major rivers (Muhuri, Feni, Halda, Karnafuli, Sangu, Matamuhuri) in the South-eastern region of the country may rise. In the next 24 hours, the rivers (Muhuri, Sangu & Matamuhuri) in the Chattogram, Feni, Bandarban & Cox`s Bazar districts may flow above their respective danger levels deteriorating the flood situation in the low-lying areas. According to the bulletin, Bandarban’s Lama recorded 227 mm of rainfall in the preceding 24 hours, which is the highest amount recorded in the current year. The hill basin also drains water from upstream areas in neighbouring India and Myanmar, where India’s Mizoram recorded 71 percent excess rainfall and Tripura 35 percent in the 24 hours until 8:00 am on 6 August 2023.

 

Chattogram has experienced 322 mm of precipitation in the past 24 hours, according to the Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD). BMD also issued a severe to extremely severe rainfall warning for six districts, including the capital Dhaka. It also issued a landslide alert for the Chattogram division because of potential heavy rain.

Residents of vulnerable areas in all the upazilas in Bandarban are advised to seek shelter through miking by the local administration as heavy rains are likely to cause further landslides. The fire service is carrying out drives in various areas with the assistance of the local administration. In fear of loss of life, families who live near the riverbank and foothills have been shifted to shelter centre facilities. Meanwhile 193 temporary shelters have been opened and 43 medical teams are ready to deal with the situation. The local administration has allocated 20 tons of rice and cash support for the flash flood victims.

 

According to the BMD, Cox's Bazar is expected to receive rainfall > 345 mm over the next five days, which could potentially trigger landslides in high-risk areas. Regional Integrated Multi-Hazard Early Warning System (RIMES) has also forecasted medium to heavy rainfall for this week in Cox’s Bazar. Based on the 5-day rainfall forecast by RIMES suggests that most of the sub-districts of Cox’s Bazar may experience more volume of accumulated precipitation amounting to 88mm-106mmrain during 7– 8 August which may slightly improve from 9 August 2023. The areas which are highly susceptible to landslide are Cox’s Bazar municipality, part of Hnila (Nayapara RegisteredCamp and adjacent areas) and Baharchhara unions of Teknaf sub-district, Marine drive/Jaliapalong adjacent areas, Balukhali areas of Ukhiya sub-district and part of Khuniapalong of Ramu sub-district. Besides, few camps are also given with landslide alert which are camp 4, 8W, 9, 10, 12, 16, 18, 20, 20-Ext and 21.

name: GIN: Flood - 2023-08 - Coyah Floods
summary:
August has recorded significant heavy rains across Guinea, affecting several prefectures of the country. In the morning hours of August 6, 2023, heavy rain in the prefecture of Coyah and its surroundings overflowed the Sarinka River, resulting in flooding in the Urban and Rural Communities of Maneah and Kouriah, affecting nine localities: Fily, Tougandé,  Batouyah, and Sambaya in the urban communities; Tanènè and Tanènè2 in the Rural Commune of Kouria, and Boguitagui, Bangouyah, and Kouria center in the Rural Commune of Kouria, destroying several homes and washing away properties of affected families. During evacuation and rescue, some women, children, and the elderly were identified to be ill that require urgent medical support, while others were trapped in their houses, and some sitting on the roof of their houses requesting rescue. Flooding has also been reported in other locations due to continuous downpours of rains. Faced with this situation, an emergency team was deployed comprising the Minister of Territorial Administration and Decentralization, the Director General of ANGUCH, the Regional Director of Civil Protection, the Red Cross and the Environment as well as medical teams and gendarmerie and police units.

The initial assessments provided by the Guinea Red Cross indicate floods reportedly killed three people, leaving 933 more injured. In this locality of Coyah with 281,757 inhabitants and 40,251 households, a total of 3,448 families amounting to 24135 people have been reported to be displaced. This same rainfall caused a landslide in the urban community of Kindia causing the fall of a tree from the top of a valley on a dwelling house leaving people injured. The technical services of the National Agency for Emergency Management and Humanitarian Disasters, the Guinea Red Cross, and the environment continue to assess the damage on the ground.

The coping capacities of affected households have already been stretched considering the floods have washed away all household items including reserved food, added to the economic crisis that has been impacting the country. While the situation remained fluid, the additional impact of flooding implies that vulnerabilities continue to increase as the capacity to cope decreases.

The Guinea Meteorological Department is forecasting more heavy rain for several prefectures that might result in floods, especially in flood-prone communities, and areas close to rivers where overflow is likely. The incessant flooding in these locations, coupled with the fact that affected people are currently without support calls for urgent efforts to address immediate humanitarian needs. The mayor, who is the political head of the Coyah prefecture has called for immediate support from humanitarian organizations and well-wishers.

name: GHA: 2023 Imminent floods
summary:
According to the Ghana Met (GMet) Agency forecast June to September 2023 issued on 5th May 2023, incidence of above normal rainfall are forecasted in the peak of rainy season (end August to early September) in Upper east region while the overall Northern part of the country ranking from normal to above normal is also likely to face mainly flash floods and revering floods incidence exacerbated by the annual opening of Bagre dam in Burkina Faso once it reach the 235m during the same period.

The National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) and the Meteorological Agency have issued a warming of increased rainfall and flooding and advised people who live in high risk flooding areas to move to higher grounds. It is forecasted that more regions in the northern part will experience flooding as a result of above normal rainfall. The historical impact analysis has shown that, over the past years, the floods impacted around 70,000 people (source: CIMA, UNIDSR, 2018, Ghana Disaster Risk Profile)

Ghana is affected by:
- Flash floods worst in urban areas due to urbanization challenges
- Revering flooding mainly linked to the important river systems length crossing from Others countries, especially Burkina Faso and going through all the North regions up to the South of Ghana. The most overflowing rivers are the White and black Volta and its tributaries like Oti River, which flows into Lake Volta from the northeast.

The connection of this river system with Burkina Faso is worsening the overall flooding situation in Ghana since the annual spilling of water from Bagre Dam in Burkina Faso make an overflowing of all the river system in Ghana, impacting first the Northern regions and areas around the rivers, beaches and dams in Northern region, Upper East, Savannah, Northeast, and Upper West. Bagre Dam is open annually when it reach 255 M which is the maximum level.

GRCS historical data analysis shows that authorities usually alert the NADMO (National Disaster Management Organization) in Ghana in charge of disseminating the information. In the past, Hydroelectric Production Department of SONABEL of Burkina Faso, open the Bagre Dam on 1st September 2022 when it reach 235M. In 2018 it was in 31 August. In general, over the years, the opening of Dam happen from 30 August to 3rd September. Others dam spilling can also be recorded but Bagre is the recurrent one.

name: NPL: Epidemic - 2023-08 - Dengue Prevention and Response
summary:
In Nepal, dengue is a rapidly emerging disease. Endemic across most provinces, dengue incidence has increased in recent years largely due to expansion of the vector Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, as well as the movement of people and the introduction of imported cases. All 4 dengue serotypes exist in Nepal, with DENV-1 and 2 historically contributing the highest burden (EDCD, 2019). The first case of dengue in Nepal was reported in 2004. Since then, dengue cases have been gradually reported in Nepal, with an outbreak in the year 2019 (n=17,992) reported from 68 districts and in 2022 (n=54,784) from all 77 districts. According to EDCD of MoHP, among the total of 54,000 cases, majority of dengue cases (n=28109) including 38 deaths happened between January to September 2022 coinciding with the peak rainy season in the country. This is indicative of exponential surge in dengue cases during July/ September considering the overall weather conditions and monsoon season which provides hibernating infected mosquitoes with an optimal environment for breeding. Until epidemiological week 29 (first week of August 2023, EWARS report, EDCD), 7,253 dengue cases has already been diagnosed which is highly alarming as this is the very first time that dengue has occurred in the consecutive year in contrary to the usual cyclical pattern of dengue incidence in Nepal. In addition, dengue incidence started even during winter season and is in increasing trend. According to a mathematical modelling projection conducted by WHO (2022), the projection shows that cases have already exceeded the alert threshold since beginning of 2023 when compared to the reported dengue cases in EWARS, indicating Dengue outbreak in Nepal. Since dengue is relatively new for Nepal, there is low level of knowledge and awareness among people. Even the priority for dengue prevention was less priority in the country until last year, Nepal government has been sincerely trying to address the emerging trend of dengue through joint planning and implementation from this year. Therefore, Nepal government, municipal authority to the national level, have requested NRCS for better coordination and collaboration in dengue prevention and response to the current outbreak. 
Furthermore, Dengue has disparate effect on different population strata. While pregnant and lactating women, children and elderly population are vulnerable to dengue, young adult population working outside (with low socio-economic status) have higher exposure risk to dengue infected vectors. The number of hospitalized cases has increased exponentially overwhelming the health facilities in Sunsari district. The current daily average cases shows that similar situation might be experienced in the affected districts in coming weeks or months. 
Likewise, the supply of blood (Platelets-rich Plasma-PRPs) will be the challenge to meet the demand. Because of all these factors the severity and mortality cases will be increased in the country. In addition, the urban design of major cities in Nepal lacks in infrastructural public health aspects along with challenging waste management system and poor sanitation facilities which provides vectors with optimal environment for breeding. People residing in slums, densely populated urban cities with poor sanitation facilities are at greater risk of being affected.

name: LBR: Flood - 2023-08 - Liberia Floods
summary: Two weeks of sporadic rainfall in Montserrado County (especially Monrovia) and Grand Cape Mount County respectively has led to flooding affecting 1,556 and displacing about 119 persons in Monrovia and adjacent communities in Grand Cape Mount County in the western part of the country at the border with Sierra Leone. Monrovia and its adjacent communities have a record of flooding in recent years. In the last 4 years, over 40,000 persons have been affected by flooding in most slum communities according to the National Disaster Management Agency. Since the last week of July, over 1,000 households have been affected by flood especially living in wetlands, swamps, and low flood plains in the slums of Monrovia and Robertsports (Capital of Grand Cape Mount County). Families are displaced in public and private facilities such as schools, health centers, churches, and mosques. In some instances in Monrovia, families are restrcited to leave their homes by high level rise of flood waters; they remain in their houses and are assisted with food and water by canoes reaching them by neighbors. Community roads and bridges are washed away preventing community people to have access to basic services. The poor conditions of community public utility facilities such as roads, bridges, etc also contribute to the risk and vulnerability of the affected population.

name: GTM: Drought - 2023-08 - Institutional Red Alert at the national level for drought, rains and forest fires.
summary:
The National Coordinator for Disaster Reduction (CONRED) issued Council resolution CN-10-3-2023 according to the population currently affected and projected by season of hydrometeorological events, by rainy season 2023 and forest fire season 2023-2024.

This means keeping the following functions active:

No. 04 Food Management

No. 18 Water, sanitation and hygiene

No. 22 Health

No. 24 Transportation Management

name: ZWE: Election Preparedness
summary:
In line with the Zimbabwe Constitution, the country holds national harmonized elections every five years, also called general elections. Hence, the next elections will be held on the 23rd of August 2023 and will include the Presidential, Parliamentary and Local council elections. Following the constitution, If there is no outright winner in the presidential contest (winning with more than 50% votes), a run-off will is held six weeks later (october). Dubbed as “dry run” to this year’s contested election, the by-election tension, voting process and the extreme political polarization in the country may lead to situations of violence during the election period. Already, politically linked violent events have been reported successively since 2022. The most significant recent examples include some skirmishes reported in recent weeks which led malicious damage to property, livelihoods and infrastructure reported in Nyatsime, Chitungwiza on the outskirts of Harare.

Hence, multiple elements are indicating a possibility of violence in the impending 2023 elections.

This analysis highlighted by several analysis from experts, media National and international is premised on the following indicators:

a. The historical trend in Zimbabwe depicts an upsurge of violence around elections time. Inter and intra-political party skirmishes at recent political meetings and the 22 March 2022 By-election. In March 2022, the country held by-elections to fill vacant parliamentary and council seats. The run-up to these by-elections witnessed violence incidences and, in some cases, Red Cross volunteers assisted the victims.

b. There are verbal attacks and counter attacks in the media between the political parties with increased political activism in the country leading to a tense political environment.

c. Lack of political tolerance in some areas which has previously experienced disputed election results which in turn ignited violence.

d. Inadequate reconciliation efforts post 2008 violence and the deaths and injuries in the post 2018 election period which predisposes people towards a tendency of violence as revenge.

e. Possibility of an increase in migration towards the elections as people return to vote.

f. Emerging pressure groups which are not directly affiliated to political parties wield potential influence in political agitation.

g. Proliferation of social media (Facebook, Twitter & WhatsApp) as political mobilization tools may result in mass agitation and protests.

h. The economic challenges and hardships have heightened tension which may cause political agitation and sporadic incidences of public disobedience (riots and protests).

name: AZE: Flood - 2023-08 - Flooding in Barda
summary:
On August 02, 2023, as a result of the collapse of a part of the “Upper Karabakh” water channel of the Barda region of Azerbaijan, the village of Garagoyunlu of this region was flooded. The cause of the catastrophe was the rise of the water level in the canal as a result of heavy rain a few days ago.

The basements of about 65 houses and the houses of 30 houses were flooded. A large number of chickens, freshly harvested crops and melon plants were significantly damaged. As a result of the severe consequences of the flood, it became much more difficult for villagers to enter their homes or yards.

name: KGZ: Flood - 2023-08 - Mudflows Kyrgyzstan Issyk-Kul province
VNM: Flood - 2023-08 - VNM: Flood - 2023-08 - flash flood and landslide
summary:
Heavy rains have caused local floods on small rivers and streams, flash floods, and landslides in many localities in the Northern mountainous region, causing damages to people, houses, production, infrastructure, especially in the provinces of Lai Chau, Yen Bai, Son La, and Lao Cai, Lai Chau, Dak Lak, Dak Nong, Gia Lai since 2 August 2023. 

 

Since August 4, the region has recorded downpours with rainfalls of 100 - 200mm, even nearly 400mm in some areas, causing flooding on small rivers and springs, flash floods, and landslides in some localities and also resulting in human and property losses, especially in Lai Chau, Yen Bai, and Son La provinces. The National Centre for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting has predicted that downpours will continue in this region from now through August 8, with rainfalls of 50-120mm, even over 180mm, which will continue posing very high risks of floods, flash floods, and landslides.

From 5 August 5 to 18:00 on 6 August, downpours and floods caused 10 casualties in northern mountainous and midland localities, including seven in Lai Chau, two in Yen Bai and one in Son La, along with heavy property losses, reported the Standing Office of the National Steering Committee.

 

According to a report from the National Commanding Committee for Natural Disaster Prevention and Control (NDPC) of Lai Chau Province, floods have caused 4 deaths and 3 injuries in Ta Mung commune, Khoen On commune, Than Uyen district, affecting 75 houses, of which 39 are in Nam Nhun district, 25 are in Than Uyen district, 10 are in Phong Tho district, the rest are in Sin Ho district. Over 3ha of rice and tea has been eroded and completely buried.

 

Floods have caused subsidence and landslides of many roads in the province with a volume of about 23,000 cubic meters of soil and rock. About 14 km of affected roads include: landslides, road talus, longitudinal trenches and some broken sections causing traffic jams on National Highway 4H at Km 272+200, Km 272+922, Km15+ 420, Km293+930, Km270+300, Km196+090. Flood also caused landslides and damaged 4 irrigation works in Than Uyen district.

A dam containing 1.2 million cubic meters of water, a volume equivalent to 480 Olympic-size swimming pools, in Dak Nong Province has showed signs of cracks following days of heavy rain. Dak Nong province has declared an emergency on natural disasters to handle situations. According to the Provincial People's Committee (PPC), from the end of 6 – 7 August, the area experienced prolonged heavy rains, the total rainfall at Dak Ha station was nearly 400 mm.

 

By 7 August, the cracks on the foot of the dam spanned around 500 m and were around 150 m deep, and showed no signs of abating. On the right side of the dam, around 10 ha of crops are sinking. An estimated 1 million cubic meters of soil has risk of landslides. The dam itself also has large cracks spanning 10-20 cm. The Dak N’Ting reservoir project cost around VND137 billion ($5.78 million), was built to irrigate around 700 ha of crops in Quang Son Commune. To ensure safety, authorities have blocked entrances into the dam area and evacuated 34 families with around 100 people.

At around 8:30 a.m on 8 August, the stream of blackish water coming from a reservoir that contains waste from the extraction of copper from ores rushed towards Ta Phoi Commune, Lao Cai province. The wastewater inundated houses and the commune's People’s Committee office. A local said the stream came quickly and without warning, so they could only escape with their lives, not having enough time to take their belongings.

 The Lao Cai People’s Committee said long-lasting rains have contributed to the breakage, and the exact amount of damage incurred is being evaluated. Lao Cai has been seeing rains over the past week, with the highest amount of rainfall seen on Monday night at 80 mm, according to the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting. Heavy rains have triggered erosion at over 140 locations in Lao Cai, damaging more than 30 houses and flooding more than 110 others. Over 340 ha of crops and around 2 ha of aquaculture have also been damaged.

name: SDN: Flood - 2023-08 - Sudan Flash Floods
summary: On the first week of August 2023, a flash flood hits the city of Al-Jabalain in White Nile State - Al-Jabalain locality, as a result of heavy rains downpours for hours in the eastern highlands of the town. A massive water run down the southern and western parts of the city it swept away and destroyed everything in its path so that the residents of these areas found themselves within the moments homeless. Many houses have been destroyed as well families lost their properties in ten areas. Total HHs affected 632 (416 HH totally damaged and 216 HH partially damaged). In Northern State 6,670 families were affected by flash floods, 1,580 houses were totally affected, 5,090 houses were partially affected and 2,250 latrines were destroyed by flash floods.

name: LBR: September 2023 Floods
summary:
