From 1st to 4th September, Liberia has experienced excessive heavy rainfall in several cities with highest flooding reported in North-Eastern counties of Liberia: Grand Cape Mount, Bong and Montserrado. Areas especially affected are Kru Town; Gbarnga City and Monrovia coastal and urban side as well as the surrounding areas. In total, around 15,200 people are reported to be affected by both urban and coastal floods which swept away infrastructure, fishing settlements, houses, communities' facilities etc. On 4th September, Monrovia and its environs recorded the major impact following the five days cumulative rains from 30 August that affected approximately 12,450 persons (1,778 HHs). The affected are mostly surrounding Moronvia or bordering Sierra Leone and the river crossing the North Est of the country.

The Liberia Meteorological Department has predicted continuous rains in September and October 2023 across all counties in the country. Obviously, with continuous heavy rainfall, it could trigger additional flooding in low-lying communities near rivers and streams. Urban flooding is also possible in areas with poor drainage systems. Sites downstream from large rivers are also vulnerable to flash flooding after relatively short periods of intense rainfall. These rains can cause further damage to infrastructure, road closures, and contamination.

name: MRT: Flood - 2023-07 - Flood in Boghé
summary:
Monday, 31/07/2023, the Moughataa of Bogué under the wilaya of Baraka in southern Mauritania, located 320 km from the capital, experienced torrential rains exceeding the barrier by 150 mm in some areas, causing flooding in several districts of the city, causing the death of a child in the village of Hamdoullah in the commune of Dar El Avia.

 

On this occasion, the government instructed the National Office of Sanitation ONAS to quickly move its machines to the city of Bogue to contribute to the water pumping operation.  

The National Sanitation Office has mobilized 7 large pumping stations, in addition to 6 km of transport pipes, and a number of reservoirs in order to evacuate water from the city.

On Tuesday of 01/08/2023, the Minister of Water and Sanitation went to the city of Bogué to learn about the situation and the work of the teams.

Since the early hours of the floods, the CRM through its disaster management center has regularly monitored the evolution of the situation with the support of the local committee of Boghé.

name: MRT: Flood - 2023-07 - Boghé Flood 2023
summary:
On the night of Sunday to Monday, July 31, 2023, torrential rains that lasted several consecutive hours, exceeding the 150 mm barrier in some areas, fell on the department of Boghé under the wilaya of Brakna in southern Mauritania, causing loss of life in the village of Hamdallah in the municipality of Dar El Avia and extensive damage to infrastructure, homes and livelihoods. The collapse of the houses caused the displacement of several dozen families.

Affected families who lost their shelters took refuge in schools. The schools transformed into reception sites are Emirates School and School 08 and several homeless families have been accommodated by parents and neighbours who have not been affected by the floods.

In general, the floods have stapled the living conditions of the populations, and have accentuated the vulnerabilities of affected households. The weak local capacity to respond to these floods pushes actors to ask for external support. The affected populations are supported by people of good will, nationals of the department of Boghé and elected officials of the city who raised their voices during the parliamentary session at the National Assembly to draw attention to the victims of the floods in Boghé. The flood is due to the surge of rainwater from the upstream slopes (top) of the village Aari Hara, this village is on a small mountain upstream of Boghé. The city of Boghé, the area most affected by flooding, runoff water has ravaged everything in its path, the "Moussafrine" area which includes several neighborhoods and the most populated was invaded by rainwater as well as part of the Nioly district. The Boghé Dow district and neighbouring neighbourhoods, located as an extension of the Manantali electrical installations, are also heavily affected by the floods. The electricity was cut off by the Somelec as a safety measure because the electricity stations that supply the area were completely flooded. On the other hand, in the districts of the Carrefour de Nioly to the bridge and Boghé Escale, the flood did little damage.

With regard to the flood situation in the other communes of the department of Boghé, it should also be noted that the communes of Dar El Avia and Ould Birom have recorded significant material damage, water pollution, destruction of agricultural perimeters and part of the main road (Boghé-Rosso axis). The quality of telephone communication was partially disrupted.

2. Summary

The joint CRM/CRF rapid assessment mission in Boghé assessed flood damage and priority needs. Interviews with local authorities and key informants collected the following data:

o 01 Deaths recorded

o 1200 households affected or 7200 people

o 330 houses totally destroyed

o 250 houses partially damaged

o 527 homeless households

o 1101 displaced persons

o 02 reception sites occupied

o 26 families accommodated in the sites

o 1200 households lost utensils and work materials (Agricultural tools and others)

o 42 Water points destroyed

o 567 families have difficulty accessing drinking water

o 530 Collapsed latrines

o 22 cases of water-related diseases and poor hygiene reported

o 1200 households lost their food stock

o 12 hectares of submerged crops

o 1294 Livestock taken away (small remunerants)

o 573 households in need of food assistance

o 343 households lost their work equipment

name: GTM: Flood - 2023-07 - Llubias de Onda del Este Afectan a Guatemala
summary:
Los departamentos de Izabal, Huehuetenango, Suchitepéques y Guatemala registran los primeros daños por las lluvias del paso de una Onda del Este. Se estima que las lluvias continúen 2 días y provocarán más datos en las comunidades más vulnerables. 

Entre las principales afectaciones se encuentran colapsos de vías, viviendas inundadas, deslizamientos y caídas de árboles y rótulos.

name: LBN: Civil Unrest - 2023-07 - Ain Al Helwe Clashes
summary:
Deadly clashes between rival groups in South Lebanon, Saida’s Ain al-Hilweh Palestinian refugee camp have been ongoing since Saturday 29th  July 2023, killing more than 14 individuals and injuring more than 60 as more than half of the camps residents fled their homes, security sources inside the camp stated. 

Among the injured was a Lebanese Army soldier who was hurt by shrapnel from a mortar shell that fell on a military barracks, the army announced on Twitter. The soldier’s condition was described as stable.

In-fighting is still at large at the time of writing, with automatic machine guns, Rocket Propelled Grenades, and medium sized artilary being used by the multiple factions. The fighting was started on Saturday after the assasination of a Palestinian Command official.

name: GAB: 2023 Election preparedness
summary:
The 2023 electoral calendar is as follows:

-11 July: Deadlines for the filing of declarations of candidacy.

-11 August: Start of electoral campaigns for the presidential election.

-16 August: Start of electoral campaigns for the legislative election coupled with departmental and council elections.

-25 August: End of the electoral campaign period. -

26 August: General elections.

The most likely period of impact is upon publication of results.

 

Although apparently stable, the situation in the country was rocked in recent years by a series of events that are still likely to wreck mayhem. On 7 January 2019, mutineers attempted to overthrow the government following a prolonged absence of the President from the country due to ill health. Since then, the illness and partial incapacity of the Head of State have been seen as a weakness, providing an opportunity to some political opponents to take over power. For the younger generation, this is the reason why they are clamouring for a swing of the pendulum.

Uncertainty about the Head of State's ability to continue in office has led to a power struggle within his own party. In addition, the current term of office is marred by allegations of bad governance and repeated scandals that increasingly make the government unpopular with certain segments of the population, especially the youths. According to Charles M'Ba, an opposition leader, "these seven years of political unrest left their mark, and severely damaged the confidence of the people of Gabon in the State, and in the entire system: its administration, its school and judicial systems, and its police force". Despite attempts at appeasement by the current government, through a dialogue initiated with the bone and sinew of the country in a bid to lead to a peaceful election, some opposition heavyweights remained aloof. Charles M'Ba, a member of the opposition Union nationale (UN) party and former Minister of Finance under Omar Bongo Ondimba, said at the time that he was not very convinced by the rounds of meetings under engineered by the government. “Loving kind words are good, but proof of love is better," he summed up. Listening to your opponents is a good thing. Now, let’s get down to work. Today, the country is at peace, OK, but that doesn't stop me from being worried about the months to come." Source: https://www.lepoint.fr/afrique/gabon-a-quelques-mois-des-elections-un-climat-poli- tique-tendu-03-04-2023-2514692_3826.php du 3 avril 2023. Not very long ago, an opposition coalition strongly denounced the poor organization of the recent revision of the electoral lists and threatened not to recognize the lists that were to be published. Several opposition leaders continue to express their dissatisfaction with the lack of transparency in the electoral process. The political strife between the government and the opposition keeps raging, and this is something that arouses fears of an outbreak of violence during the upcoming elections. These fears are also heightened by the fact that the elections will be threefold (presidential, legislative and local). Therefore, the stakes could be significantly higher, as there could be negative consequences of any protests. Although the harbingers of pre- and/or post-election violence are not yet clearly visible, it is nonetheless worth noting that the pressure increases as the date draws nearer. Political one-upmanship is gaining grounds in public debates and with the economic conditions of the population (high cost of living, water and electricity supply), there is no guarantee that things won't get out of hand.

name: HND: Others - 2023-07 - Dengue epidemic outbreak
summary:
Due to the increasing number of suspected cases accumulated to date of S.E 28 of 2023. With a total of 8,621 registered cases, this mosquito-borne disease has impacted the population in a worrying way.

Of these cases, dengue is presented as the main arbovirus, representing 99.7% of the accumulated total. Within dengue cases, it has been observed that a significant percentage corresponds to cases with alarm signs and without alarm signs, with a total of 8,545 cases, representing 99% of total dengue cases. In addition, 62 cases of severe dengue have been reported, highlighting the importance of taking urgent measures to prevent a further increase in severe cases.

Although the numbers of chikungunya and Zika are relatively low compared to dengue, with 2 cases (0.2%) and 12 cases (0.3%) respectively, it is crucial not to underestimate the presence of these diseases, as they can also have a significant impact on public health and require appropriate care.

name: SYR: Fire - 2023-07 - Syria Wild Fires July 2023
summary:
Multiple Fires have broken out around the coastal and central areas and in Syria. Possible reasons behind these fires differ, including the warm eastern winds that are active during this time of the year in Syria, in addition during the summer there are many dry herbs that burn quickly and the moisture content of the trees is less What is possible during periods of the year, in addition to the high temperature during this period. It is not excluded that there are fires caused by human errors and the intensity of the fires increased from 15 July 2023, which included the  Homs governorate, Hama governorate, and  Lattakia governorate. Most of the fires were in rugged mountainous remote areas. The intensity and size of bushfires in some areas have led to the creation of their own weather systems, generating pyro cumulonimbus clouds, trapping heat, and generating strong wind, in turn sparking further fires. High winds have also helped the bushfires to spread, with some fires jumping over highways and roads. These fires led to material and environmental damage, as a few homes of a number of residents were torched, in addition to burning agricultural crops on which they depend as a main source of livelihood, in addition to burning a large part of the vegetation, forests, and natural reserves.

In addition, there are many warnings by the government, which are as follows:

High levels of fire risk are expected to continue affecting most forest sites in the governorates of Hama and Homs and the eastern parts of the governorates of Lattakia and Tartous during Friday 21 and Saturday 22 July 2023, with the participation of the impact of medium levels on forest sites close to the coastal strip. Normal conditions of heat and dryness continue to support high levels of fire hazard.

So far the directly affected families numbers are limited comparing with previous years, all  the hazards mentioned above are raising the expectations for more fires during the coming days, the indirect effect of this fires will increase our challenges against alleviate the sufferance of the families in the affected areas and protect the remaining resilience in these communities.

name: DZA: Fire - 2023-07 - Northeast Wildfires
summary: Wildfires have been rapidly spreading across the northeastern region of Algeria since July 24th causing extensive devastation. The disaster has had a profound impact on 4000 families, with the Algerian Government reporting 34 confirmed deaths. The affected population heavily relies on crops and livestock, both of which have been severely impacted by the wildfires, resulting in further hardships for the communities. Many homes have been reduced to ashes, leaving families displaced and vulnerable. The dire situation has also affected the health of the population, as the flames and smoke have led to thousands of injuries. The magnitude of the disaster requires urgent attention and support to address the immediate needs of those affected. However, the prevailing weather conditions remain a cause for concern. With temperatures exceeding 45 degrees Celsius and wind speeds exceeding 50 km/h on the Tunisian borders, coupled with low humidity, the conditions continue to favor the expansion and intensification of the wildfires.

name: Super Typhoon Doksuri
summary:
At 10 AM of 21 July 2023, the low pressure area of East of Southeastern Luzon developed into a Tropical Depression locally named “Egay” by the State Weather Bureau.

 

Egay intensified into a Tropical Storm on 22 July 2023 and further intensified into a Sever Tropical Storm on 23 July 2023. On same day, tropical cyclone wind signal was declared in effect. Egay intensifies into a Typhoon at 11 PM of 23 July 2023,  undergoes rapid intensification as it moves over the Philippine Sea, and reached the Super Typhoon Category at 7 AM today, 25 July 2023.

 

The center of the eye of Super Typhoon “Egay” as estimated based on all available data over the coastal waters of Aparri (Fuga Is.), Cagayan (18.7 °N, 121.4 °E ) with a maximum sustained winds of 175 km/h near the center, gustiness of up to 240 km/h, and central pressure of 9355 hPa. It is moving west southwestward at 15 km/h.

countries society-name: The Republic of Korea National Red Cross
name: KOR: Heat Wave - 2023-07 - Excessive heat warning
summary: According to the data released by the Ministry if Interior & Safety of RoK on August 2nd, the heatwave in RoK this summer has resulted 16 deaths from heat-related illnesses in RoK under a prolonged heat wave with temperature above 38 degrees Celsius in some parts of the country. A total of 1,284 people reported suffering heat-related illnesses as of Tuesday August 2nd.  More than 80 participants at the World Scout Jamboree were sent to the hospital after the opening ceremony and more than 1,000 participants are suffering from heat-related illnesses.

name: WRC: Flood - 2023-07 - FLOODS FAKO
summary:
Heavy rain accompanied by winds fell continuously in the city of Limbe from 18 to 19 July 2023. These rains caused flooding in several areas of the city of Limbé (including Church Street, and Down Beach) and landslides in Mawoh. Many damages could be observed including destruction of residential houses, destruction of shops; destruction of household property, disappearance, and loss of life.

The ONCC report  indicates that this decade will be marked by heavy rains accompanied by strong winds, thunderstorms, lightning and hail in many localities in the Regions of the Centre, South, East, Littoral, South-West and West, with a risk of recording flood situations in certain agglomerations of the Littoral region (Douala, Nkongsamba) and South-West (Limbe, Tiko).

According to the weather forecast for the decade from 04 to 14 July, the South-West Region will experience a significant increase in precipitation  throughout the rainy season .
it should be remembered that On March 18, 2023, the city of Buea located in the South-West Region of the country, already knew flooding due to runoff from Mount Cameroon.
As the rainy season is only at the beginning of the rainy season, the situation could intensify, endangering people's lives.

name: COL: Others - 2023-07 - Avenida Torrencial Quetame Cundinamarca
summary:
During the night of Monday, July

17 and the early morning of Tuesday, July 18, 2023, there have been heavy rains in the eastern part of the department of Cundinamarca; due to this, a torrential avenue was generated in the Naranjal village located in the municipality of Quetame - Cundinamarca, this situation caused 11 deaths, 6 people injured and 35 people evacuated, as well as significant damage to some homes and road infrastructure. 

Faced with this emergency, the authorities have deployed rescue teams to search for the missing people and address the situation. Some intuitions such as the Firefighters, Colombian Civil Defense, Colombian Red Cross and the Departmental Unit of Disaster Risk Management are on the site joining forces to coordinate the response efforts.

At the time, the

Bogotá - Villavicencio road is completely closed due to the affectation by the overflow of several streams and the affectation in the bridge of the Orange Creek; Due to this emergency situation, several cargo vehicles and individuals were trapped.

name: COG: Other - 2023-07 - Cholera Epidemic - Shigellosis and Tyhoid Fever
summary: The city of Dolisie, in the Republic of Congo, is in epidemic of cholera, shigellosis and typhoid fever, following the appearance of a disease that already causes 12 deaths, said Monday night the Congolese government, urging departments not yet in epidemic to "put themselves on alert". On July 18, 2023, the government indicates that Dolisie, capital of the Congolese department of Niari, is in epidemic of cholera, shigellosis and typhoid fever, due to the health situation of the city, marked by a disease, with to date 1,365 suspected cases, including 12 deaths, according to a statement from the Ministry of Health. In order to reduce the spread of this epidemic in the departments of Niari and Pointe-Noire, the local Red Cross of Niari actively participates in the various inter-agency coordination meetings and contributes to the active surveillance of cases, contact monitoring and social mobilization and the prevention of hygiene rules. To do this, the local Red Cross deployed 10 teams of 5 Volunteers in the town of Dolisie with 5 supervisors.

name: NGA: Epidemic - 2023-07 - Anthrax Outbreak in Nigeria
summary:
The Federal Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (FMARD) has confirmed one case of Anthrax disease in a mixed livestock farm in Niger State. This is the first animal case to be reported in Nigeria since the beginning of the West Africa outbreak in Ghana in June 2023. On 13th July 2023, the sudden deaths of livestock in this farm with eight (8) mortality was reported. In addition, the animals who died were observed to have been bleeding from external orifices without blood clotting. The Nigerian Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) has said that anthrax disease may have spread to every part of the country. The NCDC said this hours after the Federal Government through the Ministry of Agriculture confirmed the first case of the disease in Niger state.
The case was in a multi-specie animal farm comprising of cattle, sheep and goats located at Gajiri, in Suleja Local Government Area, Niger State, where some of the animals had symptoms including oozing of blood from their body openings – anus, nose, eyes, and ears.
According to the Spokesperson of FMARD, there were significant movements of animals in the area of the last religious feast. The areas are called down south, and it’s possible that in that region where animals are infected may have made their way into the country. Most especially for animals that were brought in across the borders. So, in this context, there may be other animals with it.
The country’s Ministry of Health also expressed worry that anthrax has spread across the 36 states and the Federal Capital Territory (FCT). Stating that it is possible that the disease is currently across the country and likely other cases that are yet to be notified.

The signs of anthrax-infected animals include the oozing of blood from their body openings – (anus, nose, eyes, and ears), and high fever; it should be noted that, in many cases, the sign is not visible and leads to sudden death.

Following the report, samples were collected on 14th July 2023 from multiple species in this livestock farm and transported to the National Veterinary Research Institute (NVRI), VOM, Plateau State for testing and the results were positive for anthrax.

Further investigation is also ongoing to trace the source of the infection and to identify the spread to other farms and humans. Though human exposure has been reported, there are no reports so far of human symptoms or mortality. The FMARD and the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) are currently working closely with the Niger State Ministries of Health and Agriculture to identify, isolate and follow up all exposed persons.

name: GRC: Fire - 2023-07 - Greece Fires
summary:
The last days many wildfires hitting several areas in Greece, Firefighters are working on 90 fire fronts across the state. According to the infromation it is expected to be the warmest July on record in more than 50 years. Due to high temperatures and the strong winds most of the fires aren't under control. The wilfire in Euboea in the municipality of Karystos, cost the life of two pilots of a Canadair-style water bomber during their effort to put out the fire, and the life of a cattle breeder, also in mountainous Euboea. In the wilfire that broke out in Magnisia, Volos July 26, an eledry woman was found charred inside a mobile home, also a shepherd lost his life during his effort to save his flock. Thousand of hectares, hundred of houses, hotels, cars, factories, businesses and animals were burned. Overall, more than 35.000 thousand residents and tourists were forced to evacuate.

Attica: July 17, a wildfire broke out in east Attica, Kouvaras. The fire very quickly expanded to other nearby areas, Anavyssos, Saronida and Lagonisi. More than 30.000 hectares and several houses were burned. Eight areas were forced to evacuate. Also, due to the large fire, the Police has proceeded to stop the traffic of vehicles in nearby areas.

Rhodes: July 18, a wildfire borke out on the island of Rhodes, south aegean Greece, at Emponas area. Today is the ninth day after the fire started and are three active fronts. Around 260 firefighters, 42 fire trucks, 4 helicopters and 3 planes, hundreds of volunteers, the Greek army and the coast guard battle the blaze burning and support the evacution and other procedures. More assistant was requested. At the moment there are thousands of burned lands, houses, hotels and animals. Twelve areas were evacuated by the sea and by land. In the beggining, there are several shelters to accommodate the fire victims. Fire is not yet under control. At the moment, firefighting forces are focusing on the villages of Vati, Asklipieio and Archangelosthe. The island is in a state of Emergency. 

Eboea: July 23, a wildfires broke out in Eboea, Karystos. The fire started on three different fronts and immediately took on large proportions. At present, the situation in Karystos shows improvement, with firefighters successfully tackling scattered outbreaks. The fire has burned houses, many livestock facilities and animals. Residents and tourists of 6 areas were forced to evacuate. At the area 93 firefighters with 3 groups of pedestrians and 32 vehicles are operating at the scene, while from the air 3 is assistance from helicopters and aircraft as well as earthmoving machines and water carriers of the local municipality. 

Corfu: July 23, a wildfire broke out in northeast Corfu, burning forest and grassland areas with two big fronts which are located in the northeastern part of the island. The first goes from the village of Palia Perithia to Lavki and the second near Imerolia. Around 60 firefighters with 21 water trucks and three groups of firefighters on foot are operating, assisted by two helicopters and two PZL airplanes. Regarding the burned hectares, the estimation is around 20.000. More than 12 settlements were forced evacuation. After three days, seems that the fire is under control. 

Magnisia: July 26, a wilfire broke out in Velestino, Volos, Magnisia. At present, are two active fronts. Six areas were forced evacuation. While in the territory there are electricity issues due to the fire. Strong ground forces and air forces are working to extinguish the fire.

Other: July 17, a wildfire broke out about 30 kilometers northwest of Athens, in Dervenochoria, which by July 21 had burned an area of ​​more than 100,000 hectares and damaged many houses

July 23, a wildfire broke out in Aigio, Peloponnisos. With many scattered outbreaks of fire in an area which is inaccessible and very difficult for the intervention of ground forces. 

July 26, Large fronts broke out Lamia, Central Greece, which areas were being evacuated.

name: BLZ: Epidemic - 2023-07 - Dengue in Belize
summary: The districts of Belize, Cayo, Orange Walk and Corozal are affected the most.

name: GTM: Civil Unrest - 2023-07 - Social Demonstrations in Guatemala
summary: The Public Ministry has raided the offices of the Supreme Electoral Tribunal to hijack all the documentation of the political party Seed before alleged anomalies in the additions of the poly group Tica. This political party would contest the second round for the election of President in Guatemala, scheduled for August 20, 2023. Social protests have not been long in coming and are in different parts of the country. More Guatemalans are expected to join the call for organizations urging a national strike.

name: GRC: Heat Wave - 2023-07 - Heat Wave "KLEON"
summary: Hellenic Red Cross has immediately responded to the call of the Minister of Culture, Mrs Lina Mendoni , for providing assistance to thousands of visitors to the Acropolis place. In particular for three days, Staff and volunteers of  HRC distributed about 20,000 water bottles per day, to the visitors of Acropolis museum while at the same time  instructions for high temperature periods were communicated through leaflets of the Communications Department  under extremely difficult situations due to the high temperatures associated.

name: GTM: Population Movement - 2023-07 - Manifestaciones Sociales
summary:
Guatemala está desarrollando un proceso electoral para el cual las autoridades han emitido disposiciones que probablemente alteren a ciertos sectores de la población, tal como lo ha anunciado en las redes sociales.

En las próximas horas se espera que la población reaccione ante las disposiciones de las autoridades.

name: GTM: Drought - 2023-07 - Impact of the El Niño phenomenon in Guatemala
summary: Scarce food is expected because the pastures suffer a lot from the decrease in rainfall, generating stress, dehydration in the crop. The greatest impacts are observed in the planting of dessert, because the exit of the rainy season is usually advanced. It can cause significant losses to farmers.

name: JAM: Population Movement - 2023-07 - Haitian Migrants arrival in Jamaica
summary:
The Jamaica Red Cross was advised by the Government of Jamaica of the arrival of 38 Haitian Nationals, who landed at Boston Bay in the parish of Portland, yesterday, Monday July 10, 2023. The 38 migrants are made up of 29 males and 9 females and of that number 9 are children (5 boys and 4 girls). The Haitians were later transferred from Portland to the Parish of St Mary, where they are currently being housed in a facility owned by the Seventh Day Adventist Church. 

The Jamaica Red Cross received information from the ODPEM that te migrants would be in Jamaica until the last weekend in July, however the Passport Immigration and Citizenship Agency advised the NS yerterday July 17th that the Government is seeking to have the migrants repatraited by Sunday July 23.

The Haitians were taken to Court today July 18th and we are awaitin the outcome.

name: MNG: Flood - 2023-07 - Urban floods
summary:
Between July 3-5, rainfall of 28.4 mm have occured in 26 hours in central area of Mongolia including Ulaanbaatar. Prolonged rainfall has increased the water level of rivers by 10-30 cm from average height.  Selbe and Dund rivers run across Ulaanbaatar city and due to rainfall, both rivers are flooding and affecting the apartments nearby. The dam for the Selbe river has collapsed due to the overflooding. As of July 5, 54 apartments, 1 garage of mall, 5 houses, 15 gers, 2 main roads, 2 tunnels are in standing water caused by flood and 397 staff are working at the affected sites by draining the water with suction pumps. National Emergency Management has assisted 526 people including the elderly, disabled people and children who had been isolated by the standing water and flood and 306 vehicles have been moved from the flooded areas. In the flooded apartments, there's an electricity blackout and people are evacuating from their apartments.

Meanwhile in the ger district, there are households who are affected by the flash floods in Bayanzurkh, Chingeltei districts. Main concern is flooded pit latrines which is increasing the risk of contagious and water-borne diseases. The number of affected houses are being verified by the RC branches and will update the report once it's verified. 

The rain is expected to continue until July 10.

name: PSE: Complex Emergency - 2023-07 - Escalation in the West Bank, particularly in Jenin
summary:
The IOF  began what appears to be one of its most extensive operations in the territory in years with drone strikes early on Monday.

Nine Palestinians have been killed and 100 injured, health officials say.

Israel said it was putting a stop to Jenin being "a refuge for terrorism". Palestinians accused it of a war crime.

 

 

It says dozens of people had been detained by Israeli forces in their homes since early Monday, without being provided or allowed any food or drink.

The Israeli military said there was no specific timeline for ending the operation, but that it could be "a matter of hours or a few days".

Jenin has become a stronghold of a new generation of Palestinian militants who have become deeply frustrated by the Palestinian Authority's aging leadership and the restrictions of the Israeli occupation.

The city has seen repeated Israeli military raids in the past year as local Palestinians have carried out deadly attacks on Israelis. Other Palestinian attackers have hidden there.

name: TZA: Epidemic - 2023-07 -  ARUSHA CHOLERA OUTBREAK
summary:
On 3rd July, 2023 the Ministry of Health was notified Cholera outbreak in Arusha region and cases were said to be
originated from Sokoni One Ward in Arusha City Council.
• Reports indicates that the index case started showing symptoms on 14th May,
2023
• As of 17th July 2023 Cumulative total of 284 Suspect Cases with one death (CFR: 0.4%) were reported.
Cumulatively total of 41 samples were collected for culture and sensitivity and out of those 20 had growth of Vibrio Cholerae. Only two Councils have been affected namely; Arusha City Council and Arusha District Council

name: MNG: Epidemic - 2023-06 - Bubonic plague suspected case
summary: West Mongolia's Govi-Altai Province has been quarantined for a week due to a suspected case of bubonic plague, also known as the Black Death, said the provincial governor's office on Tuesday. Relevant authorities identified 62 individuals who made physical contact with the suspected person and placed under quarantine. The PCR test has been sent to regional health center in Khovd province and the result is expected to come on July 28, 2023. The suspected case has been reported in Bugat soum (administrative subdivision) of the province, and is now under isolation at a local hospital, the office said in a statement.

name: PAK: Flood - 2023-06 - Monsoon Rain in Pakistan
summary:
According to officials from the National Disaster Management Authority, there have been a total of 76 reported deaths in various rain-related incidents across Pakistan since the onset of the monsoon season on 25th June 2023. Additionally, 133 individuals have sustained injuries in multiple incidents. The majority of the fatalities occurred in Punjab and were primarily caused by electrocution and building collapses.

 In the provincial capital of Punjab, Lahore, there has been an unprecedented amount of rainfall, resulting in roads being transformed into waterways. This severe weather has left approximately 35% of the city without access to electricity and water this week. According to the Water and Sanitation Agency (WASA), the rainfall in Lahore has broken a 30-year record, with twelve out of sixteen monitoring points in the city recording rainfall exceeding 200 millimeters.

 

In Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, a tragic incident occurred in the Shangla district, where the bodies of eight children were recovered from a landslide on Thursday, as reported by the spokesperson of the emergency service Rescue 1122.

Please refer to the table below, extracted from the NDMA website, for a summary of the total rainfall data.

The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) has issued a forecast for the next three days. According to their alert issued on 5th July, there is a prediction of widespread heavy to very heavy rainfall, with extremely heavy falls expected at scattered areas in the upper catchments of Rivers Sutlej, Ravi, Chenab, and partially Jhelum between 8th and 10th July 2023.

 

Additionally, the PMD has warned about the likelihood of severe thunderstorms and heavy rainfall in North and Northeastern Punjab, which may result in urban flooding in municipal areas and landslides in hilly regions.

 In Sindh, including cities like Karachi, Tharparkar, Sukkur, Larkana, Hyderabad, and Shaheed Benazir Abad, the Meteorological Office has forecasted potential thunderstorms and heavy rainfall. Furthermore, there is a possibility of thunderstorms in Northeastern Balochistan.

name: ARG: Flood - 2023-06 - Inundaciones en Neuquén
summary:
Desde A raíz de las fuertes lluvias que comenzaron el día 23 de junio, los ríos de la provincia Neuquén están teniendo crecidas históricas que según los especialistas no se registraban desde hace 10 años. El mayor incremento de caudales se está registrando en la cabecera norte de la cuenca del río Neuquén y en el Río Curi Leuvú afectando a las localidades linderas en las cuencas.

A través de los medios se están reportando localidades aisladas debido a las crecidas en los márgenes de las rutas provinciales que acceden a dichas localidades.

name: COL: Population Movement - 2023-06 - Riesgo de llegada masiva de Población migrante y población Colombiana desde Venezuela ZUELA HACIA GUAINÍA
summary: Con base en la situación que se puede llegar a presentar, por la situación en la Mina Yapacana en Venezuela con influencia en el Departamento de Guainía y en municipio de Inírida, se han evidenciado algunas brechas y necesidades que se pueden llegar a presentar: Salud: Dado que se trata de un contexto complejo con condiciones del trabajo en las minas, se presume de la incidencia de enfermedades tropicales, transmitidas por vectores, de transmisión sexual, entre otras, de las personas que potencialmente lleguen a la zona. Alojamiento: si bien se presume que las personas que potencialmente lleguen buscarían acogida en hogares de sus redes de apoyo, se presumen situaciones de hacinamiento, saturación de la demanda de vivienda/arriendo, sobrecostos de arriendos, entre otras. Seguridad Alimentaria: ante una posible restricción de recursos económicos, se presumen necesidades en cuanto a alimentación. Perfiles como niños y niñas, mujeres gestantes/lactantes y adultos mayores (familiares de personas en las minas que eventualmente lleguen con ellos) serían perfiles especialmente vulnerables. Agua, Saneamiento e Higiene (WASH): las condiciones de algunos lugares de eventual acogida (p.ej. alojamientos temporales) presentan deficiencias de agua y saneamiento; además, se podrían requerir kits de higiene para las personas llegando. Protección: Debido a la dinámica en los lugares de origen, así como el perfil de las personas que eventualmente llegarían a Colombia, se requeriría de orientación jurídica, asistencia legal y posiblemente apoyo psicosocial, Protección de Vínculos Familiares. Medios de vida: la vulnerabilidad económica preexistente en las comunidades locales, así como las condiciones de dependencia de la economía local frente a la minería del otro lado de la frontera, suponen un deterioro de la situación general en el municipio, exacerbada si se presentan nuevas llegadas de personas. por parte de la seccional se establece una coordinación con las diferentes autoridades en el territorio con el fin de coordinar las acciones necesarios para una posible respuesta.

name: NGA: Flood - 2023-06 - Flash flooding due to adverse weather condition
summary:
According to social media platform and the local news 116 houses were submerged in Trademore Estate of Lugbe community following heavy rains that hit the Federal Capital Territory around mid morning (23/06/2023). The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has confirmed this information while debunking the unconfirmed report of 1 death. The NRCS has activated its Branch structures and have deployed volunteers in the locality to provide rapid assessment reports of the situation on the ground. The NRCS is working closely with movement partners in country to work out a response to the flooding situation. 

As at the time of filing this report, stakeholders responding to the flood on the estate are NEMA, Fire Service, FCT FEMA, Red Cross and Federal Ministry of Environment-Flood department.

name: AZE: Flood - 2023-06 - Flooding in Ganja
summary:
The flood was caused by the overflowing of the artificial lake in the city's park built on 12 hectares, which is more devastating than the previous floods that hit Ganja city in late May 2023.

Most of the houses based in the lower part of the park were damaged. The walls of most houses cracked, basements and backyards flooded with water.

As of June 23, more than 30 houses were damaged due to the flooding. A serious collapse has already been observed in the second concrete dam of the lake and as a result of unstable weather conditions (according to the information received from hydrometeorologists, heavy rains, hailstorms are expected in the next couple of days in the western regions of Azerbaijan, and the river waters in this region is expected to rise), the second dam is expected to collapse, which would dramatically increase the scale of the emergency.

Currently, the rescue teams of the Ganja Regional Center of the Ministry of Emergency Situations are carrying out high priority emergency work to reduce the water level in the lake. They are aiming at draining the water to prevent it from overflowing. Natural draining is not possible for the moment.

name: CHL: Inundación pluvial / riada - 2023-06 - Inundaciones - Chile 2023
summary:
Un sistema frontal afecta desde el día 21 de junio a 5 regiones, este ha presentado lluvias y vientos moderados a fuertes, lo cual a provocado la crecida de rios y remoción de masas, por esto desde el servicio nacional de prevención y respuestas ante desastres (SENAPRED), el desplazamiento de personas y evacuaciones en diferentes zonas de las 5 regiones, por lo que se ha declarado alertas amarilla y roja en provincias y comunas, y se ha realizado activación de la alerta SAE para evacuaciones en zonas en peligro.

En el día viernes 23 se ha declarado alerta amarilla referente al suministro de agua potable el cual se indica tiene capacidad de distribución de 24 horas en las reservas disponibles, lo cual en caso de que la situación no mejore se estima una damnificación de 6 millones de personas. se recomendo a la población el almacenamiento de agua 15 litros por persona. 

Región Valparaiso

  • Declaración de alerta roja para la provincia de los andes y san felipe por amenaza de desborde (23/06 - Vigente)
  • Declaración de alerta roja para la Provincia de Quillota por amenaza de desborde (23/06 - Vigente).
  • Declaración de alerta amarilla Provincia de San Antonio, Región de Valparaíso por alteración del suministro de agua (24/06 - vigente).

Los Andes: Se encuentran 12 personas albergadas en escuela río blanco y se habilitara escuela españa.

Además, 800 familias continúan afectadas por aumento de turbiedad en Servicios Sanitarios Rurales (SSR) en la comuna de Putaendo. Personal municipal ha dispuesto camiones aljibes para la distribución de agua potable.

Se mantiene el corte del suministro afectando aproximadamente 22.205 clientes en las comunas de Los Andes y Calle Larga. Trabaja en su reposición la empresa ESSVAL.

name: GRC: Population Movement - 2023-06 - Migrant boat arrival in Kalamata
summary:
On Wednesday 21 June 2023 a sailing boat arrived to the port of Kalamata  in southern Greece carrying 64 migrants on board. All arrived safely and are being proccessed at the port.

The Hellenic Red Cross was mobilized immediately in light of the emergency situation that arosed in Kalamata, to provide support to the people in need.

The staff and volunteers of the Health Sector of the Regional Department of Kalamata of the Hellenic Red Cross offered First Aid and basic necessities to the migrants while providing them with the necessary medicines and medical equipment.

The volunteers of the Hellenic Red Cross will stay by their side as long as necessary.

The nationalites of the people is as follows: 55 people from Iraq, 7 from Iran, 2 from Morocco.

name: GHA: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2023-06 - Ghana Floods 2023
summary:
In several regions of Ghana, severe flooding has resulted in the loss of life, the devastation of homes, and the displacement of entire communities. Included in the affected regions are Greater Accra, Western, Ashanti, and Volta in the beginning June 2023. At least 6632 people have been affected, 7 dead and 3974 people displaced in four affected regions.

Ghana Red Cross Society Response, at Ho in the Volta Region, the Regional Branch Manager took part in the rapid assessment team together with the Regional Coordinating Council, National Disaster Management Organisation, and other state agencies to assess the Ho Municipality floods. The District Disaster Response Team (DDRTs) of Keta Municipal responded and assisted in evacuating the affected people to safe havens.

name: ARG: Disturbios civiles - 2023-06 - Tensión Social en Jujuy
summary:
Desde el 17 de junio, en la Provincia de Jujuy, vienen aconteciendo un serie de manifestaciones pacíficas protagonizadas por comunidades indígenas y sindicatos en contra de la reforma constitucional en la Provincia de Jujuy y en demanda de aumentos salariales y asuntos sindicales para los docentes de la provincia.

El día 20 de junio, la propuesta de reforma constitucional fue aprobada. Esto fue causal de un incremento de tensión en las calles con un saldo de aproximadamente 20 heridos de gravedad. Asimismo, la circulación por la ciudad capital y sus periferias se ve limitada, causando por ejemplo, un cese en la actividad aérea del Aeropuerto local por imposibilidad de acceso de sus empleados o limitaciones en el abastecimiento de insumos en hospitales.

La situación en Jujuy implicó una movilización en el día 21 de junio en la Ciudad Autónoma de Buenos Aires desde el obelisco hasta la sede de la Casa de la Provincia de Jujuy en la zona céntrica de la ciudad. Diversos organismos, sindicatos y espacios políticos han participado de esta movilización, la cual no presentó mayores inconvenientes y desarrolló de forma pacífica.

name: ARM: Other - 2023-06 - Hailstorm
summary: On 15th of June sever hailstorm affected south region of Armenia. Due to the damage of water drainage system and following heavy rain the water accumullated in the villages, roads and bridges have been destroted, water and energy supply systems damaged as well. High water level also became a threat for population; their homes, crops and livestock significantly affected. While loocal rescue service is doing monitoring of situation and assesment of damaged infrastructure, local administartion started initial assesment of needs of affecrted population.

name: GEO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2023-06 - Flash Floods in Eastern Georgia
summary: In 15th of June, Gurjaani, a municipality in Georgia, experienced a significant disaster resulting from heavy rainfall, flooding, and hailstorms. The disaster impacted various areas within Gurjaani, affecting both urban and rural settlements. As a consequence of the heavy rainfall, the central streets of Gurjaani municipality and surrounding areas were flooded, causing severe difficulties in transportation and mobility. In addition, the sudden mudflows and landslides resulted in the destruction of roads, blockages caused by fallen trees, and damage to vital infrastructure such as bridges and power transmission towers. Gurjaani, Chumlaki, Tchandari, Vejini, Dzirkoki, Kolagi, Bakurtsikhe, Kodalo villages were flooded, and other state infrastructure such as bridges and inland roads, and power transmission towers were damaged. The disaster also had a detrimental impact on the agricultural sector, with flooding damaging agricultural lands and destroying crops. This has significant implications for the livelihoods of the affected population, as agriculture serves as a crucial source of income for many households in Gurjaani. During the Gurjaani disaster, the heavy flooding had a profound impact on the affected households. As families typically stored basic household items and food on the first floor, the floodwaters resulted in significant damage to essential supplies, appliances, furniture, and various household items. This loss added to the already challenging situation faced by the affected population

name: ZWE:Cholera Outbreak
summary: The cholera outbreak started on the 12th of February, in Chegutu town, which has a population of 66,258 within the Mashonaland West Province of Zimbabwe. The suspected case was confirmed by the Ministry of Health and Child Care (MoHCC) on the 15th of February while a second case was reported, again in Chegutu town on the 17th of February.This saw the Government set up a Cholera treatment centre in Chegutu. By the 26th of February, 37 suspected cholera cases with 2 confirmed positive cases and no deaths were reported in Chegutu district. As of the 18th of April 2023, there had been 579 suspected cholera cases reported, of which 102 were culture confirmed, and 9 deaths (CFR 1.6%). The situation was stable until the last SITREP of 1st June 2023 showing an ascendant curve in cases and death since late May to 1st June.The cases have now been reported from all the ten provinces of the country, without epidemiological link to each other. By the 18th of April, there had been 168 RDTs (Rapid diagnostic tests) conducted with 73/168 positive (42 % positivity) and 104/359 positive cultures (29 % positivity). Although this cholera outbreak occurred outside the rainy season, it mimicked the previous cholera outbreak of 2018 that started in the same town and spread to other hotspots within the country. To date, 17 cholera hotspot districts in the country have been severely affected and cases are on the rise. The MoHCC, through the Zimbabwe Cholera SitRep of 28 May 2023, reports a cumulative total of 1649 suspected cholera cases, 423 confirmed cases, 1528 recoveries, 11 confirmed deaths and 33 suspected deaths.

name: GRC: Population Movement - 2023-06 - Greece - Peloponnese Shipwreck
summary:
Early on Wednesday 14 June a fishing boat capsized in international waters 47 nautical miles southwest of Pylos in southern Greece, in one of the deepest areas in the Mediterranean. The bodies of dozens of individuals have been recovered with hundreds feared missing as reports suggest that 400-750 people were onboard.  104 individuals were rescued -none of whom were wearing a life jacket- however, as the time passes hopes of finding survivors are diminishing. This is the deadliest shipwreck off Greece in several years.

The boat had sailed from the Libyan town of Tobruk, which lies south of the Greek island of Crete, with most on board being young men in their 20s. Coast guard said the boat, which was en route to Italy, was spotted in international waters late on Tuesday 13 June by an aircraft belonging to EU border agency Frontex and two nearby vessels. It said those on board had refused assistance offered by Greek authorities late on Tuesday. A few hours later the boat capsized and sank, triggering a massive search-and-rescue operation mounted by the Hellenic Coast Guard.

Four rescued migrants were rushed to Kalamata hospital in a Super-Puma helicopter while the other rescued individuals were taken to the port of Kalamata, where preparations for their reception have been made with the assistance of the general secretariat of Civil Protection.

The Hellenic Red Cross, with the specialized nursing staff and the volunteers of the Health Sector of the Kalamata Regional Department assisted from the first moment the survivors of the wreck. Volunteer Samaritans-Rescuers of the HRC were also deployed and supported more than 80 migrants (including 20 children), providing first aid and distributing food and basic necessities while offering psychological support to the rescued migrants. The main health problems faced are secondary drowning, shortness of breath, dehydration, asthma attacks, high fever, exhaustion, dysuria, hematuria, and otitis. 

Staff of the Research & Restoring Family Links (RFL) Sector of the HRC arrived today in Kalamata, in order to coordinate from the spot the actions for the search for the missing people and the restoration of the family ties of the survivors, with the support of the ICRC team in Greece. 

The HRC will remain at the scene for as long as necessary.

name: SRB: Flood - 2023-06 - June floods
summary:
For two weeks before the date of the disaster, which occurred on 12-16 June, the Republic of Serbia was affected by heavy rainfall. The affected areas are the city of Belgrade and Kolubarski, Moravicki, Pomoravski, Raski, Zlatiborski, Rasinski, Nisavski, Toplicki, Zlatiborski, Jablanicki district and municipalities in Kosovo and Metohija. 7 municipalities and cities reported from the 4th to 6th of June that were affected by heavy rain that caused flash floods and floods. Heavy rainfalls were in the municipalities and cities of Loznica, Sabac, Babusnica, Aleksinac, Grocka, Aleksandrovac, Kursumlija, Cacak, and Vrnjacka Banja. In these municipalities and cities, it was reported that from 10 to 40 liters per square fell in just 3 hours which lead to floods and flash floods. Local streams and rivers of Dumaca and Dobrava, Mozgovacka River, Rasina, Bresnica, Bukovac, Zutaja, Vrnjacka, Lipovacka, and Rsovacka were spilled. Agriculture fields and roads were flooded, and accumulated water covered several rural roads and bridges.

From the 12th to 16th of June, due to new heavy rainfalls, additional 16 municipalities and cities declared a state of emergency due to flooding and flash floods (Arilje, Trstenik, Kursumlija, Prokuplje, Vučitrn, Varvarin, Novi Pazar, Rekovac, Kruševac, Jagodina, Despotovac, Sokobanja, Cicevac, Svilajnac, Koceljava, Kosjeric). During this period on each day in different parts of the Republic of Serbia, there were heavy rainfalls with intensity from 30 liters to 80 liters per square meter in 12 hours.

name: DJI: Cyclone - 2023-06 - Vents violents/pluies
summary:
Dans les soirées de samedi 10 juin et dimanche 12 juin 2023, 2 localités (Omar Jagaa et Sankal) situées respectivement dans les régions administratifs d’Arta et de Dikhil de la république de Djibouti ont été touchées par des vents violents accompagnées des averses sporadiques.  Ces deux localités affectées, sont des zones habitées par des personnes déplacées internes particulièrement vulnérables.  

Cet événement naturel lié au changement climatique a été qualifié par la communauté locale comme étant sans précédent de par sa violence et sa spontanéité. D’où une certaine frayeur qui reste perceptible.

Les branches régionales du Croissant Rouge de Djibouti ainsi que les autorités publiques locales ont entrepris des missions d’évaluations post catastrophes  pour évaluer l’ampleur des dégâts causés par cet événement.

Aucune perte de vie humaine n'est à deplorer. L'essentiel des degats se limitent à la destruction des habitats, les latrines ainsi que les matériels de stockage d'eau. En raison de leur faible ressources fianancières les habitats sont construits à base des materiaux de fortune. 

Au  total, les nombres des ménages sinistrés s’élèvent à 128. Soient 768 personnes selon la taille moyenne du ménage à Djibouti qui est du 6 personnes.

name: PHL: Volcanic Eruption - 2023-06 - Mayon Volcano
summary:
Mayon Volcano is placed under Alert Level III, indicating relatively high unrest, that Mayon is exhibiting magmatic eruption of a summit lava dome, with increased chances of lava flows and hazardous PDCs affecting the upper to middle slopes of the volcano and of potential explosive activity within weeks or even days.

 A total of 267 rockfall events and 2 volcanic earthquakes were recorded from 05 to 08 June, compared to 54 rockfall events from 01 to 04 June 2023. These events had durations of one (1) to three (3) minutes and transported lava debris within a kilometer range of the southern upper slopes. The volume of discrete rockfall events increased on 3 June based on the seismic record, signaling an increase in the rate of dome growth. Three (3) pyroclastic density current or PDC events on the Bonga (southeast) and Basud (east) Gullies were observed today at 6:18 AM, 9:53 AM and 11:00 AM. The PDCs lasted four to five minutes based on the seismic record and emplaced within a kilometer of the summit crater. In contrast, SO2 emission remains at baseline or background levels. The overall monitoring parameters indicate that very slow extrusion of shallow degassed magma is ongoing and is incrementally increasing in rate; i.e., effusive magmatic eruption is taking place.

name: PHL: Volcanic Eruption - 2023-06 - Mayon Volcanic Eruption
summary:
In the past 24-hour period, the Mayon Volcano Network recorded six (6) dome-collapse Pyroclastic Density Currents (PDC) that lasted three (3) to six (6) minutes and one hundred ninety-nine (199) rockfall events based on seismic and visual observations.  The PDC and rockfall events emplaced lava debris on the southern gullies within two kilometers from the summit crater. Thin light brown ash from the rockfalls and continuous moderate degassing from the summit crater produced steam-laden plumes that were bent and drifted to the general south. 
The Albay Provincial Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Council (PDRRMC) on Thursday ordered the evacuation of residents in areas surrounding Mayon Volcano (6 km radius) in order to protect lives and properties due to its increased activity.

name: SLE: Election preparedness
summary:
General elections are scheduled in Sierra Leone from June to July 2023 following the calendar issued by the Electoral Commission for Sierra Leone (ECSL). This election includes, first, a Presidential election and a Parliamentary process across the country. The Election campaign started in 2022 and was completed in May 2023. There have been indicators that social or civil unrest would likely be experienced during the election period, requiring heightened readiness of the National Society to support potentially affected communities under its mandate.

The coming elections will be held as follows:

• 24th June 2023 Presidential - voting day in the 16 districts of the country.

• 25th to 28th June 2023, Proclamation of the results of the presidential election. This is an estimated date based onhistorical process which usually takes up to 4 days.

• Proclamation of Parliamentary representative following the Proportional representative system established in early 2023. The date for the start and end of this is not specified but all election processes must be completed from June to July. Following the NS contingency planning, a period of two weeks is estimated for planning purposes.

With regards to the upcoming 2023 General Elections period, incidences of inter-communal conflict have so far been observed in many parts of the country. Indeed, these elections will be held against the backdrop of a severe complex economic crisis and periods of civil unrest surrounding governance issues. In the period leading to the election, the country has witnessed civil unrest, economic instability, currency devaluation, and multiple disasters, especially in the country’s capital city, Freetown. The widespread protest of August 2022 was a violent example of turmoil in Freetown and other cities in Sierra Leone. Indeed, thousands of protesters mobilized around the country, blocking roads and main supply routes demonstrating unemployment, economic hardship, and injustices, demanding reductions in fuel prices, economic relief for indebted families, fair prices for agricultural products, employment and labour rights, security, and protection. Over 34 people were injured, 30 deaths (including 3 police officers), and many detained in different parts of the country. These events are analyzed to be the reflection of what could happen during the upcoming general elections. Moreover, some recent analyses report that ahead of the June 24 poll, a rematch of the 2018 vote, identity issues and economic stagnation are also on the ballot. After the change of the Parliamentary voting system in early 2023 from a complete election system to a Proportional representative system. Proportional Representation is a type of electoral system under which subgroups of an electorate are reflected proportionately in the elected body. This could add more expectations from the population on the Presidential elections, given that level of changes in the presidential votes may also lead to parallel changes of the National and local possible representatives across the country. The hope for politico-economical changes is highly expected based on some allegations and past analysis reporting a high corruption level across the country with some economical challenges not resolved.

The period preceding the elections (until late March) has seen episodic protests and reports of intimidation against opposition parties. This and the intimidation actions already reported against the opposition indicate that the relative calm reported in other sources can also deteriorate. Between the most recent event, there has been members of the opposition wounded or shoot and some violence in the past weeks since the campaign. Whilst the priority is to support peacebuilding and prevention of violence efforts, previous outbreaks of violence have demonstrated the importance of planning for potential humanitarian response activities.

name: PAK: Cyclone - 2023-06 - Tropical Cyclone (BIPARJOY) Formed over Southeast Arabian Sea
summary:
The Depression over the southeast Arabian Sea has strengthened and is now a Cyclonic Storm named "BIPARJOY." It is currently located at Latitude 12.3°N and Longitude 66.0°E, approximately 1420km south of Karachi. The maximum sustained surface winds around the center of the storm are 60-70 Km/hour, with gusts up to 80 Km/hour. The environmental conditions, including a sea surface temperature of 30-32°C, low vertical wind shear, and upper-level divergence, are favorable for further intensification. The system is expected to become a Severe Cyclonic Storm within the next 24 to 36 hours and continue moving in the north/northwest direction.

The low-pressure area over the Southeast Arabian Sea has developed into a Depression, which is now a strong LPA. It is positioned near Latitude 11.5°N and Longitude 66.0°E, about 1500km south of Karachi. The environmental conditions, including a sea surface temperature of 30-31°C, low vertical wind shear, and upper-level divergence, are conducive for further intensification. The system is likely to progress into a Tropical Storm within the next 18 to 24 hours while moving in the north/northwest direction.

At present, none of the coastal areas in Pakistan are under threat from the cyclonic storm. The Pakistan Meteorological Department's cyclone warning center in Karachi is closely monitoring the system and will provide updates accordingly.

name: CRI: Insect invasion - 2023-06 - Dengue outbreak
summary:
According to the bulletin of the Pan American Health Organization / World Health Organization (PAHO / WHO) as of July 31 indicates that in the 2023, between EW 1 and EW 28, a total of 127,631 cases of dengue were reported, with a cumulative incidence rate in the subregion of 69.7 cases per 100,000 population. In this year, of the 127,631 cases of dengue reported, 10,861 (8.5%) were laboratory confirmed and 269 (0.21%) were classified as severe dengue, so a request is made to member countries to <span lang="ES">review and adjust their preparedness and response plans to make "mso-ansi-language: ES-CR;" > against outbreaks of dengue and other arboviruses, in order to prevent complications and deaths associated with these diseases.

 The four dengue virus serotypes (DENV1, DENV2, DENV3 and DENV4) are present in the Central American and Mexico subregion. In 2023, until EW 28, the simultaneous circulation of all of them has been detected in Costa Rica, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico; while in Panama, the serotypes DENV1, DENV2 and DENV3 circulate, and in Nicaragua the serotypes DENV1, DENV3 and DENV4 (PAHO/WHO).

In Costa Rica, the presence of the mosquito "Aedes aegypti" is increased during the rainy season, which is influencing the appearance of 15,417 cases of dengue in the last 6 weeks, according to data from the Health Situation Analysis of the Ministry of Health of Costa Rica, 2023.

The SN has been in contact with the Ministry of Health at the Central and Regional levels, who have requested support from the institution to address this issue.

name: ECU: Flood - 2023-06 - Inundaciones Esmeraldas
summary: Debido a las fuertes precipitaciones en los cantones de Esmeraldas, Atacames, Muisne y Quinindé, durante la tarde del 3 y madrugada del 4 de junio de 2023, se registró el desbordamiento de 7 ríos de la provincia, los que hasta el momento han provocado inundaciones que superan los 10 metros de altura en zonas urbanas, afectando a miles de viviendas y obligando a evacuar a más de 2500 familias. Así también, de acuerdo con datos de los servicios de respuesta, existen varios deslizamientos y socavamiento en vías de primer y segundo orden los que han dificultado el tránsito o evacuación de la población hacia otros sectores.

countries society-name: The South African Red Cross Society
name: ZAF: Other - 2023-06 - South Africa Cholera Outbreak
summary:
Recently there has been a cholera outbreak in Hammanskraal which was noticed from the 15th of May 2023 by health officials at local district health centre (Jubilee hospital) in Hammanskraal, north of Pretoria, according to the Gauteng Department of Health (GDoH). Significant rise of cases was witnessed from the 21st of May 2023 and unfortunately twenty-three (23) people have lost their lives since the cholera outbreak 77 patients were still admitted for the waterborne disease. It is worth noting that 29 patients have since recovered and were discharged,” the provincial department said. https://reliefweb.int/report/south-africa/cholera-death-toll-climbs-23-hammanskraal

In line with the above, the poor infrustructure in public centres like schools, day care centres, taxi ranks etc, pose a great threat for the spread due to limited infrustructure to promote good hygiene practices like handwashing. There is need for strengthened community engagement by intensifying Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) and ensure that communities are proactive to seek medical assistance when they notice symptoms related to cholera. Moreso, rumors, myths and perceptions need to be addressed through community feedback mechanism.

name: SEN: Civil Unrest - 2023-06 - Civil unrest in Senegal
DOM: Floods - 2023-06 - Affected by Vaguada in southern region of the country
summary:
En virtud de lo anterior, a las lluvias que han estado ocurriendo y lo establecido en el artículo 2 capítulo 1, de la

Ley 147-02, sobre Gestión de Riesgos, este Centro de Operaciones de Emergencias (COE), INCREMENTA EL

NIVEL DE ALERTA por posibles crecidas de ríos, arroyos y cañadas, así como inundaciones repentinas o

urbanas, para las siguientes Provincias:

ALERTA ROJA Cuando el fenómeno tiene una alta probabilidad de impactar una zona, presentando efectos que generan daños a las personas, los bienes, carreteras y a otras infraestructuras o al medio ambiente. (Azua, Independencia)

ALERTA AMARILLA Cuando la tendencia ascendente del desarrollo del evento implica situaciones inminentes de riesgo y situaciones severas de emergencia. (Elias Piña, San Juan, Bahoruco, Barahona, Pedernales, San Jose de Ocoa, San Cristobal, Peravia, Santo Domingo y Distrito Nacional)

ALERTA VERDE Aquella que se declara cuando las expectativas de un fenómeno permiten prever la ocurrencia de un evento de carácter peligroso para la población. Puede ser parcial o total. (Monte Plata, Monseñor Nouel, La Vega, Santiago, Santiago Rodriguez, Valverde, Puerto Plata, Monte Cristi, Dajabon)

name: NPL: Other - 2023-06 - Dengue prevention and control
summary: In Nepal, dengue is a rapidly emerging disease. Endemic across most provinces, dengue incidence has increased in recent years largely due to expansion of the vector Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, as well as the movement of people and the introduction of imported cases. All 4 dengue serotypes exist in Nepal, with DENV-1 and 2 historically contributing the highest burden (EDCD, 2019). The first case of dengue in Nepal was reported in 2004. Since then, dengue cases have been gradually reported in Nepal, with an outbreak in the year 2019 (n=17,992) reported from 68 districts and in 2022 (n=54,784) from all 77 districts. According to EDCD of MoHP, among the total of 54,000 cases, majority of dengue cases (n=28109) including 38 deaths happened between January to September 2022 coinciding with the peak rainy season in the country. This is indicative of exponential surge in dengue cases during July/ September considering the overall weather conditions and monsoon season which provides hibernating infected mosquitoes with an optimal environment for breeding. Until epidemiological week 17 (end of April 2023, EWARS report, EDCD), 600 dengue cases has already been diagnosed which is highly alarming as this is the very first time that dengue has occurred in the consecutive year in contrary to the usual cyclical pattern of dengue incidence in Nepal. In addition, dengue incidence started even during winter season and is steadily rising over the weeks. According to a mathematical modelling projection conducted by WHO (2022), the projection shows that cases are already exceeded the alert threshold since beginning of 2023 when compared to the reported dengue cases in EWARS, indicating early signs on outbreak in Nepal. On average, 20-30 cases of dengue have been found each week in different regions of Nepal. Since dengue is relatively new for Nepal, there is low level of knowledge and awareness among people. Even the priority for dengue prevention was less priority in the country until last year, Nepal government has been sincerely trying to address the emerging trend of dengue through joint planning and implementation from this year. Therefore, Nepal government, municipal authority to the national level, have requested NRCS for better coordination and collaboration in dengue prevention initiatives. Ongoing reported cases of COVID-19 and dengue infection has overarching effects on country’s health system with challenges to properly manage the cases. Furthermore, Dengue has disparate effect on different population strata. While pregnant and lactating women, children and elderly population are vulnerable to dengue, young adult population working outside (with low socio-economic status) have higher exposure risk to dengue infected vectors. Hence, the number of hospitalized cases will be increased in coming 3-4 months and hospital facilities will be overwhelmed. Likewise, the supply of blood (Platelets-rich Plasma-PRPs) will be the challenge to meet the demand. Because of all these factors the severity and mortality cases will be increased in the country. In addition, the urban design of major cities in Nepal lacks in infrastructural public health aspects along with challenging waste management system and poor sanitation facilities which provides vectors with optimal environment for breeding. People residing in slums, densely populated urban cities with poor sanitation facilities are at greater risk of being affected. Hence, exponential rise in dengue cases can not only overwhelm health systems but also affect the most vulnerable population with low socio-economic conditions.

name: RUS: Population Movement - 2023-06 - Belgorod region
summary: In some areas of the Belgorod region, shelling of border settlements became more frequent, therefore a centralized evacuation of the population was organized, and some people left dangerous areas on their own. The regional branch of the Russian Red Cross, in close cooperation with the Administration of the Belgorod region, provides assistance to all displaced persons, both those who are in the TAP and those who left the border areas independently.

countries society-name: The Red Cross Society of Bosnia and Herzegovina
name: BIH: Flood - 2023-05 - 30-05-2023
summary: Due to intense precipitation in a few previous days water level of rivers in the central, north, and eastern parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina is significantly increased, causing flood waves in over 16 municipalities in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Based on the information that Red Cross Society has gathered from the field, over 100 households were directly affected by the flood wave. The constant rise of the water level in these parts of Bosnia and Herzegovina presents a threat to a few thousand inhabitants in these areas. The sudden flood wave directly endangered the lives of almost ten households, and over 20 individuals had to be displaced from their homes. Following intense precipitation and flood waves, there are many landslides, while a significant part of road communication has been damaged. This course of action is especially hard for the population of the rural part of these areas, preventing their communication and aggravating the distribution of much-needed humanitarian aid for these populations.

name: ARG: Floods Quilmes 2023
summary:
Desde el día miércoles 24/5 la localidad de Quilmes se ve afectada por abundantes precipitaciones de lluvia (más de 100 mm en menos de 8 horas). En consecuencia, al día de la fecha varias zonas del Municipio se inundaron, generaron anegamientos de calles y desborde de arroyos.

En algunas zonas las calles inundadas afectaron a viviendas, principalmente en los barrios de mayor vulnerabilidad. A raíz de esto, la Defensa Civil local evacuó a aproximadamente 40 vecinos y vecinas en cuatro centros distribuidos por Quilmes durante el día 25 de mayo. Al día siguiente los niveles de los arroyos fueron bajando con el consecuente retorno de las personas a sus viviendas.

En estos momentos la filial local con apoyo de la Sede Central se encuentra en proceso de analizar las afectaciones correspondientes para acompañar a las familias en su vuelta a casa.

name: MYS: Other - 2023-05 - Squall line phenomenon
summary:
The Malaysian Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) predicts heavy rain and strong winds in the northern states of the peninsula and western Sabah as well as its waters on Wednesday until next May 31. MetMalaysia in a statement in their infosite informed that, based on analysis of weather models, it found that westerly winds in the country's region are expected to increase due to Typhoon Mawar

Additional information by Met Malaysia,  strong winds and rough seas are also expected to occur in the waters of the South China Sea, Phuket and North Malacca Straits starting from May 26 to June 1 2023

name: USA: Cyclone - 2023-05 - Super Typhoon Mawar
summary: Super Typhoon Mawar which strengthened into a Category 5 on Tuesday, May 23 is expected to make landfall in Guam. The cyclone is recorded as one of the strongest hitting in Western Pacific region, with estimated winds up to 230 kmph (143mph). American Red Cross has a strong volunteer base in Guam and is actively mobilizing personnel and volunteers to address livelihoods needs by preparing emergency relief supplies, positioning additional personnel, and supporting preparedness activities in shelters. Immediately after landfall, the teams will begin damage assessments and mobilize additional personnel and relief supplies as needed.

name: KEN: Population Movement - 2023-05 - Population Influx
summary:
Kitale Transit Centre and Kakuma Refugee Camp

According to UNHCR, the number of refugees in Kenya has continually increased over the past years, mainly due to the volatile political and security situations in several neighbouring countries. Recently, over 20,000 new arrivals have been registered with more than 10,000 recorded in the first quarter of 2023. The majority are mainly from South Sudan, with some citing drought, flooding, and food insecurity among their reasons for flight in addition to conflict and insecurity. In Kitale Transit Centre, an estimated 1,700 asylum seekers have been recorded as new arrivals with no refugee status. The centre is only able to hold 200 people resulting in over-stretching of the available planned resources where the asylum seekers are now hosted in Kitale Agriculture Society of Kenya (ASK grounds). As a result, the reception centres in both Kakuma camp and Kalobeyei settlement are holding more than their capacity, leading to congestion and posing serious health risks. There has been a discussion with the authority in Kenya as to whether register or take back those in transit and a decision has not yet been made since 23rd April hence resulting in the over-stretching of humanitarian needs in both Kakuma Refugee Camp, Kalobeyei and Kitale Transit Centre. 

Daadab Refugee Camp

Somalia continues to face the longest and the most severe drought in its recent history, due to the failure of five consecutive rainy seasons, with a sixth failed rainy season predicted. Reduced access to water and the ever-shrinking pasture have affected pastoralist and agrarian communities throughout the region, forcing them to leave their places of origin in search of water, food, pastures, or humanitarian assistance. More than 1.3 million Somalis have been displaced internally due to drought since 2022. According to the UNHCR-led Protection and Return Monitoring Network (PRMN), 234,000 displacements within Somalia were recorded in February 2023. Out of the total displacements during the reporting month, the majority, 62% were attributed to conflict/insecurity, 34% due to the drought, and 4% due to other reasons. The top five humanitarian needs of the displaced families were food (53%), followed by shelter (18%), and livelihood (12%).

Based on the arrival statistics in the first quarter of 2023, over 110,000 new arrivals have been recorded in the Dadaab Refugee camp. The three Dadaab camps do not have adequate space to host newly arrived refugees, forcing many to reside in makeshift shelters along the outskirts of the camps, where clean water and sanitation facilities are either grossly insufficient or non-existent.  Late last year, the Government of Kenya agreed to the reopening of the Ifo 2 site in Dadaab to host the new arrivals which was actioned in March 2023. The Government has also agreed to the proposed remodelling of this site into an integrated settlement similar to Kalobeyei, to provide humanitarian assistance sustainably to both the refugees and host communities.

Effects

There is a need to address the most urgent/lifesaving needs of the most vulnerable arriving population in Dadaab’s newly opened IFO2 camp (4,704 Households) and 10,700 asylum seekers in Kalobeyei Reception Centre for access to basic WASH facilities and adequate nutrition. These interventions will improve the health and well-being of the asylum seekers who have been forced to flee their homes due to conflict and/or drought. 

Needs

In its mandate to protect and provide humanitarian assistance and coordinate other partners, UNHCR continues to support through nutrition and health provision to the asylum seekers. However, given the skyrocketing arrivals in the camp and its localities, both asylum seekers and host communities are experiencing a myriad of needs that ought to be addressed amidst the ongoing crisis: 

  •  ·       Supply of Clean drinking water and extending sanitation and hygiene facilities to the outskirts of the camps.  

    ·       Provision of targeted protection services for the most vulnerable to ensure their needs are met.  

    ·       Malnourished children are being screened and admitted to stabilization centres.  

    ·       Plans are underway to boost assistance by providing additional basic relief items including dignity kits for women and girls.
