    ·       UNHCR is also working to assist host communities surrounding Dadaab by rehabilitating boreholes, providing generators for water pumps, and trucking in water.  

    ·       Together with health partners, setting up additional treatment centres to increase access to health care for new arrivals and to be prepared in the event more cholera cases are reported. 

    ·       More support is needed not only in Kenya but also in Uganda, South Sudan, Somalia and Ethiopia, where millions of people are facing dire humanitarian conditions as the rains continue to fail.

name: USA: Cyclone - 2023-05 - Super Typhoon Mawar
summary: More than a week after Typhoon Mawar hit Guam, many residents are still without power and water and it could be weeks before these systems are fully restored on the western Pacific islands. The American Red Cross is helping people with medical or disability needs, as well as emotional and spiritual support during these challenging times. More than 180 trained Red Cross disaster workers from all over the United States are on the islands working closely with officials, partners and community, and humanitarian agencies; distributing relief supplies (clean-up kits, tarps, coolers, flashlights and personal hygiene supplies), supporting feeding efforts in community-run shelters, and assessing residential damage to help and support people affected by this powerful storm. The American Red Cross has served approximately 2,400 households so far and are working with village mayors to begin hosting community distribution sites for impacted residents to find relief supplies, recovery assistance and information. The American Red Cross is also supporting feeding in the community-run shelters and has provided as many as 26,000 meals and snacks since the storm hit the islands. The Red Cross is supporting the military Emergency Family Assistance Center (EFAC) on Andersen Air Force Base and Navy Base Guam where families can receive disaster relief services and information.

name: CAF: Population movement from Sudan
summary: The populations coming from Sudan are currently arriving in Amdafock and are still located in the village, in a temporary site. According to information reported by the Birao RC committee, the number of refugees received as of 6 May is estimated to be 5,000, with approximately 1,000 returnees. These figures were updated on 8 May by OCHA with 9,700 people arriving in Am-Dafock since the beginning of the crisis. At least 10,000 refugees could arrive in CAR in the coming weeks and 15,000 returnees according to UN projections. Am Dafok is a village in the Vakaga prefecture. However, other entry points remain possible based on lessons learned from previous crises in the area. Notably, the border is the state of South Darfur. According to the 2003 census, Am Dafok has a population of about 3,500. Other villages on the border between the two countries are also expected to see an influx of people in the coming days due to the limited capacity of Am Dafok and the projected influx of up to 15,000 people in the coming days. Increased entry in Tchad bordering the North of Birao is also part of the possible parameter in the development of this crisis.

name: ESP: Fire - 2023-05 - Incendio Forestal en Pinofranqueado
summary:
De acuerdo con las últimas actualizaciones proporcionadas por medios de comunicación, autoridades locales y por personal de la Cruz Roja desplegado en terreno, el Incencio Forestal de Pinofranqueado ha arrasado más de 10.000 hectáreas. 4 localidades de la provincia de Cáceres han sido evacuadas (Ovejuela, Cadalso, Descargamaría y Robledillo de Gata) y hay otras 3 con alta probabilidad de evacuación (Castillo, Las Erias y Aldehuela). De momento 694 personas han sido evacuadas.

Situación según Copérnicus con esta imagen a falso color: https://twitter.com/CopernicusEU/status/1659814056335687681/photo/1

According to the latest updates provided by the media, local authorities and Red Cross personnel deployed in the field, the Pinofranqueado wildfire has burned more than 10,000 hectares. 4 localities in the province of Cáceres have been evacuated (Ovejuela, Cadalso, Descargamaría and Robledillo de Gata) and there are 3 others with a high probability of evacuation (Castillo, Las Erias and Aldehuela). At the moment 694 people have been evacuated.

Situation according to Copernicus with this false color image: https://twitter.com/CopernicusEU/status/1659814056335687681/photo/1

name: ITA: Flood - 2023-05 - Emilia Romagna Flood
summary:
After an initial warning, the first event occurred at the beginning of the month: harsh meteorological conditions have caused localised floods and land-slides, managed at local and regional level.

A second warning have been issued on May 14th, the national response had been ignited, according to the EWEA protocol in place, but after the 200 mm of rain which had already fallen in the first days of May, an out of scale event had occurred, with about 350 million cubic meters of water falling in the most affected area (800 km2 of territory), 100 municipalities involved, 23 rivers and watercourses flooded, another 13 which saw the alarm level exceeded, thousands of landslides (376 the main ones) between hills and mountains.

The emergency machine was already alerted, and was involved in several fronts; the European Civil Protection intervention system was activated, deploying high capacity pumping modules. The regional civil protection is intervening with 63 construction sites to make the rivers safe (e.g. some rivers, like Idice and Sillaro have changed course). 

15 people died, mainly due to a landslide, and about 23,067 people are sill evacuated. The majority 16,445, in the Ravenna area, then 4,462 in the province of Forlì-Cesena and 2,160 in the Bologna area.

There are 2,694 citizens welcomed in the hotels and in the structures set up by the Municipalities: schools, sports halls and gyms; the others have found alternative accommodations (second homes, friends and relatives). In particular, 2,094 in the Ravenna area, 351 in the Bologna area, 243 in the Forlì-Cesena area and 6 in the Rimini area.

countries society-name: The Sri Lanka Red Cross Society
name: Sri Lanka - Dengue Outbreak & Floods
GAB: Inondation - 2023-05 - inondations et vents violents  à Franceville
summary:
Selon les informations reçues du comité provinciale Croix-Rouge du Haut Ogooué,  les pluies diluviennes accompagnées des vents violents se sont abbatues  le lundi 15 mai 2023 sur la ville de Franceville et  ont causé des dégâts importants Ces dégâts  ont touché un grand nombre de ménages, ainsi que des infrastructures.

Ce Comité provincial de la CR Gabonaise est entrain d’évaluer la situation avec les volontaires On enregistre  environ 500 familles sinistrées avec près  de 200 maisons d'habitation directement touchées, sans oublier les commerces, les écoles et bâtiments administratifs. 

Certains sinistrés sont relogés chez les parents, amis et connaissance. Les autorités publiques sont  aussi descendus sur le terrain. Le 1er et le 3e arrondissement de la ville sont les plus touches et  la pluie continue de tomber sur Franceville.

countries society-name: The Red Cross Society of Bosnia and Herzegovina
name: BIH: Flood - 2023-05 - Floods 15-15-2023
summary: On Monday, May 15, 2023, floods swept through the northern part of Bosnia and Herzegovina, i.e. municipalities: Novi Grad, Prijedor, Kostajnica, Bihac, Bužim, Sanski Most, Cazin, Velika Kladuša, Kluč and Bosanska Krupa. In order to respond as effectively as possible to the dangers to life and health of the population, a state of natural disaster has been declared. The effects of the floods have endangered about 400 households, and the risk of flooding threatens about 10,000 inhabitants. The National Society works on constant analysis and monitoring of the situation and needs of the endangered population, and in the coming period, following the stated needs, the National Society will adapt its activities. By the announcements, the next period i.e.  May 18, there will be intense bouts of flooding. The National Society conducts a constant exchange of information with the Country Cluster Delegation to Central & South-Eastern Europe – Nemanja Zekić (Project manager).

name: SYR: Drought - 2023-05 - Syria Droughts 2023
summary:
After more than ten years of conflict in Syria, access to water has become one of the most prominent humanitarian challenges, which is exacerbated by climate change. According to severity scale updated in June 2023, all of Al-Sweida’s districts are ranked at levels 3 to 5, meaning they are facing a major, severe, or critical problem in water needs. The Al-Sweida governorate faced during this period a sharp decline in the water availability, the causes of which appear to be the intertwining of many factors: Loss of the main source of drinking water since 2012 the increase of the population between 2010 and 2022, increasing the demand on water and pressure on resources, and the decrease in the maintenance and technical level of logistical operating equipment. The level of the surface dams has decreased to a hazardous level and with some close to being completely dry.

 

The main reasons relate to the fact that rainfall has decreased significantly in recent years, additionally climate change has led to a lack of snowfall in large quantities which is the main source of dam water collection. Other reasons involve low electrical voltage because of the huge destruction of the infrastructures related to electrical supplies and lack of fuel and spare parts, which is the main cause of the malfunction of the pumps,
 in addition to the technical and logistical problems of the Water Corporation in Al-Sweida Governorate, which led to a large number of wells being out of service (around 80%). Moreover, Land irrigation, illegal extraction, and vandalism also helped exacerbate the water crisis in the governorate, with no capacity to replace or maintain due to the continue crises and sanctions among other clear effects of the climate changes and global warming. In June of 2023, reports confirmed through official channels that the water crisis in Al-Sweida governorate is severe, and that within two months, water will run out in surface dams. Not solving the problem of pumps in the wells will lead to the exit of more wells from the service, and thus exacerbate the water crisis that leads to a severe humanitarian disaster affecting 650,000 people. This will increase challenges and decrease resilience in these communities.

name: BGD: Cyclone - 2023-05 - Cyclone Mocha
summary:
Cyclone ‘Mocha’ was first noticed as a low-pressure area in the greater North Indian Ocean on 8 May 2023 by the Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), which gradually intensified and transformed into a very severe cyclonic storm. According to Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) it turned into a deep depression and on 11 May 2023 morning intensified into a cyclonic storm “Mocha” (pronunciation: Mokha) over the same area (ref. BMD bulletin number 1).

On 13 May 2023, BMD issued ‘great danger’ signal number 10 (ten) for one of the coastal districts Cox’s Bazar coastal district and their offshore islands and chars (char in Bangladesh refers to island in river, a piece of land surrounded by water). At the same time, BMD issued ‘great danger’ signal number 8 (eight) for Chattogram, Feni, Noakhali, Laksmipur, Chandpur, Barishal, Bhola, Patuakhali, Jhalakati, Pirojpur, Barguna districts and their offshore islands and chars (ref. BMD bulletin number 12).

According to the special weather bulletin number 17 of BMD on 14 May 2023, 2:00 am Bangladesh Standard Time (BST), the very severe cyclonic storm 'Mocha' over the east central Bay of Bengal and adjoining area moved in a North-Northeasterly direction, intensified over the same area and has centred about 490 km South-Southwest of Chattogram port, 410 km of South-west of Cox's Bazar port, 530 km South of Mongla port and 460 km south of Payra port of Bangladesh.

According to the Needs Assessment Working Group (NAWG), following the great danger signal and evacuation order of the Government of Bangladesh (GoB), over 750,000 people were evacuated to safety in Cox’s Bazar and other areas.

The cyclone Mocha made landfall in southeast Bangladesh and north Myanmar coasts around 3:00 pm BST on 14 May 2023 with a maximum sustained wind speed of 190-210 km/h gusting to 220 km/h and affected tens of thousands of families and homes and key facilities have been destroyed, especially in the camps settlement and neighbouring local communities.

During the landfall of cyclone Mocha, a strong surge with 6-7 feet tides across the coastal districts namely Cox’s Bazar, Chattogram, Noakhali, and Feni and with the storm and heavy rain destroyed a huge number of jhupri (shacks; made of jute sticks, tree leaves, jute sacks, etc.) and kutcha (temporary; made of mud brick, bamboo, sun-grass, wood and occasionally corrugated iron sheets as roofs) houses in Cox's Bazar, Bandarban, Chattogram, Rangamati districts.

name: Myanmar: Cyclone MOCHA 2023
summary:
On 14 May 2023 at 12:30 local time, Cyclone Mocha made landfall in Myanmar as an extremely severe cyclonic storm with winds gusting up to 230-250 km/h. Mocha crossed the interior near Sittwe in Rakhine State, and moved North-Eastwards to Hakha and Paletwa townships in Chin State, with wind speed of approximately 115 km/h.  By morning of 15 May, Mocha reached Sagaing region as a deep land depression with a wind speed 78 km/h.

Mocha caused storm surges in excess of two meters, strong winds and very heavy rainfall with heavy inundation reported in low-lying areas of Rakhine, particularly in and around the state capital Sittwe, and in Chin state, Magway, Ayeyarwaddy and Mandalay regions as well as lower Sagaing region. Houses,  sanitation facilities and public infrastructure were damaged or destroyed by the cyclone, including hospitals, transport infrastructure such as roads and airports, a water dam, and agricultural land and equipment was washed away. Based on available sources, at least 105,000 people were exposed to floods likely to have destructive impact on shelters and livelihoods.

On 15 May, the State Administration Council declared all 17 townships of Rakhine state as disaster affected areas under section 11 of the Natural Disaster Management Law, which recognizes the special role of the Myanmar Red Cross in disaster management.  On 16 May, a similar announcement was made for four townships in Chin State (Tiddim, Matupi, Paletwa and Hakha).

Early, local reports indicate several human casualties and hundreds of people injured, while over 137,000 people were evacuated prior to the landfall, based on Myanmar Red Cross reports from their branches. Monasteries, schools, and religious sites were designated as evacuation centers by local authorities in Rakhine, Chin, Magway and Sagaing. Communication services to Rakhine and main road access to Sittwe were cut and slowly being reestablished as of 16 May and Sittwe Airport remains closed as of 15 May. Efforts to identify impact and needs have started but there are challenges to access the affected areas, especially Northern Rakhine, Magway and Northern Sagaing; the safety and security of first responders will continue to be prioritized.

name: MYS: Heat Wave - 2023-05 - Heat Wave #3
summary:
The Meteorological Department (MetMalaysia) has issued a level one hot weather status for four areas in the peninsula and one in Sarawak. According to the latest hot weather data uploaded on the department’s Facebook today, the four areas in Peninsula Malaysia involved Baling in Kedah as well as Hulu Perak, Kinta, and Manjung in Perak. Meanwhile, the level one area in Sarawak is Mukah. “No areas in Sabah are at level one,” The alert level is when the maximum daily temperature is between 35 to 37 degrees Celsius for at least three days consecutively.

on April 27 last An 18-month-old girl in Kelantan was reported to have died on Tuesday, believed to be due to heat stroke, the second victim due to the hot weather in the state. According to a Berita Harian report, the child's father, Ahmad Faris Fazli Mohd Nasir said, he took his only child Nur Imani to the Emergency Unit of Raja Perempuan Zainab II Hospital last Monday after his son vomited. According to him, the autopsy report conducted at the hospital found that the cause of Nur Imani's death was due to heat stroke. Previously on April 25, an 11-year-old boy from Kampung Perupok in Bachok, Kelantan was reported to be the first victim of heat stroke when he reportedly died. The victim, Muhamad Syamil Aqil, is said to have died at 9.27 am while receiving treatment at a clinic.

 

Also on May 5, Utusan Malaysia reported that schools across the country had been told to stop all outdoor activities, including cross-country running, amid the heat wave. Education Minister Fadhlina Sidek said the ministry sent a circular informing all principals and school administrations about this decision.

Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Ahmad Zahid Hamidi said the secretariat of the National Disaster Management Committee has met and carried out coordination efforts with various relevant ministries and departments to help the people cope with this new phenomenon.

 

MRCS NHQ has coordinated with the MRCS of the states involved for the purpose of monitoring the effects of heat waves and identifying the appropriate form and type of response that will be channeled. At the same time, MRCS is arranging coordination with relevant government agencies at the national and state levels for appropriate response purposes.

name: PSE: Complex Emergency - 2023-05 - Opt-Complex Emergency -2023-05
summary:
Gaza :

 At 02:00 of Tuesday morning (9.5.2023), Israeli Occupation Forces launched a series of Air-strikes against civilian houses in Gaza and Rafah Governorates. According to the initial reports of the Palestinian Ministry of Health (MoH), the strikes resulted in 15  Palestinian martyrs, and 22  injuries, including women and children.

 

 Israeli air strikes continued for the hours later, with more than 50 strikes recorded against different locations. No additional casualties were recorded.

In the West Bank, particularly Nablus old city, an Israeli military operation took place between 07:30-09:30. PRCS dealt with 13 live ammunition cases, in addition to 3 rubber coated bullets injures and 135 gas injuries- 5 of them needed transportation hospitals (including 5 months old child), among other injuries. PRCS EMS teams faced Access challenges, as they were denied access to the area until the operation ended.

As well as in the 10th of May an Israeli military operation took place Jenin, PRCS dealt with 2 live ammunition cases and transported to Jenin Governmental hospital

name: ISR: Complex Emergency - 2023-05 - Rocket attack on cities in the south and center of Israel
summary:
Updated: May 13th, 20:00 (IDT)

On May 9th, 2023, in the morning hours, the Israeli authorities declared a state of emergency for the cities and villages 40 km from the Gaza Strip border. For the population in this area, restrictions on gathering, workplaces, and educational activities are in place. Several roads are closed for civilian movement. According to the Ministry of Defense reports, about 12,000 people who live near the border were evacuated to safer areas in Israel with the authorities support.

From May 10th to May 13th, two people were killed, several injured, and damages were caused to buildings, roads, and agricultural facilities in a series of rocket attacks from the Gaza Strip toward cities in the south and center of the country and cities near Jerusalem. Rockets hits were reported in Ashkelon, Sderot, Rechovot, Netivot, and other villages.

In Rechovot, one person died and several were moderately and lightly injured when a rocket hit a building on May 11th. In another rocket attack near Shokeda on May 13th, one person died and another was severely injured.  Several casualties suffer moderate and minor injuries from rockets and shrapnel hits, and when falling on their way to shelters during the attacks.

The state of emergency was extended until Monday (May 15th) at 20:00 (IDT).

In total, according to the Home Front Command (IDF) reports, more than 1,234 rockets were fired in these attacks. During and after the attacks, the population in the areas at higher risk is called to stay in or close to a shelter.

name: ETH: Population movement from Sudan
summary: On April 15, a conflict between the two main factions of the military regime in Sudan, the Sudanese Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), broke out in Khartoum, the nation’s capital. Since then, there have been clashes between SAF and RSF in different areas of the country. According to the Sudanese Ministry of Health (MoH) more than 450 deaths and more than 4,000 injuries have been recorded since the conflict started. However, the actual death toll is likely much higher, as current figures include only deaths reported to health facilities and access to many locations within the country is restricted. As of April 27, at least 18 humanitarian aid workers have been killed. Since mid April, the situation in bordering countries, include Ethiopia has severely deteriorated and are expected to get worst in the coming weeks. While other bordering cuntries started receiving population fleeing from Sudan, for the case of Ethiopia, there was no movement of populations until the temporary ceasefire of 24th April. The first case load was received in the border point of Metema where the National Society and ICRC conducted a rapid assessment mission complemented by the UNHCR report of 1st May 2023 reporting more than 8,900 people arrived in Ethiopia and 50,000 projected to arrived. (https://reliefweb.int/map/sudan/sudan-situation-overview-01-may-2023). With a temporary pause in fighting in some areas, both Sudanese and foreign nationals have been trying to flee the country to neighboring countries including Ethiopia. Ethiopia is sharing a 1,600 km border with Sudan with entry points in three regions: Tigray, Amhara and Benishangul-Gumuz. So far the majority of the people crossing into Ethiopia has been entering through Metema border post. According to UNCHR more than 73,000 Ethiopian refugees are living in Sudan, most of them having fled Ethiopia during the 2 year long Tigray conflict. It is anticipated that many of them will return to Ethiopia as the conflict in Sudan is unfolding.

name: MYS: Heat Wave - 2023-05 - Heat Wave
summary:
According to media reports (Utusan Malaysia) the current hot and dry weather has destroyed 7,800 acres of rice planted in Kelantan. The extremely hot weather not only stunted the plants but also affected the water sources. This will cause a loss of income and have an impact on food security in the state.

Local authorities through Kemubu Agricultural Development Authority (Kada) have handed over an additional 16 water pumps with a capacity of three to 20 cubic feet a second, to alleviate the situation. Kada will also supply farmers who are registered with the agency with the diesel fuel needed to run the water pumps.

 

In the meantime, MRCS is monitoring the situation and if the situation worsens MRCS will conduct a rapid assessment to see the appropriate response to help those affected especially in the livelihood sector.

name: MNG: Cold Wave - 2023-05 - Snow and dust storms
summary: Violent storms are sweeping across western Mongolia with heavy precipitation starting from May 5th to current period (May 8, 23). According to Khovd provincial emergency commission, the snow height has reached 80-120 cm in the mountanous areas, at least 40 cm in the steppe areas completely isolating (disabling the all means of transportation) Duut, Munkhkhairkhan , Zereg, Darvi soums. On May 7, a herder household was affected by the storm and 18 staff from local emergency managemnet agency worked for 18 hours to rescue the household members and took them to the hospital. Due to the isolation from the snow, about 350 households can no longer take their herd on pasture and their livestock are being exposed to cold and malnourishment. Eventually, the malnourishment and cold exposure are expected to be become issue for the herders themselves. In the affected population, there are about 72 disabled person, 480 children and 21 pregnant women.

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: COD: Flood - 2023-05 - Inondation Kalehe
summary:
Dans la nuit du 4 au 5 mai 2023, une pluie torencielle s'est abatue sur les villages de Bushushu et Nyamukubi dans le territoire de Kalehe dans la province du Sud-Kivu. Cela s'est poursuivi le 6 mai 2023 et a occasionné des inondations et des éboulements de terrain, causant environ 400 morts, plusieurs personnes disparues et des pertes en moyen de subsistance.

La Croix-Rouge de la RDC à travers sa Branche du Sud-Kivu a deployé une équipe sur le terrain pour des évaluations rapides et contribuer à l'assistances humanitaire aux personnes sinistrées.

name: GTM: Erupción volcánica - 2023-05 - Erupción Volcán de Fuego
summary:
La red de vigilancia volcánica del Instituto Nacional de Sismología, Vulcanología, Meteorología e Hidrología (INSIVUMEH) registra el descenso de flujos piroclásticos por la barranca Ceniza. Este presenta características débiles a moderadas, pero con probabilidad de incrementarse, provocando caída de ceniza en zonas cercanas.
Estos flujos son una mezcla de gases, ceniza y bloque de roca a alta temperatura que descienden a gran velocidad por los flancos del volcán. No se descarta que en las siguientes horas puedan generarse más flujos piroclásticos de características débiles, moderadas y fuertes con mayor alcance hacia otras direcciones.

name: GTM: Erupción volcánica - 2023-05 - Erupción Volcán Fuego
summary: Según el  BOLETÍN VULCANOLÓGICO ESPECIAL BEFGO #023-2023 ACTUALIZACIÓN DE LA ERUPCIÓN Guatemala, del 04 de mayo de 2023, 12:35 horas (Hora Local), en las últimas horas la actividad eruptiva continúa en un nivel alto, manteniendo una columna de gases y abundante ceniza a una altura de más de 6000 msnm (19,685 pies), la cual, de acuerdo a productos de imágenes satelitales GOES-16, sigue desplazándose hacia el oeste y suroeste a distancias de más de 100 kilómetros. La expulsión de esta columna eruptiva se acompaña de retumbos y ondas de choque moderadas y fuertes de forma constante, así como con el descenso de flujos piroclásticos moderados y fuertes que se desplazan entre 5 y 7 kilómetros de distancia a lo largo de las barrancas Ceniza, Las Lajas, Seca y Santa Teresa. En los últimos minutos ha descendido el flujo piroclástico más fuerte en la barranca Ceniza. Estos flujos piroclásticos siguen provocando la caída de ceniza de forma constante y abundante en las comunidades ubicadas en las cercanías de las barrancas por donde estos flujos continúan descendiendo. La dispersión de la columna eruptiva produce caídas de ceniza leves sobre varios municipios del departamento de Suchitepéquez.

name: RWA: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2023-05 - Heavy rains causing floods and landslides
summary:
The heavy rains registered within three consecutive days have caused intensive damages in various parts of country, particuolarly the Western province, Northern province and Southern province. The death toll is high, amounting to 130 people people dead; 77 were injured; 5 persons are missing. Overall, 7684 households were evacutated (with over 38,000 people) as a result of total destroyed houses or heavily damaged.

In addition, the people's livelihoods were affected: livestock dead, destroyed crops, food stocks and households were destroyed and merged with mud, the market supply system is particially functionnal due to damaged roads, market places and shops. 

As well, in different parts of the country, public infrastrure were affected: Damaged roads (8 National and 9 districts roads section, 26 bridges); 6 Water Treatment Plants flooded and not functional; 8 health facilities (2 health Posts, 5 health centers and 1 hospital (Shyira) were affected.

People are in heavy distress and required PSS. The burial services have strated as well as the medical care for injured people, while the surch of missing 5 people is ongoing. 

These numbers are likely to increase due to ongoing assessment together with local and security autorities and RRCS volunteers. As well, the meteo forcast predicts more intense rainfalls in coming days.

name: CHN: Earthquake - 2023-05 - M5.2 Earthquake in Baoshan, Yunnan Province
summary: A 5.2-magnitude earthquake hit the city of Baoshan in Southwest China's Yunnan province at 11:27 pm (Beijing Time) on May 2nd, 2023, according to the China Earthquake Networks Center (CENC). The epicenter was monitored at 25.35 degrees north latitude and 99.28 degrees east longitude, with a depth of 10 km. A magnitude 3.0 earthquake was registered at 3am on May 3rd, 2023. 3 people are reported to have been mildly injured in the earthquake. 2,805 houses are reported damaged in Longyang District. 37,941 people took emergency evacuation.

name: ISR: Complex Emergency - 2023-05 - Rocket attack on cities in the south of Israel
summary:
On May 2nd, 2023, since the morning hours, Israel faced a series of rocket attacks from the Gaza Strip toward cities in the south of the country, resulting in several casualties, damage to buildings and cars, and fires.

In the afternoon hours (IDT) on May 2nd, a rocket attack of 22 launches from Gaza was initiated toward cities in the south of Israel. Four people were injured, several others suffered stress related conditions, and damage was caused to buildings in Sderot and villages.

Later that day, at around 21:30 and during the night, more rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip, resulting in a series of rocket alarms in cities in the south of the country.

In total, according to the Home Front Command (IDF) reports, 104 rockets were fired in this attack. During and after the attacks, the population in the regions at higher risk is called to stay in or close to a shelter.

name: TZA: Food Insecurity - 2023-04 - LINDI FOOD INSECURITY
summary: According to the Government of Tanzania, Nachingwea district in Lindi region has recently faced a significant challenge of elephants invansion into farmsland and subsequent distruction of crops. A total of 14 out of 36 wards have been affected, and more than 730 households have been affected as well. This situation has resulted into severe food insecurity and nutrition, posing the threats to the well-being of the local communities. This also exacerbarates the human-elephants conflicts. The government through the District Administrative Secretary of Nachingwea district has requested for the urgent assistance to the affected households for food so as to meet their daily dietary needs.

name: RUS: Fire - 2023-04 - Wildfires
summary:
According to EMERCOM, since April 25, the most difficult situation has been developing in the Ural Federal District. In the Sverdlovsk, Kurgan and Tyumen regions, as a result of the spread of fire in 25 settlements, more than 6 thousand buildings were damaged, including 802 residential buildings. In order to stabilize the situation, more than 2,000 people and more than 300 units were involved in the localization and extinguishing of natural fires. equipment, including 21 aircraft. The main efforts of the EMERCOM of Russia are focused on the protection of settlements.

According to Russian Red Cross,  in Sverdlovsk region only a total of 659 people, including 148 children, lost their houses.

name: GTM: Inundación - 2023-04 - Inundaciones en Chiquimula
summary: En la Escuela Oficial Urbana para Niñas Juan Manuel Aguirre en Chiquimula, Chiquimula, ocurrió un colapso del techo, debido a las lluvias registradas en la región.

name: TZA: Epidemic - 2023-04 - DAR ES SALAAM CHOLERA OUTBREAK
summary:
Tanzania is currently experiencing one of the worst cholera outbreaks in years. The first case was registered in Ilala district in the Dar es salaam  region on 20 April 2023. The Tanzania Ministry of Health declared the cholera outbreak on 24 April 2023 after the increase and spread of confirmed cases. The cholera outbreak, initially limited to the eastern part of the country, has now spread from Kivule wards to Ilala and Buguruni wards in Dar es salaam region. 
There is also spread to neighboring Zambia, Mozambique, Malawi and Zimbabwe where outbreaks are being declared.

Tanzania Red Cross Society report that there is an urgent need to address the risk factors of the outbreak, such as the provision of safe drinking water, especially in the hotspot areas. Several displaced communities in areas that were affected in 2023 by the Floods Dar es salaam and Mtwara are still living in precarious hygienic conditions due to high rainfall still increasing and raining. The floods and associated malnutrition that has affected vast areas of Tanzania are making the communities, particularly children, more at risk of mortality due to the increased vulnerability caused by their poor nutritional status.

name: FSM: Cyclone - 2023-04 - Tropical Depression FSM
summary:
As April 20, 2023 a tropical storm watch remains in effect for Pohnpei, Sapwuafik and Pakin in Pohnpei State. Maximum sustain winds of 35 mph. Movement: West/Northwest 295 degree at 10mph

 

Communication and Power lines in some part of Pohnpei is damaged from falling tree. Community water that is not connected to the city water (PUC) was effected. Some part of roads in Pohnpei access is still a problem due to debris.

Water in the community is now limited for community water system.

Effected Population are with family and friends. Food supplies are still at a good level

Some HH with viper optic  cable have limited internet connection due to damage lines.

Assessment teams are deployed to all municipalities as National EOC was activated at 11:00 AM. Rescue team deployed for any search and rescue reports.

name: MNG: Other - 2023-04 - Snow and dust storm
summary: High winds are expected across the west to east across the country starting from the night of April 17 to April 19, 2023.  The wind speed is expected to be 24 meters per second to 34 meters per second. The highest level of disaster warning has been issued by the National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring (NAMEM) and joint press conference by NAMEM and National Emergency Management Agency have been held to disseminate the information at 15:00, April 17, 2023.

name: NPL: Heat Wave - 2023-04 - Heat wave preparedness and response
summary:
If temperature in these areas keep increasing over coming 3-4 days, the health condition of people will be deteriorated in the districts situated in southern belt of Nepal. Heatwave aggravated by forest fire, air pollutions and emergence of different infectious diseases can have disproportionate effects. 


In terms of heatwave, the most commonly children, elderly population, pregnant and lactating mothers, people with disability and daily wage labors/ people with low-income will have direct impact on their health, nutrition and living conditions. The extreme hot weather may have direct affect on health due to high incidence of dengue in approaching monsoon with overarching effects on overall health system. As a result cardiovascular effects to elderly population due to prolonged heatwaves including aggravated effects due to underlying health conditions may occur in these areas. Furthermore, extreme heat can increase the risk for preterm birth, low birth weight, fetal death, and infant mortality alongwith heat related injuries and illness among daily-wage workers due to exposure to prolonged heat.

name: TCD: Déplacement de population du Soudan pour le Tchad
summary:
A l’issu de l’attaque des villages de Tendulti du côté Soudanais, il y a eu un mouvement des populations soudanaises sur le territoire tchadien dans les villages de Koufroune, Madjiguilta et Dizé Birte. Entre 10,000 et 20,000 personnes se sont installé le long de la frontière, sous les arbres, avec parmi eux un grand nombre de femmes et d’enfants à risques. Les besoins prioritaires notés sont l’accès à l’eau, les abris, la nourriture, la santé et quelques bien non alimentaires. Les stocks de vivres des demandeurs d’asile vont s’épuiser dans 3 à 5 jours. Une dizaine de blessés graves de l’armée Soudanaise ont été enregistrés et hospitalisés à l’hôpital d’Adre. Il a été indiqué que 3 parmi ceux-ci sont décédés à l’hôpital à la suite de leurs blessures. Quelques autres blessés graves seront évacués vers l’hôpital provincial d’Abeche. Les autorités assurent la sécurité le long de la frontière et ont lancé un appel d’aide humanitaire pour assister les nouveaux arrivants.

La suite des conflits au Soudan pourrait voir s'aggraver la crise de déplacement observées coté Tchad. Les possibles temps d'accalmie résultant de l'appel à cessez le feu au Soudan seraient une occasion pour une ruée plus importante de déplacés vers les pays frontaliers les plus proches, le Tchad étant majoritairement concerné. Suivant les données historique et actuelle, la tendance ira à la hausse très certainement dans les semaines à venir.

name: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 - KYELA FLOODS
summary:
On the night 17 and 18 April 2023, the villages around the Kiwira, Mbaka and Lufilyo rivers at  Kyela District, Mbeya Region experienced severe floods as a result of heavy downpour from the ongoing monsoon rains. So far, this flood has affected a total of 3 wards, and 9 villages including; Lupaso, Kilwa, Buluma, Kabanga, Isaka, Ndwanga, Kisyosyo, Ntundumano and Lusungo. Approximately 945 households  and 4725 population have been misplaced after their houses being surrounded by water and 113 houses have been destroyed. addiitonally, number of assets have been destroyed, farms, livestock and infrastructures. More damage is anticipanted as it keeps on raining. This calls for immediate response from the government and the National Society.

The affected three wards host around 6000 households, that approximately 30,000 population. The main economic activity in these wards is agriculture,livestock keeping and Fishing. The cultivated crops are rice, maize, cassava, sweetpotatoes, groundnuts and Cocoa. Most of the agricultural areas washed away by floods. TRCS branch (Mbeya Red Cross regional team) aside of local authorities visited the affected villages on 18th April 2023 and issued initial assessment data to start guiding the first emergency assistance to the affected communities

name: EGY: Population Movement - 2023-04 - Sudan Crisis
summary:
• The situation continues to deteriorate with heavy fighting despite the announcement of a ceasefire for celebration of Eid and to enable evacuation of civilians and flow of humanitarian services.·
  • The death toll continues to rise, with at least 600 people killed and over 4,000 injured
  • 8 Million displaced individuals from Sudan
  • 300 children are trapped in a nursing home in Khartoum with 9 dead and over 50 severely injured
  • Widespread looting of supermarkets, stores, warehouses, including those of humanitarian agencies and SRCS. Lack of access to water and electricity is widely reported.
  • The Federal MoH said that 43 hospitals were destroyed out of the 130 hospitals , 125 of which are severely affected
  • 11 medical doctors have been killed some of the remaining are also affected and running out of essential drugs, oxygen, other medical supplies, and shortage of water and power supply.
  • As the situation in health facilities continues to deteriorate, SRCS and ICRC continue to negotiate safe passage for evacuating the injured, supply medicines, and manage dead bodies.
  • Th conflict has forced humanitarians to halt operations in multiple areas. WFP and IOM have officially suspended its operations due to the killing of staff members. Prior to the conflict, there were 11.7M of people in Sudan in need of humanitarian food & livelihood assistance (an increase of 2 million compared to 2022). With lifesaving food almost completely stopped, the consequences will be disastrous for families relying on this assistance
  • The conflict is dangerously approaching the borders with Chad, Central Africa Republic, South Sudan and Ethiopia, which can have consequences to sub-regional stability and population movement.
  • The conflict lead to increase the population movement towards the Egytpian-Sudanese borders including Egytpians, Sudanese, and other nationalitis. The National society in coordination with the authorities are providing the essentail humaniterian services for all population on the move. So far the Egytpian Red Crescent (ERC) has served above 1,253 individuals. The ERC will contiue providing the essential needed services, including health, PSS, communication, RFL, food, water, and hygient kits, through the Humaniterian Service Points at the affected areas. 
  • Chad, already hosting over 400,000 refugees from Sudan, may see an additional wave of displacement arriving from Darfur, which can put a strain in the capacity to provide lifesaving assistance. According to UNHCR, between 10,000 and 20,000 already fled to Chad

name: Sudan Crisis: Population Movement Neighbouring Countries
summary:
Due to the significant cross-border population movement out of Sudan as a result of the ongoing crisis, IFRC has launched an  Emergency Appeal intended to support humanitarian response plans and activities of the National Societies in neighbouring countries Egypt, Chad, South Sudan, Central African Republic (CAR), Ethiopia and Libya. It has been developed in close coordination with Movement Partners and it complements the Sudan Emergency Appeal.  

The ongoing conflict in Sudan has led to widespread displacement, with over 1,4 million people fleeing active conflict areas to find safety elsewhere in the country or across borders, primarily in Chad, Egypt and South Sudan, but also in Ethiopia, Central African Republic (CAR) and Libya. After more than one month of clashes, the situation in Sudan is still very volatile and as the fighting persists, the trend of displacement is likely to continue. The displaced population includes Sudanese refugees, returnees and foreign nationals, and there are significantly higher proportions of women, children, and older people, according to the latest reports.

 

People arriving in neighbouring countries have endured a very dire humanitarian situation in Sudan, with many having been caught in the crossfire or at border crossings for several weeks without sustained access to basic goods and services such as water, food and health, all while under tremendous psychological pressure. Many have endured harassment and extortion, and reports of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) are growing.

 

Over the border in destination countries, other challenges arise for refugees as well, such as how to protect their families and meet basic needs. And while host governments and communities have welcomed refugees and returnees, the dimensions of this crisis have still far exceeded the capacity of most host communities and local authorities. People are arriving physically and psychologically exhausted, sometimes severely injured, without food, water or shelter, and with no means to cover the cost of basic necessities. Many are anxious for news from their loved ones and urgently need to communicate with their families. This situation could last for several more days, weeks, or even longer, until a solution is found, while the risk of refugees adopting negative survival coping mechanisms increases by the day. Of particular concern are women, children, the elderly, people with disabilities and those in need of special attention. The poorest host families will face challenges to meet their own basic needs, which may lead to inter-community tensions. This situation will become more acute as  new refugees and returnees increase, as is expected.

 

Red Cross and Red Crescent National Societies in Egypt, Chad, South Sudan and CAR have been on the frontline since the beginning of this crisis, with support from the IFRC Disaster Response Emergency Fund (DREF). They have supported arrivals with vital services, from registration to first aid, to psychological support, to providing food and water, as well as Restoring Family Links (RFL). Some National Societies have also supported relocation to dignified accommodation and are now equipping these sites with basic services.

 

These National Societies, with the addition of Libya Red Crescent Society, are now planning a scale-up of their readiness and response capacities to be able to support current and projected new arrivals throughout destination countries including refugees, returnees and other nationals.

 

This Emergency Appeal will support the staff and volunteers of the National Societies in Egypt, Chad, South Sudan, Ethiopia, CAR and Libya in implementing their national response plans and will allow them to continue carrying out essential humanitarian work to support the most affected.

name: Sudan Crisis - Complex Emergency Sudan
summary:
In the early morning of Saturday, 15 April 2023, the sound of gunfire and an initial explosion was heard in Khartoum. This was the first time that the capital city of Sudan, home to 6 million people, was at the epicentre of conflict between the Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF). Clashes also broke out in other areas of the country and as at 2 May, the fighting has claimed at least 550 lives, and injured nearly 5,000 people. Hundreds of thousands of people have either been internally displaced within the country or fled to neighbouring countries (Chad, Egypt, Libya, South Sudan, Ethiopia, and Central African Republic). Families are prioritising the evacuation of women and children, who are exposed to heightened risks of sexual and gender-based violence. Millions of civilians caught in the crossfire have been in lockdown for nearly two weeks, and many have run out of basic supplies like food, water, and medicine. The conflict has also taken a significant toll on public infrastructure.

The destruction of hospitals and health facilities has left only 16% of these facilities operating regularly in Khartoum. The Sudan Red Crescent Society (SRCS) is supporting evacuations and reuniting families, providing first aid to the wounded, offering psychological support, supporting health  facilities and Restoring Family Links services across 15 locations in Sudan.

name: KEN: Complex Emergency - 2023-04 - Sudan Evacuation Operation in Kenya
summary:
An armed conflict between rival factions of the military government of Sudan began on 15th April 2023. The conflict started when clashes broke out across mostly the West side of Sudan, as well as in the capital city of Khartoum and Darfur Region.

Heavy gunfire and explosions have been witnessed in several parts of Khartoum and Darfur as Sudan Armed Forces (SAF) continue to engage the Rapid Support Forces, a paramilitary group, in what is being described as a ‘power struggle’ over who gets to run the country. Today (Monday, 22nd May 2023) marked the 39th day since the clashes began.

 

The Government of Kenya through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs have been evacuating its nationals, amongst them being students, workers, etc., through Ethiopia and South Sudan.

name: BDI: Flood - 2023-04 - Burundi: Flood Gatumba 2023
summary:
Suite à une forte pluie, la rivière Rusizi a fait un débordement qui a causé des inondations dans 5 collines de la Zone Gatumba. Ces inondations ont causé un déplacement de 679 Ménages provenant des collines Kinyinya I, Kinyinya II, Mushasha I et II ainsi que la colline Gaharawe. Ces ménages ont des maisons partiellement ou totalement detruites.

Actuellement, ces ménages sont dans des maisons de fortune et seulement 200 ont dejà bénéficié des tentes familiales, et des kits NFI de la part de la Croix Rouge du Burundi. Les nouveaux déplacés sont concentrés dans le Site Kinyinya2) et d’autres sont massés autour de la Route Gatumba-Frontière dans des conditions très défavorables.

 

Signalons que l’inondation continue à tel point qu’il y a des nouveaux ménages qui continuent à être affectés et par conséquent viennent augmenter le nombre des ménages déplacés.

name: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 - TANZANIA RUKWA FLOOD DISASTER
summary: According to the social media reports (Jamii Forum)and ITV on 12th April 2023 flood occured in Rukwa Region at Milepa Ward, Talanda Village,  that caused 7 deaths of people, including 6 chidren and 1 woman. The overflow of Talanda River has caused extensive flood water to the residential area that resulted to people dispacement, damage of houses and assets, infrastructure, crops and livestock, and public areas. The National Society local branch currently is assessing how to best support the most vulnerable households affected by the disaster in order to respond effectively to the entire situation.

countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Islamic Republic of Iran
name: IRN: Flood - 2023-04 - Farvardin Flash flood
summary: According to the report of the relief and rescue organization, heavy rainfall began on Wednesday in the provinces of Ilam, Kermanshah, North Khuzestan, South and West Lorestan, NorthWest part of Chaharmahal & Bakhtiari, South West of West Azerbaijan, West Kurdistan, and on Thursday in North and East Khuzestan, south of Lorestan, north and west of Chaharmahal &Bakhtiari continued. Heavy rain has caused the sudden rise of river water levels, flooding of canals and seasonal rivers, and widespread flooding of roads. 8 provinces include West and East Azerbaijan, Ilam, Kurdistan, Kermanshah, Gilan, Ghazvin, Lorestan, and 27 cities need relief and rescue services. 3people have died so far.

name: CHL: Movimiento de la población - 2023-04 - Crisis Migratoria Zona Norte de Chile
summary:
Desde hace ya unos años la ciudad de Iquique ha sido parte de la ruta migratoria de las personas que viajan principalmente desde Venezuela cruzando países como Colombia, Ecuador, Perú y Bolivia con destino Chile quienes hacen su ingreso a Chile por pasos no habilitados en la frontera norte en la localidad de Colchane misma que se encuentra en la línea fronteriza con Bolivia. 

 

Como última contingencia  las autoridades municipales de Colchane  el Gobierno Chileno recibió a cerca de 300 migrantes que se encontraban varados en la localidad de Pisiga Carpa en la comuna chilena de Colchane, los extranjeros de diversas nacionalidades fueron impedidos de cruzar desde Chile a Bolivia debido a su situación de migrantes irregulares.

 

Entre los cientos de migrantes varados hay niños y adultos mayores que padecían diversas afecciones debido a la altura (3.700 Metros sobre el nivel del Mar) y al intenso frío altiplánico. Gracias a las gestiones del municipio de Colchane con la delegación provincial se logró que pudieran ingresar al refugio de migrantes en el complejo fronterizo de Chile y Bolivia.

 

Los extranjeros de diversas nacionalidades fueron impedidos de cruzar desde Chile a Bolivia debido a su situación de migrantes. Sin embargo, debido a las gestiones entre el municipio con la delegación provincial, se logró que pudieran ingresar al refugio de migrantes en el Complejo Fronterizo de Chile y Bolivia.

 

La población de Colchane cuenta con un dispositivo transitorio donde anteriormente se prestaban servicios humanitarios por las distintas organizaciones, sin embargo, actualmente, debido a situaciones administrativas y de operaciones no se encuentra en su total funcionamiento, 

 

En la ciudad de Iquique de igual manera existe el dispositivo transitorio “Lobitos” el cual se encuentra a una distancia aproximada de 15 km desde Iquique, por ende, las personas que llegan a ese dispositivo tienen dificultades para trasladarse para realizar trámites o diligencias con las organizaciones que prestan asistencia humanitaria en la ciudad.

 

Durante Marzo el flujo migratorio en la ciudad se ha visto en aumento, por lo que en ocasiones llegan grupos de personas a la filial de Iquique directamente solicitando los servicios que anteriormente se prestaban con el proyecto de movilidad poblacional, a lo que se responde con lo que se cuenta en el momento, por ejemplo, agua, alimento o algunos artículos de higiene, apoyo psicosocial y RCF.

 

Por otro lado, debido a los hechos de violencia que se han visto los últimos meses en las regiones, se ha puesto un enfasis en fiscalizar a las personas extranjeras en situación irregular y  ser denunciados a las autoridades administrativas.

 

En la Ciudad  de Arica, específicamente en la Frontera Arica - Tacna  existen 150 personas (durante la semana del 20 de abril, población que iría en aumento) que no pueden  ingresar a  Perú, estableciéndose  en la línea de la Concordia e impidiendo el paso al control Fronterizo Santa Rosa (Perú) donde se realiza el proceso de documentación para la salida de Chile y el ingreso a Perú.
 
Estas personas son principalmente de nacionalidad venezolana y haitiana quienes llegan a la ciudad por bus o por avión, para luego desplazarse a pie hasta la frontera.

name: ECU: Landslide - 2023-04 - Macro deslizamiento parroquia Huigra
summary:
Antecedente

El 11 de junio del 2018, en la zona Namza Chico y Pasan, de la parroquia Huigra, del cantón Alausí, la Secretaría de Gestión de Riesgos realizó un análisis técnico, en el cual se informa que, debido a la litología y a la sobre saturación del material se ha registrado un incremento en el número y tamaño de grietas. Con este antecedente, y basados en las emergencias de Alausí y Chunchi por movimientos en masa, el 20 de mayo de 2022, la SGR declaró el estado de alerta amarilla, mediante resolución SNGE-118-20222 

Actualidad

La Secretaría de Gestión de Riesgos ha realizado el monitoreo permanente para evaluar posibles cambios de escenario ante la presencia de lluvias y el incremento de grietas en la zona, ante esto, el 9 de abril de 2023 se presenta un informe técnico elaborado por la Dirección de Análisis de Riesgos de la SGR en el que se establecen una serie de recomendaciones, mismas que han sido acogidas y se plasman en la RESOLUCIÓN Nro. SGR-106-2023 del 09 de abril de 2023:

• “DECLARAR el estado de ALERTA NARANJA por movimientos en masa al área de 152,22 hectáreas que comprende los sectores: Namza Chico, Pasan, Quebrada La Ninfa, UE Eloy Alfaro y Puente Chachán, de la parroquia Huigra, cantón Alausí, provincia de Chimborazo.

• DISPONER a los Comités de Operaciones de Emergencia -cantonal y provincial - del cantón Alausí, provincia de Chimborazo, presididos por el alcalde y Gobernador respectivamente; así como al Prefecto de la provincia en mención, se mantengan en estado de alerta y operativos, para activar las Mesas Técnicas de Trabajo y Grupos de Trabajo que correspondan.

• DISPONER a todas las instituciones que integran el Sistema Nacional Descentralizado de Gestión de Riesgos, de acuerdo con sus competencias, ejecutar las acciones necesarias e indispensables de conformidad con el Manual del Comité de Operaciones de Emergencias, en el nivel de Alerta Naranja.”

name: MNG: Fire - 2023-04 - Wildfire
summary: According to the State Emergency Commission, wildfire started in Erdenetsagaan county of Sukhbaatar province in Mongolia on April 8th has currently (as of April 12) spread in Khalkhgol, Gurvanzagal, Choibalsan, Matad soums in Dornod province. The intensifying factors of the wildfires include the strong wind (12 - 19 sec/m) and geographical character (both Sukhbaatar and Dornod are eastern provinces which are mainly grasslands). Team of 250 people including local state staff (additional forces joined from neighboring provinces which are Khentii and Sukhbaatar provinces) and community members headed by the Provincial emergency management agency worked on-site to distinguish the fire, latter, the team was strengthened by the National Rescue Brigade experts. It's currently impossible to estimate the loss of natural resources, livestock, human assets and will take more time. Known losses include the 15 households who lost their gers/houses. The State emergency commission is to allocate gers for those households. Wildfire smoke is creating a highly disturbing situation in the affected soums.

name: ISR: Complex Emergency - 2023-04 - Rocket attack on cities in Israel and escalation in tensions
summary:
Since April 5th, 2023, Israel has faced a series of rocket attacks from the Gaza Strip and south Lebanon toward cities, resulting in several casualties, damage to buildings, and fires. The attacks were initiated before Passover Evening and continued throughout the holiday.

On April 5, 2023, at night and early morning hours (IDT) a rocket attack of 18 launches from Gaza was initiated toward cities in the south of Israel. Two people were lightly injured and damage was caused to a factory in Sderot.

On April 6, Passover, at around 05:30, 7 rockets were fired from the Gaza Strip, resulting in a series of rocket alarms in cities in the south of the country. At 14:30 a rocket attack was initiated from south Lebanon towards cities in the Western Galilee region in the north of the country. 34 rockets were fired in the largest attack from Lebanon since 2006, causing damage to buildings and fires. Four people were lightly injured in this attack. At 19:30, another attack of 2 rockets was launched toward Metula from south Lebanon. Damage was caused to buildings and cars.

On April 7 at night, 44 rockets were fired in a series of attacks from the Gaza Strip, resulting in rocket alarms in Ashkelon and in cities in the south of the country along the border. Damage was caused to a house in Sderot.

During and after the attacks, the population in the regions at higher risk is called to stay in or close to a shelter.

name: TZA: Flood - 2023-04 -  Mtwara
summary: On the night of 1st April 2023, the villages around the Ruvuma River experienced severe floods as a result of heavy downpours from the ongoing monsoon rains. So far, this flood has affected the village of Kivava, especially in the suburbs of Sokoni and Kivukuni, villages of Angazo, and Kilamboma, and making 1,400 people displaced, representing 395 households affected in the suburbs of the market and the port. These 1,400 displaced people have been moved to temporary shelters in primary schools that are elevated due to their houses being surrounded by water. In addition, about 60 houses have collapsed with more than 100 toilets having collapsed and fields having been destroyed by water. The road from the village of Angazo to the village of Kilambo has been damaged, thus causing a lack of transportation and communication between those areas. Kivava village is one of the 110 villages in the district council. This village has 4 neighborhoods which are sokoni, kivukoni, dinanji, and lilumbi, the number of residents in this village is 1,976 and there are 518 households. The main economic activity in the village is agriculture and food business. The cultivated crops are rice, sorghum, cassava, cashews, coconuts, and legumes. Most of the agricultural areas were washed away by floods. TRCS branch (Mtwara Red Cross regional team) aside from local authorities visited the affected villages on 5th April and issued initial assessment data to start guiding the first emergency assistance to the affected communities Page 3 / 20 through local actions. TRCS branch, further to this assessment provided first distributions and helped the local authorities in the initial food distribution.

name: COL: Erupción volcánica - 2023-03 - Cambio Nivel de Actividad Volcán Nevado del Ruíz
summary:
Desde el Servicio Geológico Colombiano se monitorea permanentemente la actividad volcánica del país con el fin de identificar cuándo un volcán pueda hacer una erupción. Con base en los últimos registros, que indican un incremento en la sismicidad en el volcán Nevado del Ruiz, y en que el 29 de marzo se registró el mayor número de sismos diarios registrados desde que se inició el monitoreo sísmico de este volcán en 1985, el SGC elevó el nivel de actividad de este volcán de tal forma que se puedan tomar las acciones preventivas necesarias de manera oportuna.
En este caso, el nivel naranja o (II) equivale a que, dados los cambios registrados en la actividad del volcán, existe la probabilidad de que en días o semanas el volcán Nevado del Ruiz haga una erupción mayor a las que ha hecho en la última década. Vale la pena recordar que este volcán está en un proceso eruptivo desde hace aproximadamente 10 años, pero todos los eventos eruptivos que han ocurrido en este periodo han sido menores y, en la mayoría de los casos, su afectación se ha limitado a las áreas alrededor del volcán dependiendo de la dirección del viento. Por eso, es posible que este fenómeno volcánico siga presentándose sin implicar un riesgo mayor.

name: BLR: Flood - 2023-03 - Belarus floods response 2023
summary:
In connection with the emerging hydrometeorological situation on the territory of Belarus the flooding areas are being identified on a daily basis according to the data on the maximum water levels of the spring floods provided by the State Institution "Republican Center for Hydrometeorology, Radioactive Pollution Control and Environmental Monitoring" (Belgidromet), the Ministry of Emergencies of the Republic of Belarus as well as monitoring data of the Belarus Red Cross. 

As of 29-31.03.2023 floods are registered in at least 26 districts of Vitebsk, Gomel, Minsk and Mogilev regions. If the hydrological situation gets worse, new flooding sites are expected in 21 districts of Vitebsk, Gomel, Grodno, Minsk and Mogilev regions.

 

The situation is most rapidly worsening in Vitebsk region. The development of the spring flood continues on the rivers of the Western Dvina basin. Within the current day the level on the main river has increased by 24-62 cm. In the area of Gorodok,  Verkhnedvinsk, Miory, Polotsk there over water level, which begins to flood the village. Less than one meter to dangerous level value remains in Polotsk. On the tributaries the intensity of growth does not exceed 43 cm, in some rivers the level began to decline, which, may again be replaced by the rise due to rainfall.

The water temperature is between 0.1-5.6 oC.

In the coming days the water level on the Western Dvina will continue to rise, the course of water levels on the tributaries will be affected by rainfall. The dangerously high level on the Western Dvina near Verhnedvinsk and the possibility of rising to dangerous levels near Polotsk remains in the coming days.

name: ECU: Landslides
summary:
Antecedente

 

El 17 de febrero se emitió la resolución Nro. SGR-039-2023, donde se dispuso declarar el estado de ALERTA AMARILLA al polígono identificado como susceptible a movimientos en masa en las comunidades Aypug, Casual y los barrios: La Esperanza, Control Norte, Nueva Alausí, Pircapamba y Bua; el mismo que comprende un área de aproximadamente 247 hectáreas.

 

Actualidad

 

El 26 de marzo a las 21:00, se registró un deslizamiento de grandes proporciones, en el sector el Causal, cantón Alausí, ocasionando el cierre total de la vía Riobamba - Cuenca, personas atrapadas y viviendas destruidas en su totalidad.

 

El presidente de la República Guillermo Lasso dispuso la activación inmediata de la Secretaría de Riesgos y de todas las carteras del Estado. Ante la emergencia se activaron los planes de contingencia y equipos especializados de respuesta como: personal de la Secretaría de Gestión de Riesgos, Gobierno Autónomo Descentralizado, Cuerpo de Bomberos de Guamote, Chunchi, Riobamba, Cañar, Quito, Policía Nacional, Fuerzas Armadas Cruz Roja Ecuatoriana y equipo USAR de Cuenca.

 

Hasta el momento se reportan un aproximado de 60 familias afectadas por el colapso de viviendas, 20 personas heridas transportadas por ambulancia de Ministerio de Salud Pública al Hospital Básico de Alausí. Hasta el envío del presente resumen no se registran Personas fallecidas

name: BOL: Flood - 2023-03 - Inundaciones Pando 2023
summary: Actualmente el Departamento de Pando se encuentra en Alerta Roja por Inundaciones, pues se tiene el pronostico de incremento y desborde del Rio Acre, así como el incremento de rios procedentes de Brasil (rio Asis) lo que afectaria negativamente a varias comunidades aledañas a los mismos rios, a la fecha se evidencian al menos 350 personas afectadas, varias de ellas evacuadas de manera preventiva y algunas que dejaron sus viviendas por las inundaciones, mismas familias que fueron dispuestas en instalaciones provisionales.

name: KEN: Flood - 2023-03 - Floods
summary: The March April May season started this year with heavier than usual rains bringing floods, flash floods across the northern and southern parts of the country. At least 12 people have lost their lives and hundreds have been displaced from their homes in Kenya after intense flooding affected several counties over the week from 22 to 27 March 2023. Significant impacts of the floods began to be reported on 23 March and continued up to 27 March. On 27th March it was reported bad weather including strong winds and heavy rains caused damage in some Western counties (North Western and South Western), mainly in Narok, Kajiado, and West Pokot Counties. From data collected as of 27 March, at least 36,432 people are currently affected across 19 counties are already affected most being in the Western part of the country (North Western and South Western). This include Kisumu, Nyamira, Kisii, Kakamega, Narok, Turkana, Isiolo, West Pokot, Elgeyo Marakwet, Marsabit, Samburu, Mandera, Wajir, Kiambu, Siaya, Bungoma and Nairobi. Some counties have reported massive destruction of roads, houses, infrastructures, and crops and deaths have been reported due to the floods. Landslides are also feared across the Rift Valley region, where massive environmental degradation has happened due to rampant tree felling. Forecasts have warned of further heavy rainfall up to mid/late April 2023 as per the forecast from Kenya Meteorological Department. Page 2 / 21 Some of the counties affected are also affected by existing cholera outbreaks and food insecurity due to a multi-year ongoing overall drought situation.

name: MNG: Cold Wave - 2023-03 - Snow and dust storm
summary: According to the National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring, northern side of Bayankhongor, Uvukhangai, eastern parts of Arkhangai and through Bulgan, Selenge, Tuv provinces are experiencing heavy snow storms meawhile in the Gobi region, Dundgovi, Umnugovi, Dornogovi provinces are experiencing severe dust storms, the wind speed is at 15-27 meter per second.

name: PAK: Earthquake - 2023-03 - Pakistan EQ March,2023
summary:
A magnitude 6.8 earthquake with 180 Km depth, rattled much of Pakistan and Afghanistan on Tuesday, sending panicked residents fleeing from homes and offices and frightening people in remote villages. At least nine people died & 47 injured with 19 x partially collapsed houses mainly in few districts of Khyber PakhtonKhawah Province of Pakistan.

The situation was closely monitored by the control rooms of District Disaster Managment Authorties & Provincial DMAs to gather information. However, no such damage report is reported in any other province.

name: AFG: Earthquake - 2023-03 - Badakshan EQ
summary:
An earthquake with Magnitude of 6.5 on the richter scale and the epicentre was at a depth of 180Km in Hindu Kush region of Afghanistan , Jurum is the capital of Badakshan , one of the 28 districts of the province in north east Afghanistan . the district is 3 hours from the center of the province in Fayzabad and is home to approximately 41,910 residents .Casulaties reported both  in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

Based on the initial collected from EOC of Afghanistan Red Crescent from different branches and regions shows that at least 133 houses were damaged ,two people were killed ,and 29 were injured..Affected locations is laghman,kunar ,Nooristan ,Nangarhar ,Samanagan , Kapisa,Bamian,Takhr . NFI items were distributed on  a small scale in Samanagan branch so far. BDRT teams are deployed for assesment in almost all the affected branches and we are waiting consolidated information from ARCS EOC

name: ECU: Terremoto - 2023-03 - Sismo Guayas
summary:
El 18 de marzo de 2023 a las 12h12, el Instituto Geofísico de la Escuela Politécnica Nacional IGEPN emitió el reporte de un sismo de Magnitud: 6.5, profundidad: 44 km, a 29.12 km de Balao, Guayas, se han registrado 2 réplicas de 4.8 y 3.7 de magnitud.

De acuerdo con el informe emitido por la Unidad de Riesgos Ecuador el sismo fue sentido en 13 provincias, 160 cantones, con intensidad de leve a moderado. En base al análisis realizado por el Instituto Oceanográfico de la Armada, se descarta alerta de tsunami para la costa continental y región insular.

Las Direcciones Distritales de Educaciones se encuentran activadas para realizar las evaluaciones correspondientes en las Unidades Educativas. Los aeropuertos a nivel nacional se encuentran operativos.

name: ECU: Inundación - 2023-03 - Inundaciones Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas
summary:
De acuerdo con su ubicación geográfica la provincia de Santo Domingo de los Tsáchilas se encuentra expuesto a los principales eventos como, movimientos en masa e inundaciones.

Las fuertes lluvias registradas en la madrugada del 18 de marzo de 2023, provocaron el aumento del caudal y desbordamiento de dos ríos Cristal y Blanco ocasionando varias afectaciones en la zona urbana y rural.

Se detallan los daños ocasionados por la temporada:

Cantón Santo Domingo

·         Afectación parcial al ingreso del puente de uso vehicular y peatonal a la parroquia Valle Hermoso, esta tiene una población de 12.000 habitantes (Censo 2010), es importante indicar que se encuentra rodeada por los ríos Blanco y Cristal.

 

·         Inundación en la Parroquia Valle Hermoso

 

ü  Centro de Salud afectado

ü  Unidad de Policía Comunitaria UPC

ü  14 familias evacuadas (51 personas), albergadas en “Casa de retiro”

·         Colapso total de la estructura del puente de la vía Calacalí – La Independencia km 166, que conecta las provincias de Pichincha, Esmeraldas y Santo Domingo.

 

El Gobierno Autónomo Descentralizado en trabajo conjunto con personal de Cuerpo de Bomberos de Santo Domingo y Cruz Roja Ecuatoriana realizaron la evacuación de 30 familias hacia un albergue temporal, el Servicio Nacional de Gestión de Riesgos coordinó con Fuerzas Armadas el resguardo de la población afectada.

Cantón la Concordia

·         La corriente del río Blanco que aumentó su caudal debido a las lluvias, provocó el daño de la línea de abastecimiento de agua potable en el sector del Camal. Hasta la emisión del presente resumen, el total de la población no cuenta con líquido vital.

 

·         La crecida del río Blanco afectó a uno de los sitios turísticos del cantón, causando la pérdida de la tarabita que comunica al sector La Tarabita y Flor del Valle dejando incomunicados a 50 familias.

name: CMR: Inondation - 2023-03 - inondations FAKO
summary:
Dans la journée du 18 mars 2023, la ville de Buea située dans la Région du Sud-Ouest du pays,  a connu une forte pluie qui a provoqué des inondations du fait des eaux de ruissellement provenant du mont Cameroun . Le quartier le plus touché est Soppo Market. Le ruissellement de ces eaux a causé plusieurs dégâts dont la destruction d'habitations situées au pied du mont, la destruction de marchandises dans les boutiques du marché, des blessés et  des décès.

il convient de relever que naturellement la ville de Buea est située dans une plaine et dont très exposée aux inondations en cas de fortes précipitations régulières. Cette situation a été exacerbée lla crise socio-politique qui perdure dans cette Région du Pays a occasionné un fort exode rural des villages moins sécures vers les centres urbains (Buea, Limbe et Tiko...) Les populations vulnérables ont batit leurs habitations sur les marécages fermant ainsi le passage aux eaux de ruissellement. ce qui est de nature à favoriser les inondations et les maladies.

Le rapport de la salle de veille du continent du  Système Africain Multirisque d'Alerte et d'Action Précoce pour la RRC du 10 Mars classait déjà le Cameroun à une alerte de niveau 2.

Selon l'observatoire Nationale, la décade allant du 11 au 20 Mars sera marquée par par de fortes pluies accompagnées de vents violents avec un risque d'inondations notamment dans certaines agglomérations des Régions du Littoral (Douala et Nkongsamba), de l'Ouest, du Nord-Ouest et du Sud Ouest (Buea, Limbe et Tiko). 

Les pluies vont continuer de tomber car ce n'est que le début de la saison des pluies qui ira jusqu'à la fin du mois d'Avril. Le risque que la situation s'aggrave et progresse vers d'autres quartiers et villages est très élévé.

le Comité Départemental du Fako a effectué une descente sur le terrain hier 18 Mars pour appuyer l'évacuation des personnes habitant les maisons effondrées notamment les habitants de l'Eglise Presbytérienne et certains autres habitants qui ont provisoirement trouvé refuge dans les familles amies. les évaluations continuent pour voir comment venir en aide à la population sinistrée.

name: ECU: Inundación - 2023-03 - Inundación Santo Domingo
summary:
En horas de la madrugada el 18 de marzo 2023, a consecuencia de las intensas lluvias, el Río Blanco y Cristal, presentaron un aumento en su caudal, procediendo a desbordarse, causando graves afectaciones en viviendas y familias que habitan en las cercanías a la orilla de los ríos, además, ocasionó el daño estructural del puente de uso vehicular y peatonal, que permite el ingreso a la parroquia de Valle Hermoso. Se procedió a la activación de equipos de respuesta de las siguientes instituciones: Cuerpo de Bomberos, Cruz Roja Ecuatoriana, personal del Gobierno Autónomo Descentralizado (GAD), Fuerzas Armadas (FF.AA.), Policía Nacional y de la Secretaría de Gestión de Riesgos (SGR).  

La Secretaría de Gestión de Riesgos (SGR), habilitó un alojamiento temporal para las familias damnificadas, localizado en la parroquia Valle Hermoso en la Casa de Retiro, al momento se encuentran alojadas 2 familias un total de 8 personas. Continúa inhabilitado el acceso vial que conecta al Recinto Nueva Esperanza (Colonia Velasco Ibarra) afectando aproximadamente 200 familias, de la misma manera la vía Calacalí La 020 Independencia en el Km 166 (colapso del puente), que conecta las provincias de Pichincha y Esmeraldas se mantiene cerrada. Rutas Alternas ▪ Vía Alóag – Santo Domingo – La Concordia – La Independencia ▪ Puerto Quito – La Sexta – Quinindé ▪ Calacalí – Los Bancos – La Mercedes – Santo Domingo Continua el desabastecimiento de agua potable en el cantón La Concordia, afectando a 45000 personas. debido al colapso de las tuberías de conducción de agua potable, el Cuerpo de Bombero del cantón con apoyo del personal voluntario de Cruz Roja Ecuatoriana, realizan la distribución de agua segura, a través de tanqueros que pertenecen a la empresa municipal de agua potable. En reunión mantenida el 19 de marzo, el COE Cantonal la Concordia, resuelven solicitar el apoyo de Cruz Roja Ecuatoriana, para efectuar la limpieza y rehabilitación de pozos profundos (3 pozos) con el objetivo de activar la distribución de agua por la red pública.

name: TZA: Population Movement - 2023-03 - ASYLUM SEEKER
summary: According to the government and Tanzania Red Cross Society reported the mass population movement from CONGO DRC to Tanzania at Kigoma region in Nyarugusu refugee  Camp (ASYLUM SEEKER), the movement started from 10th to 15th March 2023 and the total number is 762, all these needed settlement, social services and human needs

name: TZA: Epidemic - 2023-03 - MARBURG VIRUS DISEASE
summary:
On 16 March 2023, the Minister of Health Ummy Mwalimu announced that 7 cases and 5 deaths from an unknown disease had been reported in the Kagera Region. Samples taken on 16 March 2023 were confirmed to be Marburg Virus Disease on 21 March 2023 and the Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania officially declared an outbreak. This is the first Marburg Virus Disease outbreak reported in the country. 

As of 19 April 2023, there are 9 total cases: 8 are confirmed and 1 is probable. There have been 6 fatalities and 3 cases in treatment. In total, 212 contacts have been identified and only 3 remain in isolation on follow-up.

TRCS has been working alongside other partners to support the Ministry of Health of the United Republic of Tanzania in their response to this outbreak. TRCS is directly supporting Risk Communications and Community Engagement (RCCE) and Community Based Surveillance, including at various points of entry both domestic and international. In conjunction with UNICEF, TRCS has also supported WASH activities. In addition to actively responding, TRCS is also building capacity throughout the Kagera Region via trainings and volunteer engagement.

name: YEM: Flood - 2023-03 - Heavy rains and floods in Yemen
summary:
Heavy seasonal rainfall since mid-March has caused flooding in many of Yemen’s governorates, affecting more than 18,000 families.

Floods have devastating effects on people. They cause loss of life, displacement, and damage to property and infrastructure. In Yemen, floods have caused severe damage to homes and infrastructure, including roads and bridges.

The heaviest downpours have damaged IDP shelters, crops, roads, and buildings in the governorates of Al-Jawf, Marib, Sayun, Hajjah, Amran, Marib, Shabwah, Lahj, Al-Bayda, Al-Mahwit, Taiz and Al-Mahra, leaving 31 people dead and more than 37 injured, nearly 1,000 buildings have at least partially collapsed.

In the March update, the OCHA in Yemen Said that “numerous governorates experienced heavy rains and wind, causing various degrees of shelter damage, destroying some homes. Based on the Information Management and Assessment Working Group’s (IMAWG) risk analysis, around 603,000 people in 112 districts are at high risk of floods this year. To date, 16,435 families have been affected. Out of the top 3 affected governorates, Marib has been the worst impacted, with 7,972 families affected, followed by Hajjah (2,228 families), and Amran (1,454 families). Yemen is prone to recurrent seasonal flooding which results in displacement, disruption to livelihoods, a spike in water-borne diseases, loss of crops, and property damage. In 2022, climate-related events triggered a 93 percent increase in new and secondary displacements, concentrated in Al-Hodeidah, Al-Jawf, Marib, and Ta’iz governorates. Torrential rains and flooding alone affected over 517,000 people and displaced over 170,000 people.”

The Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations reported 30 homes damaged in Salh district in Taiz governorate.

•          Areas in southern, central, and western Yemen have been affected by torrential rainfall in early April, causing floods and resulting in casualties and damage. This is the second time in a month that Yemen is hit by floods, affecting the already vulnerable population of

             Yemen. In mid-March, IDP-hosting sites in Marib Governorate were affected by floods.

•          According to the Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) and media, at least five people have died, including in Shabwah and Abyan Governorates. In addition, at least 30 houses have been destroyed or damaged in southwestern areas by flash floods, displacing people.
