According to the Global Disaster Alert and Coordination System (GDACS) and media, at least five people have died, including in Shabwah and Abyan Governorates. In addition, at least 30 houses have been destroyed or damaged in southwestern areas by flash floods, displacing people.

In Al-Jawf governorate, based on the YRCS branch, Heavy rains fell in most of the villages and areas of the Al-Zahir district, which caused damage to the following areas: Al-Uqda, Rahban, Al-Harj, Al-Marafd, Husun Al-Shanan, Bin Jamaan village, Shamsan, Al-Raqaa, Tariq Center, and Al-Jashouba, as these areas are adjacent to the Red Mountain, from which torrents flow. The heavy rains continued for several hours, and the rains were repeated, because of which torrential rains flowed and several farms, lands, and homes of citizens were subjected to great damage and losses. Soil erosion, demolition, and flood waters entered several houses and destroyed others, in addition to the fact that there are several homes and lives trapped and isolated from the torrential rains, which made it difficult to reach them to limit the existing damages. fall of several houses and other damages, estimated at 9 mud houses completely damaged and 36 partially damaged, in addition to the damage and tearing of many tents, in addition to the exit of several families and they are leaving their homes for fear of the collapse of their homes because of the gathering and flow of torrents around them.

 

In the new agrometeorological early warning report from FAO which covered 1-10 May 2023 “In the past week, heavy rainfall continued to affect much of Yemen flooding fields and causing massive dam failures that led to the death of four people in Al Mahwit. Other areas that experienced heavy rainfall that led to submerged streets and homes damaged leaving behind devastation include central Ibb and much of the Highlands. More severe weather is forecasted, and several parts of the country are at risk of experiencing flooding from record rainfall events in the coming week. The expected floods are especially likely to affect over 5,000 people in Wadi Zabid (Al Hudaydah/Dhamar/Ibb), over 2,000 in Siham (Sana’a/Raymah/Al Hudaydah), and in Mour (Hajjah/Al Hudaydah), over 1,000 in Tuban (Lahj/Al Dhale’e/ Ibb), and in the north part of Wadi Harad (west Sadah), over 800 in Rimah (Raymah/Dhamar), and in Banna (Abyan/Lahj/Al Dhale’e), and about 700 in Sordud (Al Mahwit/Sana’a). Avoiding exposure to the hazard and implementation of contingency plans is strongly advised “.

name: YEM: Flood - 2023-03 - -Heavy rains and floods in Yemen-Update #1
summary:
In the period of this update (6-11 May 2023), Heavy seasonal rainfall has increased 4,142 HHs to the affected families to reach 24,142 HHs since mid-March.

People were badly affected by the floods. It leads to deaths, evictions, and destruction of infrastructure and property. Floods in Yemen have caused massive damage to homes and infrastructure, such as roads and bridges.

The heaviest rainfall has caused the flooding of Al-Jawf, Marib, Sayun, Hajjah, Amran, Marib, Shabwa, Lahij, Al-Bayda, Al-Mahwit, Taiz, and Al-Mahra governorates across the country. Shelters, crops, roads, and buildings were damaged. 39 people were killed, more than 41 were injured, and nearly 1,158 buildings at least partially collapsed. 

The meteorological center in Sanaa forecast rainfall across the country’s central and northern highlands in Saada, Hajjah, Dhamar, and other regions, advising residents to avoid traveling through and staying in flood courses. The same center issued a similar warning about excessive rainfall, inundation, and landslides in mountainous regions of the country.

Heavy rain and strong wind hit different parts of Al Qahirah and Al Mudhaffer Districts in Taiz Governorate. The rainfall lasted for many hours and generated floods that devastated residents' properties in nine sites. No human casualties were reported. The damages caused by rainfall and floods are 156 affected HHs, 85 partially affected shelters, and 71 completely affected shelters.

Heavy rain and strong wind hit Al-Sharayer Camp in Lahj Governorate. The rainfall lasted for many hours and generated floods that devastated IDP shelters on the site. No human casualties were reported until the moment of writing this report.  The damages caused by rainfall and floods are 82 affected HHs, and 82 completely affected shelters.

A small village, Al-Mehraq, in the Utmah District of the central province of Dhamar, was declared a disaster area after heavy rain and flooding devastated the area, killing one child and injuring several others, triggering landslides, trapping and displacing many families, and washing away farms and a flock of sheep.

Locals in Ibb province’s Al-Makhadir District discovered the remains of two women who died after being swept away by floodwaters while crossing a waterway as heavy rain wreaked havoc on fields and highways across the agricultural district.

 

The deadliest single flood-related incident occurred in the mountainous province of Raymah, where at least nine people were killed, and three others injured when their vehicle skidded off a rain-damaged road.

name: FJI: Epidemic - 2023-03 - Dengue Outbreak
summary:
The Ministry of Health has declared a Dengue Outbreak in the Central Division particularly in Suva, with an unusual increase in dengue like cases presenting at its health facilities and admitted to the Colonial War Memorial Hospital.  Dengue Fever is endemic in Fiji, meaning it occurs regularly within our population. However, when there are more cases than normally seen, it is considered an outbreak.
Government health facilities in the central health division have been activated to ensure the availability of adequate manpower and the technical resources to accommodate the anticipated initial rise in case numbers of dengue fever infections.
In a coordination meeting called by the MoH, the Fiji Red Cross is preparing its team in their branches and headquarters to respond to the areas with confirmed cases, which are mostly in the Northern division. Current statistics, saw an increase in numbers of suspected cases in the Central division, but are awaiting lab test results to confirm confirmed cases. Therefore, more focus will be given to the Northern division to ensure that the spread of confirmed cases is contained.

Currently, Environmental Health Officers (EHO) are committed to Disease Investigation on case-by-case basis. Limited support on Awareness of outbreak to community due to staff ratio is one of the major issues the MoH is facing and are looking to its partners like Fiji Red Cross to support.  Competing priorities with other key FRCS community organised training and visits in these affected areas will affect its roll out due to this outbreak.

Below is the list of the most affected districts in the North and its communities.
1.	Labasa (7)- Siberia/Vunivau/Wailevu/Bulileka/Basoga/Tuatua/Vunika
2.	Seaqaqa (4) – Tabia/Seaqaqa Town area/Dreketi/Naduri
3.	Wainikoro (5) – Navoalevu/Coqeloa/Naleba/Daku/Lagalaga
This is looking at 16 communities in the 3 districts with a total of 317 confirmed cases. Majority of these confirmed cases are from the main Labasa town.

name: Malawi: Cyclone - 2023-03 Tropical Storm Freddy
summary:
Tropical Storm Freddy swept through Southern Malawi on 12 March 2023, with strong winds and heavy rains leaving the affected districts in a state of disaster and affecting the power supply throughout most of the country. Tropical Storm Freddy is set to be the longest tropical system since 1994, having weakened and re-intensified seven times over the last month.

The Malawi government has declared a state of disaster in 10 southern districts that have been hardest hit by the storm. A large number of people are reported to have been affected, of which 101.648 households (approximately 508.244 people) have been displaced with 534 camps set to accommodate the displaced, according to reports from DoDMA. The death toll, which is currently at 499 (as of 20 March 2023), is expected to rise as 427 people are still unaccounted for since some areas remain cut off due to relentless rain and fierce wind.

Our response as of the 29th of May:

The shelter sector has reached 2,699 (179%) households out of a target of 1,500 provided with emergency and temporary shelter assistance.

A total of 8,025 (160%) households have been reached with food assistance against a target of 5,000. A total of 2,800 households were reached last week with food distributions and NFIs in Zomba (1,400), and Machinga (1,200) through the support of Qatar RC.In terms of multi-purpose cash, 2,135 (43%) households have been provided with multipurpose cash grants against a target of 5,000 households. A total of 436 households were reached last week. There is a scheduled cash distribution targeting 726 households in Chikwawa scheduled for this week.

76 (32%) volunteers and staff have been trained on PFA for health and care.

7,200 mosquito nets have been distributed to 3,600 (102%) households against a target of 1,600 nets. A total of 5,600 nets were distributed last week through the Qatar RC.       

A total of 2,007 people were reached through First Aid services disaggregated as (Males - 741, females - 1266, and children – 200).

For the WASH sector, 11,879 (7%) people were reached by hygiene promotion activities (including communities and schools). 1,250 (3%) people have been provided with safe water services that meet agreed standards according to specific operational and programmatic contexts.  5 boreholes have been rehabilitated, and as per the Malawi standards, each borehole should serve a population of approximately 250 people. For PGI, 8,124 (5%) people have been reached with PGI, prevention, and response to SGBV awareness messages.

For CEA, 100% (911 queries and feedback received) of the queries/feedback received through the feedback mechanisms established were responded to. A total of 211 queries and feedback were received during last week's distributions.

A PDM was done for the households reached in the first distribution of NFIs, and the satisfaction rate was 97%.

Under Coordination and Partnerships, MRCS continues to get support from the movement (IFRC, Qatar RC, Danish RC, Belgium RC), UN agencies(IOM, WFP), and private sector players.

name: DOM: Sequía - 2023-03 - SITREP Incendios Forestales
summary:
A propósito del incendio forestal que recientemente afectó el área protegida en Valle Nuevo, Medio Ambiente reiteró en rueda de prensa su compromiso de continuar con las ejecuciones de la Estrategia Nacional de Manejo del Fuego 2021-2030, que incluye, entre otras, la disminución del impacto de la quema de bosques para actividades agrícolas, la cual provoca daños en los ecosistemas, con la participación de las instituciones gubernamentales y de la sociedad civil.

La entidad ambiental explicó que, entre las medidas que seguirá ejecutando, están convertir a los agricultores en protectores de los bosques, mediante programas de educación para prevenir los incendios en áreas protegidas y en las cuencas altas de los ríos. También se informó que los que trabajan la tierra pueden apoyarse de las oficinas provinciales y del Viceministerio de Recursos Forestales para dar cumplimiento a esta labor bajo los parámetros legales establecidos.

“El 98 % de los incendios forestales en el país son producidos por actividades humanas, bien sea por descuido o consecuencia de actividades de tumba y quema que se hacen previo a la siembra de rubros de ciclo corto”, puntualizó Medio Ambiente, institución que añadió que sólo el 2 % de ese tipo de siniestros se debe a causas naturales.

Debido a la composición de los ecosistemas forestales y las condiciones climáticas actuales, la República Dominicana es un país con altos niveles de vulnerabilidad ante la ocurrencia de dichos incendios, los cuales son de los factores que más influyen sobre la estructura y funcionamiento de los ecosistemas y afectan, de forma directa, la biodiversidad, la cantidad y calidad de las aguas y los medios de subsistencia de la población. Asimismo, a nivel global, inciden en el cambio climático mediante la emisión de dióxido de carbono y otros gases de efecto invernadero.

name: GAB: Accident de transport - 2023-03 - NAUFRAGE EZTER MIRACLE
summary: Selon le gouvernement le naufrage du navire Ezter aurait fait plusieurs bléssés , morts et disparus

name: BEN: Déplacement de population - 2023-03 - BEN: Déplacement de population -2023-03
summary: Le Bénin et le Togo font face depuis plusieurs mois à de fortes menaces de groupes armés non étatiques. Les attaques étaient initialement confinées à la frontière entre l'est du Burkina Faso et le Bénin, dans les parcs nationaux W et de la Pendjari, dans les régions d'Alibori et d'Atacora, mais elles s'étendent depuis quelques jours vers la plupart des communes. Les attaques dans la région des Savanes au Togo ont provoqué des déplacements forcés de populations dans plusieurs localités frontalières à cette région. C’est ainsi que Matéri, Cobly et Tanguiéta les communes située dans le département de l’Atacora au Bénin ont accueilli dans des togolais fuyant des violences meurtrières occasionnées par des attaques dont a été victime ces derniers temps la région des savanes.

name: Slovenia: Floods
summary:
Approximately two-thirds of Slovenia's territory is currently grappling with the aftermath of flash floods, torrential rain, and hailstorm, with 181 municipalities affected out of the total of 212. In total, 8,000 people have been evacuated to their relatives or other accommodation facilities, and six people have lost their lives as a consequence of the disaster. Heavily affected regions inclide Upper Carniola, Central Slovenia, Koroška region, as well as Savinjska region.

Bridges and roads are submerged in these areas, while water supply systems in Koroška and Savinjska have been compromised. Electricity supply is also disrupted in the Koroška and Savinjska regions. Some of the affected regions have already been impacted by extreme weather events over this summer, and some of the regions suffer from pre-existing socio-economic challenges. In the most affected areas, communication is disrupted and there is severe damage to infrastructure. Over 170 landslides are active, posing a continued threat to homes, infrastructure, and electricity. The government is continuing to evaluate the scope of the disaster, damage assessment via local actors is still ongoing. Affected population is provided with food, water and basic needs from the Civil Protection (CP) as well as Slovenian Red Cross (SRC) via air or with heavy vehicles operated by the Slovenian army or firefighters, with SRC also assisting them in the handover of relief items to the vulnerable population. On 11 August, the Ministry of Defense reported that by their first estimates more than 400 buildings (some including multiple housing units) were completely destroyed or declared uninhabitable. The loss of assets, homes and businesses, livestock, crops and infrastructure will affect job security and livelihoods in the mid-to long term. Because of the continuous threat of landslides, it is expected that more households will become in need of long-term shelter and basic needs support during the upcoming months.

name: Bangladesh Fire Incident in Camp 11
summary: A massive fire broke out in Rohingya refugee camps of Cox’s Bazar in Bangladesh on the afternoon on March 05, 2023. Around 3:00 PM, the fire ignited from block D of camp 11 and it soon spread to the other blocks including block A, B and D, leaving over 2,000+ infrastructures including shelters, community centers, water network, learning centers and health facilities fully or partly affected. Given the dry season and frequent/high wind flow, the fire spread rapidly and engulfed its surrounding areas. After trying for around two hours, the firefighters including Fire Service and Civil Defense (FSCD) units from Ukhiya and Cox’s Bazar, trained community volunteers from camp 11 and adjacent camps finally managed to douse the fire at around 05.00 PM on the same day.

name: CHL: Movimiento de la población - 2023-03 - Crisis Migratoria Zona Norte de Chile
summary:
A fines de enero de 2021, en Colchane, una pequeña localidad ubicada en la región de Tarapacá duplicó en pocos días su población debido al arribo de migrantes. La mayoría de ellos provenía de Venezuela, y llegaron a causa de la crisis humanitaria que vive ese país. Fueron días de lluvias torrenciales en la frontera de Chile con Bolivia, donde se hicieron aún más duras las condiciones climáticas de un territorio que suele tener temperaturas muy bajas en las noches, y que también destaca por la falta de oxígeno (la ciudad está ubicada a 3.650 metros sobre el nivel del mar). Esta llegada de migrantes coincidió, además, con medidas restrictivas establecidas a raíz de la pandemia, y que afectaron la circulación de buses hacia Iquique, la capital regional. Esperanzados se han mostrado algunos habitantes de la zona norte del país respecto al anuncio que hizo el gobierno del presidente Gabriel Boric, durante la semana pasada relacionado con la Ley de Resguardo de Infraestructura Crítica aprobada en enero, poder desplegar fuerzas militares para apoyar el orden y control público en las fronteras de las regiones de Arica y Parinacota, Tarapacá y Antofagasta.
Este domingo 26 de febrero comenzó el movimiento de camiones militares en dirección a la montaña, particularmente hacia la zona de Colchane, pero también en Arica y Ollagüe en Antofagasta. La comunidad confía en que baje al menos el ingreso de extranjeros por la frontera de esas zonas.
Según acusan, desde hace 3 años ha venido con fuerza una “avalancha de venezolanos” pero en el último tiempo también, de acuerdo con sus relatos, colombianos y salvadoreños. Los ingresos que, si bien hasta el 2022 eran perceptibles en las carreteras en Colchane, Huara y en la Ruta 5 Norte, hoy la situación ha cambiado, ya que muchos de los inmigrantes ilegales bajan en buses que nadie sabe de dónde y cómo pueden transitar.

En la Región de Arica y Parinacota
Desde comenzó el plan fronterizo, la entrada ilegal por la zona fronteriza de chacalluta (frontera Chile - Perú) ha disminuido considerablemente, siendo el flujo mayor en las horas de la madrugada esta disminuyó demasiado, ya no se ve familia pernoctando a las fuera del terminal nacional y tampoco en sus alrededores

En la región de Tarapacá

El flujo migratorio en la región ha bajado igual, la información que se maneja de la zona de Colchane es que ha sufrido la bajada del ingreso de población venezolana y solo la población boliviana mantiene el flujo pero esto es normal al tener un pueblo boliviano muy cerca de la frontera.

  • En la ciudad de Iquique bajo el flujo, ya no se ve población migrante en las zona concurridas como en las esquinas o semáforos
  • En Alto Hospicio la los migrantes que logran llegar se dirigen inmediatamente a las zonas de las tomas donde es difícil el ingreso y al igual manejar un número exacto
  • En Pozo Almonte es una ciudad de paso el flujo no es mucho ya que al ser una ciudad chica y en el desierto no se mantiene en la zona,

Hasta el momento no hay cifras oficiales de ingreso o de detenciones

name: LBR: Storm Surge - 2023-03 - Gbarpolu and Grand Bassa Windstorm
summary: On Sunday 12 February 2023, a heavy windstorm surge hit Gbarpolu and Grand Bassa Counties of Liberia, affecting fourteen villages. This natural disaster, which lasted for over an hour was responsible for tremendous infrastructural destruction, injuries, and economic damages. Hundreds of people were severely injured including 58 children. At moment, there are no reported deaths, but hundreds of people have been rendered homeless due to fallen trees and/or collapsed buildings. From available information, 1 village was affected in Gbarpolu County with 34 homes completely damaged and  27 homes partly destroyed affecting 434 people. In Grand Bassa County, 13 villages were affected affecting 41 homes, with a total of 278 people affected. The Liberian National Red Cross has deployed staff and volunteers who are currently conducting a rapid assessment to ascertain the impact of the disaster and the needs of the affected population.

name: AUS: Flood - 2023-03 - Northern Territory
summary:
A monsoon and embedded low are generating rains, storms and severe weather in the Daly and Gregory districts within the Northern Territory. A severe weather warning is in place for Barkly, and parts of Carpentaria, Gregory, Barkly and Tanami districts.  A flood watch has been issued for parts of the Top End and Central Inland and Carpentaria Coastal catchments where widespread flooding is expected for the next few days.

Northern Territories Chief Minister signed an emergency declaration covering the communities of Pigeon Hole, Yarralin, Daguragu and Kalkarindji in the northwest. The Upper Victoria River at Kalkarindji peaked last night at 17 metres and is currently at 16.6metres.  The bridge at Kalkarindji submerges when the river level increases above 9.3metres making evacuation difficult.  Houses at Dagaragu have been cut off by floodwaters for the past few days. The communities of Dagaragu, Pigeon Hole, Palumpa and Kalkarindji are currently being evacuated by air to Darwin. The Kalkarindji school is closed.

 

There is the potential for further evacuations in the Daly, Gregory, Barkly, Tanami, Top End and Carpentaria regions, as the number of communities impacted by widespread flooding across part of Northern Territory is expected to rise, with river levels in these districts still yet to peak in some parts.

name: GRC: Transport Accident - 2023-02 - Fatal Train Collision
summary: On Tuesday evening at 23:00, local time, a passenger train and a cargo train were involved in the fatal head-on crash at Tempi near the city of Larissa in Central Greece, resulting in the loss of at least 38 lives and more than 85 people injured. After the collision a fire erraptued at the first wagons of the train. The ones that were hospitalized had serious injuries. Passengers with minor injuries were transferred by bus to Thessaloniki.

name: Vanuatu Tropical Cyclone Judy and Kevin 2023
summary:
Over 167,000 people are estimated to be affected by TC Judy, and more than 50% houses are damaged in rural Efate Island while in urban Port-Vila at least 20% of houses are damaged. Major damage is likely in Shefa and Tafea provinces. Damage assessment is being put on hold by the government and VRCS as Vanuatu is bracing up for TC Kevin that will cross over central and southern provinces this Friday and Saturday and is forecast to intensify into Category 2 or 3 system before making landfall in Tanna Island. Yellow Alert is in effect for Sanma province, while Blue Alert for Torba and Malampa provinces.

While TC Judy Category 4 was moving in a south-southeast direction away from the Vanuatu group past midnight 2 March 2023, another tropical low that has been forming in Coral Sea was entering Vanuatu Area of Responsibility (AoR) as a Tropical Cyclone Category 1 system named Kevin. TC Kevin has rapidly intensified into Category 2 system and is forecast to affect central and southern provinces and move with similar track path of TC Judy. TC Kevin may gain its strength further into Category 3 and is expected to make a landfall in Tanna Island on 4 Mar 2023.

Damaging gale force winds of 75kph with gusts up to 105kph are expected to affect TORBA and SANMA provinces within the next 24 hours as the system approaches the northern and central provinces. Heavy rainfalls with possible thunderstorms expected over northern Vanuatu with flash flooding in low lying areas, areas close to the riverbanks and including coastal flooding. Seas will become rough to very rough with moderate to heavy swells over northern and central waters of Vanuatu.

Right after severe TC Judy exited the Vanuatu group, authorities and Vanuatu Red Cross Society (VRCS) began to commence assessment to figure out the extent of damage that was caused by TC Judy. As TC Kevin Category 2 is entering and moving across Vanuatu, assessment and clean-up have been hampered and it is still not clear the length or widespread of the damage. As of today, most parts of the capital Port Vila and northern islands are without power, schools and businesses remain closed. On remote islands, phone and internet reception is limited and people without access to cyclone warnings through radio or other means of communications are being alerted to the risks by provincial emergency coordinators.

 

An initial observation of the damage from TC Judy by the NDMO revealed many houses on Epi Island in Shefa Province were destroyed, with some families sheltering under beds and tables in their houses as TC Judy hammered most parts of the northern islands. There is likelihood of massive damage to houses, churches, crops, power lines and also flooding in low-lying areas. The storm uprooted trees and forced evacuations with power outages are reported across the area of the capital city Port-Vila. There is still no confirmed figure as to the extent of damage, it is estimated that more than 50% houses are damaged in rural Efate Island while in urban Port-Vila at least 20% of houses are damaged. Major damage is likely in Shefa and Tafea provinces.

name: PRY: Flash Flood 2023
summary:
Entre el día 15 al 18 de febrero comenzaron lluvias en la zona norte del Paraguay que desembocaron en inundaciones súbitas afectando a la ciudad de Concepción y al municipio de Puerto Casado (ubicados en los departamentos de Concepción y alto Paraguay respectivamente), ambas localidades se ubican a 409 km y 642 km respectivamente de la ciudad de Asunción.

Las inundaciones en Concepción afectaron a las viviendas de comunidades aledañas a la ciudad mientras que en Puerto Casado el desborde del río dejo completamente aislado al Municipio.
El día 27 de febrero la Gobernación Departamental de Concepción declara Estado de Emergencia departamental mediante la junta departamental conformada por los concejales. Mientras que el 24 de febrero, en Puerto Casado el Concejo Municipal declara Emergencia Distrital en dicho municipio.

El día 22 de febrero la secretaria de Emergencia Nacional (SEN) comenzó a asistir a las comunidades afectadas, realizando evacuaciones vía aérea en colaboración con la Fuerza Aérea Paraguaya debido a la condición de aislamiento en la que quedaron comunidades en Puerto Casado.
La Dirección de Meteorología e Hidrología del Gobierno Nacional continúa anunciando lluvias y ocasionales tormentas eléctricas para ambos departamentos, lo que prevee que la situación se mantenga.

name: GAB: Epidemic - 2023-02 - Marburg risk
summary: In sitrep N°2 published on February 25, 2023, the authorities mentioned that since the alert of February 13, 2023, confirming a positive sample for Marburg disease, more than 163 people have crossed the land border between the 3 countries: Equatorial Guinea, Cameroon, Gabon. It should be noted that suspected cases have been detected in the two neighboring countries of Gabon. These official travel reports, therefore, remain of concern and support the additional actions undertaken by the Gabonese Red Cross (CRG) to strengthen preventive measures, the preparation of the NS and the community alert system in contribution to the mandate of the operational unit for Response to Epidemics (CORE). On February 10, 2023, the Government of Equatorial Guinea reported the death of nine (9) people presenting the symptoms of hemorrhagic fever. On February 12, a sample of suspected cases was declared positive for Marburg disease and the WHO published confirmation of the epidemic in Equatorial Guinea on February 13, while Cameroon has continued to record suspected cases since February 9, although none have been tested positive so far. As of 02.03.2023, triangulated information from the field reported certain contact cases of the various confirmed cases not yet traced in Equatorial Guinea.

name: SSD: Epidemic - 2023-02 - Cholera Outbreak Upper Nile
summary: On the 22 of February, Medicines’ San Frontiers Spain (MSF Spain) in Malakal, Upper Nile State received an alert of increasing cases of acute watery diarrhea and vomiting in children aged 1 year and below. Two samples were collected and tested positive for cholera on rapid diagnostic testing (RDT). Additional nine samples were collected and transported to the National Public Health Laboratory in Juba on 02 March 2023 for culture and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing. Two out of the nine samples tested positive for Vibrio cholerae on PCR testing. On 25 February 2023, the Ministry of Health received notification of a suspected case of cholera from Malaka, Upper Nile State. Since then, Malakal county continue to receive more alerts of increasing cases of acute watery diarrhoea and vomiting. On 07 March, the Government declared the outbreak in Malakal, in the Upper Nile province after one case was confirmed. The Malakal cholera situational update of 11 March 2023 reported an increase of cases of 48% since the declaration of the outbreak by the Government. Indeed, with 265 cases recorded on 11 march, the cases continue to go upward, with some worrying figures on the group affected, including children under 4 being the majority of the cases (more than or equal to 91% all along the week) and cases now reported in Protection of Civilian sites where more than 34,056 people are leaving in critical coping mechanism. The situation is prompting the support from South Sudan National Society to the Government's effort to eliminate Page 2 / 18 the disease. Both the town population and PoC overall population mentioned above are at risk. SSRC activated branches and in accordance with its role with the Government has attributed some response pillars to support by county MoH to strengthen the response.

name: BRA: Derrumbe - 2023-02 - Chuvas Torrenciais - Litoral Norte de SP
summary:
El paso de una frente fría, que generó un sistema de bajas presiones, provocó fuertes lluvias en el litoral de Sao Paulo entre el sábado (18) y el domingo (19). La masa de aire se concentró en la región del Litoral Norte y Baixada Santista generando elevadas acumulaciones de precipitaciones.

Tres de las cuatro ciudades del Litoral Norte de São Paulo (São Sebastião, Ilhabela, Caraguatatuba y Ubatuba) tuvieron en las últimas 24 horas el volumen de lluvia previsto para todo el mes de febrero, según datos de la Defensa Civil. En São Sebastião, el volumen en las últimas 24 horas en el domingo fue el doble de la media prevista para el mes.

Las tormentas provocaron inundaciones, corrimientos de tierra y bloquearon tramos de las autopistas Rio-Santos, Mogi-Bertioga y Tamoios. En varios puntos del litoral paulista faltaron el agua, la electricidad y la señal de telefonía móvil.

Más de 600 personas están buscando víctimas, entre bomberos, agentes de Protección Civil y vecinos de la zona. El domingo, los helicópteros de la policía militar tuvieron dificultades para llegar a los puntos más críticos debido al mal tiempo. El Ejército envió aviones para ayudar en las labores.

A través del gobierno del estado, se declaró estado de calamidad y se hizo una primera liberación de recursos de R$ 7 millones para gastos. El gobierno del estado hizo nuevas liberaciones, y el gobierno federal también estuvo dispuesto a aplicar recursos de la Defensa Civil nacional, y también para la parte de vivienda y infraestructura para la reconstrucción de la [carretera] Río-Santos".

Más de 50 habitaciones fueron destruidas generando un impacto de personas sin hogar y desplazadas y se llevarán a cabo acciones para retirar a las familias de las regiones de riesgo generando más personas en situaciones delicadas con sus necesidades humanitarias.

name: TGO: Déplacement de population - 2023-02 - Mouvement de populations dans la Région des savanes
summary:
Selon l'Agence Nationale de la Protection  Civile (ANPC), la situation au Nord du Togo reste volatile. L'afflux de déplacés ne cesse d'augmenter tous les jours suite aux attaques des groupes armés non étatiques qui proviendraient de l'autre côté de la frontière avec le Burkina-Faso. 

Les populations réfugiées en provenance du Burkina-Faso et celles déplacées des localités visées par les attaques ou sous menace dans la préfecture de Kpendjal ont retrouvé refuge dans les villages environnants auprès des familles alliées ou des ressortissants. 

La situation reste et démeure préocupante à cause de ce caractère volatile aggravant ainsi une situation d'insécurité non maîtrisée.

name: BEN: Incendie - 2023-02 - Incendie_Fevrier_2023
summary: Vendredi 17 février 2023, le Bénin a connu des incendies dans 3 trois communes notamment à karimaman, Lokossa et Sô-Ava. Celle du village de Bessétonou dans l’arrondissement de Ahomey Lokpo dans la commune de Sô-Ava a été la plus grave. Cette situation à cause d’importants dommages aux ménages notamment des pertes des moyens subsistance, les abris etc. Les comités locaux de la Croix-Rouge Béninoise évalué actuellement la meilleure façon de soutenir les familles les plus vulnérables affectés par cette catastrophe.

name: MDG: Cyclone - 2023-02-21 - Freddy
summary: On 4th March 2023, two weeks after Tropical Cyclone Freddy crossed the south-eastern part of Madagascar to Mozambique, this tropical cyclone returned to Madagascar as an intensified strong tropical storm that almost reached the south-west coast. At 50km off the coast of Tulear, it brought up strong rains and wind between 4th and 7th March 2023, leading to damages, mainly in Tulear, Morombe and Morondava. In this context, 4 districts have been placed under red alert (Morombe, Toliara I-II and Betioky), 4 on yellow alert (Ankazoabo, Sakaraha and Benenitra and Ampanihy) and 3 on green alert (Belon’i tsiribihina, Morondava and Manja) As results, two dykes broke, leading to major floods in Morondava and Morombe. The sea water level has risen, causing the rupture of the evacuation ditches in Morondava and leading to a prolonged rise of water and a difficul t water drainin.

name: GTM: Epidemia - 2023-02 - Alerta por Gripe Aviar H5N1 en Guatemala
summary:
El Ministerio de Agricultura, Ganadería y Alimentación de Guatemala (MAGA), confirmó este martes 14 de febrero que se detectaron aves silvestres, tipo Pelícano, contagiados con la gripe aviar H5N1 en una comunidad de Puerto Barrios, Izabal, por lo que se declaró alerta gubernamental.
Hasta el momento, no existe ningún caso en la avicultura tecnificada ni en la avicultura de traspatio o familiar.

name: MOZ: Tropical Cyclone Freddy Response
summary:
The Mozambique National Institute of Meteorology (INAM) press release of 9th February 2023 reported that Maputo, Gaza and Inhambane province, have been hit by heavy rainfall reaching up to 100mm in 24hcausing widespread flooding in Maputo city and Maputo province. The floods situation report, released byNational Institute for Disaster Management and Risk Reduction(INGD). As the heavy rainfall continued, there has been a monitoring of the situation with consideration of successive reports shared by INAM. On 11th of February 2023, floods have affected 30,605 people (5721 families), 4 dead, 422 displaced, including 5 health centres and 15 schools affected in Maputo city and province. The National Institute for Disaster Management and Risk reduction (INGD) reports On the 16th of February that continuity of floods has affected people up to 43,426 people (8,685 families), including 15,891 people displaced and 10 deaths. 15 emergency settlement are open to provide shelter to 15,853. The reports also indicates that 35 sanitary units has suffer damages, 8,684 houses were flooded, 28 partially damaged and 3 fully damaged, in Maputo City and Province.

The forecasted impact of TC FREDDY will cause additional needs to the current dire situation in Maputo which is part of the areas to experienced river flooding as in the map. The overall floods situation in the country is expected to worsen as TC FREDDY will likely induced rains and floo

name: DOM: Population Movement - 2023-02 - Flujo Migratorio Haití - Republica Dominicana
summary:
El flujo migratorio entre Haití y la República Dominicana es un fenómeno complejo y dinámico que tiene implicaciones sociales, económicas, políticas y sanitarias para ambos países. Según la Organización Internacional para las Migraciones (OIM), se registraron más de 37.000 movimientos de personas haitianas ingresando a la República Dominicana en noviembre de 2020 y más de 25.000 en agosto de 2021 , lo que muestra que se trata de un flujo continuo y creciente.

Los motivos que impulsan a los haitianos a cruzar la frontera son diversos, pero se relacionan principalmente con la búsqueda de mejores oportunidades de trabajo y comercio, así como con la situación de inestabilidad política y violencia que vive Haití desde hace años. La mayoría de los migrantes haitianos se insertan en sectores de baja calificación y precariedad laboral, como la agricultura, la construcción, el servicio doméstico y el comercio informal. Estas condiciones los hacen más vulnerables a la explotación, la discriminación y la exclusión social.

La migración haitiana también plantea desafíos para la salud pública de la República Dominicana, especialmente en lo que respecta a la prevención y el tratamiento del VIH/SIDA. La isla de La Española tiene una de las tasas más altas de prevalencia de esta enfermedad en América Latina y el Caribe, y los migrantes haitianos se encuentran entre los grupos más expuestos al riesgo de contagio debido a las barreras lingüísticas, culturales y económicas que enfrentan para acceder a los servicios de salud.

Ante este escenario, la República Dominicana ha adoptado medidas para regular y controlar el flujo migratorio en su frontera con Haití, como la implementación de un sistema biométrico de identificación, el fortalecimiento de los controles migratorios y aduaneros, y la construcción de un muro fronterizo que abarcará 54 kilómetros en su primera fase . 

La migración entre Haití y la República Dominicana es un asunto que requiere una visión integral y una cooperación binacional para su gestión. Es necesario reconocer las causas estructurales que originan este fenómeno, así como sus consecuencias e impactos en ambos países. Asimismo, es imprescindible garantizar el respeto a los derechos humanos de los migrantes haitianos y promover su integración social y económica en la República Dominicana.

Las deportaciones de haitianos en República Dominicana han aumentado en los últimos meses, en medio de una crisis humanitaria y política en el país vecino. Según la Dirección General de Migración (DGM), entre enero y julio de 2022 se repatriaron a 57,764 haitianos por estar de manera irregular en el país. Sin embargo, organizaciones de derechos humanos han denunciado que muchas de estas deportaciones se han realizado sin respetar los procedimientos legales y los principios humanitarios. Entre las irregularidades se encuentran la separación de familias, la violencia física, la falta de documentación y la expulsión de personas dominicanas de ascendencia haitiana.

La situación se ha agravado por la inestabilidad política y social que vive Haití desde el asesinato del presidente Jovenel Moïse el pasado 7 de julio. Miles de haitianos han huido de la violencia y la pobreza en su país, buscando refugio en República Dominicana o intentando llegar a Estados Unidos por vía marítima. La Agencia de la ONU para los Refugiados (ACNUR) ha expresado su preocupación por la creciente ola de peligrosas travesías de migrantes y refugiados a través del mar Caribe, y ha pedido a los países de la región asistirles en cumplimiento de las obligaciones de salvamento marítimo.

name: GNQ: Épidémie - 2023-02 - Fièvre hemorragique virale
summary: The Ministry of Health of Equatorial Guinea received reports of a cluster of deaths due to an unknown illness in two north-eastern districts of the continental region of Equatorial Guinea (Nsok-Nsomo and Ebebiyin). A total of nine people died from January 7 to February 6 with symptoms similar to a viral haemorrhagic fever infection. Samples were collected from the deceased and sent for testing in Dakar, Senegal. One tested positive for Marburg virus disease (MVD). On 13 February 2023, Equatorial Guinea’s Ministry of Health officially declared the outbreak, marking the first-ever Marburg outbreak in the country. According to government information, initial alerts and deaths were traced back to public events which, according to local religious and cultural customs, brought together several dozen and sometimes hundreds of people. As of 13 April, 15 cases of Marburg virus have been confirmed, with 11 of those cases resulting in death. Untraced contacts in the community, rumours and lack of information within the communities could be important transmission levers that need to be urgently managed.

name: SDN: Epidemic - 2023-02 - Dengue fever outbreak
summary: The first reported case presented on July 28th 22 in West Kordofan, Kassala and West Darfur. The cumulative number of reported cases since 28 July/22 up to 20 March/23 is 7,935 cases. Among all reported cases, 46% are female. Twelve states are affected by dengue fever, the majority of cases were reported from Khartoum, Gadarief and North Darfour states. The situation is now stable in most states except Khartoum and Gadarief states. The first suspected cases appeared in Khartoum and Gadarief states on 07 of Feb. and from that moment until now the cases are increasing.

name: CMR: Epidemic - 2023-02 - Anticipatory action for Marburg
summary: Since February 7, 2023, several suspected cases with symptoms of Marburg Hemorrhagic Fever have been declared in Equatorial Guinea in districts of Kie-Ntem province. On February 13, 2023, the first Marburg epidemic was declared by confirmation of a positive sample. Several contact cases are to be traced and Cameroon has recorded suspect cases since 9th February in areas bordering Equatorial Guinea. Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea share a 189 km long border. On both sides of this border, live the Ntumu populations, who are part of the Fang group. They are established in the North-West of Gabon, also on the other side of the border in the South of Cameroon and in the East of Equatorial Guinea. They are found in Cameroon in the Ntem valley, in the districts of Kyé-Ossi, Ambam, Olamze and Ma'an. Despite their different historical backgrounds, these populations still share fraternal and cultural ties (funeral rites, traditional ceremonies, etc.), economic (trade) and social ties that punctuate their daily life. Faced with the high risk of spread of the disease, the local administrative authorities have restricted the movement of populations at the Cameroon - Equatorial Guinea border and activated the incident management system throughout the region.

name: LBN: Other - 2023-01 - Lebanon Severe Weather (2023-02-06)
summary:
Lebanon has been facing severe weather conditions since the 19th of January 2023. Adverse conditions intensified by the end of January, thus deepening the already existing vulnerabilities in the country, particularly for populations that are already at risk. Heavy rain, precipitation, cold temperatures, and strong winds have led to the inundation of roads and heightened traffic safety risks across the country. These factors have also aggravated health risks for those living in inadequate shelter, including displaced Syrians in informal tented settlements (ITS), Palestinians living in undermaintained camps, and Lebanese already struggling with the socio-economic collapse.

 

As of the 3rd of February, UNHCR, through Inter-Agency Coordination, reported an estimated 1388 individuals affected by the weather conditions in Syrian ITSs. Moreover, by the 6th of February, the Lebanese Government had not yet estimated the overall number of people affected; however, the local and state media reported an increase in traffic incidents, road closures at high altitudes, and at least 3 cases of drowning related to the winter rains.

 

This comes as Lebanon is attempting to recover from a Cholera outbreak in late 2022 and has an overstretched healthcare system.

 

In the early morning hours of the 6th of February, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck Southern Turkey and Northern Syria. The earthquake’s epicenter is located 450 km from Beirut and the earthquake was felt in all Lebanese regions at a 4.8 magnitude. Damages are still being assessed and the risks of aftershocks and potential damages could unfold as the severe weather continues.

 

LRC through its presence throughout Lebanon and across its operational sectors supported all communities (host and non-host).

 

1. LRCs 140 Emergency Hotline received many calls directly after the Earthquake while Emergency Medical Teams has been on alert since 3:20 A.M and transported and treated 18 cases.

2. LRCs Disaster Management Sector has provided support to 600 HHs in Akkar with the provision of blankets, bread and other relief items.

3. LRCs Disaster Risk Reduction Unit launched the dissemination of the earthquake awareness video and the booklet including the main key messages.

4. LRCs 1760 Non-emergency Hotline received more than 20 calls requesting information about evacuations and safety measures, damage assessment, and settlement support.

 

In addition, LRC's EMS teams are ready to respond to any mission and upscale the availability of the teams upon the need, whereas the DMS teams will continue the provision of relief services and support with the evacuation when needed; The DRR teams will be participating in the awareness raising on earthquake topics on a national level, stressing on the schools and vulnerable areas as agreed with the Lebanese Government in the meeting that took place on the 6th of February, 2023 in the Grand Serail.

 

Under close coordination with the authorities, LRC is also in the process of assessing risks and needs related to the weather conditions in the country and the aftereffects of the earthquake.

 

At last, the Lebanese government has asked LRC to deploy a Team to Turkey along with the Civil Defense and Army to help with the Search and Rescue mission, and the Lebanese Red Cross Secretary General is in close coordination with the IFRC, Turkish Red Crescent, and Syrian Arab Red Crescent to facilitate any further request for assistance.

name: Türkiye : Earthquake - 2023-02
summary:
Turkish Red Crescent (TRC) is responsible for coordinating mass feeding services in the disaster area.

TRC maintains activity in 1,000 locations in the earthquake zone, providing aid, especially in remote areas with low accessibility.

Displacement: According to IOM, the estimated displaced within the earthquake-affected provinces is 2.7 million, of whom 1.1 million have evacuated to different Turkish provinces. As of 6 March, 214,000 buildings have collapsed or are heavily damaged. More than 1.9 million people have been provided with shelter in the form of tents, containers, and public buildings, including dormitories and sports halls. There are also informal camp settlements and rural settlements consisting of smaller villages in the 11 affected provinces where relief interventions are more difficult.

Basic Needs: Over one million earthquake survivors received a household support payment of 10,000 TRY from the Turkish Government. The Government will also provide 15,000 TRY to earthquake survivors who are moving to a new home. In an assessment of 290 key informants in Adiyaman, Hatay, Gaziantep, Kahramanmaras, and Kilis, 85 per cent of respondents said that they do not have a reliable source of income, stressing the need for cash.

Shelter: AFAD reports that 1,593,808 people have been given shelter within the earthquake-affected provinces, and 329,960 people have been given shelter in other provinces throughout Türkiye. Rental prices have increased.

Food: Ready-to-eat foods and hot meals continue to be needed. Out of 780 assessed displacement sites across the 11 provinces, key informants in 51 per cent of sites indicated that people purchase their own food. In 24 per cent of sites, key informants reported insufficient availability of baby foods.

WASH facilities remain a pressing need. A high need for hygiene and dignity kits has been reported, and 45 per cent of key informants in temporary accommodation sites indicated kits were unavailable.

Health: Among the priority concerns, as listed by WHO, are the provision of essential medicines, emergency kits and supplies, prevention of outbreaks and diseases, and access to mental health and psychosocial support. Another pressing health concern related to demolished buildings is asbestos, a material used in the construction of buildings before it was banned in 2010. It can cause serious illnesses (lung disease and cancer) when inhaled, and thus its handling requires centralized systematic management in the affected areas along with the use of specialised personal protective equipment.

Protection, Gender and Inclusion: According to UNFPA, access to safe deliveries and post-natal care is a major concern as many health facilities are damaged or services are disrupted. Additionally, there is a high need for mobile and temporary service units and sexual and reproductive health supplies in the affected regions.

See assessments, situation reports, information products, and appeal documents for more details.

name: Syria: Earthquake - 2023-02
summary:
On 6 February at 4:17 am, a 7.8 degrees magnitude earthquake struck southern Turkey near Syria’s northern border. The US Geological Survey said the earthquake was centered about 33 km (20 miles) from Gaziantep, a major city and provincial capital. Tremors were felt as far away as Lebanon, Greece, Palestine, and the island of Cyprus. Another big earthquake was felt on the same day at around 1:24 pm local time, largely in the same affected areas. Aftershocks will continue to shake the area as fault lines adjust to such a huge initial tremor. There’s even a risk—albeit a small one—of an aftershock bigger than the original quake.

SARC’s analysis currently stated that Aleppo, Latakia, Hama, and Tartous are the governorates affected the most by the earthquake, and assessments in neighboring governorates are underway. According to the Syrian MoH’s recent figures, as of 28 February, the number of casualties stood at 1,414 deaths and 2,357 injured in affected governorates. The numbers are expected to increase in the coming days. Major infrastructure damage is being witnessed and raising concerns in Aleppo, Latakia, Hama and Tartous Governorates (in the major cities and in the countryside). The extent of damage is being continuously assessed due to the wide range of affected areas by the earthquake.

The earthquake hit amid a very harsh winter with some areas in the northern part of the country hitting sub-zero temperatures, at a time when people are facing huge electricity, fuel, and water shortages.

The Syrian crisis is today even more critical than ever, with a multitude of challenges that make it one of the world’s most complex humanitarian emergencies. A decade of protracted crisis and economic collapse has left more than 15.3 million people in need of some form of humanitarian assistance

SARC also suffered some losses and damage to their infrastructure. A warehouse in Latakia has completely collapsed and another branch building was affected. Another Primary Health Care Centre (PHC) in Hama was also affected and needed to be immediately evacuated. Some Mobile Health Units were unable to move.

name: SYR: Earthquake - 2023-02 - Syria EQ 2023, PRCS-Syria Response
summary:
In the aftermath of Feb-6 earthquake in Syria affected Palestinian Refugee camps having a total population of 438000. PRCS Syria Branch responded to the EQ. initial assessment report indicate 15000 Palestinian Refugees were impacted by the EQ.

PRCS Syria Branch Provided first aid and other emergency support and is preparing to expand its operation support to reach all affected in the camps. 

PRCS Branch in Syria, is mandated to support the Palestinian refugee camps in Syria.

name: SOM: Population Movement - 2023-02 - Laas Caanood, Sool Region
summary: Laas Caanood is the capital City of the Sool Region, with approximately 190,000 to 200,000 people. The increase in the conflict started on 5 February has led to increased movement of families from the city. According to UNOCHA (report dated 9 Feb), reports from local authorities and humanitarian partners show that the current conflict has displaced more than 126,000 people with over 40 casualties and over 60 injured.

name: ECU: Inundación - 2023-02 - Temporada Invernal 2023
summary:
En el primer trimestre del año, se han registrado 643 eventos peligrosos por lluvias en diferentes provincias del Ecuador, según los reportes del INAMHI se registró el aumento de lluvias a mediados del mes de febrero, provocando mayor afectación en las provincias: Manabí, Guayas, Santa Elena, Los Ríos, Imbabura, Chimborazo y Pichincha.

A partir del 15 de febrero las lluvias se han intensificado a nivel nacional. La intensidad de las lluvias ha causado desbordamientos de ríos en provincias como en Manabí, donde el cantón Chone sigue afectado por inundaciones; también en Guayas, donde se desbordó el río Bulubulu causando inundaciones a cantones como: San Jacinto de Yaguachi y El Triunfo; en el cantón Milagro se vieron afectados varios sectores por acumulación de agua, y el desbordamiento del río Milagro; en la provincia de los Ríos en el cantón Montalvo por incremento de caudal del río El Cristal, colapsó un puente en una vía de primer orden

name: KEN: Drought - 2023-02
summary: The IFRC Disaster Response Emergency Fund (DREF) has approved a total of CHF 499,199 for the Kenya Red Cross. The approved amount consists of an allocation of CHF 135,978 for readiness and prepositioning and CHF 363,222 allocated to implement early actions once the defined triggers are met. Allocations are made from the Anticipatory Pillar of the DREF, under the DREF appeal code MDR00001. Unearmarked contributions to the DREF are encouraged to guarantee enough funding is available for the Early Action Protocols being developed. This Early Action Protocol (EAP) is a tool to guide the timely and effective implementation of early actions. These actions are informed by specific weather or climate forecasts and biophysical indicators predicting and/or indicating drought events. If such events materialise and no proper actions are in place, they have a high likelihood of generating a humanitarian crisis. Humanitarian crises can be avoided or minimised by the joint and timely action of the Government of Kenya at National and County level, communities at risk, stakeholders including the Kenya Red Cross Society (KRCS), United Nations Agencies, Non-Government Organisations (NGOs) and Development Partners. This EAP has been designed by KRCS in collaboration with the National Forecast-based Financing Technical Working Group (TWG) composed of key actors in disaster risk reduction (DRR) and disaster management (DM). All the stakeholders involved in this plan are members of the TWG and have a key role during the preparation and activation of EAP. The climate in Kenya ranges from tropical (in the coastal region) to arid (in the mountain regions). There are two main rainy seasons; the March-April-May (MAM) “long rains” season and the OctoberNovember-December (OND) “short rains” season. The occurrence of droughts in Kenya is not a rare event, since 80% of Kenya is composed of arid and semi-arid land (ASAL) with annual rainfall ranging from 200 to 500 mm resulting in periodical droughts that are part of the climate system. In the past, communities were able to cope with the periodic droughts and had developed resilience to drought events. However, local observers report that an intensification in both the length and severity of these events has been observed in the last few decades. This perception is confirmed by the Famine Early Warning Systems Network (FEWSNET) analysis that monitored and mapped rainfall trends over 50 3 years between 1960 and 2009 revealing that “long rains in central Kenya have declined by more than 100 millimetres since the mid-1970s” (FEWSNET 2010). Columbia University - International Research Institute for Climate and Society (IRI) data also affirms this decline in the long rains. Haile et al. (2019) reports that severe droughts have already hit the country (e.g. 2017) and over the recent years have become more frequent, long lasting and more severe. The impacts of drought are felt hardest in the agricultural sector which is the backbone of Kenya’s economy. Agriculture contributes to food security, employment and economic development of the country (e.g., ROK, 2010). According to UNDP (2012), the sector contributes 26% directly to the annual GDP and 26% indirectly through industries that feed from the sector such as wholesale, retail sales, agro-based manufacturing and transport. Further, it contributes 65% to total exports from the country and 16% to formal employment. The sector employs about 80% of the rural population (World Bank; CIAT. 2015) who rely on small-scale (3ha units) subsistence farming, livestock rearing and fishing (IFAD 2019). With regards to historical drought impacts recorded in Kenya between 1973 and 2022, food insecurity, loss of livelihood, crop failure, disease outbreak, disruption of education, water scarcity, increased cattle rustling, and conflicts are the most reported impacts (Figure 1). The magnitude of these impacts have been found to vary across different counties in Kenya. From the analysis, high drought risk was in the Northern Kenya Counties of Turkana, Marsabit, Samburu,West pokot, Wajir, Mandera and Tana River. Other Counties in eastern and southern Kenya with relatively high risk includeNarok, Makueni and Kwale.

name: CHL: Incendio - 2023-02 - Incendio Forestal Ñuble
summary:
Pasadas las 21:00 del dia miercoles 01 de febrero 2023, inicia un incendio forestal en la comuna de chillan viejo region del ÑUBLE emitiendo desde SENAPRED alerta amarilla. A las 22:00 hrs se actualiza pasando a alerta roja y 23:27 solicitando la evacuacion de Villa Jerusalen.

En el sector caserios de linares ya se encuentra una vivienda afectada, y se mantienen 2 bomberos lesionados.

Actualmente se mantiene focos activos en el incendio en combate, y se mantiene a la espera de los datos de afectacion en la zona.

name: CHL: Incendio - 2023-02 - Incendios Forestales Zona Centro-Sur
summary:
Pasadas las 21:00 del miércoles 01 de febrero 2023, inicia un incendio forestal en la comuna de chillan viejo región del ÑUBLE emitiendo desde SENAPRED alerta amarilla. A las 22:00 hrs se actualiza pasando a alerta roja y 23:27 solicitando la evacuación de Villa Jerusalén. Frente a este siniestro, se encuentran más sectores afectados:

 REGION DE MAULE

-          Se mantiene alerta amarilla para la comuna de Longavi y Alerta Roja para las comunas de Cauquenes y Chanco.

-          Se mantienen focos activos en combate sin afectación reportada por la autoridad, Además, Incendio presenta amenazas a viviendas en la comuna de Cauquenes

REGION DE ÑUBLE

-          Se declara Alerta Roja Regional y Estado de Catástrofe, Además, se mantienen alerta roja para las comunas de Quirihue, Coelemu, Quillón, Chillan, Chillan Viejo, Ranquil, Nilhue

-          Se mantienen diversos focos activos y existe una amenaza a la población en las comunas de Chillan, Chillan Viejo, Quirihue, Quillón y Coelemu. Además, se ha evacuado diversos sectores de la región donde se reportan viviendas dañadas con levantamiento de información pendiente.

 REGION DEL BIOBIO

-          Se declara alerta roja regional y Estado de Catástrofe, Además, se mantiene alerta amarilla para las comunas de Hualqui y Chiguayante y Alerta roja para las comunas de Santa Juana, Nacimiento, Los Ángeles, Florida, Penco, Tome, Arauco, Yumbel.

-          Se mantiene focos activos y se realizo evacuación de sectores poblados en riesgo, Además, se reportan viviendas dañadas con levantamiento de información pendiente.

-          Se cierra ruta Itata por peligro de fuego en peaje Agua Amarilla.

 REGION DE LA ARAUCANIA

-          Se declara alerta roja regional y se mantiene alerta amarilla para las comunas de Galvarino y alerta roja para las comunas de Puren, Lumaco, Traiguen, Vilcun y Curarehue.

-          Se mantiene focos activos y se realizó evacuación de sectores poblados en riesgo, Además, se reportan viviendas dañadas con levantamiento de información pendiente.

 REGION DE LOS RIOS

-          Región se encuentra en Alerta Preventiva por altas temperaturas con peak de hasta 39°C.

-          Actualmente sin incendios forestales en combate.

 REGION DE LOS LAGOS.

-          Se declara Alerta Amarilla regional y mantiene alerta amarilla para la comuna de Castro.

Según ultimo reporte de CONAF, Se mantienen 184 Incendios Forestales en Combate.

countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Islamic Republic of Iran
name: IRN: Earthquake - 2023-01 - Safa EQ West Azarbayejan 2023
summary: According to national seismological report, an earthquake of 5.9 magnitudes on the richter scale occurred at a depth of 7 kilometers in the area of Safa  10 Km to Khoy.. 3 death and 500 casualties have been reported so far.261.378 (77.920) are living in the affected regions. 2 cities and 86 villages.

name: NPL: Earthquake - 2023-01 - Nepal Bajura Earthquake 2023
summary:
At 2.43 PM on 24 January 2023, a 5.9 magnitude earthquake with an epicenter occurred in the Himali Rural Municipality of Bajura district from Sudurpaschim province according to National Earthquake Monitoring and Research Centre. According to Nepal Government authorities, one person was reported dead, three others injured and up to 42 households were damaged after an earthquake struck, with authorities still searching for damage. In addition, the shock of the earthquake was felt more in the hilly districts of the region and damaged 11 households in the adjoining Bhajhang district. People have come out of their houses after the earthquake and are taking temporary shelters with their relatives.

 

Likewise, District Disaster Management Committee (DDMC) had a quick meeting and requested 200 tarpaulins, 300 blankets, and mattresses with the NRCS Bajura district chapter to provide immediate relief support to the affected families.

name: ZMB: Flood
summary: On 22 January 2023, the Zambia Red Cross Society (ZRCS) received an alert on the Impact Based Forecasting (IBF) and Global Flood Awareness System (GloFAS). The system is able to detect riverine flooding and its connecting to water gauge stations managed by Water Resource Management Authority (WARMA) on water bodies across the country. The trigger statement indicates that the flood will be 20 years return flood, 7 days lead time, above 1000 HH and 100% threshold in the IBF and GloFAS. The early action activities will be implemented in 7 days. According to the system, there is a likelihood to experience floods in 10 districts across the country and potentially affecting a total of 100,264 people (16,712 Households). The IBF portal has pinpointed Kitwe district in the Copper Belt Province as likely to record the highest impact, estimated at 16,468 people, or 2,745 households. The anticipated floods are likely to occur on 28 January 2023. Photo of tiggered Impact Based Forecasting portal showing triggered stations and ZRCS Branches- 23rd January 2023, Credit: ZRCS and 510. EAP Activation Notification Zambia: Floods P a g e | 2 Public From the time the alert was received, the FBF Technical Working Group on Anticipatory Actions held a meeting to evaluate the situation and agreed to activate the EAP. The Government through DMMU and ZRCS Kitwe Branch is already in Kitwe district conducting some early warming information dissemination in high-risk communities through local radio stations. The government also broadcasted some mass SMS to the resident of Kitwe alerting them on the anticipated floods.

name: URUGUAY: Drought
summary:
La falta de lluvias registradas desde septiembre del 2022 ha provocado una reducción significativa en la disponibilidad y acceso al agua en el país, que a su vez se ha visto afectada por la presencia del fenómeno de La Niña en la región y el aumento de las temperaturas dentro de las épocas del año estivales. El viernes 20 de enero de 2023, el Estado uruguayo, a través del Sistema Nacional de Emergencias (SINAE), extendió una solicitud formal a la Cruz Roja Uruguaya para brindar apoyo en la evaluación de necesidades y posible respuesta a las consecuencias de las sequías.

 

Esta sequía afecta a todo el país, siendo los departamentos más afectados Tacuarembó, Cerro Largo, Florida, Lavalleja y San José. Adicionalmente, de acuerdo con la información proporcionada por el Sistema Nacional de Emergencia (SINAE), la situación más compleja está relacionada con la falta de acceso a agua segura que limita a las familias ante el consumo y uso del agua habitual, así como el mantenimiento de cultivos y ganado de aproximadamente 20,000 personas en todo el país.

 

En octubre de 2022, el gobierno nacional, a través del Ministerio de Agricultura, Ganadería y Pesca (MGAP) declaró el estado de emergencia agropecuaria por un período de 90 días para todo el país. En enero de 2023, el estado de emergencia se prorrogó hasta fines de abril y se amplió al ámbito de la ganadería, lechería, fruticultura y/o horticultura, agricultura, avicultura, apicultura y forestación1 Durante la temporada de verano (diciembre, enero y febrero) la media de precipitaciones fue de 126,4 mm, 225.4 mm por debajo del valor medio para el periodo de referencia. El verano en curso ha sido el más seco de los últimos 42 años de los que se tiene registro.

 

De acuerdo con información divulgada por el Instituto Nacional de Meteorología (INUMET), todo el país se encuentra actualmente afectado por sequías con 20.51% del territorio, equivalente a 3,623,300 hectáreas, reportadas bajo sequía extrema. En todo el territorio nacional, las precipitaciones no han superado los 10 mm, salvo en algunas zonas excepcionales del este y noreste del país. Por otra parte, el INUMET emitió un comunicado de prensa en el que pronosticó que las lluvias acumuladas esperadas de diciembre de 2022 a febrero de 2023 estarían por debajo de lo normal. Al mismo tiempo, se pronostica que las temperaturas medias trimestrales estarán por encima de lo normal en la mayor parte del país, con una probabilidad de ubicarse en el tercil superior del 45%.

 

 

 

Diferentes actores clave se encuentran realizando declaraciones y divulgando información sobre el impacto de la sequía. A finales de febrero la Asociación Rural del Uruguay (ARU) aseguró que las pérdidas en cultivos de soja y maíz son irrecuperables y se afectará la producción incluso hasta 2026. Desde la asociación afirman que las afectaciones con más impactos están relacionadas con los servicios ganaderos, por lo que habrá menos pariciones que generaran un gran impacto en la disponibilidad de comida para animales (faena) para el 2025 y 2026.

 

Por otro lado, el presidente de la República afirma que la situación es compleja y si bien en algunas zonas puntuales llovió, las consecuencias y pérdidas en la producción, en la economía, en el trabajo y en los ingresos del país no se recuperarán. Según informa la Unidad Agroalimentaria Metropolitana, a consecuencia de los escases de lluvia, los precios de tomate, lechuga, zanahoria, pepino y sandía se han incrementado en un 40%, mientras que el precio del resto de frutas y verduras sufrieron un incremento promedio del 10%. Durante el 2022, los precios de la canasta de frutas y verduras se mantuvieron entre 30 y 45 pesos por kilo, actualmente alcanza a casi 55 pesos el kilo2

 

Por su parte, Obras Sanitarias del Estado (OSE) publicó el pasado 8 de marzo un nuevo estado de situación sobre el déficit hídrico, donde se informa que la sequía que afecta a todo el territorio nacional está provocando un continuo descenso de los embalses y cursos de agua que se utilizan como fuente de abastecimiento a la población. En este contexto, el directorio del ente resolvió prohibir el uso de agua potable para fines no prioritarios. 

 

Tras el proceso de evaluación, Cruz Roja Uruguaya definió las líneas de acción para brindar respuesta en coordinación con el Sistema Nacional de Emergencia, de manera de no duplicar esfuerzos y maximizar el alcance de las acciones

name: NGA: Epidemic - 2023-01 - NIGERIA: Diptheria Outbreak
summary:
The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control and Prevention (NCDC) has confirmed reports of diphtheria cases in Lagos, Osun, Kano and Yobe States. In addition to clinically suspected cases, there have been laboratory-confirmed cases and the Nigerian Red Cross Society is working closely with the NCDC, State Ministries of Health and partners to enhance surveillance and response to the outbreak.

Diphtheria is a severe bacterial disease caused by the bacterium Corynebacterium species, mainly by toxin-producing Corynebacterium diphtheriae and rarely by toxin-producing strains of C. ulcerans and C. pseudotuberculosis. It manifests as laryngitis, pharyngitis or tonsillitis and is associated with the presence of an adherent membrane covering the tonsils, pharynx and/or nose. Beyond the respiratory symptoms, approximately a quarter of cases may develop heart problems (myocarditis). The mainstay of Diphtheria treatment is antibiotics and Diphtheria antitoxin (DAT).

As at the time of this report, Kano State has the highest number of 100 cases and 32 deaths, followed by Lagos State with five recorded confirmed cases and three deaths, Yobe has 17 confirmed cases and three deaths and Osun State with one confirmed case with no death recorded. According to the Director General of NCDC, Given the sub-optimal coverage for the third dose of diphtheria containing pentavalent vaccine (54% – 2021 Nigeria Immunization Coverage Survey) in the country, we expect more cases from more states.

The most common type of diphtheria is classic respiratory diphtheria. The onset of signs and symptoms is usually from 2 – 5 days (could be as high as 10 days) after exposure. Initial symptoms may be mild and include fever, runny nose, sore throat, cough, and red eyes (conjunctivitis). In severe cases, the bacteria produce an exotoxin that causes a thick grey or white patch (pseudo-membrane) on the tonsils and/or at the back of the throat. This can block the airway making it hard to breathe or swallow and causing a barking cough. The neck may swell in part due to enlarged lymph nodes and may frequently confer a bull-neck appearance.

To reduce the risk of diphtheria, the NCDC has published a Public Health Advisory which offers the key messages and health advice to healthcare workers and the general public.
The NRCS Health team are coordinating with the Incident manager at NCDC for more updates, while the state teams are actively participating in the coordination meetings at the Emergency Operations Centre (EOC).

name: SRB: Flood - 2023-01 - Serbia January Floods 2023
summary: In the last several days municipalities in the western, southwestern, municipalities in provinces of Kosovo and Metohija, and southern parts of the Republic of Serbia were affected by heavy rainfalls that caused the filling of river beds in these areas. Municipalities Sjenica, Novi Pazar, Lucani, Brus, Aleksandrovac, Prijepolje, Priboj, Zubin Potok, Zvecan, Istok, Klina, Srbica, Leposavic in this area were affected by overflowing of the river from its bed and flash floods. Municipalities Lucani, Brus, Aleksandrovac, Priboj, Prijepolje, Novi Pazar, Prokuplje, and Kursumlija till now declared an emergency situation. In total, more than 3.000 people are affected by this event. Due to heavy rainfalls lands slides were also activated, making traffic difficult and not roads not usable.

countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Islamic Republic of Iran
name: IRN: Earthquake - 2023-01 - western Azarbaijan
summary: according to relief and rescue, organization reports a 5.9 Richter occurred at 13:19 P.M 18 January in western Azerbaijan,Khoy and Zar abad are the most eaffected areas. the assesments are going to be continued.

name: GIN: Epidemic - 2023-01 - Yellow Fever
summary: On Monday, January 16, 2023, a suspected case of yellow fever was reported in the village of Konsondou, sub-District of Bissikrima, District of Dabola. The patient was received for fever, headache, vomiting, and jaundice. In the history of the disease, the parents thought of simple malaria by self-medicating based on initial symptoms. Given the persistence of these symptoms, the parent was taken to consult the prefectural hospital of Dabola for better care. From observed symptoms and high fever, a sample was taken from this patient and sent to the virology center in Conakry for examination. Following laboratory investigation, it was confirmed to be a positive yellow fever case. A second test was carried out on the sample sent to the Virology Laboratory of the Institute Pasteur in Dakar / Senegal was also positive, thus confirming yellow fever. The Government through the ministry of health on Tuesday, January 17, 2023, declared a yellow fever outbreak in Dabola district of Guinea. At the epidemiological level, there is no notification of travel outside the prefecture according to the parents.

name: ISR: Complex Emergency - 2023-01 - Jerusalem terror incidents and rocket attack in the south of the country
summary:
On January 27 early morning 6 rockets were fired from the Gaza strip towards cities and villages in Israel. There were no casualties following the launches.

On January 27 at 20:15, MDA 101 Dispatch Center received several reports about a number of people injured from gunshots, next to a synagogue at the Neeve Ya'akov Blvd in Jerusalem. In this terror attack, 7 people were killed (5 males and 2 women) and 3 injured (2 males and a woman) 1 in moderate to severe condition and 2 in moderate condition.

On the following morning, MDA teams were called to another shooting incident in David's City in the old city of Jerusalem, where two men were shot and injured, one in severe condition and the other in moderate condition. They were treated and transported to hospitals.

name: GMB: Population Movement - 2023-01 - Population Movement in Cassamance and Foni - Senegal Soldiers and Rebels Military Tensions
summary:
It was exactly a year ago when clashes between the MFDC (Separatist Movement) and the Senegalese Soldiers began. Affected families, then, were temporarily resettled for a couple of months in Gambia villages within the West Coast Region.

 On Sunday 15 January 2023, fighting between the same actors rejuvenated in the same Casamance Region of Senegal with roaring of loud and heavy artillery from the affected region.  One Isatou Gibba a refugee/IDP herself, from the Cassamance of Kallachai, speaking by telephone to the Disaster Management Unit confirmed the ongoing event in the region,  and that she is temporarily seeking  refuge in Kusamai Village, Foni District, The Gambia.

The affected families are from the villages of  Kalachai, Kajaluk and Kayeng and Faraba in the Casamance Region are being hosted by families the Gambia. Some Gambian families closer to the border have started moving as well to safe places.

This  information is reported and confirmed by Emergence Response Team (ERT) members who are also Red Cross Youth authorities, as well as some heads of affected villages such as the Kampati and Gifanga, Foni District.

name: BOL: Epidemic - 2023-01 - Bolivia Epidemia por DENGUE 2023
summary:
La situación va con un pronostico de crecida de casos, mas allá de las campañas ya realizadas para el control de vectores con el rociado de biolarvicidas y las campañas de eliminación de criaderos. los números de casos continúan en incremento y corresponde a la gestión con el mayor número de casos acumulados en comparación a gestión pasadas. 
Con ello se tiene en cuenta que por la variante reportada, los casos tienden a ser graves sin distinción de edades, genero o condición física. pero si es de importancia mencionar que los niños son los que tienen una menor respuesta a los casos y ya se cuenta con un porcentaje de interrelación de 90 a 95% de camas ocupadas. 
Sumado a todo ello esta el inicio de actividades escolares que incrementa el número de personas susceptibles a ser picadas por el mosquito transmisor de la enfermedad, así como otras enfermedades como ser Zika y Chikungunya.

name: GTM: Earthquake - 2023-01 - Sismos Sensibles en Guatemala y El Salvador
summary:
Un sismo ocurrió el 15 de enero a las 17:07 horas local, el cual, según las autoridades, ha provocado más de 60 réplicas sensibles y no sensibles.

Algunas viviendas de Jalapa, frontera con El Salvador, presentan daños en sus estructuras. No hay reportes de personas heridas o fallecidas.

name: GTM: Terremoto - 2023-01 - Enjambre Sísmico Fronterizo entre Guatemala y El Salvador
summary:
De acuerdo al boletín sismológico de las 07:00 horas local, del lunes 16 de enero de 2023, el Insivumeh informa que, luego del sismo registrado el 15 de enero de 2023 a las 17:07 horas, al menos 108 sismos se han registrado en la región fronteriza con El Salvador, con epicentro en Jutiapa, 4 de ellos sensibles, con profundidad de entre 1.1 y 7.8 metros. 
La Coordinadora Nacional para la Reducción de Desastres (Conred) informó en sus redes sociales de daños en viviendas en el departamento de Jutiapa. Es por ello que han publicado los avisos 1 y 2, dirigidos a las autoridadades y a la población, alertando sobre la situación sísmica.

name: SLV: Terremoto - 2023-01 - San Lorenzo, Ahuachapan , EL SALVADOR
summary: Desde el dia 15 de Enero se han desarrollado un total de 562 sismos en el muicipio de San Lorenzo en el Departamento de Ahuachapan en El Salvador, hasta el momento las autoridades de proteccion civil tienen identificadas 677 familias afectadas de las cuales 433 se han desplazado a albergues temporales mientras se normaliza la situacion, actualmente Cruz roja Salvadoreña en apoyo al Sistema Nacional de Proteccion Civil se encuantra en la zona en catividades de monitoreo y evacuacion.

name: GNB: Fire - 2023-01 - Menegue Fire Incident
summary:
A fire disaster on January 14, 2023, broke out in Menegue Village close to Canhabaque that burnt down 44 houses covered with straw. Menegue Village is an island of the Bijagós archipelago, off the west coast of Africa, with an area of 111 km². The origin of the fire was a result of an explosion of an overload solar battery used to provide electricity. Menegue village lacks public electricity, relying on batteries and solar panels for charging phones and providing electricity. Due to farming activities and other traditional practices, adults do not stay at home during the day, leaving teenagers, young people, and the aged with little or no knowledge to properly handle the batteries and panels that provide electricity.  While the detailed assessment will provide additional information, inhabitants of the village have associated the cause of the explosion with a poor connection of battery terminals leading to the battery being heated up to dangerous temperatures, hot enough to cause fires and explosions.
