countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Republic of Kazakhstan
name: KAZ: Fire - 2022-09 - Wildfire
summary:
02.09. at 15-10 on the territory of the Basmansky, Semiozerny forestry farms of the Auliekolsky district of the Kostanay region, trees and dry grass caught fire. 

03.09 due to the complication of the meteorological situation, including a high air temperature of 36 degrees, storm gusts of wind up to 23 m / s, the fire area exceeded 9,400 hectares.

There was a threat to settlements , therefore , the evacuation of 1,841 people from the village was carried out . Ozernoye (250 people) and the northern part of Amankaragai village (1000 people), Kalinino village (228 people), Lesnoye village (363 people).

The evacuees were placed in the Auliekol secondary school and the Auliekol boarding school provided them with food.

A hotline of the Ministry of Emergency Situations has been opened, the work of psychologists of the Ministry of Emergency Situations and Emergency Situations of Kostanay region has been organized.

Akimat of Kostanay region is working on the issue of declaring a local emergency. 

Starting from 16.00 on 09/3/2022 , the transition of the fire to residential buildings was registered . Ozernoye (8 residential buildings, 1 administrative building),

Lesnoye village (1 residential building), Amankaragai village (98 residential buildings and outbuildings), the territory of the Amankaragai oil depot as a result, 108 buildings were destroyed and damaged by fire.

name: BGR: Flood - 2022-09 - Plovdiv Floods
summary:
Heavy storm and rains on 22 and 23 in August 2022 flooded the towns of Karlovo and Sopot, located in Central South Bulgaria, in the region of Plovdiv and caused serious damage on public infrastructure – bridges, buildings and roads, interruption of power and water supply, flooding dozens of houses, sweeping away vehicles and bringing massive amounts of debris.

While recovery of these affected areas in the region carried out by the local authorities was still underway, intense rain on September 2, 2022 caused heavy flooding in several more villages located west of the town of Karlovo and affected also other municipalities. The three most affected municipalities are Karlovo, Kaloyanovo and Maritsa.

Residential and commercial buildings, industrial enterprises were flooded, bridges and roads were damaged, rocks and mud were dragged into many villages within these three municipalities. The most affected are the villages of Karavelovo, Bogdan and Slatina in Karlovo municipality. Minimum 1920 people are affected, with needs assessments going on. Damages are roughly estimated at 60 million BGN (approx. 30 million EUR).

Running water could be available in some areas but not suitable for drinking. Emergency state was declared in several villages of Kaloyanovo municipality, where bridges, roads and houses were destroyed or severly affected by the floods and families were evacuated from their homes.

name: BEN: Inondation - 2022-08 - Inondation 2022
summary:
De fortes précipitations ont causé une montée des eaux au Bénin et des inondations dans plusieurs villes du pays. La cellule de prévision et d’alerte actualise chaque jour son bulletin avec des niveaux de relevés d’eau qui inquiètent. Lundi, le ministre de l’Intérieur a publié un communiqué de sensibilisation contre l’imprudence et des comportements à risque. Les premières alertes ont été signalées un peu après la mi-août.

L’eau est montée dans les bassins des fleuves jusqu’à 9 mètres, c’est le pic enregistré à Zagnanado à 170 kilomètres au nord de Cotonou.

À une centaine de kilomètres de là, toujours au centre du pays, le maire d’une commune a signalé une cinquantaine de cases balayées par les eaux faisant de nombreux sans-abris. Des planteurs ont perdu plusieurs hectares de leurs récoltes, plusieurs pistes menant dans les champs sont inaccessibles, elles sont englouties par les eaux.

Une route importante qui dessert Nikki et N’Dali, deux villes majeures du nord, est coupée, camions, véhicules et motos sont bloqués. Toujours au nord, il est difficile de traverser le pont du fleuve Okpara, six motocyclistes qui l’empruntaient ont vu leurs motos emportées par les eaux

La cellule d’alerte agite pour l’instant le drapeau orange mais le ministre de l’Intérieur prévient que l’alerte peut rapidement virer au rouge. Alassane Seidou interdit le transport fluvial nocturne, les barques surchargées et demande de quitter les maisons menacées de ruine.

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: COD: Épidémie - 2022-08 - L'épidémie de méningite dans le territoire de Banalia,  province de Tshope /RDC
summary:
La zone de santé de Banalia dans Territoire de Banalia province de Tshopo connaît une recrudescence de la méningite depuis la semaine 34 dans l’aire de santé de MANGI. 

Durant les quatre derniers mois de 2021,  la méningite a fait plus de 200 décès, sur plus de mille  cas notifiés.  L’épidémie avait été maîtrisée grâce à l’implication du  gouvernement de la République et ses partenaires dont la Croix-Rouge de la RDC. Jusqu’à la semaine 35, plus de 41 cas sont enregistrés dans l’aire de santé de MANGI, dont 11 décès. Pour rappel, cette aire de santé était parmi celles qui avaient enregistré beaucoup plus des cas, soit deuxième derrière PANGA.

name: BEN: Inondation - 2022-08 - BEN: Inondation 2022
summary:
De fortes précipitations ont augmenté une montée des eaux au Bénin et des inondations dans plusieurs villes du pays. La cellule de prévision et d'alerte actualise chaque jour son bulletin avec des niveaux de relevés d'eau qui inquiètent. Lundi, le ministre de l'Intérieur a publié un communiqué de sensibilisation contre l'imprudence et des comportements à risque. Les premières alertes ont été signalées un peu après la mi-août.

L'eau est montée dans les bassins des fleuves jusqu'à 9 mètres, c'est le pic enregistré à Zagnanado à 170 kilomètres au nord de Cotonou.

À une centaine de kilomètres de là, toujours au centre du pays, le maire d'une commune a signalé une cinquantaine de cas balayés par les eaux faisant de nombreux sans-abris. Des planteurs ont perdu plusieurs hectares de leurs récoltes, plusieurs pistes menant dans les champs sont inaccessibles, elles sont englouties par les eaux.

Une route importante qui dessert Nikki et N'Dali, deux villes majeures du nord, est coupée, camions, véhicules et motos sont bloqués. Toujours au nord, il est difficile de traverser le pont du fleuve Okpara, six motocyclistes qui l'empruntaient ont vu leurs motos emportées par les eaux

La cellule d'alerte agit pour l'instant le drapeau orange mais le ministre de l'Intérieur prévient que l'alerte peut rapidement virer au rouge. Alassane Seidou interdit le transport fluvial nocturne, les barques surchargées et demande de quitter les maisons menacées de ruine.

name: GTM: Population Movement - 2022-08 - Alerta por crisis de movilidad humana
summary: Ante el incremento de flujos mixtos masivos de las personas en movimiento durante los últimos meses y aumentado las demandas de servicios humanitarios como la necesidad de expandir nuevos  puntos en el del país,  la Sociedad Nacional actualmente implementa sus acciones de atención humanitaria: atención prehospitalaria, agua segura, apoyo psicosocial, merienda, protección, derivaciones seguras, entrega de kits diferenciados, mapas orientativos, Restablecimiento del Contacto entre Familiares (RCF), entre otros; en 7 Puntos de Servicios Humanitarios (PSH), distribuidos en cuatro rutas migratorias que forman parte del corredor migratorio y zonas de frontera. Con este llamamiento se tiene planificado realizar las intervenciones con 51,425, en coordinación con socios, comunidades de tránsito y receptoras temporales de población migrante en las zonas de intervención. Asimismo, en los Puntos de Servicios Humanitarios (PSH) y en las atenciones móviles a lo largo de las rutas migratorias, se fortalecerá la atención tomando como base las Normas Mínimas de Protección, Género e Inclusión, para garantizar un enfoque centrado en las personas, en línea con la práctica y los compromisos de la FICR.

name: Uganda : Floods 2022
summary:
On 30th July 2022, eastern Uganda received 10 hours of continuous heavy rains in the Elgon region causing floods in the districts of Mbale, Kapchorwa, Bulambuli, Bukedea, Butaleja Sironko and landslides in Bududa.  

 

The flooding led to the loss of 21 lives in Mbale and 3 lives in Kapchorwa districts respectively with an unknown number of livestock lost. Further, the flooding left a trail of destruction to homesteads, schools, government and social institutions, damage to vehicles and displacement of thousands of people from their homes. Those displaced populations are currently in host families within safer zones in the neighbourhood while others are currently living at established temporary internally displaced persons camps in nearby primary schools. Bridges have been cut off and roads filled with debris limiting the delivery of needed humanitarian assistance and effective search and rescue.  Four health centres have been submerged while the remaining ones are not accessible, and people travel long distances to access health care.  

 

Combined with search and rescue, rapid assessments have been conducted revealing the extent of the flooding with some parts of Bududa district facing landslides.   

The weather forecast by the Uganda National Meteorological Authority (UNMA) for the Elgon region for the month of August 2022 has projected enhanced rains for the region with the possibility for the flooding challenges to continue.  

 

In recent years, flood disaster occurrences in Uganda have become more frequent, particularly in the low-lying and built-up urban areas in the Eastern and South-western regions as well as in the areas near major water bodies of Lake Victoria, Lake Kyoga and Lake Albert that were affected by flash-floods due to rising water levels. These flood events are causing more devastating effects. The high concentration of people in large cities is promoting the uncontrolled expansion of construction. Generally, June, July and August are the wettest months in Uganda, and the situation is expected to worsen as the rainy season continues until the end of August 2022.

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: COD: Inondation - 2022-08 - Les inondations dans les provinces des Maniema, Sud-Ubangi et Haut-Uele
summary:
La République Démocratique du Congo à deux saisons à savoir : la saison de pluie et la saison  sèche dans sa partie de l’est  nous entamons la période de pluies depuis le mois d’aout 2022. De fortes pluies ont affecté trois provinces du l’est, la province du Sud-Ubangi dans la ville de Zongo, la province de Manieme dans le territoire de Lubutu et la province du Haut-Uele dans la ville d’Isiro. Ces pluies ont occasionné la montée des eaux des différentes rivières qui traverse ses zones depuis le 8 aout 2022 et cette montée des eaux progresse jusqu’à ce jour
Plus de 622 184 personnes reparties de manière suivant : la province du Sud-Ubangi dans la ville de Zongo 611 915 personnes, la province de Manieme dans le territoire de Lubutu 6634 personnes et la province du Haut-Uele dans la ville d’Isiro 3635 peronnes ont été touchées depuis le début  du mois aout. Toutefois, des pertes de vies humaines, des biens matériels  et des maisons détruites totalement et partiellement ont été signalées. D’autres estiment que leurs stocks de denrées alimentaires et biens matériels auraient été emportés par les eaux.
La CRRDC a été informée ce jour, à travers ses comités provinciaux de trois provinces qui ont menées la première évaluation. Les volontaires ont été  déployés  sur le terrain pour une réponse rapide en le premier secours,  l’évacuation et  une évaluation rapide de la situation des personnes affectées.

name: PHL: Cyclone - 2022-08 - Ma-on (Florita)
summary:
At 8:00 AM of August 21, 2022, the low pressure area east of Northern Luzon developed into a tropical depression locally named “Florita” by the State Weather Bureau. As of 8 AM of Augsust 23, STS Florita accelerates North Northwestward and is now over the coastal waters of Palanan, Isabela with a maximum sustained winds of 95 km/h near the center with the gustiness of up to 115 km/h, and central pressure of 992 hPa.

 

TCWS No. 3: The southern portion of Babuyan Islands (Camiguin Is., Fuga Is., Dalupiri Is.), the northern and eastern portion of mainland Cagayan (Santa Praxedes, Claveria, Sanchez-Mira, Pamplona, Abulug, Ballesteros, Aparri, Buguey, Camalaniugan, Santa Teresita, Santa Ana, Gonzaga, LalLo, Gattaran, Baggao, Peñablanca) and the eastern portion of Isabela (Maconacon, Divilacan, Palanan)

TCWS No. 2 : The rest of mainland Cagayan, the rest of Babuyan Islands, the rest of Isabela, Quirino, the northern and eastern portion of Nueva Vizcaya (Quezon, Diadi, Bagabag, Villaverde, Solano, Kasibu), Apayao, Abra, Kalinga, Mountain Province, Ifugao, the northern portion of Benguet (Buguias, Bakun, Mankayan, Kibungan), Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, and the northern portion of Aurora (Dilasag, Casiguran, Dinalungan, Dipaculao)

TCWS No. 1: Batanes, the rest of Nueva Vizcaya, the rest of Benguet, La Union, Pangasinan, the eastern portion of Tarlac (San Clemente, Camiling, Moncada, San Manuel, Anao, Santa Ignacia, Gerona, Paniqui, Ramos, Pura, Victoria, La Paz, City of Tarlac, Concepcion), Nueva Ecija, the rest of Aurora, the eastern portion of Pampanga (Magalang, Arayat, Candaba), the eastern portion of Bulacan (San Ildefonso, San Miguel, Doña Remedios Trinidad, San Rafael, Angat, Norzagaray, City of San Jose del Monte), the eastern portion of Rizal (Rodriguez, San Mateo, City of Antipolo, Tanay, Baras), the northern portion of Quezon (General Nakar, Infanta, Real, Mauban, Perez, Alabat, Quezon, Calauag) including Polillo Islands, the northern portion of Laguna (Santa Maria, Famy, Siniloan, Pangil, Pakil, Paete), and Camarines Norte

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: COD: Inondation - 2022-08 - Les inondations dans le territoire rural de Lubutu province de Maniema
summary:
Les pluies diluviennes qui  sont abattues depuis le 15 octobre 2022 et se poursuivis jusqu’à au  mercredi  17 octobre 2022, dans la commune rurale de Lubutu   et ses environs dans le territoire Lubutu, province de Manieme, ont causé des dégâts matériels et ont provoqué le déplacement de la population.

Le territoire de Lubutu qui est l’un de sept de territoires de la province de  Maniema (au nord Maniema) avec une population totale de 611915 habitats sur une superficie de 16055 km². Limité à l’est par le territoire de walikale de la province du Nord-Kivu traverse la rivière oso, au sud par le territoire de Punia qui est traverse par la rivière yumbi, à l’ouest par le territoire d’ubundu de la province de Tshopo qui est traverse par la rivière Ayane et au nord par le territoire de Bafasende de la province de Tshopo traverse par la rivière Maiko.

Silonns que la commune rurale de Lubutu se trouve au milieu des rivières lubilinga, kalibatete, nyafanza, ndeka et moyo.

Population vit dans les familles d’accueil et dans les écoles de la place

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: COD: Incendie - 2022-08 - Epidémie Ebola à Beni
summary:
Le lundi 15 août 2022, le laboratoire mobile de Beni de l'Institut National de Recherche Biomédicale (INRB) a reçu un échantillon de sécrétion oropharyngée prélevé sur un patient décédé qui était pris en charge à l'Hôpital Général de Référence de Beni (HGR-Beni). L’échantillon a été testé positif pour le virus Ebola (EBOV) à l'aide du test Cepheid Xpert Ebola avec des valeurs ct de 32,5 pour la glycoprotéine virale (GP) et de 28,2 pour la nucléoprotéine virale (NP). Pour contrôle qualité et confirmation, des prélèvements ont été envoyés au Laboratoire Rodolphe Mérieux INRB-Goma le mardi 16 août 2022, où l'analyse a confirmé le cas de MVE.
 
La patiente a été admise le 23 juillet 2022 au service de médecine interne de l'HGR-Beni pour toux, céphalées, polyarthralgies, asthénie physique intense remontant à plusieurs jours et pour lesquelles elle s'était automédicamentée avec des médicaments non précisés. Elle était séropositive sous traitement antirétroviral et elle avait également présenté une tuberculose pour laquelle elle recevait un traitement antituberculeux.  Le 13 août 2022, son état de santé s'est détérioré avec l'apparition d'une congestion bronchique et d'une insuffisance rénale, ce qui a incité son transfert aux soins intensifs pour une meilleure prise en charge. Elle est décédée le 15 août 2022. Au total, son hospitalisation a duré 23 jours..

name: CUB: Chemical Emergency - 2022-08 - Fuel tanks catch fire at Oil Terminal in Matanzas
summary:
REPORTE PRELIMINAR SOBRE TRABAJO DE LA SOCIEDAD NACIONAL CUBANA DE LA CRUZ ROJA  EN EL EVENTO DE INCENDIO DE GRAN MAGNITUD EN LA BASE DE SUPERTANQUEROS EL DIA 6 DE AGOSTO DEL 2022. 

 En horas de la tarde noche del día 5 de agosto un rayo impacto sobre un tanque de combustible de la base de súper tanquero de la zona industrial de Matanzas causando un incendio de grandes proporciones.

De  inmediato se presentan en el lugar las fuerzas de bomberos y  defensa civil y el grupo provincial Especializado de  operación y socorro de la Cruz Roja de Matanzas .

Posteriormente se incorporaron voluntarios/as  del  grupo de socorristas de las Provincias de la Habana, Mayabeque y Artemisa .   

Los voluntarios/as han trabajado en acciones de socorrismo sacando las víctimas del aérea siniestrada, han realizado acciones de logística y traslado hacia las unidades de sistema integrado de urgencias médicas del Sistema Nacional de Salud.

Participaron en el traslado de los insumos médicos necesarios para la escena, han apoyado en los hospitales que recibieron a los lesionados y han realizado donaciones de sangre, para salvar vidas.

Desde el día 6-8-22 comenzamos labores de apoyo Psicológico y RCF tanto por parte de la Filial Provincial de Matanzas como la Filial Municipal de Cárdenas .

Hasta la fecha no se han realizado solicitudes de búsquedas, pero se brindaron los primeros auxilios psicológicos a choferes de CUPET que se encontraban en espera de evacuar combustibles, a los  familiares   de los diferentes trabajadores, de los  bomberos  y de los propios socorristas y de las personas afectadas directamente por el siniestro. Participaron junto a los expertos del grupo Nacional de Psicología en el lugar donde estaban concentrados los familiares brindando esta  colaboración.

Se activó la oficina de RCF de la Cruz Roja provincial de la Habana, para apoyar en  la información precisa y oportuna a los familiares de los lesionados que fueron trasladados para Unidades de salud de la Habana.

Esta operación se está desarrollando desde el día 5 hasta la fecha, 5 días de labor ininterrumpida y se mantiene las fuerzas en el terreno, han participado un total de 103 voluntarios /as de la Cruz Roja en diferentes acciones .

Se reportaron 4 lesionados voluntarios  de la Cruz Roja de Matanzas  con quemaduras leves sin criterio de ingreso hospitalario, se ha realizado acompañamiento a sus familiares.

El grupo de periodistas amigos de la cruz roja han estado desde los primeros momentos informando a través de la Televisión cubana y otros medios y las redes sociales toda la información necesaria relacionada con las acciones y la situación de los voluntarios /as que están participando en el operativo.

La TV Cubana ha transmitido información de las acciones de los rescatistas de la Cruz Roja, han sido entrevistados y han expresado su sentir ante esta situación de gran magnitud.

Mencionar el apoyo permanente de las autoridades del partido y del gobierno , asi como otros actores , para el buen desempeño de nuestros voluntarios/as en el terreno.

name: ISR: Complex Emergency - 2022-08 - Rocket attack on cities in Israel and escalation in tensions
summary:
On August 5, 2022, at around 21:00 (IDT) a rocket attack from Gaza was initiated resulting in a series of rocket alarms in cities in the south and the center of Israel.

Since August 5, 2022, at approximately 16:00 (IDT) a state of emergency has been declared by the authorities for the population of 80 km from the Gaza strip border. In addition, for the population of 40 km from the Gaza strip restrictions on gathering, workplaces, and educational activities are in place. Severe restrictions on the movement close to the border were applied two days earlier.

countries society-name: The Trinidad and Tobago Red Cross Society
name: TTO: Flood - 2022-08 - Potential Riverine Floods in Trinidad
summary: On Thursday 4th August 2022 at 5:00pm the Trinidad and Tobago Met Office issued a Riverine Flood Alert for Trinidad at a Yellow Alert Stage. For several days Trinidad and Tobago have been experiencing significant amounts of rainfall due to the passage of several tropical waves back to back. Water courses across the country are not getting an opportunity to drain out to sea due the amount of rainfall. Our major river, the Caroni River has been at threshold levels for some days. On Thursday afternoon there were reports that at one point along the Caroni River, farmers cut the embankment for access to water for farms and at this point, the river began to overtop its banks and was slowly flooding some streets within the Caroni community which was located approximately 1000 feet from the river bank. At 9pm approximately six residents in the area reported flood waters entering their property and homes. The Municipality deployed a vehicle with three small water pumps, which were not able to displace enough water. Around 2am on Friday 5th August, the Ministry of Work deployed a trailer mounter 12" pump which was able to slow the water from entering further in to the community, until more rains began to fall during the early morning hours. At 10pm we received media reports of several streets in Caroni being flooded with 6-8 inches of water as well as some homes having about 1 foot of water. Reports from the Disaster Management Unit indicate that there are about 30 possible homes that may have been affected, but detailed assessments are still underway. The Met Office has since discontinued the Riverine Flood Alert as waters begin to recede from all areas.

name: PSE: Complex Emergency - 2022-08 - Israeli Escalation against Gaza 2022 / AUGUST
summary:
The recent escalation of hostilities in Gaza started on Friday 5 August 2022 at around 16:00 hours Gaza time. Israel struck targets in Gaza including an extra-judicial killing among others which also resulted in the killing of a woman and a child and dozens of injuries. Before this apparently unprovoked strike against Gaza, Israel imposed a total siege on Gaza 4 days before this strike. It is worth noting that Gaza has remained under siege since 2007 with limited permits for people and goods.

The extent of damage and impact of this recent escalation is not yet clear nor how this escalation will develop in the coming days and weeks.

countries society-name: The Sri Lanka Red Cross Society
name: Sri Lanka: Extreme Weather
summary:
The Southwest monsoon activation has been intensifying rainfall in Sri Lanka from 1 to 8 August 2022, where the Northern, Central, Western, Southern and Sabaragamuwa provinces of Sri Lanka have been affected. Most damages were reported on 6 August, particularly in Kandy, Nuwara Eliya and Rathnapura districts due to heavy rains, high winds, floods and landslides.

According to the Department of Meteorology, massive rainfall of 243mm was reported in the Northern sub-district, the Nuwara Eliya, Nawalapitiya and Delthota sub-districts in the Kandy district (Central Province), where several landslides and rock falls damaged houses and blocked roads and railway line. Rainfall over 100mm was observed in the Rathnapura district (Sabaragamuwa province), and the districts of Kandy and Nuwara-Eliya (Central Province). Five deaths were reported while three people have been missing. Rescue teams were working around the clock despite heavy rains to recover the missing bodies.

The continuous heavy rains coupled with high winds over 50 km/hr have caused landslides, road embankment failures/cutting failures, floods, rock fall and fallen trees across various districts: Nuwara Eliya, Kandy and Matale (Central Province); Galle, Hambantota and Matara districts (Southern Province); Rathnapura and Kegalle districts (Sabaragamuwa Province); and Gampaha district (Western Province). Due to the severity of the situation, agricultural lands and standing crops were also damaged in low lying areas due to flooding while infrastructure and housing damages have also been reported.

According to the Disaster Management Centre (DMC) situation report, as of 8 August 2022, over 15,000 people (4,000 families)havebeenaffectedacrosstendistricts.Further, several landslides, rock falls, and collapse of retaining walls have been reported in the Nuwara Eliya and Kandy districts blocking the rail line and main roads at several places. A number of houses were affected due to flooding in Nuwara Eliya district. Flooding was also reported in the Rathnapura district, cutting off access roads at several places where people were stranded or had to wait until water levels recede. The DMC is coordinating the national response efforts.

Due to heavy rain, the existing water and sanitation facilities in the communities are affected and inundated, including the sewerage lines. Due to the impact of landslides, people living in low-lying areas have also lost their basic amenities at the household level. Initial reports from DMC and Divisional Secretariats reveal that there is a need for essential household items and there are challenges as transportation of goods to affected areas is disrupted due to road blockages as well as fuel shortages. In addition, households will require support to cover their immediate basic needs as the local employment opportunities have been reduced due to continuous rain and exacerbated by the current economic crisis that is continuously affecting the households’ economic condition. Overflow of water from several major dams in the central hills was reported, threatening downstream communities with the risk of flooding. The Department of irrigation has been monitoring the situation and as the heavy rains stopped on 8 August, currently there is no risk of downstream flooding.

name: TCD: Flood - 2022-08 - Inondations à Ndjaména et en provinces
TCD: Flood - 2022-08 - Pluies torrentielles et inondations à Ndjaména et en provinces
summary: Les précipitations qui s’abattent sur la plupart des provinces du Tchad depuis le début du mois d’août 2022 ont de nouveau déversé leurs eaux dans la nuit du 4 au 5 août. Ces pluies diluviennes qui rappellent la catastrophe de l’année 2020 ont déclenché depuis 3 jours, des inondations presque partout dans la capitale, avec des dégâts matériels énormes, en particulier dans les 6ème, 7ème, 8ème et 9ème arrondissements. Les quartiers les plus affectés à ce jour, sont ceux du 7ème et 9ème arrondissements. Des milliers de familles sont ont été touchées depuis le weekend dernier. En dehors chiffres parcellaires et non officiels qui circulent sur les réseaux sociaux, aucun rapport statistique précis n’a été rendu public par le gouvernement, ni par les organisations humanitaires. Toutefois, des pertes de vies humaines et des destructions d’habitats ont été signalées par certaines victimes. D’autres estiment que leurs stocks de denrées alimentaires et biens matériels auraient été emportés par les eaux. La Société nationale de la Croix-Rouge du Tchad) a été informée ce jour, à travers son comité provincial du Salamat que 250 ménages ont été sinistrés dans le village de Mouraye et 176 ménages sinistrés dans le village Amtiman, plus précisément dans les quartiers Dingues, Ridina 1 et Ridina 2. Dans la capitale Ndjaména, plusieurs centaines de familles dont les maisons ont été détruites soient totalement ou partiellement détruites ont été contraintes à se déplacer auprès des parents proches dans des quartiers les moins affectés, ou carrément dans des écoles et des bâtiments inachevés. Dans toutes les localités touchées, les besoins en secours alimentaires et non alimentaires sont cruciaux. En outre, il existe un risque élevé d'épidémie de maladies d'origine hydrique, car les inondations ont submergé les maisons et détruit les systèmes d'égouts, ainsi que des latrines. Le CRT a déployé 138 volontaires sur le terrain pour une réponse une évaluation rapide de la situation et besoins des personnes affectées. Ces volontaires travaillent sans relâche avec les autorités locales pour aider leurs communautés à se protéger et à se préparer à l'aggravation des inondations. Car, les prévisions du Service métrologique du Tchad continuent d’alerter sur une possible intensification des pluies dans les prochains jours. Déjà en avril dernier, le forum des Prévisions saisonnières des caractéristiques agro-hydro-climatiques de la saison des pluies pour les zones Soudanienne et Sahélienne (PRESASS 2022) qui s’est tenu à Niamey avait alerté sur un risque élevé d’inondations dans les zones soudanienne et sahélienne d’Afrique de l’ouest et du Centre. Les experts climatiques conviés au Forum entrevoyaient «Une saison des pluies 2022 globalement humide au Sahel, avec des dates de démarrage précoces à moyennes, des dates de fin tardives à moyennes des séquences sèches courtes à moyennes dans la partie Ouest et moyennes à longues dans la partie Est et des écoulements globalement excédentaires à moyens dans les principaux bassins fluviaux». Pour faire face à ces risques d’inondations, le forum avait proposé de renforcer la veille et les capacités d’intervention des agences en charge du suivi des inondations, renforcer les digues de protection et assurer la maintenance des barrages et des infrastructures routières, éviter l’occupation anarchique des zones inondables par les habitations et les cultures et renforcer la communication des prévisions saisonnières et de leurs mises à jour. Le forum PRESASS avait conseillé aussi de suivre de près les seuils d’alerte dans les sites à haut risque d’inondation surtout le bassin moyen du fleuve Niger, les hauts bassins du Chari et de la Volta, la rivière tributaire du lac Tchad (Komadougou Yobé), de curer les caniveaux, de prévoir des sites d’accueil pour les populations exposées au sinistre, etc. Ce sont ces différentes recommandations du forum PRESASS que le Gouvernement du Tchad a réitéré hier, notamment : l'évacuation des eaux, l'enlèvement des immondices, la pulvérisation de la ville et l'assistance d’urgence aux sinistrés, détaille la Primature. Le gouvernement a par ailleurs instruit la réactivation du Comité Interministériel pour faire face aux catastrophes naturelles, ainsi que le décaissement conséquent des ressources pour amoindrir les effets des grosses précipitations annoncées par la météo. Entre-temps, les équipes de la Croix-Rouge du Tchad poursuivent l’évaluation de la situation dans toutes les provinces et les localités affectées.

name: GMB: Epidemic - 2022-07 - The Gambia Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)
summary:
On 26th July 2022, the Epidemiology and Disease Control unit of The Gambia received a report through the Director of Health Services from a Nephrologist indicating a sudden increase in the number of cases of acute kidney injury (AKI) among children aged 5 months to 7 years who were being treated at Edward Francis Small Teaching Hospital (ETSTH). AKI refers to an abrupt decrease in kidney function that happens within a few hours or a few days. AKI causes a build-up of waste products in the blood and makes it hard for the kidneys to keep the right balance of fluid in the body. 
Some of the signs and symptoms of AKI include oliguria or anuria, oedema, confusion, nausea, diarrhoea, shortness of breath, chest pain, coma among others. A case definition was developed, and active case search revealed additional cases. The index case was traced to 4th July 2022. As of 30th September 2022, about 78 cases of AKI had been reported including 66 deaths (CFR 85%.) About 72% of the cases were under the age of two years. Cases were reported from all the 7 regions of the country, with 87% of cases reported from three health regions (Western Region 1 and 2 and Upper River Region). Clinical features among cases include fever (81% of cases), vomiting (61%), diarrhoea (51%) and cough (10%). The average duration of illness is nine days (range 5-18 days). This is the first known outbreak of acute kidney injury (AKI) in the country. Stool sample-test results from 62 children with acute watery diarrhoea (AWD) showed 38 (61%) tested positive for E. coli, including two samples positive for Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (O157:H7). 
In addition, nine samples of medicines taken by children with AKI were sent for toxicological tests, and the medications were found to contain diethylene glycol and ethylene glycol. 
For the past 2 weeks, 2 confirmed cases were reported, and they both died. The 2 deaths occurred at EFSTH on 27th September 2022 and 28th September 2022. The latter was a female, 31 months old, admitted at EFSTH on 27th September 2022 and presented with vomiting for 12 days; oliguria for 6 days; anorexia for 5 days; anuria for 5 days and swelling of feet for 4 days. The patient was taken to a health centre where she was diagnosed with malaria. 3 syrups were prescribed, but the mother could not remember the names, though she was told that one of the syrups was paracetamol. The vomiting stopped on day 2 of the illness. 6 days after using the syrup, the mother noticed reduced urination; during the night the child didn’t urinate but passed a little in the morning. The next day, vomiting continued and she returned to the health centre where tests were conducted and she was sent home and given ibuprofen, cotrimoxazole and B-complex, the child also had a swollen foot. The patient’s mother took her to EFSTH on self-referral and she died the next day.
Of all the cases reported, 60% are male while 40% are female. The minimum (mean) age is 20 months (+ SD), maximum (median) age is 17 (IQR) months, with a range of 2-84 months. The highest number of cases was among children 1-2 years. At the time of writing this report, 78 cases have been recorded. 
Earlier, the Medicines Control Agency (MCA) quarantined all suspected syrups and seized all batches of syrups with DEG and EG from the importers, wholesalers and retailers including government-owned hospitals. Active case searches at the health facilities are on-going to identify missed cases and also to update line-list. 2 cases were reported in the last 14 days. They both died at the EFSTH referral hospital. Hospital-based case control study was completed and awaiting presentation. Study controls were matched according to age, sex, hospitalization dates and presentation of fever in patients. Study findings will be documented for reference. Anthropologists are in the field to conduct in-depth interviews with caregivers and investigate narratives around the AKI cases and nearby communities. Active case searches at the health facilities are on-going to identify missed cases and also to update line-list. 2 cases were reported in the last 14 days. They both died at the EFSTH referral hospital. Hospital-based case control study was completed and awaiting presentation. Study controls were matched according to age, sex, hospitalization dates and presentation of fever in patients. Study findings will be documented for reference. Anthropologists are in the field to conduct in-depth interviews with caregivers and investigate narratives around the AKI cases and nearby communities.

name: YEM: Flood - 2022-07 - Heavy rains in Yemen led to deaths and damage
Migratory Flow through the Southern Border
summary:
Durante los dias de la semana anterior se mantuvo un flujo migratorio pequeñño pero constante por el sector fronterizo sur de nuestro pais. Muchas de las personas que cruzan la Región del Darién – por lo general, adultos jóvenes y familias – llegan a comunidades indígenas de difícil acceso con hambre y deshidratación, exhaustas y requiriendo atención médica.

La mayoría de los cuales provenía de Haití, incluyendo su descendencia nacida en Chile y Brasil, seguidos de, cubanos, venezolanos y personas de lugares tan alejados como Bangladesh, Ghana, Uzbekistán y Senegal.


En respuesta al creciente número de personas que cruzan la Región del Darién, las diferentes agencias, incluida nuestra Sociedad Nacional han incrementado su presencia en esta region de Costa Rica fronteriza con Panamá para apoyar con asistencia humaniitaria a las personas migrantes con elementos como por ejemplo: productos de higiene femenina y general, aplicacion de primeros auxilios debido a las lesiones de leve a moderadas con las que llegan, servicios de wifi y carga de telefonos celulares.



Con estas acciones se ha logrado apoyar a más 2,600 personas migrantes tan solo en esta semana pasada, de alrededor de 14 nacionalidades distintas en donde se registran una gran cantidad de mujeres de diferentes edades por encima de los hombres que han llegado.

Asi mismo se ha trabajado en algunos sectores de la frontera norte, en las que se ha distribuido una gran cantidad de asistencia humanitaria asi como los servicios mencionados para la region sur.

Afghanistan - Flash Floods (July 2022)
summary: Off-seasonal rainfall peaked between July and August 2022 in Afghanistan, causing the country's rivers to overflow. The flood affected 16 provinces, out of which 13 provinces (Ghazni, Kandahar, Kunar, Logar, Laghman, Maidan, Nangarhar, Nuristan, Paktia, Parwan, Wardak, Urozgan, and Zabul) were severely affected. A total of 156 people lost their lives and 124 people were injured, including women and children due to the floods. Over 35,700 houses were affected (16,000 houses destroyed and 19,700 partially damaged) which affected 249,900 people in the area. Thousands of acres of crops in farming fields were destroyed. The rapid assessment conducted by the Afghan Red Crescent Society (ARCS) revealed that the flash floods caused massive damage and destruction in these parts of the country. A substantial number of houses were flooded, with household items damaged. Several plots of farmland were swept away, and the flow of water cratered several roads. Many communities were left with inaccessible roads due to landslides. Because of the remoteness of some of the affected areas, the onset of harsh winters would aggravate the already precarious situation of the affected population.

Pakistan: Monsoon Floods
summary:
Calling the incessant monsoon rains a “climate-induced humanitarian crisis of epic proportions”, the Government of Pakistan on 25 August 2022 officially declared a ‘national emergency’ in light of the rain-induced floods, which have killed 1,700 people already, including 632 children since 14 June.

 

Pakistan Red Crescent reached 267,358 people with emergency lifesaving assistance, coordinating with the local authorities, UN, and other agencies to cover the larger needs across the country.

One-third of Pakistan’s territory and around 33 million people have been impacted by the floods in 84 calamity-declared districts, of which 32 are in Balochistan, 23 in Sindh, 17 in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), 9 in Gilgit-Baltistan (GB) and 3 in Punjab. The number of people affected represents the entire population of Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark, Ireland, and Slovakia combined.

Between 26 September and 2 October, almost 25 per cent of the country was still underwater and there are still about 15 million individuals who could be affected by flooding or live nearby. In KP, waters have receded and people are slowly returning to their home areas in need of early recovery support. In Sindh and Balochistan receding has also begun, but especially in parts of Sindh, the emergency continues and flooding may still occur in the southern parts. According to provincial authorities, completion of the receding of waters will take 3-6 more months.

More than 2 million houses have been damaged or destroyed leaving approximately 8 million people displaced and approximately 600,000 people living in relief camps. Almost 88 per cent of the destruction of houses occurred in Sindh, which has borne also the brunt of the damage to roads and bridges, leaving people stranded in many places.

Destruction of water, sanitation and health facilities has caused a heightened risk of a public health crisis. Assessments are illustrating increased trends in water- and vector-borne diseases, with outbreaks of diarrheal diseases, measles, skin infections, respiratory tract infections, malaria, and dengue, particularly in Sindh and Balochistan. Access to already limited health services is constrained further due to the damage to over 1,400 health facilities across Sindh and Balochistan.

Access to safe drinking water, sanitation and hygiene are of serious concern. In the newest projections, more than 8.6 million people will face crisis or emergency levels of food insecurity (IPC 3+) mainly in Sindh and Balochistan. The acute food insecurity in the coming months is driven by the destruction of crops, agricultural land, livelihood assets, and livestock.

The priority needs are preventative public health interventions, including rehabilitation of water and sanitation facilities and hygiene campaigns for the prevention of disease transmission, increased access to health services, maternal and child health care interventions, shelter items and winterization support in the cold areas, and assistance to meet basic needs and to recover livelihoods. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies Emergency Appeal is prioritizing humanitarian response for the heavily affected populations in KP, Balochistan and Sindh provinces.

The aim of this Emergency Appeal is to support the priority humanitarian response for the heavily affected populations in the flood-hit regions of Pakistan. This also includes a focus on the response capacity and readiness of the National Society and affected communities.

CRI: Cyclone - 2022-07 - CRI: Cyclone -2022-07
summary:
La Onda Tropical #13 continúa su avance hacia Centroamérica, se ubica a 381 km al Noreste de Limón y se traslada a una velocidad de 30 km/h hacia el oeste. Los vientos sostenidos se mantienen de 65 km/h. Se observa cada vez mejor organización de este disturbio por lo que la probabilidad de
desarrollarse en tormenta tropical es mayor en un corto periodo de tiempo.

En la trayectoria pronosticada, el sistema se desplazará sobre el suroeste del Mar Caribe este viernes; durante esta noche cruzará el sur de Nicaragua/norte de Costa Rica, trasladándose al Océano Pacífico el sábado.

Pronóstico: La influencia del sistema en Costa Rica irá aumentando conforme transcurre este viernes y sábado.

Durante este viernes: aguaceros fuertes principalmente para las regiones de la Zona Norte, Caribe y norte de Guanacaste con montos estimados (en 24 horas) de alrededor de 100-200 mm. En el Pacífico Central y el Pacífico Sur, montos estimados de 100 mm. En el Valle Central se estiman lluvias de variable intensidad, montos entre 40-70 mm, los más altos en sectores montañosos.

Ráfagas de viento entre 65km/h y 100 km/h en las cercanías de la Cordillera de Guanacaste, principalmente en los cantones de Los Chiles, Upala, Guatuso, La Cruz; Liberia, Tilarán, Bagaces y Cañas durante la noche del viernes y madrugada del sábado.

El sábado las lluvias continuarán en la Zona Norte, norte de Guanacaste y menor cantidad Caribe Norte, con montos estimados (en 24 horas) entre 100-250 mm. En el Pacífico Central y el Pacífico Sur entre 100-150 mm. Lluvias de variable intensidad en el Valle Central, especialmente n sectores
montañosos, acumulados entre 40-70 mm.

Para el domingo, los efectos irán disminuyendo mientras este disturbio se interne en el Océano Pacífico; por tanto, en este día se estiman precipitaciones propias de la época lluviosa, con montos estimados entre 90mm y 120mm en 24 horas de forma puntual.

Advertencia: Especial atención regiones tanto de la Zona Norte y el Caribe Norte por ya que debido a la cercanía de estas regiones la posible trayectoria, estas zonas con mayor vulnerabilidad a inundaciones en este momento. Ráfagas intensas cerca de las Cordilleras de Guanacaste

IRQ: Other - 2022-06 - The response of the Iraqi Red Crescent Society to the outbreak of cholera
summary: A cholera outbreak in Iraq has infected hundreds of people, and records of more suspected cases have been sent for lab testing in the central laboratory in Baghdad, most of which are from the northern Kurdistan region. As announced by the Ministry of Health (MOH) officials in Baghdad, there has been a recent spike in hospitalization following diarrhea cases in Sulaymaniyah, Erbil, Duhok, and southern governorates of Iraq. The KRI Mnistry of Health, published a statement on Thursday 23 June 2022, and issued a directive in regard to dealing with the diarrheal outbreak in the region. The increase in Cholera cases in Sulaymaniyah and other governorates is a reason for concern for the MoH, as it is coming on the backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic and other epidemic-prone outbreaks. However, the Ministry of Health both in Baghdad and in the Kurdistan region is ready to prepare for and respond to this outbreak and lessen the impact on the affected population. The MoH has also requested that the in-country humanitarian actors support government efforts to deal with this outbreak.

Migration: Mexico & Central America 2022
summary:
Since the beginning of 2022, there has been amassiveincreasein the number of refugees, migrants, and returnees in transit by land northwards through Central America, compared to previous years.

Migrants, returnees, and  refugees  are  moving  mostly  through  irregular  channels.  Along  the  routes,  many  of them face bureaucratic barriers, suffer accidents and injuries, face extortion and sexual violence, or disappear and are separated from their families. Tragically, others are killed or die from disease or the harsh environmental conditions and weather.

The majority of migrants and refugees in transit through Central America come from Cuba, Venezuela and Haiti.1 The situation is especially serious for  the  most  vulnerable  groups  such  as  children  and  youth,  women, indigenous populations, the elderly, disabled and LGBTIQ people.2

As expressed  by  migrants  themselvesin the information  collected  by National Societies, the main reasons for migrating include improving their income,   escaping   violence,    reuniting   with    family   members,    and recovering from the impact of recurring disasters and extreme weather events. The devastating socioeconomic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic and continuing political crises are also factors and will continue to increase population movements and exacerbateexisting vulnerabilities.

 



People on the move are facing extreme conditions and require significant assistance, including those with health problems. This high demand for assistance can be hampered by the exhaustion of personnel or the limited availability of food, water, facilities, and first aid supplies. The impact of migration on children is of increasing concern as they face various threats such as drowning, violence, sexual violence, human trafficking, exploitation, and other health risks, including mental health. Out of every 100 migrants crossing the Darien Gap in 2022, 16 are minors. After several years of working on migration flows, and through IFRC’s network of Humanitarian Service Points (HSPs) and Community Engagement and Accountability (CEA) approach, Red Cross National Societies in the region have identified the needs expressed by migrants, ranging from protection and health care to accessing specific information that allows them to make informed decisions along the route and at their destination. The most vulnerable need access to medical care, mental health support, humanitarian assistance (food, water, shelter) connectivity, and legal information).
 
 
1 SNM Panama Statistics of Migratory Flows in the Darien 2022, INM Honduras.
2 UN Human Rights Office of the High Commissioner, Forcibly displaced LGBT persons face major challenges in search of safe haven.

ZWE: Epidemic - 2022-06 - Measles outbreak and polio risk in Zimbabwe
summary: From early April 2022, Zimbabwe was affected by a national measles outbreak, that killed more than 750 childrenwithin the outbreak’s first 6 months to the 2nd of October 2022. This outbreak saw humanitarian organizations like UNICEF, Red Cross and the WHO activating an emergency response strategy to provide support and resources to the Government of Zimbabwe (GoZ). The first case was recorded in Manicaland province on the 10 April 2022 in Mutasa district and by the 31st of August, 639 children had succumbed to the virus accumulating to 750 deaths by early October. In response, the Government of Zimbabwe has rolled out a nationwide emergency immunization programme targeting 95% of all children from 6-59 months and in some instances up to 15 years in an attempt to attain herd immunity. Nationally, there are reports that cumulatively around 85 % of all children under the age of five are fullyvaccinated against measles by the 2nd of October 2022. Currently the GoZ’s focus is ramping up efforts to immunizethe remaining eligible populations prioritizing Manicaland Province. According to the Midlands Province MOHCC, 65%of all children under the age of five are fully vaccinated against measles by the 20 October 2022.Vaccinations have been ongoing at all static facilities and outreach teams were visiting hard-to-reach areas and children in the 6-59 months category are being vaccinated irrespective of their vaccination status. At least 85% of the children have been vaccinated in Manicaland Province and of the 7 413 children affected by measles, 5 600 have recovered, representing 76% recovery. Countrywide immunization will continue until all the areas are covered in as much as it continues until it reaches the national 95% vaccination target.

SOM: Rain and Windstorms in North Galkacyo(2022)
summary:
On 12 May 2022, the local government of Galkacyo hosted an inter-agency coordination meeting where they requested assistance from humanitarian partners to address the immediate and urgent humanitarian needs assessed in 18 out of 20 makeshift camps located in the periphery of the city. This is following sudden heavy rains and windstorms which struck North Galkacyo on 10 May, impacting the city of Galkayo and its surrounding areas, which host the camps. The most affected people by this disaster are approximately 4,416 internally displaced people (736 HH) people living in 18 of the 20 recorded camps. These 18 camps around Galkayo are home to approximately 40,254 internally displaced persons (IDP) or 6,709 households, based on the needs assessment. The Somali Red Crescent Society (SRCS) staff and volunteers from Galkayo Branch quickly mobilised and began to support the affected communities and carried out a rapid assessment of the damage. On 11 May, SRCS joined an interagency rapid assessment in all the 18 affected IDP camps, led by North Galkacyo Municipality in coordination with OCHA, to which other partners1 participated.

As per the initial information from the SRCS and interagency rapid assessment, the IDP settlements were the most affected by the rains and windstorms, which destroyed IDP shelters and other communal assets such as latrines, health facilities, schools, etc. The assessment reports that about 4,416 internally displaced people (736 HH) were affected and in need of humanitarian assistance. Based on this, SRCS is requesting IFRC support through the Disaster Relief Emergency Fund (DREF) to provide relief to the most vulnerable families targeted in the IDP settlements in coordination with the local government and humanitarian agencies. Through the inter-agency coordination meeting conducted on 12 May 2022, it was agreed that SRCS will support the affected people with the ongoing response by providing emergency shelters, NFIs, WASH, Food security and livelihood, CEA and PGI, and a mobile health team.

name: Bangladesh - Flash Flood 2022
summary:
Summary

Torrential rain and incessant downpours from upstream regions since 15 June 2022 have resulted in the worst flooding in living memory in the north-eastern districts of Bangladesh. Cherrapunji and Mawsynram in India’s Meghalaya district, bordering the northeast part of Bangladesh, have registered record-breaking rainfall which has resulted in overflowing of the Surma-Kushiyara river basin and flooded 80 percent of the north-eastern region of Bangladesh.

An estimated 7.2 million people have been affected by the flood in nine northeastern districts of Sylhet, Sunamganj, Moulvibazar, Habiganj, Kishorganj, Netrokona, Brahmanbaria, Mymensingh and Sherpur. Among these nine districts, the most severely affected districts are Sylhet, Sunamganj, Netrokona and Habiganj district. The affected people have been forced to leave their inundated or near-to-inundated houses to take refuge elsewhere as the water level in nearby rivers continues to rise. The Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief (MoDMR) reported more than 481,827 people have been evacuated to 1,615 flood centres as of 21 June 2022.



Communications with Sunamganj district was cut off for a few days, including mobile communication, due to disruption of the electricity supply for several days since 16 June. At the same time, access to Sylhet district by air and rail became unavailable. Rail communication has been re-established on 20 June. There are fears of road communication disruption if the heavy rains continue.

The flood will increase food insecurity in the north-eastern districts as it has damaged 113,297-hectare croplands mainly Aman paddy, seedbed, maize, and vegetable and cash crops.Livestock and fisheries are also facing significant challenges as the fishing hatcheries and farms were washed away. The majority of people in these districts are dependent on agriculture for their livelihoods and employment, hence, their primary means of making a living have been hugely impacted during this crisis.

Due to the floods, more than 40,000 tube wells and more than 49,000 latrines are damaged. In the collective centres, water points and sanitation facilities are enormously overburdened. In Sunamganj and Sylhet districts, most of the water supply and sanitation services are submerged. According to the WASH cluster, many women and adolescent girls are facing problem in using the WASH facilities at the collective centres.

The National Health Emergency Operations Centre and Control Room of the Directorate General of Health Services (DGHS) recorded (dated 20 June 2022) a total of 2,492 cases of diseases and injuries. Among these cases, 1,229 are acute watery diarrhoea (AWD) cases. According to the health cluster, there is a possibility of increased prevalence of communicable diseases, particularly waterborne disease outbreaks as the floodwaters recedes.


At the same time, monsoon floods are occurring in the northern part of Bangladesh, particularly in the Jamuna River basin area. The flood waters inundated new areas in Kurigram, Jamalpur, Nilphamari, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha, Bogura, Tangail and Sirajganj districts since 20 June 2022. According to the Situation Overview and Anticipatory Impact Analysis of Need Assessment Working Group (NAWG) dated 20 June 2022, around 3.7 million people are expected to be impacted by monsoon floods in the Northern districts of Bangladesh while the peak of the monsoon floods is likely between 25 to 30 June 2022

La alerta se activó a las 11.30 hs de la mañana y rige en la franja costera y los departamentos al sur del Río negro.

URY: Inundaciónes
summary:
El 26 de abril el Instituto Uruguayo de Meteorología (INUMET) emitió un aviso a la población por el desmejoramiento de las condiciones meteorológicas en todo el país. Posteriormente se emitió una alerta de nivel naranja por tormentas y lluvias.

 

Durante la madrugada y primeras horas de la mañana se registraron intensas lluvias con rachas de viento fuerte y muy fuerte en todo el territorio nacional. Según INUMET, las rachas máximas de viento alcanzaron los 120 km/h. A su vez se registraron lluvias de hasta 73mm.

 

De acuerdo a la evaluación preliminar de daños, el departamento más afectado es Artigas donde se registran un total de 275 personas desplazadas de las cuales 127 son evacuadas y 148 autoevacuadas.

 

A su vez, en el departamento de Cerro Largo se vieron afectadas 25 viviendas de la ciudad de Melo (capital departamental). Por parte del CECOED se continua monitoreando la situación y se encuentran acondicionando el gimnasio municipal frente a posibles inundaciones.

 

En la ciudad de Rivera se encuentran acondicionando las carpas instaladas en la ciudad para poder albergar a familias desplazadas ya que existe pronóstico de tormentas para la tarde-noche del día de hoy.

 

A nivel de servicios, la principal afectación es la interrupción del suministro de energía para 73000 clientes de los cuales 2840 aún se encuentran sin servicio

Acciones realizadas por la Sociedad Nacional

 

Se encuentran activos los Equipos Nacionales de Intervención (ENI) realizando monitoreo y evaluación del avance y actualización de las alertas en los diversos departamentos.

 

Se permanece en contacto con los Centros Coordinadores de Emergencias Departamentales.

Costa Rica: Afectación por Temporada de Lluvias 2022
summary:
Fuertes aguaceros vespertinos por la cercanía de la Zona de Convergencia Intertropical

-Actualización-

 

La influencia de la Zona de Convergencia Intertropical, latente al sur de Centroamérica, está generando lluvias y aguaceros de moderada a fuerte intensidad, de manera localizada, sobre sectores recurrentes en estos dos días anteriores. Al momento se ha registrado acumulados entre los 30-55 mm en sectores de Pérez Zeledón, Puerto Jiménez, San Vito, Ciudad Neily, Osa, Parrita y Quepos en el Pacífico Central y Sur, además localmente en Nicoya y Santa Cruz para Guanacaste.

Durante el final de la tarde y primeras horas noche se estarán presentando lluvias variables, que disminuyan paulatinamente. Se estiman montos en el Pacífico entre 15 mm y 50 mm. En la Zona Norte y el Valle Central, se esperan lluvias de aisladas con montos estimados entre 15 mm y 30 mm. En el Caribe se las precipitaciones serán escasas Se estima que durante la madrugada se estén presentado chubascos con tormenta aislada, sobre sectores recurrentes del Pacífico Sur.

Se mantiene un especial vigilancia por la llegada de la Onda Tropical #44 que se encuentra cerca de las costas de Venezuela y Colombia.

name: STP: Épidémie - 2022-04 - Epidémie de Dengue à Sao Tomé
summary: Le ministre de la Santé de São Tomé et Príncipe (STP) a officiellement déclaré une épidémie de dengue le 4 mai 2022, devenant ainsi la première épidémie de dengue signalée dans le pays. Une alerte a été initialement notifiée par l'équipe de gestion clinique d'un hôpital de la capitale de São Tomé le 11 avril 2022. Un homme de 27 ans présentant des symptômes évocateurs d'une infection par la dengue s'est présenté dans l'établissement huit jours après son arrivée de l'île de la Guadeloupe, dans les Caraïbes, où la dengue est endémique. Les tests effectués n'ont pas confirmé qu'il s'agissait d'un cas aigu de dengue, mais ont révélé la présence d'anticorps IgG suggérant une infection antérieure au cours des dernières semaines. Néanmoins, le cas suspect a incité le département de surveillance épidémiologique à mobiliser une équipe d'investigation multidisciplinaire en collaboration avec le Centre national d'endémie pour enquêter sur le cas, les contacts personnels et identifier les moustiques vecteurs et leurs sites de reproduction au domicile du cas. Du 18 avril au 17 mai 2022, 103 cas et aucun décès ont été confirmés par le test de diagnostic rapide (TDR) dans cinq districts sanitaires : Água Grande (90, 87,4 %) ; Mézochi (7, 6,8 %) ; Lobata (4, 3,9 %) ; Cantagalo (1, 1,0 %) ; et Région autonome de Príncipe (RAP) (1, 1,0 %). Le taux d'attaque de Água Grande est de loin le plus important, avec 10,7 cas pour 10 000 habitants. Les groupes d'âge les plus touchés sont : 10-19 ans (5,9 cas pour 10 000), 30-39 ans (7,3 cas pour 10 000), 40-49 ans (5,1 cas pour 10 000) et 50-59 ans (6,1 cas pour 10 000). Les signes cliniques les plus fréquents sont la fièvre (97, 94%), les céphalées (78, 76%) et les myalgies (64, 62%). Tous les cas ont été confirmés positifs par RDT, cependant un total de 30 échantillons ont été envoyés à l'Institut d'Hygiène et de Médecine Tropicale de la Nouvelle Université de Lisbonne (IHMT - NOVA) au Portugal pour des tests supplémentaires et ont été reçus le 29 avril. selon le bulletin d'information n°101 du 26 août 2022, les cas cumulés  sont au nombre de 980 et les cas  actifs cumulés sont au nombre de 10.  La saison des pluies du pays dure généralement 9 mois, de septembre à mai, mais de décembre 2021 à début mars 2022, le pays a connu des pluies torrentielles de grande ampleur. le pays a connu des pluies torrentielles d'une grande intensité et de longue durée provoquant des inondations. Les pluies devraient se poursuivre jusqu'en juin de cette année Cette année, les pluies devraient se poursuivre jusqu'en juin et ont déjà accumulé de l'eau stagnante qui fournit des conditions favorables aux sites de reproduction des moustiques. favorables aux sites de reproduction des moustiques. Les inondations ont également causé problèmes pour les activités de gestion des déchets et de l'assainissement dans le le pays et, par conséquent, les conditions sont réunies pour la transmission d'autres maladies potentielles. Il est par conséquent prendre les dispositions pour mieux préparer la communauté et réduire les risques de propagation

UGA: Population Movement - 2022-04 - Uganda - Western Region: Refugee Influx 04/2022
summary:
Families fleeing violence in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are arriving in Uganda traumatized and without possessions, in the hope of reaching safety. However, they find themselves in another humanitarian crisis as there is insufficient shelter to house them, and overcrowded centres lack water and sanitation, forcing people to camp out in the open putting their safety and health at risk.

The conflict in the North Kivu and Ituri provinces in the eastern part of the DRC has intensified since late March 2022, triggering the large-scale displacement of refugees into Uganda. Up to 26 May, Uganda had received over 41,018 new arrivals fleeing the violence from DRC.

From 10 June, the IFRC has seen a further increase in people crossing the border due to an escalation in violence in the DRC. Families have been forced to flee with limited or no possessions and can be seen camping on the streets, in schools, markets, and on the open grounds of border towns Bundibugyo and Bunagana. Due to the sudden increase in people crossing, not all have been registered and, hence, the numbers are not at this stage confirmed but it is estimated they could have increased to over 100,000 people, putting a significant strain on host communities.

This rapid and large-scale influx of refugees has put tremendous pressure on the basic social services in the settlements where refugees are hosted, impacting education, food, shelter, health and nutrition centres, and WASH infrastructure.

The refugees are received at several collection points, transit, and reception centres across the country. They are registered and provided with basic protection services and humanitarian assistance pending their relocation to refugee settlements. Besides those registered at the camps, there is a large number of additional refugees still living with host communities in Bundibugyo and Bunagana.

The influx of refugees has created a large gap in terms of shelter. The transit centres are designed to host refugees for a maximum of five days, but the situation has forced longer stays. Refugees have arrived with few belongings and there is an urgent need for emergency shelters and essential household items.

The transit centres and camps are already congested and lack sufficient health, water, and sanitation facilities raising the risk of disease outbreaks if no immediate actions are taken with regard to health, hygiene, and sanitation. Their basic shelter and WASH infrastructure need to be upgraded to comply with the minimum humanitarian standards at the receiving locations. Refugees face numerous protection issues; including cases of sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV), separated families and unaccompanied minors and many more all arising due to the magnitude of the displacement and growing vulnerabilities, and strained basic social services in refugee-hosting communities. The level of trauma is high among the current refugee population and additional psychosocial assistance is needed. Some families have been displaced three or four times, thereby, leading to a continuous cycle of displacement in settlements.

countries society-name: The Sri Lanka Red Cross Society
name: Sri Lanka: Complex Emergency
summary:
Summary

An economic crisis and a ban on synthetic fertiliser in Sri Lanka, which has been developing since March 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic, has sparked civil unrest and food insecurity. To save its foreign currency reserves, the Government of Sri Lanka (GoSL) limited the import of essential items.

In the first quarter of 2022, GoSL was unable to import the required quantity of petroleum products such as diesel, petrol, coal, and other hydrocarbons used in thermal power plants. This resulted in long power cuts (even 13 hours a day), long queues at fuel and cooking gas stations for days and disrupted schedules for public transport services. 

Since the GoSL decided to limit the import of nonorganic fertiliser in January 2022, homegrown agricultural product inflation increased to 24.7 per cent in February 2022, due to production shortages. By April 2022, food inflation in the country increased to 45.1 per cent from 29.5 per cent in March 2022. The shortages in food, fuel, and medicine turned months of peaceful protests into violence which killed 10 people and injured more than 250 by May 2022.

Sri Lanka’s president declared a state of emergency on 6 May 2022, the second time in a span of five weeks. Protests have continued to take place sporadically, also after a new prime minister was appointed on 12 May 2022 to lead the government.

Severe food shortages are expected in the coming months as food production dropped approximately 50 per cent during the last season (Maha cultivation season September 2021- March 2022) and more than 50 per cent of commercial farmers have stopped cultivation in the current season (Yala season, May-August 2022) due to non-availability of fertiliser and fuel to operate their equipment. According to a World Food Programme (WFP) rapid assessment, an estimated 38 per cent of people are already facing moderate to severe food insecurity.

Over a third of households in urban and rural areas are applying emergency coping strategies, such as withdrawing children from school, migrating to other areas in search of employment and selling houses or land. The lack of fuel has affected the income of staff employed in the transportation sector as well as the capacity of fishing communities, for example, to operate their fishing boats which they depend on for sustenance.

The suspension of routine surgeries was reported in four major hospitals due to a shortage of medical supplies, medicines, and 10-13 hours-long power cuts.

Key humanitarian impacts due to the ongoing crisis:

  • Civil unrest and violence resulting in injuries, hospitalisations, property damage and arrests.
  • Loss of livelihoods, particularly by urban and rural daily wage earners, who consequently face food insecurity due to the sudden loss in income and high price increases of essential food and household items; by fishing communities which do not have fuel to operate their fishing boats; and farmers who lack fertilisers and are hit by sharp price increases in agricultural inputs.
  • A severe food insecurity crisis is looming across the country while certain food supplements for children and nursing mothers, such as milk powder, fresh milk and Thriposha (an additional food rich in nutrients) are not available.
  • Children’s education is affected due to power cuts, inadequate public transport, and the lack of stationery items.
  • Days spent in the hot sun and rain waiting in long queues without drinking water, food and sanitation is resulting in deaths and hospitalisations.
  • The multiple challenges and increased burdens are having a detrimental effect on people’s mental well-being.
  • The shortage of consumables in the country and sharp decline in agricultural production has resulted in rapid price increases in staple food items like rice and vegetables.

KEN: Integrated Vector Borne Diseases Outbreak
summary:
Kenya has been affected by numerous health crises and natural disasters in the past two years. Currently, more than 4 million people are affected by drought coupled with the negative effects of COVID 19 on the economy, the situation is very dire among the poor and those in the hard-to-reach areas of the country (mostly in the arid and semi-arid areas) which, as a result, are the localities most affected by health crises.

The recent emergence and re-emergence of viral infections transmitted by vectors in the country namely Chikungunya, Dengue, Yellow Fever (YF), and others is a cause for international concern. In 2021 an outbreak of Dengue Fever affected 3 counties of the coastal region - Mombasa, Kilifi, and Lamu. This was supported by a DREF allocation. The first two months of 2022 have now also recorded two outbreaks that are currently under national response; Yellow Fever and Chikungunya.

The current vector-borne outbreaks are confirmed in two counties of Wajir and Isiolo. The Yellow Fever virus being more lethal has already led to a swift response from the ministry of health that has put the whole country under alert and vaccination is scheduled to start in around two weeks.

name: BHS: Epidemic - 2022-03 -  The Bahamas- Epidemic: 08-15-2022
summary:
The Princess Margaret Hospital is still on the rebound since the pandemic and is dealing with the challenges of having more space in the already packed facility. Addressing the backlog of surgeries and providing more beds has become the priority of the government. Along with disposing of the faulty equipment in the operating rooms.

With three out of 8 wards not available  the bed capacity has diminished considerably making this a crisis situation for the Ministry. Repairs could not be carried out during the pandemic and funds had to be diverted so this caused a delay on any work being done.

name: BHS: Epidemic - 2022-03 -  The Bahamas- Epidemic: 10-15-2022
summary:
With Covid-19 cases continuing to be on a decline there is only one island that reported a positive case in Eleuthera. So we can see the amount of new cases remain low but the government has discontinued all mandatory Covid-19 protocols. This means that people are free to move about without masks and keeping 6 ft apart. However, there are some residents who despite the lifted restrictions still cover their nose and mouth along with keeping their distance. Residents are allowed to take free tests at various locations throughout the Bahamas, making it easier for the government to track the number of cases. 

As it relates to the Covid 19 vaccine tracker a total of 364,421 doses were administered, 162, 321 accounts for 1 dose excluding the J&J, and 173,380 represent people fully vaccinated including the J&J. The numbers did increase with a total of 1,769 persons that took the vaccine with the numbers not as robust as it was during the peak of Covid-19. There are sites throughout the Bahamas where people can easily locate with accessible hours.

Malawi - Cholera Outbreak
summary:
Malawi is currently experiencing one of the worst cholera outbreaks in years. The first case was registered in Machinga district in the Southern region of Malawi on 02 March 2022. The Malawi Ministry of Health declared the cholera outbreak on 03 March 2022 after the increase and spread of confirmed cases. The cholera outbreak, initially limited to the southern part of the country, has now spread to Malawi's northern and central regions. Cases climbed steadily throughout mid 2022, climbing rapidly towards the end of the year and into early 2023. The country continues to register new cholera cases in different parts of the country, with all districts affected. The fatality rate exceeds the acceptable threshold set by the WHO of less than 1%.

There is also spread to neighbouring Zambia, Mozambique, Tanzania and Zimbabwe where outbreaks are being declared.

The Malawi Red Cross report that there is an urgent need to address the risk factors of the outbreak, such as the provision of safe drinking water, especially in the hotspot areas. Several displaced communities in areas that were affected in 2022 by the cyclones Ana and Gombe are still living in precarious hygienic conditions. The drought and associated malnutrition that has affected vast areas of Malawi are making the communities, particularly children, more at risk of mortality due to the increased vulnerability caused by their poor nutritional status.

Ukraine and impacted countries crisis
summary:
On 24 February, a new phase in the armed conflict in Ukraine started with the intensification and spread of the hostilities that are now affecting most parts of the country and causing major concern for the protection of civilians and essential civilian infrastructure.

This rapid evolution of the situation on Ukraine’s borders and ongoing active military action inside Ukraine does not allow the humanitarian community to have much clarity on existing and immediate needs, particularly inside Ukraine. However, the needs are expected to be massive and to affect all regions of Ukraine, neighboring countries and beyond. 

Based on estimations provided by government authorities, international organizations and Red Cross National Societies, the total number of people now affected by the conflict is estimated to be up to 18 million. As of early May, there is an estimated 7.7 million displaced within Ukraine, with millions more living in active conflict zones who are facing a loss of electricity, difficulty accessing drinking water and severe shortages of medicines and available medical assistance. Over 5.6 million have fled the country since the beginning of the conflict - 1.3 million of which have reportedly returned to Ukraine. From available information, many returnees to Ukraine are not considered permanent, however, and that a significant portion of those returning are doing so in a pendular nature to check on family members or assess the safety or state of their homes.  

Poland has received the vast majority of those fleeing the conflict (over 3 million) followed by Romania and Hungary. The number of daily arrivals into neighboring countries continues to fluctuate, but has generally declined since the beginning of the crisis. In Poland, for example, daily arrivals remain close to 20,000 as of early May compared to an average of 100,000 daily arrivals in early March. In total, Ukrainians submitted over 21,000 applications for asylum in EU+ countries between February 21 and April 24. However, asylum applications quickly declined from early March, as the Temporary Protection Directive was activated on March 4, and was implemented by national authorities with the assistance of the EUAA.  According to provisional estimates, about 2.3 million persons fleeing Ukraine have been registered for temporary protection as of April 24 – less than half of those who have fled. The movement of people in need remains immensely complex and difficult to predict, but the situation is being monitored daily to anticipate needs, movements and developments in the conflict. We know that assistance at border points remains a large need – both in terms of information for those fleeing, as well as ensuring protection of those most vulnerable. Shelter needs are dynamic: many have been taken in by host families or relatives/friends in neighbouring countries, but for those in collective accommodation centres, needs for improved sanitation, personal care items and hygiene items remains a high priority. Finally, the need for financial assistance is ever-expanding, as people lose their primary sources of income, face unpredictable futures, and struggle to meet basic needs.

 

 

The current situation in Ukraine is governed by the four 1949 Geneva Conventions, its First Additional Protocol from 1977 and customary international humanitarian law. The International Red Cross Red Crescent Movement (the Movement) calls upon concerned authorities to support and facilitate the humanitarian response of Movement partners, including by ensuring that any restrictive measures contain effective protection of the humanitarian space, by managing any support to the parties responsibly as well as supporting the parties in fulfilling their responsibilities under International Humanitarian Law.

name: Ghana - Explosions
summary:
On 20th January 2022, a large blast occurred in an area at Apeate community, near the city of Bogoso about 300km (180 miles) west of the capital of Ghana, Accra. The explosion occurred when a motorcycle went under a truck carrying explosives that were en route to the gold mine at Bogoso. After the blasts, people in the community rushed down to the scene when a second blast occurred a few minutes later. This resulted in the destruction of dozens of buildings. 

As of 22nd January, a total of 17 people had been confirmed dead, and some 59 injured people were rescued and referred to Bogoso Government Hospital where they are receiving treatment. As of 26th January, 3,300 persons (1,122 males and 2,178 females) have been affected by the event, excluding those who were at the various health centers.

Reports from the National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) indicate that 500 buildings have been destroyed by the blasts and approximately 1,500 people are now homeless. The explosion blew-off major roads in the area, with many commuters getting stranded due to the situation. Schools, markets, and other services at the community level were equally impacted, disrupting activities as children can no longer go to school and community members have lost their livelihoods.

The Prestea Huni Valley Municipal Assembly has set up a relief center at the Catholic Church Parish Hall in Bogoso which is hosting the displaced people, and the Government through the Municipal Chief Executive of Prestea Huni Valley Municipal Assembly has issued a statement highlighting the need for assistance including temporary shelter, food items, and medical needs. The government is taking full charge of the medical bills of the injured while the Vice President of the Republic of Ghana, mining companies, and other non-profit organizations have provided cash (undisclosed amounts) and in-kind donations to the Municipal assembly, as a contribution to support relief actions.
