Cameroon: Mouvement de population à l'Extrême-Nord
summary: Civil unrest and violence in north-east Nigeria spilled over to areas of neighbouring countries in the Lake Chad Basin including the Far North region of Cameroon. The civil unrest and ethnic conflicts forced more than 2.6 million people to flee their homes. This situation is exacerbated by the challenges of long distances and large geographic desert-like areas, displacements, remote communities prone to heavy rains and droughts, and general shortage of basic services. The harsh environment has largely affected agriculture and livelihoods, with economic setbacks felt across many generations experiencing the direct effects of the crises, with devastating effects on health, housing, food security and livelihoods. This, of course, means that vulnerability is increasing and poverty is rife in many parts of this large geographic area, now also faced with population movement and violence which has become part of the people’s daily lives. As at now, some 253,813 IDPs are registered in the Far North region of Cameroon as a result of the violence cause by armed groups.

name: Malawi: Floods
summary: The Government of Malawi has declared a state of emergency. At least 45 people have been killed and 739,000 people affected in 13 districts following heavy rains, triggering flooding. The southern part of the country has been experiencing above normal rain since 22nd January. 230,000 are reportedly without shelter, and with forecasts by the Malawi's Meteorological Department of more rains and flooding the situation is likely to further deteriorate. Food, water and WASH are critical needs, as is emergency shelter and assistance to rebuild and repair damaged homes. A DREF was launched 30 January 2019 to provide immediate relief assistance to 2,000 households in WASH and Shelter who have been most affected by the flooding in Makhuwira, Lundu, Maseya, Ndakwela, Masache, Ngowe and katunga. The DREF will also ensure that MRCS is able to finalize a detailed assessment that will inform the course of the operation and allow for the plan of action to be revised if necessary.

Venezuela - Health Emergency
summary:
The country has faced several challenges in recent years. In 2019 there has been a series of events that increased the need for actions aimed at strengthening efforts to support capacities to meet the demand for health care and other sectors such as water, sanitation and hygiene promotion, food safety and nutrition.

 

Various national, governmental, and international organizations are developing projects to support affected families. However, needs continue to increase, and humanitarian actions are required to meet the most urgent needs in the Venezuelan context.

 

Access to medical equipment, medicines and medical consumables in hospitals has been reduced, including in the Venezuela Red Cross (VRC) health network. Another challenge is the rapid deterioration of equipment and accessories to assist the population that requires health and care services. Medical equipment needs replacement and urgent maintenance to cover the high demand for medical services, throughout the wider public health care system, including VRC health network. Also, national power outages have caused the deterioration of the functioning conditions in the health facilities, which generates an immediate need to invest in a better operative integrity in case of presenting or prolonging the difficulties of having continuous electrical sources in public health installations. Medical equipment, including power generators, are particularly in demand.

 

According to reports from VRC, health services particularly affected are those attending patients with chronic or life- threatening diseases. Medical items are not available on the local market, or only in a very limited quantity, and lifesaving treatments are lacking (especially insulin, ARV for HIV, diabetes, hypertension drugs or cancer, among others). There is a shortage of medical supplies and access to antibiotics, analgesics, nutritional supplements, and contraceptives is limited.

 

There has been a re-emergence of diseases that were previously under control. Provision of essential health care to the most vulnerable communities is required to significantly reduce cases and prevent the spread of infections including malaria, tuberculosis, HIV, measles or diphtheria.

 

The current context has diminished the capacity of health services due to the lack of health personnel (mainly physicians and nurses, including also lab technicians, psychologists, physiotherapists, etc.), which is combined with low salary rates, and the hyperinflation which made it very difficult for patients to comply with treatments, undergo surgical procedures, and treat acute diseases (breast cancer, leukemia, hemophilia, etc.).

name: Pakistan: Drought
summary:
Animals are dying and people struggling to feed themselves as drought tightens its grip on Pakistan’s Largest provinces of Balochistan & Sindh. According to drought alret situation issued by Pakistan Metrological Department PMD, due to deficient summer, monsoon rainfall, Moderate drought-like conditions have emerged over Both Provinces Sindh & Baluchistan including Sukkur, Khairpur, Sanghar, Umerkot, Badin, Tharparkar, Kachho & Kohistan areas of Districts Thatta, Jamshoro and Dadu in Sindh and Noshki, Pashin, Kharan, Dalbandin, Gwadar, Jiwani, Panjgur, Pasni, Nokkundi, Ormara, Quetta and Turbat in Baluchistan In total, Sindh faces moderate to severe drought in 08 districts while Baluchistan faces the same in 18 districts. Since October 2018 the drought situation had forced thousands of people out of their homes in Sindh & Baluchistan. on January 18, 2019, National Disaster Management Authority who is main coordinating body for disaster response body in Pakistan, declared mentioned areas as calamity hit areas and urged humanitarian actors to support govt and affected people in time of need. 

Due to no rains over the long period in Pakistan, the areas of Sindh and Baluchistan are suffering from drought situation and estimated people affected are Sindh 420,946 HHs & Baluchistan 134,115 HHs and animals are dying due to lack of fodder and local community is forced to migration if there are no urgent actions are taken to support their lives and livelihoods. Government is providing some wheat 50kg packages that is not fully up to the needs. in addition to government response some of local organization are providing some fodder to small group of communities and that is also not sufficient. National Drought conference has been organized on January 18, 2018 in Islamabad, where national disaster response authority requested UN agencies and other non governmental organizations to extend their support in time of need.  Keeping in view PRCS has also deployed teams for rapid need assessment in affected districts of Sindh and Balochistan.

Dominican Republic: Outbreak
summary: La Cruz Roja Dominicana, desde el 4 de Julio de 2018, empieza a recibir notificaciones de que en el Municipio de la Descubierta, en  la sección de Angel Felix y los Pinos, Provincia Independencia han estado reportando casos de EDA(Enfermedades Diarreicas Agudas)  El Presidente de la Cruz Roja de la Descubierta, especialista en Agua, Saneamiento e Higiene (Equipo EDAS), se movilizo a las mencionadas comunidades a realizar una evaluación del Sistema de Acueductos Rurales y a entrevistarse con la Directora del Centro Médico de los Pinos.-Esta evaluación arrojó que el tanque de agua de este sistema de acueducto estaba muy contaminado por basura, hierro y barro.  Lo cual conllevo a una intervención por la Cruz Roja Dominicana junto a las redes comunitarias de la zona que limpiaron y pusieron en funcionamiento este tanque. En el estudio del agua, se reflejó la falta de cloro y una elevada acidez.Los Líderes comunitarios expresaron a la Cruz Roja su preocupación, ya  que muchas personas estaban descendiendo con vómitos y diarrea desde la parte alta de la comunidad de los Pinos y Angel Félix, siendo la mayoría de esta población personas migrante desde Haití. Los cuales trabajan la agricultura en la zona. En sus asentamientos no tienen baños. Defecan al aire libre y contaminan las fuentes de agua que abastecen los acueductos comunitarios. Se empezaron a recibir en el Centro de Salud personas con vómitos y Diarrea de la misma comunidad de Angel Feliz y los Pinos. Así como de la comunidad de Mamuse. El Personal del Centro de Salud reporta que se les ha notificado de personas fallecidas las cuales no han sido llevadas a este.El Presidente de la Descubierta realiza un informe de situacion, en base a las evaluaciones realizadas y lo envía al Nivel Nacional. La Sede Central de la Cruz Roja Dominicana,  moviliza un equipo de Salud Comunitaria encabezado por el Dr. Leonardo Arias,  por el Presidente de la Cruz Roja  Dominicana filial Duvergé y el Presidente de la Filial de Cruz Roja de la Descubierta, los cuales se entrevistaron en el Hospital de la Descubierta, con su directora, para hacer una evaluación integral de todas las áreas afectadas. En esta reunión se confirmo que los pacientes provenían de las zonas antes mencionadas, que se habían enviado muestras al Laboratorio Nacional y que algunas habían resultado positivo a Vibrium cholera, confirmando la muerte de una persona en días anteriores realizada a este brote de EDA. A partir de acá se establecieron las lineas de acción a seguir: 1.	Trabajar labores de Agua, Saneamiento e Higiene2.	Fortalecimiento de Capacidades a los líderes comunitarios 3.	Sensibilización sobre buenos hábitos de higiene y promoción de la Salud4.	Entrega de Ayuda humanitaria

name: Sri Lanka: Heavy Rain and Strong Wind Advisory
Costa Rica: Floods
summary: On 2 October 2018, the IMN warned of a low-pressure system coming in from the south-western Caribbean Sea, which activated an Inter-Tropical Convergence Zone over the country and over the waters of the Pacific (Meteorological Report # 2). On 4 October, IMN detected two other low-pressure systems (Meteorological Report #8), one in the Caribbean near the Nicaraguan coast and another in the Pacific in western Costa Rica, that led to even more intense rainfall and severe weather conditions along the Pacific coast and slightly milder conditions in other parts of the country. Rains of varying intensity fell in Pacific regions and even in the Central Valley. The greatest amount of rainfall was recorded in the Nicoya Peninsula and the Central Pacific, where between 50 to150 mm over a period of 24 hours. 125,190 people were affected by the floods.

name: Dominican Republic: Cholera Outbreak
summary:
During Epidemiological Week (EW) 28, the Ministry of Public Health and Epidemiology reported that the Los Pinos Health Center (La Descubierta, municipality) saw an increase in the number of patients with acute diarrhoeal diseases from surrounding communities, which were suspected to be cases of cholera.
In EW 32, the Ministry of Health reported that Vibrio cholerae had been identified in samples collected from residents of La Descubierta municipality in the National Public Health Laboratory. The same report also stated that three confirmed cases of cholera in the municipality had been identified.
Since the outbreak began in EW 28 and up to EW 34, 4 confirmed cases of cholera and 91 suspected cases have been identified in the municipality (please see Figure 1 below), in residents of Los Pinos del Edén, Ángel Feliz, urban area of La Descubierta and Los Bolos.
.

name: Bangladesh: Displacement Due to Embankment Collapse
summary:
Bangladesh is situated on the Ganges Delta and highly prone to floods. Coastal flooding, combined with the bursting of river banks is common, and severely affects the landscape and society of Bangladesh. 80% of Bangladesh is floodplain. Flooding normally occurs during the monsoon season from June to September. The usual rainfall of the monsoon is added to by relief rainfall by the Himalayas. Meltwater from the Himalayas is also a significant input. 

The current river erosion and water related disaster in some parts of Bangladesh particularly in Shariatpur is however not due to heavy rain in the area but due to rise of river water in one of the major river systems – Padma river, due to torrential rain and major flooding in some parts of India and Nepal recently. Padma river receives most of water discharged from Ganges, a major river network in India, and when there is flooding in India that obviously puts enormous pressure on Padma, and its destructive power increases accordingly. That was why there has been huge damage of and impact on the river bank and many houses and shelters across about 5 km stretch of Padma river were washed away. The erosion however wasn’t the new problem and it did start some time ago and communities were of course seen vulnerable since long time ago. However, the river has struck hard to the already vulnerable points in last 2-3 weeks because of its increased water level and velocity, hence the vulnerable portion of the river bank could not withstand it and collapsed along with houses and shelters.

As of now, 4 unions and 1 municipality eroded of Naria Upazila and 2 uinons of Zajira Upazila in Shariatpur district. The erosion has been continuing since last couple of weeks. In both upazila’s total numbers of 8,710 families (8,595 families in Naria upazila and 115 families in Zajira upazila, approximately 43,550 peoples) have been affected by the river erosion 2018 . There is severe erosion in at least 10 points covering 7 kilometers on the banks of the Padma in Shariatpur district including Naria Pourashava, Kedarpur Union, Moktarer Char Union, Nawa Para Union, Charatra Union and Gharisara union. In addition to homes, all of the roads, bridges, culverts, and other critical infrastructure in the areas have submerged in the river. At least 200 businesses at Sadhur Bazar and 200 shops in the Wapda Bazar area have eroded into the river as well. It is also reported that riverbank erosion has been started in Gaibanha, Bogra, Rajbari, Manikganj and Jamalpur district.

name: DPR Korea: Floods and Landslides
Ghana: Devastating floods in the north
summary: Torrential seasonal rains beginning from the first week of August to date, have devastated many communities in the Northern and Upper East regions of Ghana and have been worsened with the annual spillage of the Bagre and Kompienga dams in Burkina Faso. The impact has been the displacement of several people especially those living along the White Volta and are currently living with relatives and friends. The rains have since not ceased and is now raining almost on daily basis. So far 110 communities in 13 districts with a total of 18,886 people have been affected in the Upper East region, whilst in the Northern region 202 communities in 9 districts and 10,567 people have been affected. Several houses and farm crops have been destroyed. Furthermore the Northern region have reported the deaths of 9 people and 12 people injured, whilst the Upper East region reported 6 people dead 1 and missing. A joint assessment team made of the Red Cross, National Disaster Management Organization (NADMO) and the Inter-Agency Working Group for Emergencies of which the Ghana Red Cross Society is also a member are currently in the field conducting a detailed assessment of the situation.

name: Ethiopia IDP Population Movement
summary:
Since September 2017, over 1.2 million people have been internally displaced mainly along the Somali-Oromia borders, due to conflict. These people are still suffering due to a lack of basic services and facilities such as shelter, water and health care. In addition, localized inter-communal conflict has also been claiming lives of many people, damaging property, belongings and livelihoods in Moyale Somali and other parts of the country. Since 18th April 2018, there has been growing tension and conflict in the region following a significant political, social and economic reform the Federal government is implementing all over the country.
Since 4th August 2018, there have been ethnic clashes between Somali and non-Somali ethnic groups in the Somali region of Ethiopia. The clashes have turned into widespread violence causing at least 52,000 people being internally displaced in Jijiga, Kebri Dehar, Degehabur and Gode towns.

name: Armenia: Hailstorm and floods
summary: Between 17 to 18 August 2018, devastating hail storms damaged almost all yield capacity of about 12 communities in Shirak region, Armenia. According to the rapid assessment reports conducted by the Shirak regional administration and the ARCS`s Shirak Branch 12 communities have been affected by the disaster. The number of affected households is still to be assessed which will be done by ARCS shortly. Among the most damaged crops are potatoes, vegetables, flax, cumin, lentils, peas, cucumber, etc. Moreover, there were also a few cases of the storms damaging roofs of the houses and cattle farms.Namely, with the loss of the harvest, the communities will not only be unable to repay the debts they have already acquired but they are not in a position to buy goods in the shops on credit any longer.  The provincial commission is in the disaster area, trying to estimate the amount of damage. As for the support, it is being calculated how much damage has been made due to the disaster. This is compared to the state's financial resources and may be supported in a certain proportion. Previously the support was provided with land tax compensation, or in the form of a compromise on water, this year the Government is discussing the issue of the possibility of direct monetary cash support.

countries society-name: Red Cross Society of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea
name: DPR Korea: Typhoon Soulik
summary: Soulik became a typhoon on last Friday, 17th of August. DPRK could potentially see significant impacts from Typhoon Soulik from Thursday into Friday 23-24th of August. Even though it might be weakening by then, Soulik could still remain a dangerous typhoon and bring life-threatening conditions. Heavy rainfall spreading across the Korean Peninsula may lead to flash flooding and mudslides across the rugged terrain.

name: India: Floods
summary: India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued the below alert late evening on the 07th August followed by another one on 8th morning on the below mentioned, that are causing rainfall across Central, North, East and North-eastern parts of the country.There is a deep depression lay over north west bay of Bengal, which is close to Balasore in Odisha state (Eastern part of India).There is a cyclonic circulation over north Pakistan and adjoining Jammu and Kashmir (Northern part of India).There is cyclonic circulation over northwest Madhya Pradesh (Central part of India).Rainfall has been reported over the past 24 hours across many parts of the East, North-East, Central and Northern parts of the country. IMD forecasts massive rainfall for North-East covering Manipur,  Assam, Arunachal and other NE states and will cause floods and landslides disrupting normal life. IMD also forecasts that these conditions will prevail for the next 10 days.Since the monsoon set in during June; Assam, Gujarat, Kerala, Maharashtra, West Bengal and Maharashtra have received rainfall and floods that has caused around 553 deaths, 1.5 million people affected, thousands of people evacuated to safe shelters.

countries society-name: Red Cross Society of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea
name: DPR Korea: Heat wave
summary: On 2nd August 2018 the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea Red Cross Society officially informed the IFRC Country Office in the DPRK of a developing emergency in both South Phyongan and South Hamgyong Provinces due to a recent heatwave which is severely affecting agricultural production. The heatwave has brought temperatures of over 35C across the country and has as of 3rd August has lasted for 23 days in all parts of the country beginning on 12th July 2018. This climatic event is seriously affecting agricultural production of the country. There have been reported casualties among elderly people and children due to heat stroke and these reports are being followed up by the local branches. It is anticipated that this weather pattern will continue until mid-August and will significantly reduce the yield and affect the livelihood of the people in the affected communities. According to state media. Korean Workers' Party newspaper Rodong Sinmun stated on 2 August the Pyongyang government has declared a state of emergency because of the unusually hot weather.

countries society-name: Papua New Guinea Red Cross Society
name: Papua New Guinea: Polio outbreak
summary:
•	Index case is six year old boy from ‘4 mile’ settlement in Lae, Morobe, VDPV type 1 confirmed from child’s stool- Confirmed by VIDRL on 21 May 2018
•	As per WHO guidelines, children in the index case’s community contacts were tested, to determine if the virus is circulating
-	22 from Morobe and 20 from E. Highlands
•	On 21 June, results received from lab that the same virus was found in two contacts in Lae
•	This demonstrates that the virus is circulating in Lae, Morobe; however missed transmission in other areas cannot yet be ruled out
•	Results from East Highlands (origin of the family)- Pending

Initial Action taken:

	On 22 June, the National IHR Focal Point of Papua New Guinea notified WHO of the index case of cVDPV1 and the confirmation cVDPV1 among two asymptomatic community contacts of the index case.
	On 25 June, the National Department of Health declared a polio outbreak in Papua New Guinea.
	On 26 June, the Papua New Guinea National Executive Council and Cabinet declared the polio outbreak as a National Public Health Emergency. The Government committed PGK 6.7 million to support outbreak response.
	The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) provided initial supported to Papua New Guinea with USD 500,000 for response activities.
	On 27 June 2018, the National Department of Health activated the National Emergency Operations Center and formed a National Emergency Response Team.
	First Emergency Health Cluster meeting organized today for coordination and update the situation. PNG RC and IFRC present in the meeting.
	PNG will be considered an infected country for 12 months after the most recent detection
	Other Member States to be alerted to the risk through Disease Outbreak Notification
	Travelers Health will be updated also so that visitors to PNG may get vaccinated

Surveillance:

	Increase the target rate for non-polio AFP
–	Increase the annualised target for non-polio AFP rate to 3 cases per 100,000 population in the provinces of Chimbu, Eastern Highlands, Jiwaka, Madang, Morobe, Western Highlands and National Capital District
–	Increase the annualised target for non-polio AFP rate to 2 cases per 100,000 population in all other provinces 
	Collect stool samples from contacts of AFP cases
–	Collect stool samples from 3 close family or household contacts of all AFP cases in Goroka, Lae, Madang City and Port Moresby. 
–	Collect stool samples from 3 close family or household contacts of all AFP cases with inadequate stool sample collection in the provinces of Chimbu, Eastern Highlands (outside Goroka), Jiwaka, Madang (outside Madang City), Morobe (outside Lae), Western Highlands and National Capital District.
	In seven highest risk provinces, (Morobe, Madang, EHP, Jiwaka, Chimbu, WHP, NCD)
–	Active search of AFP cases
–	Review medical records for last 6 months
–	Training on AFP surveillance for health care workers to be conducted
	Implement environmental surveillance, initially in NCD and Lae

Low Vaccination coverage (%) across the provinces:


RC/RC Action:

-	As per the request from NDoH and WHO, PNG Red Cross will mobilize volunteers during the vaccination campaign
-	PNG RC send volunteers for Polio vaccination training will organize by WHO
-	IFRC requested PNG RC to make soonest possible decision whether or not request for DREF operation.
-	PNG RC will have council meeting tomorrow, the decision will be taken the meeting and shared with HoCO, IFRC.

name: Niger: Cholera Outbreak
summary:
On the night of 4 to 5 July 2018, the health centre of N’Yelwa (Maradi region of Niger) received three (3) people originated from JIBIYA (in the neighbouring Nigeria), they were presenting acute watery diarrhoea, vomiting with severe dehydration. Out of the three affected people, one died 20 minutes after their admission to the health Centre. They were all from the same family and they are all Niger citizens.

On 6 July 2018, a new case was reported at the same health Centre, this new case came from Dan Koussou village situated at four (4) kms away from the health centre. 

On 7 July 2018, three (3) other new cases were admitted to the same N’Yelwa health centre. Among the three, two (2) people came from Dan Koussou village and one from Abdallah village situated 4 km away from JIBIYA health Centre.

On 12 July 2018, the CERMES Laboratory of Niamey confirmed the presence of Vibrio cholerae 01 inaba in the sample taken from the affected cases that originated from. Dan Koussou village.
According to the report of the Directorate of surveillance and response to Epidemics of the Niger Ministry of Public Health and Population, on Cholera Epidemic outbreak in the Maradi region of the country, a cholera epidemic outbreak have been declared in 6 health centres of the region. The report revealed that 123 suspects cases have been reported as of 17 July 2018 including four (4) deaths for a lethality rate 2,4%. The report also indicated that at least six (6) health centres are affected by the outbreak they includes: Dan Issa, Gabi, Harounawa, Madeini, Maraka and N’Yelwa. The Health centres are all in the region of Maradi. Further, the report indicated that 50.4% of the affected population are males. 

The Niger Minister of Public Health and Population made an official declaration on Friday 13/07/2018 during a press conference. Further, he instructed the following actions:
-	To open six (6) operational sites for free of charge treatment, 
-	To reinforce epidemiological surveillance with daily report on new cases in all the health centres of the region, 
-	To pre-position cholera treatment kits in high risk health districts, 
-	To deploy treatment products in the affected health centres, 
-	To hold daily meetings of the epidemic management committee put in place by the MoH including the Niger Red Cross Society;
-	To increase community-based awareness raising to the population on the symptoms of cholera through the existing communication channel,
-	To increase community-based awareness raising to the population on the use of health services;
-	The use of community relays, Red Cross volunteers and community leaders for community-based awareness sessions

With regard to the awareness raising activities, the Governor of the Maradi region, calls upon the regional Red Cross branch President to seek for Red Cross support in response to this epidemic outbreak. So far the Niger Red Cross Maradi regional branch has deployed 15 volunteers to carry out awareness sessions at the affected health centres and the Red Cross also provided six (6) tents for isolation of the affected people during their treatment.

name: Dominican Republic: Floods
summary:
Los remanentes de Beryl dejaron lluvias en la Republica Dominicana, especialmente en Santo Domingo y San Cristobal.
La Cruz Roja Dominicana Filial San Cristobal, en coordinación con la Dirección Provincial de Salud Pública, realizó prevención de enfermedades, en los Barrios afectados por las fuertes lluvias producto del paso de la tormenta Tropical, Beryl, donde Fueron afectados los Barrios- Simón Bolívar, Urb. Primaveral, Madre vieja norte, sector Universidad UNIREMHOS, Pueblo nuevo Centro, La Suiza, los Molinas, Villa Progreso 2, Moscú, Los Americanos, Bo. Urbio, lava pies, Sante 1-2-3, las personas ya volvieron a sus casas- se ha cerrado el albergue del centro comunal el Moscú.
Se reporta daño en la planta distribuidora de agua de la comunidad la cual imposibilita la distribución, camiones del INAPA y comerciales suplen el agua a la población.-

Evaluación realizada en el municipio de Haina: en los siguientes sectores: 

1-) Itabo-
2-) Cachon
3-) Puente Seco.
4-) Hoyo de Yoya y 5 de Mayo.

En el sector de Itabo El Ministerio de Salud se encuentra interviniendo, así como la sindicatura.
El Ministerio de Salud esta vacunando en conjunto con voluntarios de la Cruz Roja de la Filial de San Cristóbal, y la sindicatura está realizando descacharizacion en el sector, donde se suplen de agua para tomar de la compañía Luz María. 

Las familias en este sector son 51, de las cuales la mitad están albergados temporalmente en la iglesia, a causa de que sus hogares perdieron el techo.

En el sector Puente Seco la situación es a causa de represar la cañada del sector por parte del propietario de un taller de mecánica, provocando inundaciones, comunitarios del lugar realizaron un censo de la población afectada. La situacion ha sido transmitida a la Sindicatura.

En el sector Hoyo de Yoya, comunitarios expresaron que el agua proveniente del acueducto llego en la noche de ayer (el servicio del líquido está siendo suplido en lo que se visualizó por camiones cisternas.)

Las Evaluaciones EDAN fueron realizadas por los Tec. Julio Urbaez y Juan Almonte, se llevaron a cabo tomas aéreas con un Vehículo Aéreo No Tripulado, Piloteado por el Tec. Juan Almonte con apoyo y colaboración conjunta con el Centro de Control del Instituto Dominicana de Aviación Civil realizando llamadas telefónicas 10 min. Antes de despegar y al culminar la operación.

Recomendaciones: Continuar el monitoreo y coordinación conjunta con el Comité de Prevención Mitigación y Respuesta del municipio. (Sector Itabo).

En el ámbito de Shellter: comunidad de 51 familias. 
Necesitan apoyo en la reparación de las viviendas, menos de la mitad de las causas, a causa, de la pérdida del techo. Por condiciones preexistentes, en malas condiciones antes del evento. 
Intervención no es lo más recomendable ya que el ayuntamiento y el INVI están en el lugar reparando los techos y las paredes destruidas

name: Nigeria: Floods
summary:
Due to the unabated rainfall that started in the month of July had plunged more than 80 percent of Nigeria with flood, 28 states out of 36 including Federal Capital Territory have been affected with unprecedented highwater level. Nigerian Red Cross already secured DREF with which we commenced the initial response. However, recent reports from the NRCS 37 branches indicated that, more states are now affected. Above 100 deaths have been recorded with the highest death more than 48 from Niger state housing 6 Dams.  NIMET has predicted more rainfall in the next three weeks across the nation which may likely lead to higher flooding from the upper catchment of the Niger basin. States that are affected are those contagious to River Niger and Benue which are Kebbi, Niger, Kwara, Kogi, Edo, Anambra, Rivers, Delta, Bayelsa, Adamawa, Taraba, Benue and Nasarawa.
In all the States, the Red Cross local Branch volunteers worked with other emergency response agencies to evacuate the injured, provide first aid and psychosocial support and keep track of the incident. A total of 7,417 persons have so far been affected with over 4,000 displaced mostly in Katsina State. The NRCS NHQ is mobilizing for a detailed assessment on the situation and reviewing its Contingency plan.

name: Serbia: 11 Municipalities affected by heavy rain and hail falls
summary:
In last three days Republic of Serbia was affected by heavy rain and hail falls. Most affected areas were districts of Zlatibor, Kolubara, Morava, as well Eastern part of Serbia. 11 municipalities and cities reported that were affected by heavy rain and hail storms. 
City of Uzice was affected by heavy rain and hail falls. Due to this hazards and huge quantity of water that came from mountains, city Center of Uzice was totally blocked and flooded. Dozens of cars and facilities in the centre of the city were affected.
City of Pozarevac was also affected by heavy rain falls. Streets in city centre were covered by water and in some streets basements were flooded. There was one tragic event in Pozarevac, man 67 years old loosed his life. 
City of Ljig, municipalities Velika Plana, Svilajnac and Smederevska Palanka were affected by storm surge. In Ljig fields and roads were flooded, accumulated water drove several rural roads and bridges. The most affected were Belanovica and Kozelj, where many houses remained under water.
The municipality of Topola was affected by storm surge. Due to heavy hail falls lands with fruit and vegetables in some villages was completely destroyed. Several households and objects were severely affected in villages of Belosavci, Krcevac i Tresnjevica.
City of Petrovac na Mlavi was severely affected as well by heavy rain and hail falls. Villages of Burvac, Tabanovac, Oreskovica, Dobrnje, Bošnjak i Lopusnik were most affected. There was a threat of bursting a dam. Currently state of emergency is declared and situation is under control. 
In Aleksinac there is a situation drinking water. Several villages in this municipality are having problems with drinking water. Water sources in this villages are affected by high groundwater level. Also, drinking water sources in centre in Kuline (special hospital and social welfare centre for persons with Intellectual disabilities) are not usable

countries society-name: Red Cross Society of China, Philippine Red Cross, Vietnam Red Cross Society
name: GDACS Orange: Philippines, China, Viet Nam TC Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 93 km/h)
summary: From 15/07/2018 to 15/07/2018, a Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 93 km/h) ELEVEN-18 was active in NWPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Philippines, China, Viet Nam (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.

name: China: Floods
summary:
Heavy and continuous rainfall since July 7, has caused flooding in most parts of Sichuan and the southeast of Gansu Provinces. In some areas of North Central Sichuan, there has been heavy rainstorm for 4 consecutive days and a local torrential rain. According to reports from National Disaster Reduction Commission, as of July 13, floods have affected 1,381,000 people, 3 persons have died; 222,000 have taken emergency resettlement, 22,000 persons needed emergency relief in Sichuan prefectures of Deyang, Mianyang, Guangyuan that includes 15 cities and 70 counties (cities, districts). More than 900 houses have collapsed and 29,000 have been damaged. A total of 36,900 hectares of crops have been affected by the floods and 5,200 hectares will have no harvest this year. The direct economic loss has been estimated to be over CNY 5.3 billion.

According to the rapid assessment of the National Disaster Reduction Center, heavy rainfall may cause a large number of seriously damaged houses continue to collapse in these 2 provinces. More rain has been falling over the past week, worsening the flood situation. The flooding season will continue until the end of August and more rain can be expected until then.

name: Benin: Affrontement entre agriculteurs et éleveurs
summary: Suite aux affrontements entre éleveurs et agriculteurs survenus le dimanche 08 juillet 2018 dans la commune de Cobly (Département de l'Atacora), huit cent (800) personnes se sont déplacées. Dans un message radio le lundi 09 juillet 2018, conjointement au Maire de la commune de Cobly, Madame le Préfet de l'Atacora a notifié la situation et a convié les populations à un apaisement car des dispositions sont amorcées afin de maîtriser les dégâts enregistrés. A ce jour, 2708 déplacés sont recensés dans les cinq (05) sites d'hébergement répartis dans les 2 communes affectées.

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: DRC: Épidémie de choléra / zone de sante de Lukula
summary:
Le ministre de la santé du Kongo-central a déclaré vendredi 06 juillet 2018 dernier l’épidémie du choléra dans toute la province du Kongo-Central. Dix personnes ont déjà trouvé la mort dans cette province à la suite de cette maladie depuis le début de l’année 2018.Les zones de sante déjà touchées par cette épidémie sont la zone de sante de Lukula, Matadi, de Boma ainsi que les zones de sante de Boko Kivulu et Kimpese.
Actuellement c’est la zone de sante de Lukula qui est entre en épidémie, et on dénombre à ce jour 218 cas dont 10 décès.
La maladie se propage avec une vitesse vertigineuse parce qu’elle se transmet par la voie oro-fécale, c.à.d. par ingestion d’eau ou d’aliments contaminés par des déchets humains infectés. Les facteurs favorisants sont :
-	Faible accès à l’eau potable ;
-	Absence d’actions d’assainissement ;
-	Faible pratique des règles d’hygiène individuelles, domiciliaire et péri-domiciliaire ;
-	Manque de respect de règles de l’hygiène fécale : les gens déversent les excréments dans des rivière Lufiku, Lukula etc…
-	Absence totale des activités de sensibilisation.

Il est demande à la population au respect des mesures d’hygiène notamment en lavant convenablement les aliments ou les fruits avant de les consommer, en se lavant les mains après les toilettes et en consommant toujours de l’eau potable.
Plusieurs centres de traitement de choléra ont par ailleurs été installés depuis le week-end dans les villes de Matadi et de Boma pour la prise en charge gratuite des éventuels malades, a-t-il annoncé.
Avant cela il y a un mois, en juin dernier une épidémie de choléra a été déclarée dans les zones de sante de la Division Provinciale de la sante de du Kasaï Oriental le samedi 16 juin 2018, que le Gouverneur provincial vient de déclarer l’épidémie de choléra dans la Ville de Mbuji-Mayi et dans quatre mois dans la ville de Mbuji-Mayi un total 833 cas de choléra ont été notifies dont 104 décès. Bonzola, Lubilanji, Nzaba, Citenga, Muya, Diulu, Muya et Bipemba.

name: El Salvador: Heat wave
summary:
el día 9 de julio de este año eñ Ministerio de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales declaro sequía meteorológica severa para los cuatro departamentos de la zona oriental del país y sequía moderada para la zona paracentral y zona costera de la región central y algunas partes de la zona occidental.
Este fenómeno a generado impacto especialmente en le cultivo del maíz en la zona oriental del país, ademas se debe suspender el plantío de cafeto hasta que inicien las lluvias ademas de vigilar el aparecimiento de ´plagas y enfermedades en el sector agropecuario
dado lo anterior el secretario para asuntos de vulnerabilidad y director General de Protección Civil emitió el 13 de julio AVISO SOBRE EL FENÓMENO DE SEQUÍA Y SU ATENCIÓN

name: GDACS Orange: Japan FL Magnitude 0.00
summary: On 05/07/2018, a flood started in Japan, lasting until 09/07/2018 (last update). The flood caused 100 killed and 1500000 displaced .

name: Mongolia: Floods
summary: Due to heavy rain in Western part of the country followed by dry session followed by heavy rain, flash flooding occurred in the Western part of the country. More than 200 families affected and 468 more need support.

name: GDACS Red: Japan TC Hurricane/Typhoon > 74 mph (maximum wind speed of 213 km/h)
summary: From 02/07/2018 to 05/07/2018, a Hurricane/Typhoon > 74 mph (maximum wind speed of 241 km/h) MARIA-18 was active in NWPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Japan (vulnerability Low). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 1.271 million.

name: Georgia: Flash Floods in Svaneti
summary:
On July 5th, 2018, the part of the mountain in Chuberi community has collapsed, which caused blocking of the Nenskra River. Accumulated water has flooded the Nenskra valley villages. There are 10 villages in Chuberi community with thousands of residents living there. 
Infrastructure has been damaged; roads and bridges connecting the villages as well as agricultural lands, fruit trees and wooden factories are totally destroyed. Electricity lines have been damaged. 
Emergency Management Service and all relevant ministries are involved in the liquidation works of the flooding of the river Neskra in Chuberi village, Mestia Municipality. The taskforce is established and the members are holding the meetings to deal with the situation. Additional rescue teams and techniques are mobilized from the nearest locations and in case of need evacuation of the Chuberi population will be carried out. 
According to the information received from the Georgia Red Cross Society Mestia branch representatives, by this time eight families are evacuated and they are living in their relatives’ houses.
Currently, the main threat to the river Nenskra has been solved, but some risks still exist.
Specialists of the National Environmental Agency are studying the causes of the disaster in the affected area; They are developing recommendations to carry out preventive measures. 
It’s planned to construct four temporary bridges to connect the villages of Chuberi community.

name: Kyrgyzstan: Explosion
summary:
Following the information received from Red Crescent Society of Kyrgyzstan (RCSK) volunteers on 4 July 2018 a fire lead to massive explosion at the gas station in Arka village, Leilek district, Batken province. Explosion blew up several near located buildings, 10 vehicles and affected four people (3 citizens of Tajikistan and 1 Kyrgyzstan citizen). All injured people were hospitalized- citizens of Tajikistan were transported to near located hospital of Tajikistan and Kyrgyz citizen was taken to the Arka village hospital. 
According the information received from Ministry of Emergency Situations Batken department fire have begun at 20:30 on 4 July and was localized at 05:25 next day. One fire brigade from Kyrgyzstan came to the site of emergency; and three fire brigades came from Tajikistan. The operative group of Leilek regional MES KR department and an ambulance team came to the place. At about 22:40 the fire was localized. Because of the fire, the gas station was completely burnt down, the operator's second gas station, five waggons, two gas carriers, two Mercedes-Benz Sprinter minibuses, and a car burnt down. 
According to preliminary data, one gas station was completely burnt down, the operator station burned down at the second station. Among victims, three Tajikistan citizens and one Kyrgyzstan citizen. Tajikistan citizens were hospitalized to Tajikistan’s hospital and a Kyrgyzstan citizen were hospitalized to Kyrgyzstan.
Now, RCSK Batken branch team is continue to monitor the situation.

name: Sudan: Flash floods
summary: On 3rd July 2018 heavy rains and wind storms hit Gezira State, affected 4 villages Hajar Amokashfi, Kudos, Gboja and Maslamya village. 288 houses totally damaged, 172 houses partially damaged, 85 household latrines submerged by water, the winds blown out the schools roofs, 2 school class and one office collapsed. Main major channel collapsed due to water volume, that it cannot absorb. The number of people affected 2300 people (460 households). The stagnant water leads to mosquitos and flies breeding. The urgent needs waters pump for shifting stagnant water, spraying pumps, mosquito nets, tarpaulins, tents, chlorine tabs, insecticides.

name: India: Floods in the North-East
summary:
The monsoon rains that have spread across the country are slowly covering the length and breadth of the country. The states in north-east part of India are currently receiving heavy to very heavy rainfall triggering flash floods and landslides across the region wrecking havoc especially in Assam, Manipur, Mizoram and Tripura. As reports emerge, there is damage to infrastructure, roads washed away and people rendered homeless.
The preliminary information indicate floods affecting 3 districts in Assam, 4 districts in Manipur, I district in Mizoram and one district in Tripura.
The total number of dead are yet to be verified and set to increase with inclement weather forecast for the next week, more flash floods and landslides expected.
The government has established more than 350 relief camps where affected people were evacuated to safer places. Nearly 130000 persons were sheltered in relief camps. nearly 26,000 houses are damaged and 20000 livestock affected.
WASH, shelter and dry food ave been identified as immediate needs of the affected persons.

name: Serbia: Floods
summary:
On 29th of June and several days before there were severe rainfalls on the territory of the Republic of Serbia. Due to this severe weather conditions many cities and municipalities on the territory of the Republic of Serbia were affected. During the 29th of June 2018 there were also thunderstorms in Vojvodina, Sumadija and Pomoravlje regions. The most stronger winds were in Vojvodina with impacts in Subotica 14 m/s and Novi Sad 18 m/s. The most affected were cities of Subotica, Novi Sad and Belgrade. The most affected municipalities in Belgrade were Lazarevac, Rakovica and Obrenovac. Problems occurred due to the fact that in many places the sewage system could not receive large quantities of water that fell on the territory of this cities and municipalities (Belgrade 30-50 L/m2, Novi Sad 116 l/m2, in period of 24 hours). 
The most affected municipalities were in city of Belgrade : - municipality of Cukarica, where were flooded houses in one Roma settlement; municipality of Lazarevac, 35 families were evacuated, with about 100 members. Alost all evacuated people weres accommodated with relatives and neighbors; - In the municipality of Rakovica, about 20 houses have been flooded; in municipality of Obrenovac, 57 houses were partially flooded with the outflow of the Baric brook;

name: GDACS Orange: Japan, Korea, Republic of, Korea, Democratic People's Republic of TC Tropical Depre...
summary: From 28/06/2018 to 28/06/2018, a Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 93 km/h) NINE-18 was active in NWPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Japan, Korea, Republic of, Korea, Democratic People's Republic of (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.

countries society-name: The Red Cross Society of Bosnia and Herzegovina
name: Bosnia and Herzegovina: Population Movement
summary:
On 23th December, fire broke out in Lipa camp destroying large parts of its infrastructure. An estimated 1,400 migrants living in the camp had already begun moving out, along with humanitarian agencies providing support in the camp, because of the poor condition of the camp. The fire  left around 1,400 people withhout shelter together with an estimated 1,500 migrants currently sleeping in the streets and in abandoned buildings in the Bihac area.

Red Cross staff and volunteers continue distributing food and essential items as well as providing health assistance to the migrants residing in the area while negotiations are underway to find sheltered location for the migrants. There is increasing tensions between the migrants and the host community in the area and as of 4th January 2020 migrants have refused all the assistance to increase the pressure on authorities to find a solution and provide living conditions suitable for the winter. 

Background

Countries throughout theaffected  Balkans experienced a significant influx of migrants in 2015 and 2017. BiH, however, not being situated on the main migratory route, was only marginally at that time. Since the beginning of 2018, the country has seen a significant increase in the number of arrivals, with migrants arriving via two different routes: one through Albania and Montenegro; and the other through the Republic of North Macedonia or Bulgaria, and Serbia. Entry points to BiH were in the areas of Trebinje, Foča, Višegrad, Zvornik, and Bijeljina in the Republika Srpska (RS) and Goražde in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina (FBiH). 


The majority of people arriving were heading through Tuzla and Sarajevo to Una-Sana Canton (USC) and seeking to enter the European Union (EU) through Croatia. Many continue to arrive overland in an irregular manner (i.e. not at official border crossings) at several entry points.

Timeline of Events

  • 2018: Due to changes in migration routes, the number of migrants arriving in BiH began to increase. In June 2018, IFRC issues a DREF for 212,444 CHF to assist 3,000 people with food and hygiene parcels. On 8 December 2018 IFRC issues an Emergency Appeal for 3.3m Swiss francs to support up to 7,600 migrants and 1,500 households from the host communities.
  • 2019: Joint IFRC/RCSBiH assessment is carried out throughout the country in October. On 22 November, IFRC issues the Revised Emergency Appeal for 3.8 million Swiss francs to assist 35,000 people and 1,500 households from the host communities.
  • 5 March 2020: First case of COVID-19 confirmed in Bosnia and Herzegovina and shortly afterwards, Government imposed strict movement measures for citizens below 18 and above 65 as well as strict procedures at borders. Revised Emergency Appeal Bosnia and Herzegovina: Population Movement Image 1- Red Cross Mobile Team (MT) assisting people on the move.
  • 22 April 2020: The camp near the village of Lipa, some 20 kilometres from Bihac, is set up.
  • 30 September 2020: Una Sana Canton authorities, forcibly transferring refugees and migrants from the temporary reception centre “Bira” in Bihać outside the emergency facility in Lipa, which is already at full capacity. As a result, hundreds of persons are left in harsh weather conditions without shelter and access to basic assistance.
  • 7 December 2020: Revised Emergency Appeal no. 2 is published extending the operation time frame by 12 months, increasing the targeted population to 50,000 and including additional activities in the camps to address the continuous needs in country.
  • 23 December 2020: Fire breaks out in Lipa camp destroying large parts of its infrastructure. An estimated 1,400 migrants living in the camp had already begun moving out, along with humanitarian agencies providing support in the camp, because of the poor condition of the camp. The fire  left around 1,400 people withhout shelter together with an estimated 1,500 migrants currently sleeping in the streets and in abandoned buildings in the Bihac area.

name: Viet Nam: Flash floods
summary:
•	Continued heavy rainfall in the northern mountainous regions of Viet Nam, including in the provinces of Lai Chau and Ha Giang, has caused extensive flash floods and landslides, claiming lives and destroying important parts of infrastructure and agriculture.
•	According to the reports of the Provincial Steering Committees for Natural Disaster Prevention and Control in affected provinces, .as of 09:00, 26 June, 2018, the flash floods and landsides have caused the damages as follow:
Human:
- Deaths: 15 (Ha Giang: 03 people; Lai Chau: 12 people);
- Missing: 11 people in Lai Chau 
Shelter:
- Collapsed/Swept away: 83 houses 
- IDPs due to damaged houses: 508 households
- Inundated : 962 Houses 
Agriculture and Aquaculture: 735 ha of paddy fields, vegetable crops and livestocks
Transportation system:
-	The highways in Lai Chau have been severely affected. Some roads have been blocked or witnessed the severe congestion due to the landslides 
-	3 suspension bridges and 3 other concretized bridges in Lai Chau have been swept away
The economic loss is etimated at VND 110.6 billion (Ha Giang: 14 billion, Lai Chau: 90 billion, Thai Nguyen: 0.32 billion, Lao Cai: 6.3 billion)

name: Zimbabwe: Blast during a political rally
summary: On 23.06.18 ZRCS response teams managed to successfully render first aid before transferring people injured to nearby medical facilities during the blast incident at a rally at White City Stadium in Bulawayo. Several people were injured and provided immediate assistance by the 32 ZRCS response members and 2 staff members. This First Aid coverage was part of ZRCS’ emergency preparedness and response, enabled by PNS support and working closely with relevant humanitarian authorities in the provision of first aid coverage at public gatherings. Public authorities are still investigating the incident. Meanwhile the the ZRCS is reviewing its preparedness and continues to provide First Aid coverage across the country.

name: Niger: 2018 Floods forecast
summary:
In 2018, Niger is likely to face new floods that could affect more than 170,000, the United Nations warned on Tuesday.

"Some 170,000 people could be affected by the floods this year in Niger, especially in the regions of Dosso and Niamey", in the south-west, warns the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) of Niamey, in its bulletin.

According to the Niger 2018 Rain forecast, it is expected excess rainfall to normal trend over most part of the country. Excessive rainfall accumulations to normal are expected in the Tillaberi, Niamey and Dosso, Tahoua and Maradi regions. Further, normal to excess rainfall accumulations are expected in Zinder and Diffa regions.

The "forecasts" for the period from July to September 2018 "suggest heavy rains" in several parts of the country that may cause "significant floods".
The rainy season has just started in Niger. Despite its short duration - no more than three months - and low rainfall, this country has been facing recurring floods in recent years, including in the very desert areas of the north.

A paradox in this very dry state where poor harvests are usually caused by drought.
This year, the authorities have announced the completion of the construction of several dikes, in order to protect thousands of residents of the capital from the deadly floods caused by the flooding of the Niger River.

In 2017, 56 people, including 20 in Niamey, died in floods that affected more than 206,000 people. More than 12,000 homes have been destroyed, 16,000 heads of cattle decimated and more than 9,800 hectares of crops damaged, according to the UN.

In 2012, floods killed dozens of people and left some 500,000 people affected, causing damage estimated at around 148 million euros, according to an official report

countries society-name: Red Cross Society of Côte d'Ivoire
name: Côte d'Ivoire: Inondations
summary:
Dans la nuit d’hier à aujourd’hui (18 au 19 Juin 2018), des pluies pluvio-orageuses d’une intensité sans précédente se sont abattues sur la Côte d’Ivoire particulièrement sur le district d’Abidjan et le littoral
Tous les quartiers d’Abidjan ont connu des inondations qui ont fait plusieurs victimes. L’on évoque plus d’une centaine de ménages sinistrés et une quinzaine de morts. 
Toutefois plusieurs équipes de la CRCI sont sur les différents sites pour non seulement des opérations de secours, mais aussi pour évaluer la situation afin d’identifier les sinistrés et leurs besoins

name: Japan: Earthquake
summary: A magnitude 6.1 earthquake hit Osaka on 18 June at 7:58 am local time. According to NHK, Japan's public broadcaster, the quake killed 3 people and injured more than 200 people.

name: Bangladesh: Flood
summary: The flood situation in five upazilas of Moulvibazar district worsened further on Saturday with water inundating new areas, leaving people of several hundred villages marooned. According to National Disaster Response Coordination Center (NDRCC) report dated 17 June 2018; total 193,296 people from 40,200 families were affected due to on-going flood. it is also reported embankment was breached in 25 points and 6 people were killed

name: Somalia: Tropical Cyclone Sagar
summary: A tropical cyclone formed in the Gulf of Aden between Yemen and northern Somalia on 16 May 2018. The cyclone system caused heavy rains along the coast Northern Somalia on 17 May. Flash flooding was reported in the Bari region, which were not limited to seasonal riverbeds. The road linking Bossaso and points south has reportedly been affected. There are also reports of some fishing boats having been washed away by waves off the coast of Sanaag region.By 18 May, the cyclone had gained strength, reaching tropical storm-wind levels and assigned the name Tropical Cyclone Sagar. Heavy rains are projected for the northern coastal areas of Somalia.

name: Kyrgyzstan: Flash floods in Batken province
summary:
On 15 June 2018 heavy rainfalls caused massive Flash floods in Batken province of the Kyrgyz Republic. The governor of Batken province declared an emergency situation in three affected districts of Batken province. Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic (MES KR) and local authorities conducted rapid damage assessment and provided cleaning and relief activities.

The Red Crescent Society of Kyrgyzstan (RCSK) conducted emergency needs assessment (ENA) along with MES KR representatives on 15-16 June 2018. According to the RCSK ENA and MES KR assessment results, the total number of affected households in three districts is nearly 200 households and at least 59 houses are damaged

name: Namibia: Repatriation of refugees from Botswana
summary: Repatriation of 900 refugees Dukwi refugee camp in Botswana back to Namibia. This exercise is anticipated to take place as of now until 11th July 2018.

name: Kenya: Rift Valley Fever outbreak
summary: An outbreak of Rift Valley Fever has been reported in Wajir County- Eldas and Wajir East sub counties following the heavy rains experienced throughout the country. Nineteen (19) Human cases of RVF have been reported by the county disease surveillance officer resulting in 6 deaths - CFR 31.6%. Six (6) of the fifteen (15) samples taken for laboratory confirmation have tested positive for RVF. The situation is expected to get worse with syndrome surveillance data reported by the Directorate of Vetenary services indicating that the Pastoral counties (Wajir, Mandera, Marsabit, Isiolo, Samburu, Kitui, Tana River, Garissa, Turkana, West Pokot, Narok, Kajiado and Baringo) have a high risk of being affected. The animal reference laboratories has received 60 animal samples

name: Republic of the Congo: Ebola Virus Disease
Bangladesh: Monsoon effect in the camps in Cox’s Bazar
summary:
Heavy rain has continuously hit the Cox’s Bazar From 11th to 14th June 2018 (http://www.bmd.gov.bd/?/nwp-products/&/wrf-model/) which has impeded the access to and within the camps. Road from Cox’s Bazar to the camp has disturbed by flooding and road damage. Military road has been severely eroded in at least 6 major locations. This appears unlikely to be quickly resolved as water has undermined the structural integrity of culverts and recent remedial works have failed. Remedial works such as concrete drainage and reinforcement does not appear to be assisting in the manner intended, as sand washed from around the concrete preventing water from flowing into them. There are groups of camp workers digging away with shovels with little direction, however little in the way of major earthworks occurring. The rear of the military road, through to the WFP warehouse has turned to deep mud and is impassable. At present, the military road is intact from front to rear (blocked at rear from mud), though with bottlenecks and weak points that will be quickly eroded from heavy vehicle traffic. Other smaller arterial roads (Tasnimarkhola, Burmapara, Kutupalong etc.) appear to be damaged in places however are passable. The Cox’s Bazar-Teknaf Highway has experienced localized flooding; however, this appears to then flow into adjoining plains not remaining on road.
Retaining walls of the sandbag and bamboo design have been collapsed in many locations. Many latrines have been collapsed down hillsides, while latrines at ground level are overflowing into floodwater flowing throughout camps. The outbreak of waterborne diseases is now a serious likelihood with floodwater mixed with polluted stagnant water bodies and latrine sludge. Landslides have been widespread but generally not of a spectacular scale and therefore likely to under-reported. These are mainly land slides into the rear of shelters not always visible from the front, rendering shelters uninhabitable. Camp community are attempting to dig these out thus causing greater potential for slipping in future rains. Given the above considerations and potential for existing medical services to be disrupted or relief supplies to be obstructed by road conditions or repairs, levels of desperation may increase in the coming weeks. Primary risks include the spread of pathogens through polluted waterways and water supplies and the subsequent risks to staff health.

name: Nepal: Monsoon is active
summary:
The Meteorological Forecasting Division has officially declared the onset of monsoon in Nepal June 8, two days ahead of the normal date. This marks the arrival of the rainy season in the country. Monsoon usually enters Nepal on June 10 and withdraws on September 23 every year. 

Monsoon lasts for an average of 105 days. Nepal receives an average of 80 per cent annual rainfall during the monsoon, which originates in the Bay of Bengal and moves along the southern flanks of the Himalayas. The average annual rainfall in Nepal is 1,600 mm, but it varies from place to place depending on climatic conditions.

The period between June and September is called southwest monsoon season. “As per the forecast of the 2018 South Asian Climate Outlook Forum in Pune of India, normal rainfall is most likely during monsoon over most parts of South Asia, including parts of Nepal,” the bulletin read. Countries under SASCOF — Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, Myanmar and Maldives — share weather services with each other.
As monsoon has already been active all over the Nepal, moderate to heavy rainfall is expected in different parts of Nepal, including Kathmandu in coming days. As it is raining heavily since 30th June, it may trigger flash floods over some parts particularly Terai areas.
The Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM) has warned the water level in the rivers and rivulets, including Kamala, Khado, Gagan, Ratu, Bagmati, eastern Rapti, Riukhola, Badganga, western Rapti, Babai, Mohana and Machheli are predicted to rise above the danger mark,” said a flood bulletin issued by the DHM.

name: Cape Verde: Drought & Bad Agricultural Year in Cap Verde
summary:
In view of the drought and bad 2017/2018 agricultural year in Cabo Verde, the Cabo Verde National Red Cross Society plans to make arrangements in partnership and coordination with the "Sahel" Cluster Office of the International Federation to plan and coordinate the launching of an emergency appeal in order to be able to respond in time, with appropriate assistance, to the needs of the most vulnerable individuals, by proposing programs to the financing of donors of the International Federation.

Poor precipitation in time and space, chronic desertification, insufficient harvesting and slaughter of animals have led in 2017/2018, according to the indicators of the recently developed harmonized framework (March 2018), to serious situations of material distress, malnutrition in the areas most affected by drought in the archipelago. This disaster will accentuate the vulnerabilities of groups of populations often exposed to food shortages, and more particularly, children, affected in their growth.

The National Society of the Red Cross of Cabo Verde (CRCV) has conducted as soon as possible, in close collaboration and consultation with its key partners (Ministry of Agriculture, Directorate General of Agriculture, Directorate General of Food Security and of Nutrition and Civil Society Organizations), a needs assessment (see EPoA developed) in the most notoriously affected areas or islands, targeting very precisely the future beneficiaries of our action according to the obvious nature of their vulnerability and the difficulties they are going through right now. It is not a question of filling the considerable deficits due to the poor harvests in 2017/2018, which reveals rather the role of the public authorities, nor to mobilize immense means, but to bring rather to groups well identified a real relief to their suffering and concrete hope for the future.

This evaluation allowed the CRCV to design a response adapted to the needs observed with obviousness, which made it possible to plan our actions taking into account the capacities of the National Society, but also those of the affected communities. This evaluation presented in the form of a Program Description or Action Plan (EPoA) (attached), drafted with an estimated budget, was analyzed and finalized internally a planning meeting of the Operation's DM National Coordination Team (Disaster Management), following field research, local consultations and program development sessions within the team.

The DREF to be requested and the emergency appeal to be developed will then be submitted to the Federation Secretariat in Geneva (Switzerland) for follow-up.

- Meteorological and pluviometric situation: Specifically, 2017 was one of the worst ever since the 1990s (in 1997), where rainfall was scarce and production did not cover 1% of the country's food needs. The CILSS / FAO / Ministry of Agriculture and Environment joint mission, tasked with assessing the agricultural situation of this year 2017, concluded that the 2017/2018 Agricultural Campaign has evolved rather unfavorably, contrary to the forecasts of the Niamey-based Agrhymet Center in Niger ) that predicted a campaign with globally normal to excess rainfall and with a regular early start to the Sahel region. From the beginning of the campaign to date, the pluviometric situation has been characterized by a marked deficit.

- Situation of the evolution of crops: In Cape Verde, until the present date, the evolution of the rained crop in the sowing period (June / July) did not evolve as expected, due to the weak rainfall registered in the months of July to September.

- Water resources situation: Until the end of the rainy season (October 2017), the situation of water resources at national level was characterized by lack of rainfall. Hence, the water reserves of previous years suffered consequences that had repercussions on the annual average volume of available flows, with direct impacts mainly on agriculture and livestock. Given the lack of precipitation, it is not expected to recover the stored volume of water in the main reservoirs / dams (Poilão, Faveta, Saquinho, Canto Cagarra, Figueira Gorda and Flamengos).

- Pasture production situation: With this pluviometric situation at the national level so unfavorable, the forage production is very weak, to see nothing. Livestock reserves stored by farmers are in the final stages of consumption, the availability of water for animal watering tends to become scarce, further aggravating the nutritional status of livestock, consisting essentially of ruminants (81.4% ). The ruminant herd therefore starts from a regular situation to a bad one, in which animals lose weight quickly and begin to show signs of malnutrition, parasitic infestations and other health problems, being sold to the scam by the breeders.

- The phytosanitary situation: Very worrisome in particular by the appearance of a new pest known as the Maize Carrion Spodoptera (Spodoptera frugiperda), in addition to the two usual plagues of the rainforest - locust (Oedaleus senegalensis) and green stink bug (Nezara viridula).

- Zoo-sanitary situation: In all the islands, the most relevant sanitary problem is the internal and external parasitism, associated with problems of nutritional disorders. In some islands, the epidemiological situation is worrisome due to the risk of cattle losses caused by ectoparasitas, especially mites. 

For this year, with the drought and the irregularity of the rains, there was a negative impact on forage production with a direct consequence on the nutritional and sanitary status of the livestock. This fact associated with the limited availability of water for watering has consequences on animal health, production and mortality.

- Food and socio-economic situation of families in rural areas: Considering the current situation of the poor agricultural year of the 2017/2018 campaign due to the drought, agricultural production is deficient in all the islands, reflecting the scarcity of agro-food products and the increase in prices, thus aggravating the state of food and nutritional insecurity with the reduction of economic access to food.

In view of the reality described above, the Government of Cape Verde stated that the country is, in general, facing an inevitable bad agricultural situation. Therefore, the production of maize and beans in the rained is not foreseen, since there are no agro meteorological conditions that favor the production. Even in humid and sub-humid strata where microclimatic conditions tend to be more favorable, agricultural production is not predictable due to lack of precipitation.

According to data from the Economic Analysis of Families, the deficit is stronger for the Seedlings and Small Ruminants (CV02) and Horticultural / Banana and Papaya (CV02). However, the survival deficit is stronger in the "Horticultural / Banana and Papaya" (CV02) Medium of Existence areas, with the islands of Santiago, Santo Antão and Boa Vista being most affected by 25%, 17% and 1% of people very poor, respectively, living at the survival threshold (LS). The protection deficit of means of existence is, to a certain extent, significant in the two areas of Medium Seed and Small Ruminants (CV01) and "Horticultural / Banana and Papaya" (CV02), having areas CV02 , the islands of Santiago (18%) and Santo Antão (18%) were most affected and, in areas CV01, the islands of São Nicolau (17%), Boa Vista (17%) Salt (17%), Brava ), Fogo (14%), Santo Antão (10%) and Santiago (8%), respectively, with poor and very poor people living below the means of survival threshold (LPME).

The information provided by the methodology of the Harmonized Framework for Assessing the Situation of Acute and Projected Food Insecurity in February / March 2018: (Current situation from March to May 2018), it is estimated that from September 2017 to May 2018, approximately 107,432 people (21,487 families) will be in the phase under pressure (Phase 2) and that, 20,641 people (4,129 families) in the crisis situation (Phase 3). Analysis of the Harmonized Framework from February / March 2018 also revealed that the critical population (Phase 4) was 171 (35 households); with no families in a situation of famine (Phase 5) in Cape Verde, from this scenario:

- Phase 5 (Famine): No Municipality referred to as being hungry.

- Phase 4 (Critical situation): Also, no Municipality faced with the critical situation.

- Phase 3 (Crisis situation): Only the Municipality of Porto Novo on the island of 
Santo Antão is in a crisis situation and therefore has households in the most 
affected areas that need immediate intervention to save their lives, protect and 
recover their means of existence (MoU).

- Phase 2 (Situation under pressure): 14 Municipalities are under pressure - All 
Municipalities of the Island of Santiago (Ribeira Grande, São Domingos, São 
Lourenço dos Órgãos, São Salvador do Mundo, Santa Catarina, Tarrafal, Calheta 
de São Miguel and Santa Cruz); Tarrafal de São Nicolau; Boa Vista; Maio; São 
Filipe and Santa Catarina in the Island of Fogo; and Brava.

The drought phenomenon in the 2017/2018 campaign diminishes the ability of rural families to access basic products, aggravating food insecurity and triggering survival strategies, including rural-urban migration movements in search of new livelihoods, with all the inherent implications. If Cape Verde is already a structurally dependent country on the supply of basic food products such as cereals, oils, milk and sugar, the impact of the drought is worsening the situation, especially in the balance of payments.

In summary, the most striking effects of the drought and the bad agricultural year 2017/2018 in Cape Verde are the reduction of the productive capacity of the rural families, the food insecurity, the stress and the depression of the populations. As a consequence, several strategies of survival emerge, just as negative as the rural exodus, with all its implications in urban centers. It was found that 20,812 people, with 4,164 agricultural households (62.3% of rural families) becoming more vulnerable to the situation of the bad agricultural year. The reduction in the productive capacity of rural families is essentially associated with the deterioration of the nutritional and health status of livestock (with a higher incidence in ruminants - 81.4% of livestock) and the reduction of water reserves with negative consequences on the water supply systems. There is also a worrying phytosanitary situation of crops, mainly due to the appearance of pests. Impacts are also being felt on wage-earning agricultural workers who are losing their jobs, as are small traders (retailers) who are suffering from reduced incomes.

name: Malawi: Cholera outbreak
summary:
Salima district in the Central Region of Malawi registered 99 cases of Cholera in the first wave of the year 2017/18 cholera season and there is second wave which has affected some villages like Kasonda and Mtalimanja under GVH Kasonda and Ndewere village under GVH Seketeni, T.A.Khombedza which started last week on 7th June, 2018. The first Cholera which came from Kasonda village died at Salima district hospitals and three cases have been identified. Salima lies along the Lake and apart from cholera the District also experiences floods. Malawi has a running project in the District under Swiss Red Cross(Integrated Community Based Health Project)
Current situation the District has registered seven cases cumulative with two facility deaths. Only one case is in camp as of 25 June 2018

name: Bolivia: Epidemia de Influenza
summary:
En la zona andina de Bolivia (departamentos de La Paz, Potosí y Oruro) el incremento de casos de Influenza inicia entre junio y agosto coincidente con la temporada de invierno. Mientras que en la zona tropical de Bolivia (departamentos de Beni, Pando y Santa Cruz) se registran casos de Influenza en todo el año, existiendo tres picos anuales (el primero durante los meses de abril y mayo; el segundo entre los meses de julio y agosto y el tercero entre los meses de septiembre y octubre). 

Hasta la Semana Epidemiológica (SE) 20 (del 13 al 19 de mayo) el Ministerio de Salud de Bolivia reportó que se tiene 1292 casos confirmados de Influenza a nivel nacional, de los cuales el Departamento de Santa Cruz presenta el mayor porcentaje de casos confirmados (96%), seguido por el Departamento La Paz (1,3%) y el Departamento del Beni (1%). A nacional se tiene 24 decesos confirmados (letalidad 1,85 %)

De acuerdo al canal endémico de la Influenza A (H1N1) y de la Influenza B, desde la SE 14 hasta la SE 18 (abril - mayo) hubo un brote epidémico de Influenza a nivel nacional (ocasionado por la elevada incidencia de Influenza en Santa Cruz). Desde SE 19 el territorio nacional se encuentra en zona de alarma.

El Departamento de Santa Cruz se encuentra en el oriente boliviano, con 370.621 km2 es el departamento más extenso con una población de 3.078.000 habitantes (censo 2012). Políticamente está dividido en 15 provincias y la capital del Departamento es Santa Cruz de la Sierra (ciudad con una población aproximada de 1.454.539 habitantes)
Históricamente los virus tipo A (H1N1 - H3N2) y tipo B se encuentran circulantes en territorio cruceño ocasionando brotes anuales con características estacionales que producen saturación de los servicios de salud y aumento de las demandas de recursos (económicos, materiales y recursos humanos) para poder hacer frente a las emergencias características de cada gestión, así como también ocasionado decesos principalmente en personas con factores de riesgo (niños menores de 5 años, embarazadas, adultos mayores o personas con enfermedades de base) .

Un elemento muy particular que ha alarmado al Ministerio de Salud y al SEDES Santa Cruz es la alta letalidad de la Influenza en la presente gestión, afectando a personas pertenecientes a grupos de riesgo ante este tipo de enfermedades. El 100% de decesos eran personas que tenían enfermedades crónicas de base (diabetes, cardiopatías, hipertensión, cáncer, entre otras). Se ha identificado como causales de estos decesos que estas personas no habían recibido la vacuna contra la Influenza y que acudieron en búsqueda de atención médica de forma tardía (3 o 4 días después de iniciado el cuadro clínico) 

Los casos positivos detectados en el Departamento de Santa Cruz afectan principalmente la periferia de la capital del Departamento (Santa Cruz de la Sierra) y varios municipios rurales. 

Según datos proporcionados por el SEDES Santa Cruz, de los 1043 casos positivos identificados en la Ciudad de Santa Cruz, el sector más afectado es el distrito municipal 7, distrito municipal ubicado en la periferia de la ciudad de Santa Cruz de la Sierra. 

El Servicio Departamental de Salud (Sedes) declaró el Alerta Roja el 20 de abril, lo cual implicó el reforzamiento de las acciones de control y la activación de un plan de contingencia, orientado a reforzar la asistencia a las personas afectadas por la Influenza

name: Central African Rep: Ebola Virus Disease Epidemic

countries society-name: Red Cross Society of China, Vietnam Red Cross Society
name: GDACS Orange: Viet Nam, China TC Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 65 km/h)
summary: From 02/06/2018 to 03/06/2018, a Tropical Depression (maximum wind speed of 74 km/h) FIVE-18 was active in NWPacific. The cyclone affects these countries: Viet Nam, China (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.

name: Guatemala - Fuego Volcano Eruption
summary:
Fuego Volcano erupted on Sunday, 3 June 2018, forcing the evacuation of 12,089 people and 3,319 people to seek shelter in collective centres, injuring 44 people and causing 75 deaths; currently, 286 people have been reported missing and 1.7 million people are either at risk of or being affected by the fall of volcanic ash. Additionally, heavy rainfall yesterday, 5 June 2018 caused some slopes and damaged roofs in the affected area to collapse.  

Guatemalan Red Cross (GRC):
The National Society has put all 1,648 of its volunteers from its 21 branches on alert; the volunteers are ready to be mobilized if needed
Conducting restoring family links (RFL) actions
Supporting the rescue and evacuation efforts
Ambulances from 3 GRC branches have been deployed to transport people to hospitals
Has provided psychosocial support (PSS) to 800 affected people
Activated its Emergency operations centre (EOC)
Has provided medical and pre-hospital to people in the collective centres
 
For more information about the GRC’s actions, please visit .https://www.cruzroja.gt/noticias/acciones-humanitarias-por-erupcion-volcan-de-fuego/
 

International Federation of Red and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC):
Launched a Disaster Relief Emergency Fund (DREF) for 256,877 Swiss francs (CHF) to assist 500 families (3,000 people) for 3 months
Deployed its disaster management coordinator for Central America and its head of the country cluster office for Central America to Guatemala
IFRC personnel conducted a field visit to the affected area with the GRC’s director of risk management
Participating in the GRC’s EOC meetings
Americas regional office for the Americas (ARO)’s Disaster and Crisis Department is maintaining continuous communication with the GRC
