Partner National Societies (PNSs) and other stakeholders:
At the national level,  the GRC held a meeting with the Spanish Red Cross, which activated its emergency funds and contributed directly to the GRC’s response efforts
The Spanish Agency for International Development Cooperation (AECID) activated its emergency fund to contribute to the GRC’s response efforts
Along with the Spanish Red Cross, the GRC held a field meeting with European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (ECHO), which is interested in contributing to the DREF
Needs:
Maintaining a yellow alert
Unless the situation significantly worsens, neither the mobilization of regional or global teams nor an emergency appeal will be necessary

name: Mouvement de populations au Nord Togo
summary:
Depuis le 2 juin 2018, la Région de la Kara et plus précisément la préfecture de Dankpen connait un afflux de réfugiés ghanéens. Ces réfugiés sont arrivés au Togo suite à un litige foncier ayant débouché sur un conflit armé. Rappelons que les litiges fonciers sont récurrents dans ces localités depuis des années. 
Les réfugiés se retrouvent dans 5 villages de la préfecture de Dankpen à savoir Yabido (755 réfugiés), Kpankpandé (550réfugiés), Sékouba (190 réfugiés), Tchardo (156 réfugiés) et Koulfiékou (102 réfugiés). le nombre total de ces réfugiés est estimé à 1753 personnes provenant de 333 ménages. Ils sont hébergés par 88 ménages des 5 villages.

name: Yemen tropical cyclone
summary:
On 24 May, Mekunu cyclone passed through Socotra in Yemen and continue to move towards the shores of Oman and Yemen. The cyclone is continue moving with maximum sustained winds of 140-160 km/h and it was classified as Category 2 in the Saffir Simpson Hurricane Scale. It comes just days after Cyclone Sagar had struck Yemen, Somalia, and Djibouti, killing at least 20 people and destroying dozens of houses.
For days now, large areas of Yemen have witnessed heavy rain. In Socotra, where flash floods washed away thousands of animals and cut power lines on the isle in the Arabian Sea, it is feared that some may be dead. the initial information state that Hadibu the capital of Socotra and Qalansyah district are strongly impacted and the situation now is calm in Socotra but the cyclone has caused damage to the infrastructure and the telecommunication towers.
In Al Mahra strong winds started to form in Hawf and few telecommunication tower destroyed. Locations from Sayhut in eastern Yemen to Ash Shuwaymiyyah in western Oman are at risk for significant impacts from this cyclone. This is the first major cyclone to effect both countries in the history of record keeping in the Arabian Sea.

name: Tajikistan: Floods
summary: During the period of May 16 - 21, 2018 prolonged and heavy rains caused series of small-scale and localized floods and mudflows in different parts of Tajikistan. According to the Committee of Emergency Situations and Civil Defense of Tajikistan, floods and mudflows affected following districts: Farkhor, Panj, Vakhsh (Khatlon province) and Panjakent, Ayni, Kanibadam, J.Rasulov (Sughd Province). Especially floods and mudflows caused 8 causalities, mainly due to population's negligence. Floods and mudflows mainly damaged agricultural land plots, household kitchen gardens, roads and bridges in Farkhor and Panj districts of Khatlon province. Local authorities along with the relevant branches of the Committee of Emergency Situations are currently completed assessing the damages, cleaning the debris and providing relief assistance to the most affected population. Tajikistan Red Crescent Society has prepared updated Situation Report.

name: Croix-Rouge Togolaise
summary: Le 25 mai 2018, un conflit armé s'est déclenché entre deux ethnies du Nord du Ghana. Il s'agit des Kombas et des Chakosis. Ce conflit s'est poursuivi jusqu'à entraîner depuis le samedi 2 juin 2018 des déplacements de populations dans cinq villages de la préfecture de Dankpen au Nord du Togo. Parmi les milliers de réfugiés on peut noter des vulnérables comme des personnes âgées, femmes enceinte et des enfants.

name: GDACS Orange: Oman, Yemen TC Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 139 km/h)
summary: From 22/05/2018 to 23/05/2018, a Tropical Storm (maximum wind speed of 157 km/h) MEKUNU-18 was active in NorthIndian. The cyclone affects these countries: Oman, Yemen (vulnerability High). Estimated population affected by category 1 (120 km/h) wind speeds or higher is 0.159 million.

name: Yemen - Cyclone
summary: Tropical cyclone Mekunu hit the shores of Yemen between 22 - 27 May. The winds and storm surge have caused both human casualties as well as damage to the infrastructure in Socotra and Al Maharah governorates. Over 20 people have died and over 4 000 have been displaced. The cyclone has also caused significant damage to the distribution of water and electricity.

countries society-name: The Sri Lanka Red Cross Society
name: Sri Lanka - South West Monsoon 2018
summary: Due to the activation of South-West Monsoon weather condition heavy rain falls took place from 20th May 2018 in the south-eastern parts of the island. Disaster Management Centre (DMC) confirms that 12 districts are currently affected due the heavy rains. Out of the 12 districts 04 namely Galle, Kegalle, Kalutara & Ratnapura are fully affected from flash Floods.Following the heavy rain falls, Landslide Warnings have also been issued to Kalutara, Ratnapura, Galle, Kegalle & Badulla Districts by National Building Research Organization (NBRO). Further, the government urged the people who live in Colombo, Matara, kalutara,Galle,Ratnapura,Kurunegala & Gampaha Districts, especially on river banks to be on alert for possible flash floods. People who live close to the shores are also informed to refrain from fishing and other naval activities by the Meteorology Department as the seas around the island could be very rough due to the activation of South-West Monsoon weather condition. Further the Met Department urged the people to be vigilant of thunderstorms & lightning. Also, the DMC has issued warnings to the people who live by the Gin, Kalu, Nilwala and Kelani River banks & low lands to be on alert for flash floods. today, the Government confirmed that the Tri Forces ready to deployed for emergency relief activities and evacuations. The government of Sri Lanka confirmed that the required funds for evacuations and relief operations have been allocated by the Ministry of Finance. Further, the government has published a contact number 117 by DMC for emergencies.Met Department report released at 12.00 Noon, stated that the heavy rains and thunderstorms could be expected in the next 24 hours with high winds up to 80 km per hour.

name: Burundi - Floods
summary: ButerereBURUNDI has experienced unprecedented flooding this year as a result of heavy rainfall starting 2 months ago. The downstream move of the Mutimbuzi River Floods and the release of water from dams is causing very important damage. Two Zones of Bujumbura Town considered severely affected are Buterere – Kiyange1 and Ngagara - Sabe. A total of 525 household with 2576 displaced : 247 men, 411 woman and 1918 children are staying with their relatives and friends while some are living in the private plots, public schools or in rented houses within the two zones. The last report gives 325 houses totally destroyed 325 and 186 houses partially destroyed 186. GatumbaThe second zone affected was Gatumba in Bujumbura Rural Province with 37.500 people. During the night of 4th May 2018, 9 cities were flooded by Rusizi River crossing the zone to the Tanganika Lake. The main cause of floods was the discharge of electric dam in Democratic Republic of Congo which increase the volume of Kivu Lake and automatically the volume of water in Rusizi River crossing Gatumba from Kivu. The rapid emergency needs assessment done on 09th May, 9 collines affected with a total of 12946: 2143 men, 2258 woman and 8555 children in the need of assistance. From the field assessment report of 09th may. In term of damage and loses 505 houses totally destroyed, 588 partially destroyed and 1041 flooded and 2133 families affected

name: El Salvator - Earthquake
summary: se mantiene Alerta Naranja sobre los municipios de Chirilagua del departametno de San Miguel, Intipuca y el Carmen del departameto de La Union emitida por la Dirección General de Protección Civil, de acuerdo al dato oficial de esta direccion registra un total de 289 viviendas dañadas, 11 viviendas destruidas, daños en Centros Escolares y vías de acceso obstruidas debido a deslizamientos de rocas. Se han instalado 19 albergues (9 en Chirilagua y 10 en Intipucá); los albergados son un total de 2,043 personas que corresponden a 304 familias.

name: Americas - Population Movement
summary:
Millions of people are currently moving across Venezuela and several other countries in the Americas, and the humanitarian needs are growing. National Red Cross Societies in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Ecuador, Guyana, Panama, Peru, Trinidad and Tobago, and Uruguay are being supported by IFRC to deliver much-needed assistance. Recently, in response to a sustained increase in the number of migrants in the Americas region, the Movement has been establishing humanitarian operations in all the countries receiving migrants and ensuring strong connection with existing long-term regional plans for continuity of humanitarian services as well as social protection and communication initiatives.

Update 15-10-2020 from R4V:

Venezuelan refugees and migrants’ figures update

October 2020 Venezuelan refugees and migrants in the world: 5.5 M
Venezuelan refugees and migrants in Latin America and the Caribbean: 4.6 M

 • Starting in March 2020, countries in Latin America and the Caribbean adopted measures to curb the COVID-19 pandemic, including border closures and movement restrictions, which considerably limited the regular flow of refugees and migrants.
• Over the past months, refugees and migrants from Venezuela have become even more vulnerable, including loss of their already limited social and economic support to cover basic needs especially in vital areas such as shelter, food, protection and healthcare.
• For those on the move and in densely populated areas, physical distancing became virtually impossible to implement, facing additional stigma by host communities, including negative perceptions associated with a fear of the spread of the virus.
• Different sources estimate that over 100,000 Venezuelans have returned to their home country since early April. Nevertheless, the exodus of refugees and migrants from Venezuela continues to be the biggest population movement in Latin America’s recent history and one of the largest external displacements in the world.

name: Colombia - Floods and landslide
summary: A partir de una obstrucción en el túnel de desviación del río Cauca, a la altura de las obras principales del proyecto Ituango, presentando el 29 de abril, se generó un represamiento de agua en la parte de arriba de la presa y variaciones en el caudal del río aguas abajo (disminuciones e incrementos). En el transcurso de los días se han venido presentando taponamientos y destaponamientos de los túneles, que intensifican las variaciones mencionadas en el caudal del río Cauca.La obstrucción del túnel fue generada por una condición geológica que causó el desmoronamiento de roca y tierra al interior del túnel de desviación del río Cauca. Si bien la ola invernal arrastra a esta altura del río Cauca una enorme cantidad de residuos orgánicos, basura y material vegetal, observadas en algunas fotos que han sido publicadas en las redes sociales, esta empalizada fue descartada como responsable de la obstrucción del túnel. Desde el Puesto de Mando Unificado que se lleva a cabo en Bogotá, en donde se evalúa y se hace seguimiento a la contingencia presentada en la obra del proyecto Hidroituango, se ratifica la orden de evacuación preventiva emitida por EPM a las comunidades que habitan la zona de influencia del río Cauca, tales como Valdivia, Puerto Valdivia, Cáceres, Taraza, Nechí, Caucasia; así como las zonas bajas de San Benito Abad, Caimito y Guaranda en el departamento de Sucre, con el fin de salvaguardar y preservar la vida e integridad de las personas que habitan estos municipios

countries society-name: Red Cross Society of Côte d'Ivoire
name: Cote d'Ivorie - rain and floods
summary: Le vendredi 11 mai 2018, des pluies diluviennes se sont abattues sur la capitale économique de la Côte d’Ivoire Abidjan. Les six (6) quartiers à risques d’inondations : Abobo, Adjamé, Attécoubé, Cocody, Koumassi et Yopougon ont connu de sévères inondations.  Des voitures immobilisées piégées par les eaux stagnantes	Des voies impraticables, interrompues par les eaux	Une parte importante de la population y compris les travailleurs, les élèves, les commerçants n’ont pu vaquer à leurs occupations quotidiennesFort heureusement, ces inondations ont entrainé peu de dégâts matériels. Malheureusement un (1) corps a été retrouvé dans les décombres.

countries society-name: Red Cross of the Democratic Republic of the Congo
name: Ebola Virus Disease Response and Containment
summary:
Situation

On 7 February 2021, the Minister of Health announcement of the resurgence of EVD in Biena health zone, Butembo territory. After the confirmation of the first case in the Masoya health area . According to the Ministry of Health, it concerns a farmer, wife of an Ebola survivor. She showed the typical signs of the disease on 1 February and went to the health centre in Biena where the sample was taken, before going on to the Matanda hospital in Butembo. She died on February 3 and the Gene Xpert result came back positive. On 10 February 2021, a second confirmed case of EVD was notified in the Biena health zone, Masoya health area. This is a 60-year-old farmer, who died on 10 February 2021, with an epidemiological link to the first case. This new outbreak has been declared in the backdrop of spread of the CoVid19 pandemic across the country.

Response

In response to this complex situation IFRC, has sent a Rapid Response Team to Biena so start supporting EVD response and it continues to support efforts to contain CoVid19 epidemic in North Kivu and Ituri as well as the recovery in Equateur province. The team in the field with focus on decontaminating the houses of confirmed patients and performing Safe and Dignified Burials. 

Constraints
Access constrains to the affected area and community resistance are key challenges for the response, IFRC and DRC RC are implementing the lessons from the previous outbreaks to reach these areas and work with communities to reduce resistance.

name: Afghanistan: Drought and Flash Floods
summary: Despite increased precipitation in April and start of May, Cumulative seasonal precipitation deficits remain significant in most areas, especially in the north and south western parts of the country. Initial estimates from field reports indicate that area planted for rain fed wheat is smaller than last year, reflecting dry soil conditions and the use of extended areas for grazing. Maximum daily air temperatures have been above average since mid-season in most areas, and are expected to remain above average in the coming months. Forecasts indicate below-average to average precipitation for the remaining weeks of the spring wet season. Along with cumulative precipitation deficits, the below-average forecast is reflective of a low frequency of storms entering the region, increasing the risk for extended periods of dryness that could impact agricultural production. In Kunduz province, more than 1,400 people from six villages in Khanabad district have been displaced due to the drought to Kunduz City and requested assistance from DoRR. Authorities in Hilmand Province estimate that nearly 50,000 people could be affected the loss of crops and livestock and forced to displace in the near future. Around 2,900 people who were displaced two weeks ago from Badghis to Hirat due to the drought received food rations, NFIs and emergency shelter from humanitarian partners. UPDATE: elow average precipitation and above average temperatures since October 2017 have resulted in significant reductions in (1) snow depths, (2) river flows, (3) water level in dams, (4) water tables, and (5) soil moistures. These conditions have already negatively and irreversibly impacted the winter 2017–2018 and spring/summer 2018 agricultural season in Afghanistan. According to the data presented by OCHA to the latest Humanitarian Country Team meeting on 13 September 2018, the drought affected IDPs are estimated at 266,000. 84,000 of them have settled in Herat, and 182,000 within Badghis, their province of origin. In the last month alone, more than 84,000 people have been displaced to Herat city and 18,579 families (94,945 people) have been displaced to Qala-e-Naw City (capital of Badghis province). IDPs are residing in dozens of sites on the outskirts of the cities, or in makeshift shelters within the main cities. This makes it more difficult to reach them in a smaller number of catchment areas. Four years of failed rains have led to massive loss of livelihoods for millions of Afghans in the northwestern provinces. Ninety-five per cent of the population there rely on agriculture, livestock and crops to survive. People have been left without enough food to feed their families. The upcoming severe winter months will likely deteriorate their situation. Temperature in these areas has already dropped close to zero degrees at night, the coming weeks will really be testing for the drought affected families with freezing conditions, potentially resulting into winter related sickness and potential deaths. On 16 October 2018 the United Nations’ Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund (AHF) and Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) have released funds to support people affected by a severe drought. The overall response in drought-affected communities has been hampered by the access restrictions caused by security concerns. Humanitarian actors, including the Red Cross Red Crescent (RCRC) Movement, have had very limited access in the past three months. For instance, Ghazni City was attacked by an armed opposition group (AOG) which took control of the locality straddling the highways. An ensuing fight resulted in displacement and deaths, including of civilians. The UN Assistance Mission in Afghanistan (UNAMA) has reported that there were 210 civilian casualties during the period 10 August to 15 August. In addition, the RCRC Movement encountered access limitations following a declaration by an AOG in mid-August that security guarantees given to RCRC operation in Afghanistan would be withdrawn. This resulted in restricted personnel movement and reduced operational capacity pending dialogue to address concerns of the AOG. After weeks of dialogue, security guaranties to the RCRC Movement were restored on 14 October 2018. These developments have now set the pace for RCRC Movement partners to gradually resume activities, including to roll out interventions in support of communities affected by food insecurity. It is in this context that this DREF request is being submitted. Beyond that DREF support, a scaled-up response, utilizing other established resource mobilization channels, is envisioned. The latest reports from Famine Early Warning System Network (FEWSNET) alarming that in the absence of adequate humanitarian assistance for drought affected communities the severity of drought is likely to be one step worst in most of the country. Resulting in the further expansion of crises situation in north, northwest, central and south-central provinces and start of emergency phase in northwestern provinces of the country. People in these areas are expected to face more challenges to meet their consumption requirements until the next year spring harvest. The onset of severe winter will also create a large food deficit for the worst affected households. Though there are positive signs in terms of area planted for winter wheat is anticipated to be higher than last year due to the increased likelihood of El Niño. Government and organizations are also encouraging households to start preparing for winter panting season. However, the drought affected population is critical need of food and livelihood assistance during this lean season. Crisis (IPC Phase 3) outcomes are present throughout Afghanistan due to declining purchasing power, disruption of normal livelihoods due to conflict, and poor rainfed staple performance and will contribute to the increased food assistance needs as compared to recent years. Poor household dependent on rainfed wheat production, particularly in northern, northeastern, and northwestern areas, are expected to experience difficulty meeting consumption requirements until next year’s spring harvest. The worst-affected households will likely experience Emergency (IPC Phase 4) as large food deficits emerge with the onset of winter. Households have started preparing for the winter wheat planting season, likely starting in October. The area planted for winter wheat is anticipated to be higher than last year due to the increased likelihood of El Niño. Due to the forecasted El Niño, there is an increased likelihood of average to above-average precipitation during the 2018/19 wet season however, there remains a large spread of possible precipitation outcomes for the season.

name: Flash floods in Ankara, Turkey
summary: On 5th of May in Turkey's capital Ankara Mamak's Boğaziçi neighbourhood was hit by a sudden flash flood caused by excessive rainfall. The flood dragged dozens of vehicles from the streets and washed away several vehicles. Dozens of homes and offices in Mamak were also flooded, while residents sought shelter on top floors.6 people were slightly injured. It is estimated that over 100 vehicles were damaged. Municipal workers are at the scene to initiate clean-up activities. Only Mamak district was affected by the flood.

name: USA- Kilauea Volcanic Eruption
summary: Volcanic eruption Kilauea can have a medium humanitarian impact based on the Magnitude and the affected population and their vulnerability.

name: Dust storm in North and North West India
summary: A chain of powerful thunderstorms, a freak pre-monsoon phenomenon that experts blamed on a confluence of three weather factors, pounded parts of north and north-west India overnight Wednesday, killing at least 117 people, injuring around 260 persons and leaving a trail of destruction in at least six states. Several people were injured in the windspeeds of up to 130 km per hour, and wrecked mud houses, damaged crops, uprooted trees and electricity pylons, cutting off power supplies and disrupting train traffic in Uttar Pradesh, Rajasthan, Uttarakhand, Madhya Pradesh, Punjab and Haryana. Apart from traffic snarls, 15 flights, including two international ones, were diverted because of bad weather, airport officials in Delhi said. Railway traffic was also affected, with about 50 trains delayed. As per the statement from the officer of the India Meteorological Department (IMD), a cyclonic circulation, induced by a western atmospheric disturbance, high moisture levels brought by easterly winds and a recent spell of unusually high temperatures that soared to 45 degrees Celsius were responsible for the thunderstorms, The result was a squall line or a chain of thunderstorm clouds that emerged on Wednesday afternoon from north Rajasthan to eastern Uttar Pradesh, passing over Delhi as well.India Meteorological Department report further said that more thunderstorms are expected in parts of north and central India in the next two days. The hill regions of Himachal Pradesh and Uttararkhand may experience hailstorms. The intensity of the storms may be much less than the Wednesday night’s chain of storms. Climate scientists attributed an increase in the frequency of storms to climate changes stemming from global warming, caused by heat-trapping greenhouse gases.

name: Twin Bomb Blast in Mubi, Adamawa, Nigeria
summary: Update on Twin Bomb Blast at Yan Gwanjo Mosque in Mubi Old Market of Mubi North LGA of Adamawa State, Nigeria on Monday, 01.05.2018At about 12:00hrs GMT on Monday, 1st May, 2018 when workers all over Nigeria were celebrating May 1st Workers Day, a suicide bomber detonated an IED in a Mosque in the Yan Gwanjo part of the Old Mubi Town Market in Mubi North LGA of Adamawa State, NE Nigeria. Adamawa is the second most affected state by insurgency after Borno state -still being perpetrated by some different factions of AoG The primary blast was immediately followed by secondary blast outside the mosque couple of minutes later. Following are the casualties sent by the senior management of the branch to the National Headquarters, Nigerian Red Cross1. Number of death recorded is 30, including one person who died on the way to Federal Medical Centre, (FMC) Yola. And four died in the hospital.2. Number of casualties on admission:353. Casualties with serious injuries: 154. Casualties Referred to FMC Yola as at Monay, 1st May is: 95. Nineteen ( 19 ) NRCS volunteers responded, out of which 9 volunteers accompanied casualties evacuated to FMC Yola.6. Injured persons still remaining in Mubi General Hospital: 24On Tuesday, 2nd May, Nigerian Red Cross volunteers in Adamawa branch have been mobilized for voluntary blood donations to aid and support medical treatment of the injured still on admission beds.

name: Kenya Floods
summary: March 2018 have further resulted in erosion of livelihoods. The rainfall pattern has changed this year affecting at least 29 counties and it has been described as a `mini El Nino phenomenon` by the local meteorological department. According the preliminary reports, the rains have caused flooding that has left 211,155 people displaced, 72 dead and 33 injured. These numbers are likely to increase as the heavy rains are expected to continue until July.   The flood impacts include destruction of crops with farms reported as submerged, destruction of irrigation systems, disruption of transport for market access, interruption of road infrastructure, and destruction of key installations including health care and water sanitation infrastructure. Affected households are staying in various displacement sites in the affected areas and are mostly in need of food, shelter and household items, access to clean and safe water for use, access to sanitation facilities, access to health services and protection. The access to public health services has been disrupted which increases the likelihood of diseases outbreak. Increased precipitation with the warm conditions creates a conducive environment for the breeding of vectors such as mosquitoes thus increasing the spread of vector borne disease such Malaria, Dengue and Chikungunya.   The impact of floods on livelihood is expected to result in loss of income for the affected communities resulting into low purchasing power. This is already seen with the deteriorating food security status of the affected counties; thus, requiring humanitarian assistance to meet affected households’ food and other basic needs. As per the agricultural calendar, planting had commenced with the onset of the long rains, therefore resulting in large loss of standing crops. Most affected counties reporting agriculture and livestock losses include Garissa, Tana River, Kilifi, Kisumu, Homa Bay, Elgeyo Marakwet, Turkana and Marsabit. The crop loss will further worsen the already fragile food insecurity situation in most of the affected counties.   At the onset of the floods, the National Society through the Red Cross Action Teams (RCATs) conducted rapid assessments to determine the immediate needs of the affected population. Since the onset of floods, the KRCS has provided NFIs to 10,088 households and is involved in Search and Rescue, First Aid and public awareness campaign using national media and messaging. KRCS also works in partnership with UNICEF during such emergencies. So far UNICEF has provided 3,750 family kits to assist the communities in Kisumu and Garissa.   The KRCS teams are currently conducting detailed assessments to determine the comprehensive needs of the affected population and the extent of damages (housing, health facilities, schools and other essential infrastructure).

name: Jordan - Flash Floods
summary:
1. Due to climatic circumstances, Jordan has encountered heavy rainfalls with high precipitation rates resulting in flooding houses, road blockages, and trapping people in their homes. Unfortunately, 4 lives were reported lost (1 electrocution & 3 drowning) along with the evacuation of thousands of people was carried out by the Civil Defense Rescue Teams and the Security Services and managed to transfer them to safety.
2. Moreover, in Al Mafraq Governorate, roads and houses were tremendously affected and around 400 families were displaced; the Governor of Al Mafraq stressed that the people are in direct need of humanitarian assistance (shelter, food parcels, blankets and hygiene kits).The Jordan Red Crescent has taken action by distributing 2210 blankets and 50 tents and is currently in the process of requesting a DREF.
3. the amount of rainfall is estimated at more than 19 million cubic meters and it is foreseen that the weather will get worse mid of this week.

countries society-name: Red Crescent Society of the Republic of Kazakhstan
name: Landslide in Jalal-Abad, Kyrgyzstan
summary: On April 29, 2018 a massive Landslide (1.5 million cubic meters) hit Jalal-Abad province-southern part of Kyrgyz Republic.48 thousand cubic meters of landslide blocked the Kok-Art river flow. No casualties were reported. According to the Ministry Emergency Situations reports there was a high risk of river water breakthrough with further flooding communities located near to the river bank.Following day on 30 of April 2018 the Government of Kyrgyzstan imposed the state of emergency and started emergency evacuation of population settled near to the river banks. 1 300 households, which is almost 6 000 individuals were evacuated from hazardous area.Further the situation developed in positive way, the risk of water breakthrough was mitigated. Earlier evacuated population started to return to their houses. Later this day the Government of KR canceled the state of emergency.

name: Argentina - Floods - Buenos Aires
summary: Debido a las continuas precipitaciones que se desarrollan desde la madrugada del sábado 28/04, y que se intensificaron en la madrugada y mañana del día de la fecha (domingo 29/04), se produjeron anegamientos y la crecida del Río Luján en la ciudad de Luján. La medida actual del río a las 16hs. era de 2.58mt. siendo el nivel de evacuación 2.60mts. y un río que crece aproximadamente 15cm. por hora. Según los alertas del SMN para las próximas horas se esperan tormentas fuertes, ocasional caída de granizo y fuerte actividad eléctrica. Además la semana entrante será una semana de precipitaciones y tormentas según los pronosticos actuales. Por el momento hay un total de 42 evacuados de barrios Villa del parque, Lanusse y Los Laureles; los mismos se encuentran En el instituto Mignone, otro centro está siendo habilitado en estos momentos. Se ha declarado el Alerta Rojo según el Plan Nacional de Respuesta de la Sociedad Nacional.

name: Tanzania Floods
summary:
Heavy rainfall occurred in different parts of Tanzania mainland and Zanzibar from 12 to 18 April 2018, causing floods. The flood affected regions include
Dar es Salaam (Kinondoni, Ilala, Temeke and Kigamboni Municipals); Arusha (Arusha District Council, Meru, Longido, Monduli districts); Zanzibar; Kilimanjaro (Same, Hai, Mwanga districts); Tanga (Handeni, Lushoto districts); Manyara (Simanjiro, Kiteto, Babati districts); Tabora (Nzega and Kaliua districts); Pwani (Mafia and Rufiji districts); Mwanza, Morogoro, Dodoma, Mbeya, Rukwa, Mtwara, Shinyanga, and Geita.
 TRCS volunteer sending plastic sheltering material to flood victims in Longido, Arusha © TRCS
 
Page |2
Immediately after the flooding occurred, TRCS deployed a National Disaster Response Team (NDRT), a Branch Disaster Response Team (BDRT) and volunteers from TRCS branches of Arusha, Dar es Salaam and Zanzibar to evacuate affected people, administer first aid to people in need and conduct a rapid initial assessment of the situation. The evacuations and first aid activities are ongoing in Arusha due to the continuous flooding.

name: Central Russia Storm
summary: Storm Central RussiaThe storm was on the afternoon of April 21 the night of April 22 in Central RussiaThe number of wounded is being clarified. It is known about 2 people were killed.The RRC monitors the situation. At 09.00 Moscow time information about the need for the intervention of the Red Cross has not been received.In Moscow, the roofs of more than 30 houses and administrative buildings have been damaged, more than 580 trees fell, 3 billboards, 92 personal vehicles were damaged, and 4 commuter trains were delayed. In the village of Kosivka Troitsky and Novomoskovsk administrative district, a short-term (within an hour) disruption of power supply of 60 residential buildings occurred. At the MCC of Moscow, four passenger electric trains were delayed up to 30 minutes.In the Moscow region, emergency power outages occurred in 25 settlements, 655 houses, more than 145 trees fell, 17 personal vehicles were damaged. On the Moscow railway there was a delay in the movement of 31 passenger suburban electric trains and 2 long-distance passenger trains from 6 minutes to 2 hours.In the Tver region of two municipal districts emergency power outages occurred in 493 settlements, 7,394 houses, 3 trees fell, and the roof of one socially significant object was damaged.In the Tula region in 11 municipalities emergency power outages occurred in 63 settlements, 3,418 dwelling houses, fall of 29 trees, damaged 11 krovel. There are no victims.In the Vladimir region, emergency disconnections of power supply in 130 settlements and 4,045 residential buildings occurred in 10 municipalities.In the Ivanovo region in 3 municipal areas emergency power outages occurred in 33 settlements and 1,034 residential houses.In the Smolensk region in 10 municipal areas emergency power outages occurred in 203 settlements and 1,335 residential buildings.In the Ryazan region, emergency power outages in 89 communities, over 11,100 houses, the fall of 16 trees, the roofing of an apartment building, damaged one car occurred in 7 municipal areas.In the Lipetsk region, 7 trees collapsed, 7 roofs were damaged, including 4 multi-apartment houses, one private house, a school, a covered market.In the Bryansk region, 15 trees fell, 2 cars were damaged.In the Pskov region, 9 trees and one advertising banner fell, one unit of personal vehicles was damaged.In the Leningrad region in one municipal area emergency power outages occurred in 2 settlements and 295 apartment houses.In the Novgorod region in 5 municipal areas emergency power outage occurred in 64 settlements and more than 1500 residential buildings. There were falling 2 trees, damaged the roof of a multi-apartment apartment building and one unit of personal vehicles.During the day: the power supply of the territory of 7 entities in 13 municipalities, in 101 settlements, more than 5,040 houses, in 2 socially significant facilities was restored.As of 06.00 Moscow time on 22.04.2018: on territory of 7 subjects in 35 municipalities more than 690 settlements, more than 15140 houses, one socially significant object remain without power supply.On 22.04.2018, EMERCOM plans to conduct emergency restoration works and provide all-round assistance to the population.

name: Nicaragua: Civil Unrest
summary: Por sexto día consecutivo en diversos puntos de nuestro país se continúan dando protestas. Las calles de Nicaragua amanecieron hoy lunes aun con barricadas y muchos negocios continúan aun cerrados. El país de Nicaragua sumida en protestas populares y disturbios civiles en contra a las reforma del Seguro Social, que aumenta la cuota patronal y laboral y crea una nueva cotización para los jubilados. Las manifestaciones han provocado 16 personas fallecidas y decenas de heridos, según confirmó la Policía Nacional en dos comunicados este viernes 20 de abril de 2018.Los disturbios se ha intensificados cada día progresivamente, en Managua se han presentado protesta en varios puntos neurálgicos de la capital. A la vez se están llevando a cabo disturbios que dejan lesionados en los Municipios de Granada, Nagarote, Ticuantepe, Tipitapa, Masaya, Jinotepe, Camoapa, Estelí, Sébaco, Matagalpa, León, Chinandega, Chichigalpa, Jinotepe, Jinotega, Tisma Rivas, Ocotal y Rio Blanco. Escuelas y universidades de varios municipios de Nicaragua suspendieron las clases ante la violencia a causa del conflicto y se han sumado a las protestas con motines. En Managua son varios los puntos de protestas, principalmente en las universidades. La Policía Nacional ha desplegado antimotines para replegar a los protestantes usando gases lacrimógenos y balas de goma. Jóvenes estudiantes de medicina, que provienen de distintas universidades y se encuentran este viernes en la Catedral de Managua, brindando asistencia humanitaria, alimentos y agua a los estudiantes que resulten afectados durante las protestas contra las reformas a la seguridad social.

name: Bangladesh: Monsoon early warning - Cox's Bazar
summary: The first rainfall for the monsoon season in Cox’s Bazar has started indicating the arrival of the monsoons. The monsoon season is expected to bring heavy rains that can impede the access to the camps. It is expected that the dirt roads will get muddy and landslides might occur in the camp. Some of the areas in the camp is also expected to be inundated with heavy rains which can cause further accessibility challenge. Provision of aid is likely to be disrupted as access to the camps become increasingly constrained. An estimated 100,000 are at high risk of being affected directly by potential floods and landslides. In general, the rest of the camps will also be affected by the rains. The mud footpaths in the camp will potentially be damaged by heavy rains reducing the accessibility of the people in camp. The makeshift shelters in the camp can get damage from heavy rains and winds. Water contamination is likely to occur during the rains due to seepage into poorly constructed water infrastructures, reducing the quality of water.

name: Indonesia - Banjarnegara Earthquake
summary: Earthquake with magnitude 4.2 earthquake in the region of Pekalongan Regency, Central Java has struck on wednesday (18/04) located at 7.22 LS, 109.66 BT (19 km southeast of KAB-PEKALONGAN-Central Java), 10 km Deep based on report from Meteorological Agency BMKG-PGR VII).It is reported 1 Junior School facility building in SMPN 2 Kalibening-Banjarnegara was damages in three clas rooms, 1 unit of religious facilities are also included with medium damage caused by Earthquake Shock. Now a day the situation in Dusun Kebakalan, Kertosari Village, Kec. Kalibening was affected 136 KK approximately 544 people and almost 90% of settlements damaged. Currently some of injured have been taken to the nearest health center and for the temporary residents evacuated to the homes of residents in Dusun gunung tawang, Desa kertosari. It is reported that 1 person died as a result of the ruins.

name: Niger-Meningitis Epidemic Outbreak in
summary: On Monday 16 April 2018, the Minister of Public Health in Niger, in a Press release has officially announced a Meningitis outbreak in three regions of the country (Tahoua, Maradi and Zinder). According to the Minister, as of 16 April 2018, the meningitis situation in the country is as follows:-	Four health districts have reached the alert threshold (3 cases per 100,000 inhabitants), this is the level from which investigation to guide the immunization are conducted. The affected health districts includes: Madarounfa, Aguié, Keita and Zinder commune.-	In addition, some isolated health centres have crossed the epidemic threshold and the germs identified by the laboratory are meningococci C, X and pneumococcus. The concerned health centres includes Dan Issa health Centre in Madarounfa in the region of Maradi, Fararatt in Keita in the region of Tahoua and Deoulé in Bouza in the region of Tahoua. The causative germs identified is mainly meningococcus C requiring an immunization response to A/C vaccine which is available in the warehouse of the Ministry of Public Health. Other areas continue to register sporadic cases but have neither reached the alert threshold nor the epidemic threshold. In order to respond to this situation, the Ministry of Health has taken the following measures:1-	All patients are to be treated for free at the Health centres;2-	An immunization campaign is organized in the affected health areas to stop the spread of the disease; the immunization target people aged 2 to 29 years old;3-	The Ministry of Public Health has prepositioned stock of medications for the treatment of meningitis in all health Centres;4-	Awareness sessions activities are undertaken. As of 16 April 2018, the Ministry of Health has 104,740 doses of meningococcal vaccine in stock. Instructions are giving for the deployment of the vaccine doses in the field.5-	Instruction are also given to the National and regional committees for epidemic management which initially meets on weekly basis to hold their meeting on daily basis in order to better monitor the situation,Efforts are being made by the state, its partners and the Health personnel to properly control the situation. The Minister of Public Health called upon the population to rush to the nearest health Centre for free treatment as soon as they identified the symptoms.Finally the Minister reassured the population that the situation is under control, and he instructed the health services, at all level, to further strengthen the consultation framework, the monitoring, the awareness-raising and a better health care in order to return to the normal situation

name: Fiji - TC Keni
summary: A TROPICAL CYCLONE WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR WHOLE OF FIJI.A HURRICANE WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR SOUTHWEST VITI LEVU, FROM SIGATOKA TONAVUA, VATULELE, BEQA, KADAVU AND NEARBY SMALLER ISLANDS , MOALA, TOTOYA,MATUKU AND ONO-I-LAU.A STORM WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR THE REST OF VITI LEVU, YASAWA GROUP,LOMAIVITI GROUP AND THE REST OF SOUTHERN LAU.A GALE WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR VANUA LEVU. TAVEUNI AND NEARBY SMALLERISLANDS AND NORTHERN LAU GROUP.A HEAVY RAIN WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR THE WHOLE OF FIJI.A FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN FORCE FOR PARTS OF FIJI. For more information, referto the latest Special Weather Bulletin on Flood issued by RSMC, Nadi atwww.met.gov.fj/aifs_prods/20016.txtSEVERE TROPICAL CYCLONE KENI CENTRE 970HPA CATEGORY 3 WAS LOCATED NEAR 18.4SOUTH 176.7 EAST OR ABOUT 175 KILOMETRES SOUTHWEST OF NADI AND 140 KILOMETRESSOUTH OF VIWA AT 10:00 AM. MEANWHILE, RAIN BANDS ASSOCIATED WITHTROPICAL CYCLONE KENI CONTINUE TO AFFECT THE GROUP.ON THIS TRACK, THE CYCLONE CENTRE IS EXPECTED TO BE LOCATED ABOUT 30 KILOMETRESSOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF KADAVU AT 04:00PM TODAY, AND ABOUT 110 KILOMETRES WEST OFONO-I-LAU, OR ABOUT 330KM SOUTH-SOUTHEAST OF SUVA AT 10 PM TONIGHT. PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN AND SQUALLY THUNDERSTORMS. FLOODING, INCLUDING SEA FLOODING OF LOW LYING AREAS.DAMAGING HEAVY SWELLS WITH STORM SURGE OF MORE THAN 2 METERS COULD BE EXPECTEDOVER COASTAL AREAS.FOR VANUA LEVU. TAVEUNI AND NEARBY SMALLER ISLANDS, NORTHERN LAU GROUP:DAMAGING GALE FORCE WITH AVERAGE SPEED OF 80KM/HR AND MOMENTARY GUSTS TO110KM/HR.PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN AND SQUALLY THUNDERSTORMS.FLOODING, INCLUDING SEA FLOODING OF LOW LYING AREAS.DAMAGING HEAVY SWELLS EXPECTED.The following information is provided especially for the mariners:HURRICANE WARNING.TROPICAL CYCLONE KENI CENTRE 970HPA CATEGORY 3 WAS LOCATED NEAR 18.4 SOUTH 176.7EAST AT 092200 UTC.

name: Italy - Earthquake Muccia
summary: A 4.7 magnitude, with seismogenic depth of only 8 killometers, earthquake shook the towns of Muccia, Pieve Torina e Pievebovigliana in the province of Macerata at 05:11, 10th April 2018, followed by a 3.5 magnitude aftershock at 6:03.Due to the first shock, Varano’s church bell tower came town. The event has caused further damage to already condemned buildings and intact ones. As a precautionary measure, 4/6 families (nearly 20 people) have been evacuated and extensive on-site inspections will be conducted to assess the stability of buildings. The schools of Muccia and Pieve Torina have been closed.

name: Nicaragua -Incendio Forestal Reserva indio Maíz
summary:
Las llamas del incendio que se registra desde el miércoles pasado en la Reserva Indio Maíz podrían alcanzar en las próximas horas, las comunidades más cercanas de la zona, aseguró hoy Adonis Coulson, reportero voluntario de la brigada comunitaria.

unas 4689 hectáreas impactadas por el incendio según los puntos de calor de los satélites Modis y CIIRS de la Nasa”, indicó el director de Fundación del Río, Amaru Ruiz.

La reserva Indio Maíz esta ubica esta ubicada en la región autónoma atlántico SUR.

name: Fiji-TC Josie followed by TD 13F
summary:
A low pressure system that had developed to the west of Fiji has intensified to a Tropical
Disturbance (TD13F). It is expected to intensify into a Tropical Depression by Sunday and
possibly intensify further into a Category 1 cyclone as it moves towards the Group.
The system is expected to take a similar track as tropical cyclone Josie, passing southwest of the
Group early next week. It is likely that the system will be stronger than TC Josie and depending
on how far from the Group it tracks; the likely impacts may be similar or even worse if it tracks
closer to land areas.
As the system moves closer to the Group, expect strong wind to damaging gale force winds with
frequent heavy rain. With more rain forecasted and soil being saturated, there is high risk of
severe river flooding especially in the Western Division. The system has potential to produce
more than 120mm of rainfall in 24 hours this weekend.
Meanwhile, an active trough of low pressure with associated cloud and rain remains slow moving
over Fiji.
All communities living in flood prone and low lying areas are reminded to take all necessary
precautions and remain alert, similarly for those living in landslide prone areas. Members of the
public are advised to remain updated with the latest weather information and take alerts and
warnings seriously.
We will continue monitoring the situation closely and any alert and warning will be issued as and
when necessary. For more details and the latest on weather, please contact the National Weather
Forecasting Centre on 6736006, 9905376 or visit the Fiji Meteorological Service’s website,
www.met.gov.fj

countries society-name: Papua New Guinea Red Cross Society
name: GDACS Orange: Papua New Guinea EQ Magnitude 6.6M, Depth:10km
summary: On 3/26/2018 9:50:59 AM, an earthquake occurred in Papua New Guinea potentially affecting About 83000 people within 100km. The earthquake had Magnitude 6.6M, Depth:10km.

name: Russian Federation-Fire accident in shopping center in Kemerovo
summary:
The fire at the Zimnyaya Vishnya shopping mall in Siberian city of Kemerovo started on March, 25 at 4 pm on the fourth floor and consumed an area of about 1,600 square meters. Twenty people were saved from the burning building, and 700 others were evacuated. The number of casualities are 64, including 41 children. The number of people affected by fire is 79, the 12 of which stay in the hospital, 67 people received medical help in policlinicks. 

PSS will be rendered by Russian Red Cross to 150 families approximately (1000 people).

name: GDACS Orange: Madagascar, Miscellaneous (French) Indian Ocean Islands TC Tropical Storm (maximum ...

Philippines - Tropical Storm Tembin
summary:
The Tropical Storm Tembin made landfall with maximum winds of 90 km/h and gusts of up to 125 km/h, according to the national meteorological agency, Philippine Atmospheric Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). The tropical storm then continued west across Mindanao, tracking over the provinces of Misamis Oriental, Misamis Occidental and Zamboanga del Norte. It weakened before re-intensifying on 23 December 2017, prior to making a second landfall in Balabac, Palawan. The storm brought heavy rainfall that caused widespread flooding as the major rivers breached their banks. The heavy rain also caused flash floods and landslides in high lands across northern Mindanao and southern Palawan. Northern Mindanao is particularly prone to flash floods and landslides.


The Revised Emergency Appeal is to enable the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) to support the Philippine Red Cross (PRC) in delivering assistance and support to 25,000 people affected by Tropical Storm Tembin over 12 months. 


The revised operation focuses on shelter, livelihoods, water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH), protection, gender and inclusion (PGI), disaster risk reduction (DRR) and National Society capacity building.

Flash floods in the South of Israel
summary: As of April 25th, Israel is affected by severe rain fall, with hail and wind gusts (in some areas in the South of the country, 57mm of rain fell within 1 hour, the amount equal to 1 month of rain fall). Due to the type of soil, this is associated in the South of Israel with flash floods. As of April 25th afternoon, all MDA regions are on heightened alert due to the weather (expected to last until April 27th afternoon). On April 26th, around 1530, MDA dispatch centers received information on a group of teenagers, travelling in the area affected by the flooding, that have been washed away by the water.

Bangladesh - Population Movement (MDRBD018)
summary:
The Bangladesh Red Crescent Society (BDRCS) continues to run the Population Movement Operation (PMO) with the support of IFRC and 10 in-country Partner National Societies (PNSs), to meet the needs of displaced people from Rakhine in Myanmar, and the host community (local Bangladeshi community) severely impacted by the influx of displaced people. From January to March 2022, a total of 434 staff was engaged in the operation. This includes 417 national staff, out of whom 282 are from BDRCS. The total number of delegates (expatriates) is 17, who are employed by IFRC and Partner National Societies (PNSs). The following Red Cross Red Crescent partners continue to support BDRCS in its implementation of the operation, through multilateral contributions via the IFRC Emergency Appeal last revised in November 2021, as well as bilateral arrangements.

This reporting period has seen the following developments: ▪ Fire incident: Between January and March several fires broke out in camps 5, 16 and 17, where initially 100 Cyclone Preparedness Programme (CPP) camp volunteers, trained in multi-hazard disaster preparedness, were deployed by site management support agencies (SMSA) in coordination with BDRCS which jointly runs the CPP with the Bangladesh government. The timely response was conducted in coordination with the RRRC office and ISCG. The BDRCS Emergency Response Team monitored the situation, deploying 15 staff, 10 Red Crescent Youth (RCY) volunteers and 30 community volunteers to support tent installations, relief distributions and debris cleaning under the guidance of the respective Camp-in-Charge in the affected camps. ▪ High-level meeting: A Stakeholder Meeting on Multi-hazard Preparedness and Response for camp and host communities in Cox’s Bazar was held on 27 March, organised by the Government of Bangladesh and supported jointly by BDRCS/IFRC and the UN-led Inter Sector Coordination Group (ISCG). The meeting was graced by the new Secretary of the Ministry of Disaster Management and Relief, Md Kamrul Hasan, whose attendance marked his first visit to Cox’s Bazar in this capacity. This multistakeholder gathering which has taken place twice a year since 2018, with BDRCS/IFRC undertaking a significant part in organising the event, is testament to the major role played by BDRCS in disaster risk management specifically in reference to the population movement crisis, as well as the convening and coordinating influence of BDRCS/IFRC in bringing together different actors.

WSM: Flood - 0023-06 - flood
summary:
Flash floods had hit parts of Samoa due to heavy downpour on Thursday, the 8th of June 2023, causing damages to homes and infrastructure on the North Eastern coastal area of Savaii Island with roads submerged by river flows downhill with their power derived from gravity, through complex meandering paths. Reports were of damaged roads and bridges, power outrages and schools’ closures across 14 village communities in the Fa’asalele’aga district group.
About 14 village communities with an estimated population of a little over 7,000 were directly impacted by strong floods which scattered across the north eastern coastal area of Savaii Island on Thursday morning. The NS quickly mobilized its technical ERT members from headquarters, comprised of staff and volunteers to help its Savaii Branch ERT, to respond to the impacts of the Flash Floods emergency on the affected population.   The first team was deployed on the early morning ferry on Friday (9th June, 2023), with more relief supplies in  support of the Savaii Flash Floods Emergency Operation with the Branch Team, who were already in the field assisting with evacuation of the affected population, especially women, children, elderly, people with disabilities (PwD) and providing first aid services to the injured people.

SRCS has prepositioned relief supplies at its branch office in Tuasivi, Savai’i.  At the time of the emergency, the volunteers from the north western side of the island could not access their way towards the branch office, due to the serious impacts of flash floods, given the site of the branch office, located right in the middle of the  villages that were severely affected by the flash floods, hence the quick mobilization of the neighboring communities ERT members have made impact. These are volunteers who have undergone CDCRM training by the NS through its on-going DRM program.
